column2: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, facing an increasingly tough challenge in next week's Democratic primary from Representative Joe Sestak, has released a new television ad featuring none other than President Obama.

Hedge funds posted modest gains in April, drawing in more capital from investors. The HFN Hedge Fund Aggregate Index was up 1.55 percent for the month, according to a preliminary figures complied by HedgeFund.net. The index, made up of dozens of funds across different strategies, is up 4.35 percent for the year.
The period in a person's twenties, before careers and relationships have settled.

Today, President Obama proposes new plans to regulate offshore oil drilling, Pope Benedict XVI says sins inside the Catholic Church pose a great threat, and Afghanistan's president gets a warm welcome in Washington.
Ferrari is rampaging through the spring tulips.

DETROIT - A strong bullpen - its 2.22 earned run average is the lowest in baseball - a solid lineup and good starting pitching should keep the Tigers in contention deep into the summer in a shallow American League Central.Â  But what if the Tigers were to fall behind Minnesota? Would they start considering selling off some talent before the July 31 trade deadline? Someone like, say, Johnny Damon?

In this week's Critics' Picks video, A. O. Scott look back at Jean Renoir's World War I drama "Grand Illusion." The film follows a group of French officers who are imprisoned by the Germans and are plotting their escape. Mr. Scott says the film's antiwar message still resonates today; that categories of "race, class, ethnicity, religion, nationality are not what matter. What matters is the individuality of each person." Please share your thoughts on "Grand Illusion" and the work of Jean Renoir.

The future will be greener, we hope, both environmentally and for our personal finances. Yet getting there will take work, both architectural and mental, as old consuming habits give way to new habits of thrift, industry and pluck.
Anxious Detroit Red Wings fans are trying to read the tea leaves, looking for clues to figure out captain Nicklas Lidstrom's future.

Turin, Italy, was where the sun set on the mighty Friedrich Nietzsche. Some say that syphilis had gotten to his brain, but in the last lucid months before he was carted back over the mountains to a madhouse in Switzerland, he declared the regal city on the Po to be the first place in which he was "possible."
Due to the Internet's wondrous ability to manipulate time and space, my column on cava is already posted.
Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.
Two years after I found out that I had an aggressive Stage 3 prostate cancer, I've learned that, more than anything, cancer is about stories and friendships.
The number of unemployed workers per job opening barely changed from February to March, when the ratio was 5.57 jobless workers for each available position.

Lenny Kravitz is among the musicians with ties to Louisiana who will participate in a benefit concert to assist residents affected by an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kravitz, who lives part-time in New Orleans, was the first performer to commit to the benefit, called Gulf Aid, which is scheduled for Sunday at that city's Mardi Gras World River City. Other artists expected to perform include Allen Toussaint, Mos Def, Ani DiFranco, the Voice of the Wetlands Allstars (including Tab Benoit, Dr. John and Cyril Neville) and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. Tickets are $50 and will be sold through Elevate Tickets. The event, whose proceeds will go to organizations that help Gulf Coast fishermen and the area's seafood industry as well as those that address environmental issues, will also be broadcast on the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage radio station WWOZ 90.7 FM and wwoz.org.

The space is little more than a cramped room with teal-colored walls, a griddle, and a refrigerator filled with Mexican sodas. But this modest restaurant in the South Bronx has become the hub of the Melrose community, a place where police officers, construction workers, lawyers and local residents gather to eat tamales and gossip about the neighborhood. A visitor could see a group of musicians playing the drums one day, and the longtime local congressman eating a Cuban sandwich the next.
A composite drawing of the suspect in the assault of a 16-year-old on April 30 has been released by the Maplewood Police Department.

The New York Times invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the forward operating base, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships and rewards of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.
The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected four architectural firms as finalists to design its expansion.

3:32 p.m. | Updated Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on Tuesday sued a fund-of-funds unit of Bank of New York Mellon for fraud over the $227 million that the unit's investors had lost as a result of its investment in Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme.

France Coach Raymond Domenech will not take striker Karim Benzema to the World Cup in South Africa, but says it has nothing to do with the player's alleged involvement in a prostitution investigation.

Margaret Atwood on Monday accepted the Dan David Prize at Tel Aviv University in Israel, telling an interviewer before the ceremony that to snub the honor would be tantamount to "throwing overboard the thousands of writers around the world who are in prison, censored, exiled and murdered for what they have published."
Finland is a sparsely populated country whose most famous exports are supermodels, textiles, glass and furniture - though not necessarily in that order.
The Calculus of UpgradesAirline travelers hoping to use frequent-flier miles to get better seats need to have a calculator handy while reading the fine print.

1:53 p.m. | Updated Lorne Michaels, you've got no one to blame for this but yourself. You invite Betty White to host "Saturday Night Live" after hundreds of thousands of Facebook fans clamor for it -- yielding a memorable show and strong ratings in the process -- and you open the door for copycat campaigns to put other stars of a certain age onto your show.
11:44 a.m. | Updated The redistricting forum this Sunday at 3 p.m. will be held at Deerfield Elementary School, 26 Troy Lane, Short Hills, not the Millburn Library.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Henriette Lazaridis Power knows a little about ambition. A Rhodes scholar who taught English at Harvard for a decade, she is the founding editor of the new online literary magazine The Drum, which publishes audio versions of fiction writing.
The New York Times Lens blog recently invited people all over the world to take pictures at one "Moment in Time" (15:00 U.T.C., Sunday, May 2). Over 10,000 photographers responded.

Our panel of economists is back with another installment of answers to your questions about the Greek debt crisis and its repercussions. The panelists are Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, an author of "13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown," and a Daily Economist here at Economix; Carmen M. Reinhart, an economic historian at the University of Maryland whose recent book, "This Time Is Different," chronicles 800 years' worth of debt crises and sovereign defaults; and Yves Smith, the financial analyst behind the "Naked Capitalism" blog and "ECONned," who heads Aurora Advisors, a management consulting firm specializing in corporate finance advisory and financial services.

In a hearing this morning, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee is set to examine various issues related to offshore oil and gas exploration and to grill executives from BP, Halliburton and Transocean about the fatal and environmentally calamitous destruction of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig.
On Monday evening, President Obama issued a statement on the death of Lena Horne, the groundbreaking actress and singer who died at 92 on Sunday.

The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources is holding a hearing on offshore gas and oil development, including the Interior's Department's recently announced plan to allow more drilling and the April 20 accident involving the Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico. Green is live-blogging the hearing, with the most recent updates at the top of this post.
Susan Dominus interviews Cortney Novogratz, above, who stars in Bravo's new "9 by Design" with her husband, Robert. The couple design and sell high-end homes while raising seven children.

President Obama is proposing to split the agency that oversees offshore oil drilling into two parts, one to inspect oil rigs and enforce safety, the other to oversee leases for drilling and collect royalties, the White House said Tuesday.
TheÂ Royal Bank of Scotland's insurance and retail business has lost 2,600 more jobs, bringing the total jobs lost at the firm to 22,600 since the 2008 bailout, The Guardian reported.
What we're reading this morning:

In anticipation of next month's World Cup in South Africa, FIFA has commissioned 17 artists to create limited-edition soccer-themed prints. The Cup organizers initiated the art-for-athletics program back in 2006, printing posters by the likes of Andreas Gursky to promote the German games. This year's portfolio includes a drawing by the South African artist William Kentridge of a player in midkick (above); a latex sculpture of an elephant, its trunk wrapped around the ball, by the German-born Isolde Krams; and a colorful embroidered work by the Sudanese artist Hassan Musa, who reimagines Jacob's tussle with the Archangel as a center-field struggle. The original artworks were auctioned at New York's Phillips de Pury, but the signed and numbered prints - 2,010 of each image - go for as little as $121. Go to 2010artedition.de.

So many major events in this country repeat themselves, first as tragedy and then as Congressional hearing. The BP oil spill is a case in point: several major players will testify Tuesday morning before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources before facing the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works in the afternoon. We'll be live-blogging the first hearing.
President Obama has made his choice for the Supreme Court. But what will the Senate think of Elena Kagan?

It's a double coup: First, "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" lines up a week's worth of special musical guests to cover tracks from the Rolling Stones' "Exile on Main Street," to promote a coming re-release of that album. Then, NBC secures the clearances to those songs in time to post video of those "Late Night" performances the morning after they're broadcast. What's next? Keith Richards switches to pomegranate juice?

If you're having a tough time keeping straight who's in and who's out for the Preakness, that's probably because this year's race is expected to have the first full 14-horse field since 2005.

Greetings from San Francisco, where I am on a dual assignment, one an overdue visit to my younger daughter and the other for The Times's Travel section. On Monday, while hanging out with the first and ignoring the second, we sprinted to the Mission for lunch.
Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)
Goldman Sachs isn't the only firm that made a trading gain every day last quarter.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has filed to raise as much as $500 million by selling new shares once the buyout shop moves its listing to the New York Stock Exchange, Bloomberg News reported.

Golden Gate Capital has ridden to Zale's rescue, following reports that the struggling AmericanÂ  jeweler was in talks with several private equity firms about an investment to help reverse the company's fortunes.

You can change the icons and the way they're arranged on your personal computer at will. And you can change which applications appear on the initial screen of a smartphone. So why can't you customize your car's dashboard display? Cisco thinks you will able to do just that in future.

SmartMeters Prove Not So Smart | The Pacific Gas and Electric Company acknowledged on Monday that tens of thousands of customers using its new SmartMeters might have received inaccurate utility bills. A few weeks ago, the company insisted that only "a few" customers had received the bungled bills. The California Public Utilities Commission is investigating the meters' accuracy. P.G.&E. has installed 5.5 million of the meters throughout Northern California and continues to install about 10,000 a day. [The San Jose Mercury News, The San Francisco Chronicle]

Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island and a member of the Senate Banking Committee, on Monday filed an amendment to the financial reform currently in the Senate that would require all hedge funds, private equity shops and venture capital firms to register with either a state regulator or the Securities and Exchange Commission, Politico reported.
Activist shareholder Carl C. Icahn raised his stake in mobile phone maker Motorola, according to a regulatory filing, Reuters reported.

As I write in an article in Tuesday's Science Times, blowout preventers are a critical piece of oil-rigging equipment designed to help maintain pressure control in a well as it is being drilled. The aim is to avoid a catastrophic blowout like the kind the occurred on April 20 in the Gulf of Mexico. In that accident, the blowout preventer failed to work.

Prudential Plc, the British insurer, and American International Group are in advanced talks to change the terms of the announced $35.5 billion purchase of A.I.G.'s Asia life insurance unit, cutting the cash component by about $2 billion to win the approval of Britain's Financial Services Authority, The Financial Times reported Tuesday. A.I.G.'s board is weighing the proposal and the prospectus may be published later this week, according to the report, which cited unidentified people close to the situation.

All of these posts about business groups have been interesting.Â I've never joined one or even considered joining one, even though my uncle was executive director of Young Presidents' Organization for many years.Â (O.K., I considered it then but didn't qualify.)
British bankers, the butt of political and public criticism for getting taxpayer bailouts and large bonuses, at least have some friends in London's courts.
Today's idea: The Supreme Court looks diverse in terms of race, gender and ethnicity, but it's still a pretty monolithic crowd from the educated elite, an article says.

Opponents of proposed European Union legislation that would increase regulation of the private equity and hedge fund industries won a reprieve Monday when lawmakers once again pushed back a vote on the rules.

Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund firm, has shuffled top management, expanding the duties of Abigail Johnson, the daughter of its chief executive, and hiring a top Bank of New York Mellon executive to run its asset-management business, Reuters reported.

The son of billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett has an old-world spiritual message for today's money-rich parents: teach your children values and do not give them everything they want.

The Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's second-largest bank by assets, planned to raise about 800 billion yen ($8.7 billion) in common shares to prepare for stricter capital requirements, Reuters reported, citing three sources familiar with the matter.
The insurer Liberty Mutual Group said Monday its subsidiary Liberty Mutual Agency planned to raise $100 million with an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

Chesapeake Energy said Monday it plans to raise about $5 billion over the next two years in an effort to expand its investment in oil and natural gas liquids and to reduce its debt, The Associated Press reported.

At Centrale Montemartini, a former thermoelectric power plant turned museum, it's all about juxtaposition. Elegant ancient marble statues are displayed against hulking diesel engines and a massive steam turbine. Now organizers are adding a new element: live jazz.

Shortly before midnight Monday, Portugal Telecom announced it had received an "unsolicited, binding and unconditional offer" from TelefÃ³nica to pay 5.7 billion euros to buy out its interest in their Brazilian joint venture, Vivo.

When Elena Kagan was introduced yesterday as President Obama's nominee to the Supreme Court, both he and she remarked on her background and upbringing as part of her path to the nomination. Look ahead into your own future. How do you think your background may influence your own career and life path?

A former official accused of awarding kickbacks for steering investments made by California's giant pension fund denied fraud allegations against him in a statement Monday, The Associated Press reported.

Most of Canada's large English-language daily newspapers will come under the control of an investment group led by the former head of a rival publisher, Canwest Global Communications announced on Monday evening.

The wave of relief that swept global stock markets after the announcement of a giant European bailout package fizzled in the Asia-Pacific region by Tuesday, as markets erased earlier gains on worries that the measures would not be enough to contain the debt crisis, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.

Shares of Moody's fell sharply on Monday after it disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had warned that it might sue the firm for making "false and misleading" statements as part of its application as a ratings organization.

President Obama had just flown into Hampton, Va., Sunday morning to deliver a commencement address. But before he donned his silky academic robes, he was on the phone with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, offering urgent advice - and some not so subtle prodding - that Europe needed to try something big.

Genetic tests that assess a person's risk of getting various diseases are heading to the corner drug store. Pathway Genomics, a start-up company, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it will sell such a test through most of the nation's 7,500 Walgreens stores, Andrew Pollack writes in The New York Times.

Web sites publishing local deals are popping up everywhere, from Groupon and its imitators to Twitter and Foursquare to super-local neighborhood sites. The colors of the New York City subway map have been described as a rainbow. Turns out, they could also be described as a grove. The N, R, Q and W lines sport a shade called ''sunflower yellow.'' The Nos. 1, 2, and 3 trains use ''tomato red.'' And the No. 7 line, proudly purple, is actually a hue known as ''raspberry.'' (Those are usually heard on the 7 only when the Mets are having a bad day.)

WASSERSTEIN--Joseph. On May 7th, 2010, Joseph ("Jerry") Wasserstein passed away at the age of 94. Jerry is survived by his wife, Florence, and their children, Alan, Rita, Stephen, Susan, and Maxine. He was the proud grandfather of twelve and became a great-grandfather in November. The family will be sitting shiva tonight at the home of Susan and George Sard, 110 Riverside Drive, from 6-9pm.

Maybe Supreme Court justices, United Nations ambassadors, presidential envoys to troubled parts of the globe and divorce mediators should all be at least 60 years old. This, let me hastily note, is my own hypothesis after wading into a provocative new study in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Its lead author, Igor Grossmann, a psychologist at the University of Michigan, is far too cautious a scientist to make such sweeping suggestions. But look at what he and his colleagues have discovered.

''Her open-mindedness may disappoint some who want a sure liberal vote on almost every issue. Her pragmatism may disappoint those who believe that mechanical logic can decide all cases. And her progressive personal values will not endear her to the hard right. But that is exactly the combination the president was seeking.'' WALTER DELLINGER, an acting solicitor general in the Clinton administration who is close to Elena Kagan, President Obama's Supreme Court nominee. [A14]

LONDON -- Britain's quest for a new government took a sudden turn on Monday when Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced that he would resign within months as Labour Party leader as part of a bid to lure the Liberal Democrats into rejecting the Conservatives and joining a rejuvenated Labour in a left-of-center governing coalition. Speaking to reporters outside 10 Downing Street, Mr. Brown said he would remain in office to oversee negotiations for a new government, but would stand down as Labour's leader when a successor was elected sometime before the party's annual conference in September. His resignation would end 13 years as Labour's chancellor of the Exchequer and prime minister.

Survived by her husband Yale with whom she shared 49 years of a devoted marriage; by sisters Evelyn Schwartz and Judith Cohen; and by numerous nieces and nephews, great-nephews and nieces, and great-great nieces and nephews. Services Wednesday, May 12 at Riverside Nassau located at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY at 2pm.

DORFMAN--Martin S. Beloved husband of Sonia, loving father of Jeffrey (Kelly), Susan, and Andrew, adoring grandfather of six. World War II army veteran. Grand City Container executive. Kindest, most thoughtful man, irreplaceable in our hearts.

David E. Apter, a Yale professor who wove his expertise in political science and sociology into influential treatises on the often-tortured birth of developing nations, died Tuesday at his home in North Haven, Conn. He was 85. The cause was complications of cancer, his daughter, Emily Apter, said.

May 9 We are all completely exhausted after two successful hikes to the summit of Mt. Marojejy, including night work there. And best of all, we found amazing chameleons, including two of the rarest species in the world!! It is now time to catch up with some sleep, then photograph the animals, and then start some of the lab work. Also, lots of other wonderful things here, including a super-sticky narrow-mouthed toad that you can pick up by touching your finger on its back. The weather has been kind to us -- no rain, although lots of clouds and mist above 2,000 m (summit at 2,132 m).But my sweat-laden T-shirt from the first day hike is still not dry at our mossy camp.

BAUMEISTER--Matthew C. April 5, 1986 - May 11, 2005 Our dearest Matthew, it is five years since we have held you - both a lifetime ago and yet just an instant. Your death has left a heartache that does not heal and sorrow that feeds our tears. Your love has left us wonderful memories that we will treasure for all our years. Not a day goes by when you are not in our hearts. Loving you forever. Missing you always. Mom, Dad and Jared

Why do some men and women cheat on their partners while others resist the temptation? To find the answer, a growing body of research is focusing on the science of commitment. Scientists are studying everything from the biological factors that seem to influence marital stability to a person's psychological response after flirting with a stranger.

On March 20, the Plastiki, a 60-foot vessel made from recycled plastic bottles, set sail from San Francisco Bay on an 11,000-mile voyage to Sydney, Australia. The goal of the voyage, masterminded and financed by a banking heir, David de Rothschild, is to call attention to environmental issues like bottled water and plastic waste. Solar panels and windmills power the vessel, and the crew uses Skype, Twitter and blogs to stay in touch with the outside world. They've also posted regular video updates. After 38 continuous days at sea, the crew anchored at Christmas Island on April 27 for a few days' rest before the next leg, a 20- to 30-day voyage to Fiji. Before the boat sailed, we chatted by e-mail with Jo Royle, the Plastiki's 30-year-old skipper, about the challenges that the crew has faced. Here are excerpts, edited for brevity and clarity.Q.For starters, describe your whereabouts for our readers. Are you happy to be onshore after a month at sea?A.Right now I am on the beautiful tropical shores of Christmas Island, which is situated 1.5 degrees north of the equator. Moving very slowly, as it's very hot and I am having to acclimate to this tropical heat. I have to work on the boat as the sun rises, hide at lunchtime and then surface again before sunset. This is a very welcome rest.Q.Did you have any harrowing moments in those 38 days sailing the Pacific? Surprises?A.Thankfully, we experienced no head winds and no constant wind speed above 25 knots. If we had spent 38 days in the Atlantic, we would have seen so much more, and experienced more complex weather systems. It has taken this experience for me to really realize what an adventure we are on. I know the Pacific Ocean covers one-third of the planet, but wow, it felt massive out there. We were so alone!

It's official: Zenyatta is a crossover sports star. In fact, she's a home-run horse. The undefeated mare is the newest Los Angelean to be featured in the ''This Is My Town'' marketing campaign for the Los Angeles Dodgers. It is fitting for many reasons, not the least of which is that Dodgers skipper Joe Torre is an avid horseplayer and owner. Zenyatta has long owned the hearts of Southern California race fans, but now she has laid claim on some prime real estate in the City of Angels (er Dodgers).

WOLFSON--Cecil. We honor the life and mourn the passing of Cecil Wolfson, beloved husband of Barbara of 53 years and treasured and devoted father of Michael. A true southern gentleman in every sense of the word, he was loved and respected by everyone who knew him. Though he endured inordinate physical hardship in his final years, he always maintained his joyful spirit, humor, warmth and caring for his many lifelong friends as well as for those he had only just met. After a life built around good deeds, family and friends, may he find the peace and comfort that he so deeply deserves. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Cecil Wolfson Fund for The Wolfson Childrens Hospital, 841 Prudential Drive, Jacksonville, FL 32207. Barbara and Michael Wolfson

ALBANY -- New York unveiled what it billed as the nation's first comprehensive statewide cancer map, which became available Monday on the Web site of the State Department of Health. Not that the Health Department is doing so eagerly. The creation of the map was opposed by both the department and the American Cancer Society when it was proposed two years ago, according to a review of state records, amid concerns that its unfiltered data could be misinterpreted.

4th May 2010, Madagascar At the town of Andapa everything went extremely well. Exhausted from the two days of driving, we checked into the small Crystal Hotel at 8 in the morning, enjoyed a breakfast of eggs and French bread, and then presented our research permits to the local Madagascar National Parks office. The park director explained to us that there was no problem working in the Marojejy Park at night (which was a huge relief since many reserves have stopped this because of security concerns), and very quickly we were looking at maps, and making plans for guides, porters and camping fees. My priority on this survey was to work the highest elevation forests, close to the summit, as these forests had been the most poorly explored and had the potential to have the highest degree of local endemism (species restricted to Marojejy, or the local massifs). Of course, there is a good reason why the highest elevation areas have had the least amount of study - they are hardest to reach, and are the most difficult to resupply.

Two men have been charged with killing two teenagers who had been at a birthday party in the Bronx in the early-morning hours of Sunday. The victims, Quanisha Marie Wright, 16, and Marvin Wiggins, 15, were at a child's first birthday party in the Tremont section when a group of men showed up uninvited and began to harass young women, prompting an argument, witnesses said. The group left, but returned a half-hour later, at about 2 a.m. This time they were armed.

ALBANY -- The Legislature approved an emergency budget bill on Monday that would authorize Gov. David A. Paterson to furlough about 100,000 state employees, roughly half the state's work force, without pay for one day. Public employee unions contended that the furloughs, which officials said would be the first for state workers in New York, would be illegal, and they said they would seek a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court here to block Mr. Paterson's plan.

An article on Wednesday about stock market losses across Europe because of worry about Greece's finances misstated the euro's record low exchange rate versus the American dollar. As an accompanying chart correctly showed, the euro's exchange rate dropped to under 83 cents in 2000; its low was not 88 cents in 2001.

SHIPMAN--Matthew. Died peacefully on May 8, 2010 following a massive stroke, surrounded by his extended family who adored him and whom he adored. A resident of New York City and Garrison, New York, Matthew was born in 1938 in Brooklyn and raised in Long Island, beginning his lifelong love of sailing and reading. Matthew graduated from Woodmere Academy, Middlebury College and the Thunderbird School. Following service in the U.S. Army, he worked on a Chilean freighter, jumping ship in Peru. He stayed in Peru for several years, farming in the Ayacucho Valley, publishing in Lima and editing the poetry review, Haravec. Returning to New York City, in the early 1970s Matthew pursued his interests in startup ventures and local politics, and later in real estate and land preservation in the Hudson Valley. Known as a raconteur and for his infectious joie de vivre, Matthew will always be treasured for his sense of adventure, mastery of sailing and love of the sea, poetry and prose, but most of all his acts of generosity and kindness. Matthew is survived by his beloved wife Susan Mackenzie, sons Christopher and Timothy, nephews Andrew and Peter and niece Nancy, sister Judith, and a host of other loving in-laws, nieces and grand nieces and nephews, and friends. A celebration of his life will be held on May 29, 2010 at 2pm at St. Philip's Episcopal Church, Route 9D, Garrison, New York, followed by a community reception at 3pm at the Garrison Landing. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Hudson Valley Land Trust, P.O. Box 226, Garrison, NY 10524 or the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, 1601 U.S. 9, Garrison, NY 10524-4406.

New Haven AMONG its other virtues, the nomination of Solicitor General Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court is an opportunity to rescue the confirmation process from the ''vapid and hollow charade'' that it has become.

An article on Saturday about research on creativity and the brain, in citing examples of questions that some researchers posed to subjects, misidentified the Alabama city in which Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white person and referred incorrectly to that person. The incident occurred in Montgomery, not Birmingham, and the white person was a man, not a woman.

A report in the World Briefing column on April 24 about a rare public protest in China, in which three graduates of People's University in Beijing tossed currency notes worth five mao onto a university stage where the deputy director of the propaganda department in Yunnan Province was speaking, misstated the currency's value. Five mao is worth less than 10 cents, not less than one cent.

Europe's leaders stared into the abyss and finally decided to act. The nearly $1 trillion bailout package, arranged over the weekend, is intended to head off Greece's default and stop the crisis from dragging under other weak economies -- Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Italy are all vulnerable. The European and American markets celebrated on Monday. The CAC-40 index in Paris rose almost 10 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.9 percent. It was certainly the right thing to do. Coupled with the European Central Bank's promise to buy bonds from stricken European countries, it arrested the financial turmoil -- at least for now.

LEVINE--Robert, 88, died peacefully May 8, 2010 in Minnesota, of congestive heart failure. Loving husband for 56 years of the late Lee (Ruthen), beloved father of Amy Levine and son-in-law Brian Horrigan, adored grandpa of Colin and Delia. Son of the late David and Lena (Murav) and brother of the late Cal and the late Marcia Kashkett; loving uncle to his nieces and nephews and friend to many cousins. A 1942 graduate of CCNY, Bob was a lieutenant in the Army Air Corps in WWII. Staunch member of the Harry Hershkowitz lodge of B'nai Brith, he was an IRS agent for 35 years. Bob was a mensch: ethical, kind, generous, and with unfailing good humor. We were blessed to have him in our lives and will miss him always. Memorial donations to the Fanconi Anemia Research Fund, 1801 Willamette St., Eugene, OR 97401, or at www.fanconi.org.

KONIGSBERG--Vivian. Together with her husband Sidney, she was particularly interested in encouraging the careers of exceptionally talented engineers and students, as shown by support of projects including the Vivian and Sidney Konigsberg Career Development Chair, the Vivian Konigsberg Award for Excellence in Teaching, the Vivian and Joanne Konigsberg Fellowship in Adolescent Medicine, and the Sidney and Vivian Konigsberg Fund for Exceptionally Gifted Students. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

Tenth graders at Hunter College High School in Manhattan had a substitute teacher in their American history class on Monday for an unusual reason: Their regular teacher, Irving Kagan, was in Washington, watching his sister, Elena, accept President Obama's nomination for a seat on the Supreme Court. Both siblings attended Hunter, and Mr. Kagan returned to be a social studies teacher there. Their mother, Gloria, taught for years at the affiliated elementary school. So it was with a special sense of pride that students and teachers in the schools on East 94th Street welcomed the news that Ms. Kagan, the nation's solicitor general, had risen even higher on the school's long list of notable alumni.

An obituary on Friday about the Italian mezzo-soprano Giulietta Simionato, using information from the Lyric Opera of Chicago, misstated the date and location of her American debut. It was in 1953 at the San Francisco Opera, not in 1954 at the Lyric Opera of Chicago.

ANGELL--Callie. The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, Inc. mourns the untimely death of film curator and scholar Callie Angell. Her book, "Andy Warhol Screen Tests: The Films of Andy Warhol Catalogue Raisonne Volume 1" is a landmark in film scholarship. With her eagerly awaited work on Volume 2, Callie Angell has made an unparalleled contribution to the study and appreciation of Andy Warhol's art. We shall miss her penetrating intellect and erudition, her generosity as a colleague, and her warmth as a friend.

The Kentucky Derby champ Super Saver pleased his jockey and trainer on Monday morning at Churchill Downs with a three-furlong blowout in a crisp 36.60 seconds. As good as he looked, however, the colt is hardly scaring the competition away from the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes. The Derby favorite Lookin at Lucky will ship to Baltimore as his trainer, Bob Baffert, gives him a new rider, Martin Garcia, in the hope that Lookin at Lucky can return to the form that made him the Juvenile champion last year.
International AS CRICKET GREW IN INDIA,

Wednesday morning in Madagascar's capital, Antananarivo, which is known as Tana, and with all research permits now in hand, it is time to start thinking about the practical aspects of starting the fieldwork. That means trying to plan (and pack) for everything that can go wrong. And a lot can go wrong in Madagascar. For example, when the car breaks down and strands you in the middle of nowhere, with absolutely no roadside towing, except maybe a couple of zebu cows in the closest village, if you can find their owner. So, a very good place to start the practical preparation is with the car -- my trusty old Land Rover, ''Baby.'' She will be carrying us down 2,000 km of road and tracks to Marojejy mountain, so she is the most critical piece of research equipment. Baby has had a distinguished and adventurous life, which includes crossing the Betsiboka River (one of Madagascar's largest) in full flood, on top of three canoes, during the 2002 political crisis. Like a doting parent, I am always nervous, when she goes in for her checkups. Nicholas, my team driver, mechanic and car guard, told me the car had just been serviced after a trip with one of my students, but would benefit from an additional ''verification,'' just to make sure all was in good order.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 3 about YouTube's move into live sports broadcasting misstated the number of cricket teams in the Indian Premier League, whose 60 matches YouTube carried. It has eight teams, not 20.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a benefit concert for the Rainforest Fund on Thursday at Carnegie Hall erroneously included some performers among those scheduled to appear. Billy Joel, James Taylor, Brian Wilson, Feist, Kathleen Battle, Chris Botti and Natalie Clein were on the program for the benefit concert in 2008; they are not scheduled to perform at this week's concert.

8 P.M. (ESPN) STRAIGHT OUTTA L.A. In 1982 Al Davis, the principal owner of the Oakland Raiders, won an antitrust suit against the National Football League and moved his team to Los Angeles, capturing, in the process, a large number of black and Hispanic fans. Soon the newfangled Raiders were transformed into a brand as the team's silver and black colors and swagger became linked to the hip-hop scene in South Central Los Angeles, including the rap group N.W.A., of which Ice Cube was a member. In this documentary, part of ESPN's ''30 for 30'' anniversary celebration, Ice Cube, above, now an actor and filmmaker as well, looks at the culture clash between the football franchise and Tinseltown. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOLJamie Foxx tutors the four remaining singers: Crystal Bowersox, Michael Lynche, Casey James and Lee DeWyze.
An obituary on Saturday about the museum administrator Jan van der Marck misspelled the surname of the art historian with whom he studied at Columbia University. He was Meyer Schapiro, not Shapiro.

As an undergraduate at the University of Washington in the late 1990s, Wendie Wilson noticed some striking ads in the campus newspaper: appeals to young women to sell their eggs for what seemed to her exorbitant sums of money. But she had no idea what was involved until she herself decided to go through the process a few years later. To her surprise, Ms Wilson recalled recently, she discovered that helping an infertile couple conceive a child made her feel ''fantastic.'' And she certainly appreciated the $5,000 payment. ''It seemed a relatively small amount of my time for what seemed to be pretty decent compensation,'' she said. She found the experience so empowering, she submitted to it four more times and eventually founded her own egg donation agency in Los Angeles, Gifted Journeys, which maintains a registry of 300 to 400 potential donors.

An article on Monday about the investigation into an abrupt stock market plunge on Thursday erroneously included a company in a list of stocks on the Dow Jones industrial average, and also referred incorrectly to the size of the Dow index. The Dow industrial average has 30 companies, not five, and Accenture is not among them. The article also misstated part of the name of an electronic exchange whose senior officials were scheduled to meet on Monday with the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. It is Direct Edge, not Direct Trading.

We finally left Tana on May 2, fully loaded with all our equipment and supplies. The packing is always high stress, as the omission of a single item can have terrible consequences in the field, when resupply is not an option. For example, no formalin or alcohol (perhaps due to a leaking bottle top), or no spare flashlight bulbs, can bring research to a complete stop. I had hoped we could have departed the previous afternoon, but my driver, Nicholas, was nervous about nighttime attacks on vehicles between Tana and Antsohihy, so we left at first light. The drive went smoothly (except for the shaking from the unbalanced new tires above 80km/h!) and we crossed the Betsiboka River at midday, admiring the brown silt-laden rapids, which told us we were still at the end of the rainy season. Herpetologists love the rain, as it keeps the frogs and reptiles active, but the cost in the tropics is fungus growing in your optics and electronics, and the worst kind of slippery mud off-road. My dead dog count for our first day of driving reached three - it really is a dog's life in Madagascar. They are considered so unclean that they are left at the roadside to be scavenged by crows. We also had the bizarre situation where a small wild dove (which love to sit in the middle of roads in Madagascar) flew through the Land Rover's side window as we were driving at speed. After a minute it had recovered itself, and we released back out the other side. As bird twitchers would say, you can put that on your life list of bizarre bird observations.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an American symphony orchestra's performance at the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai, which echoed its groundbreaking diplomatic mission to China 37 years ago and helped pave the way for the return of Western art and culture to China, misstated the orchestra's name. It is the Philadelphia Orchestra, not Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra.

STAMAS--Elaine Heidi, 78 on May 10, 2010, after a brave battle with ovarian cancer. Adored wife of 55 years of Stephen Stamas; loving mother of Heidi Stamas of New York City and of Ted Stamas and mother-in-law of Katrina Stamas of Montclair, New Jersey. Best grandmother in the world to Alexandra and Samuel Cox, and Stephen, Alexander and Georgia Stamas. She is also survived by her brother, Dr. Nicholas Zervas. Her family was the center of her life. Her devotion and love enveloped family and friends alike. Born in 1931 to Dr. Themistocles and Demetra Zervas in Lynn, Mass, she graduated from Colby College where she later served first as an overseer and then as a Trustee from 1992-2006. She was awarded an honorary M.A. at Colby and was Trustee Emeritus. Music was a great interest throughout her life. She was one of the original Colbyette singers, and she sang for many years in the Westchester Choral Society, which brought her immense joy. She was also a longstanding Board member of the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale, NY. During her husband's tenure as Chairman of the New York Philharmonic, Elaine developed enduring friendships with many musicians and was a vibrant presence at concerts and tours. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Hoff-Barthelson Music School or the Elaine Stamas Scholarship fund at Colby College. Services will be held on Thursday May 13th at 11am at the Church of St. James the Less, located at 10 Church Lane in Scarsdale, New York.

Campbell, 1076 Madsion Ave. (81st St.) Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell Thursday, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Joseph's name to City Harvest, 575 8th Ave., 4th floor, NY, NY 10018 Attn: Jasmine Abbatiello.

After reading the summer issue of 032cÂ  (which I wrote about in an earlier post), featuring William T. Vollmann and photographs by Danko Steiner, I rooted out my few copies of Nest. I hadn't thought about them in a while and wasn't surprised that their look and sense of freedom continued to inspire. A frustration voiced a lot these days - by art directors, writers, bloggers and others - is that people aren't actually creating new things today. They are repeating, mimicking, collecting, downloading, endlessly commenting upon - activities that may be interesting andÂ that may reflect the present moment butÂ  are not about creating anything. One could even argue that they are the opposite of creativity and produce the feeling of being in a prison. Of course, when you consider the very real problems that many people in the world face, like hunger and shortages of medicine, these sorts of complaints sound silly. But creativity in the arts and in applied arts like fashion obviously does matter, and the ways that people insist on being outside the prison are interesting. At Marakuthai, tucked away in a house in Jardins (above; Alameda Itu, 1618; 011-55-11-3062-7556; entrees $20 to $29), the 21-year-old Renata Vanzetto takes inspiration from Thai food for her cooking, which is based on fresh local fruit and produce, for dishes like shrimp in curry sauce with coconut-crusted banana. As a baseball great once said, "It ain't over till it's over," and in the case of the Ken Burns documentary "Baseball," it ain't over yet. In September PBS will broadcast a new documentary called "The Tenth Inning," directed by Mr. Burns and Lynn Novick, that will continue the story begun by Mr. Burns's 1994 film about the great American pastime. "The Tenth Inning," which will be shown in two parts on Sept. 28 and 29, will track baseball's history from the 1990s to the present, including the 1994 strike; the home-run-record Â chases of Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa and Barry Bonds; the use of performance-enhancing drugs in the sport; the re-ascenscion of the New York Yankees; the long-awaited World Series victory of the Boston Red Sox; and the sport's reaction to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

Audit Finds Considerable Overtime at Muni | Muni could save $3 million annually by reining in overtime, according to an audit by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors' budget analyst. Muni experiences a high level of absenteeism among its drivers, making service less reliable, in part because of incentives in the way that they are paid. Now, drivers can work overtime - earning time-and-a-half pay - even if they have not worked 40 hours in a week. That rule creates a financial incentive for drivers to skip work on regular workdays and to work overtime on other days, the audit found. The beleaguered transit agency recently cut service 10 percent. The Transport Workers Union's contract expires on June 30, 2011. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

In the sixth installment of Ozier Muhammad's series, ''Sounds From Uncommon Spaces,'' we meet Chris Washburne, a trombonist and an assistant professor of ethnomusicology at Columbia University. He often practices in Morningside Park. His remarks, to Mr. Muhammad, have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity. ''I came to New York City to be a studio musician, to play jazz, but I didn't want to flip burgers while I broke into the scene. I didn't have that many connections with other musicians, so - on a whim - I applied to graduate school.'' He was accepted at Columbia. ''After a while I started digging graduate school. I was in it for the long trek. It took me 9 years to finish my Ph.D.''

An obituary on Friday about Max Palevsky, the founder of the computer-chip company Intel and a donor to Democratic politicians, referred incorrectly to Senator George McGovern's history as a presidential candidate. He ran briefly for the Democratic nomination in the summer of 1968 and announced his candidacy for the 1972 nomination in 1971; he did not begin running for president in 1972.

ARLINGTON, Tex. -- The Class A Stockton Ports opened a new ballpark in 2005, but the players still parked at the old one. The day of the first practice, Daric Barton and Richie Robnett, both first-round draft picks, rolled into the old lot and dropped off their cars: a Tahoe for Barton, a Range Rover with 24-inch rims for Robnett. The next day, their new teammate Dallas Braden, a lanky left-hander, approached them and asked if the cars did, indeed, belong to them. Warily, Barton said yes.

ALBUQUERQUE -- As the Arizona Legislature steamed ahead with the most stringent immigration enforcement bill in the country this year, this state's House of Representatives was unanimously passing a resolution recognizing the economic benefits of illegal immigrants. While the Arizona police will check driver's licenses and other documents to root out illegal immigrants, New Mexico allows illegal residents to obtain driver's licenses as a public safety measure.

PITTSBURGH -- The moment was almost vintage Sidney Crosby. He was working the puck along the Montreal Canadiens' end boards against the rookie defenseman P. K. Subban. Crosby then carried the puck up the side boards, abruptly changed directions and headed back into the corner and, finally, darted up the boards again. Subban struggled to keep up with the masterly Crosby, but he did stay with him. Crosby reversed once more, back down through the corner, to the end boards. Subban was falling behind. Crosby planned to gain space to make a centering pass or step to the net and shoot. But Subban lunged and caught up -- no pass for Crosby, no path to the net. Crosby did another stutter-step. This time, he freed himself of Subban, but the puck rolled off the end of his stick. Crosby, seemingly exhausted, could not summon the energy to retrieve it. The Canadiens won the loose puck.

ESTREN--Solomon, MD. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Estren came to Mount Sinai in 1947 after graduating from The New York University School of Medicine. He was a superb clinician in the field of Hematology and was nationally known for his research in vitamin B12 and metabolic disorders. In 1964 he translated and edited "Thannhauser's Textbook of Metabolism" from German into English. He dedicated more than 60 years of service to the institution and the care of his patients and trained several generations of Hematology residents. He will be remembered as an outstanding researcher and practitioner and a wonderful man. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD President Gila Leiter, MD Vice President Amy J. Weinstein Administrator

PRYSTOWSKY--Milton, MD passed away unexpectedly on May 10, 2010. Milt was born in Charleston, South Carolina on February 17, 1922. He was the beloved husband of the late Rose Prystowsky, MD. and is survived by his loving children, Doctors Stephen, Eric, Michael, Barry, and Richard, devoted daughters-in-law, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and brother, Sidney, MD. After training in pediatrics and pediatric cardiology at the Harriet Lane Home of Johns Hopkins University under the tutelage of Helen Taussig, Milt was the first pediatric cardiologist in New Jersey and opened the Division of Pediatric Cardiology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. In his signature bow tie, he practiced as a pediatrician and pediatric cardiologist in Nutley, NJ from 1951 to 2004. Even in retirement, he continued to see patients as a consultant at Children's Hospital of New Jersey. His many years of service as a tireless healer of and advocate for children--especially those who are most vulnerable--as well as his longtime service on public health committees in New Jersey, led to improved health care and insurance benefits for children. In his more than 60 years of medical service, he had numerous accomplishments and received many awards. He was on the Founding Board of Children's Hospital (in Newark, NJ), for example. He served as President of the Public Health Council of New Jersey, which oversees the New Jersey State Department of Health. United Hospital of New Jersey recognized him with a special title, given only to him: "Role Model for Pediatric Residents." The New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry presented him with a Lifetime Dean's Award. He was also Clinical Professor of Pediatrics and Pediatric Cardiology at the medical schools. And, to take but one more example, he was with the national organization of all NACRI organizations (with Children's Hospital), representing New Jersey in Washington, DC, to lobby for much needed funds. Milt's seemingly indefatigable advocacy for children is perhaps best exemplified by his having led the years-long effort to establish New Jersey's Catastrophic Children's Illness Fund--a unique model in the nation, which ensures that no family in New Jersey ever has to go bankrupt because they have a child in desperate need of catastrophic medical care. This accomplishment underscores that, first and foremost, Milt was a model humanitarian, who cared about helping persons regardless of their ability to pay, and regardless of their social station in life. Indeed, what those who knew him say that they remember most about Milt was his genuine kindness, his warmth, his caring personality. No problem was ever too small to be brought to his attention, as the many persons whose lives he touched knew it. Dr. Milton Prystowsky influenced the lives of thousands of countless lives and made a significant impact on the quality of families and communities. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, May 12, 10am at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King St., Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Dr. Prystowsky's honor should be made to the Drs. Milton and Rose Medical Student Award at the Foundation, The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, 65 Bergen Street, Newark, NJ 07107.

O'REILLY--Rita M.,passed from this life on May 10, 2010 at the age of 94. Rita was born August 12, 1915 to Michael and Catherine (Parks) O'Reilly in New York City. In addition to her mother and father, Rita was predeceased by brother Michael (Dorothy), sister Eileen and brother Lt. George Patrick. She is survived by her brother Joseph (Jeanne) of Pleasantville, NY. Rita graduated from Cathedral High School and attended Hunter College. In April, 1934 Rita was employed by a world leader in precious metals corporation, Handy & Harmon, where she had a wonderful career spanning forty seven years serving in many managerial positions, retiring as Marketing Manager. Rita, in addition to her career, loved reading, Broadway shows, traveling, her beautiful home, and being with family at Breezy Point Beach. She enjoyed being with her brother Joseph's children, George (Edie), Jennine (Ed), Sean and Kristin (Geoffrey) and seeing her grand nieces and nephews, Joseph Conway, Daniel, Alex, and Julia O'Reilly, MacKenzie and Geoffrey Scott II Porteus. Rita was a devout Catholic and parishioner for 52 years at St. Barnabas Church in Woodlawn. She was extremely charitable to missions and other worthy causes. She will be missed by her family, extended family and many friends and neighbors. Rita will be waked at David J. Hodder & Son, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers. Visiting hours Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:45am, St. Barnabas Church. Entombment St. Raymond Cemetery.

The space is little more than a cramped room with teal-colored walls, a griddle, and a refrigerator filled with Mexican sodas. But this modest restaurant in the South Bronx has become the hub of the Melrose community, a place where police officers, construction workers, lawyers and local residents gather to eat tamales and gossip about the neighborhood. A visitor could see a group of musicians playing the drums one day, and the longtime local congressman eating a Cuban sandwich the next. Until recently, the area had more rubble than residents, but Melrose is on the rebound, and if Coqui Mexicano, called the neighborhood's living room, has not ignited the resurgence, it has at least nourished it.

(49) THE DOORS: WHEN YOU'RE STRANGE From the formation of the Doors, above, in 1965 to the death of their lead singer, Jim Morrison, in 1971, the group -- including the drummer John Densmore, the guitarist Robby Krieger, the keyboardist Ray Manzarek and Morrison -- were one of the most influential, theatrical and even frightening American rock bands. Using only original footage, much of it previously unseen, this ''American Masters'' documentary from Tom DiCillo chronicles the creation of the band's six studio albums, starting at the U.C.L.A. film school, where Morrison and Mr. Manzarek met, and venturing onto concert stages. Johnny Depp narrates; Dick Wolf and Peter Jankowski (''Law & Order'') produced. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Geneen Roth talks about her new book, ''Women Food and God.''

An article last Wednesday about a dispute over the possession of a bullhorn used by Harvey Milk to rally crowds during his battles for gay equality in the 1970s in San Francisco erroneously attributed a distinction to him. Mr. Milk, who was elected to the Board of Supervisors in 1977, was the first openly gay man to attain such a high office in San Francisco, but not the first to do so in the United States. (Allan P. Spear, a state legislator in Minnesota, came out before being re-elected, in 1976.)

A Reuters article on Monday about Boeing's plans for delivery of its first 787 Dreamliner misstated the aircraft's chief rival in the jetliner market. It is the A350 jet made by Airbus, not the Airbus A380.

How angry is the world at Facebook for devouring every morsel of personal information we are willing to feed it? A few months back, four geeky college students, living on pizza in a computer lab downtown on Mercer Street, decided to build a social network that wouldn't force people to surrender their privacy to a big business. It would take three or four months to write the code, and they would need a few thousand dollars each to live on.

An article on Monday about the sacrifices in sound quality of audio in compressed computer files misstated the common unit of measurement for the transfer rate for digital audio formats. It is kilobits per second, not kilobytes. The article also rendered incorrectly the name of a New York City company that makes master recordings. It is Masterdisk, not MasterDisk.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the Philadelphia Flyers' 5-4 victory over the Boston Bruins in Game 4 of their N.H.L. playoff series on Friday misstated the time at which Simon Gagne scored the winning goal. It was at 14 minutes 40 seconds of overtime -- not 4:40.

An article on May 1 about the tension between academic goals and the scandal-plagued athletics department at the University of Oregon, which has some of the most opulent athletic facilities in the country, referred imprecisely to a learning center and a laptop program there. While primarily for athletes, the center, which is often called the Jock Box for its design, contains areas that are open to the public or used by others on campus; it is not ''for athletes only.'' And if athletes at Oregon want one of the 550 laptops donated by Phil Knight, a Nike founder, for their use, they need to request one and pay $100 a year to insure it; it is not the case that ''all they have to do is ask'' for one.

STAMAS--Elaine Heidi, 78 on May 10, 2010, after a brave battle with ovarian cancer. Adored wife of 55 years of Stephen Stamas; loving mother of Heidi Stamas of New York City and of Ted Stamas and mother-in-law of Katrina Stamas of Montclair, New Jersey. Best grandmother in the world to Alexandra and Samuel Cox, and Stephen, Alexander and Georgia Stamas. She is also survived by her brother, Dr. Nicholas Zervas. Her family was the center of her life. Her devotion and love enveloped family and friends alike. Born in 1931 to Dr. Themistocles and Demetra Zervas in Lynn, Mass, she graduated from Colby College where she later served first as an overseer and then as a Trustee from 1992-2006. She was awarded an honorary M.A. at Colby and was Trustee Emeritus. Music was a great interest throughout her life. She was one of the original Colbyette singers, and she sang for many years in the Westchester Choral Society, which brought her immense joy. She was also a longstanding Board member of the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale, NY. During her husband's tenure as Chairman of the New York Philharmonic, Elaine developed enduring friendships with many musicians and was a vibrant presence at concerts and tours. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Hoff-Barthelson Music School or the Elaine Stamas Scholarship fund at Colby College. Services will be held on Thursday May 13th at 11am at the Church of St. James the Less, located at 10 Church Lane in Scarsdale, New York.

STAMAS--Elaine H. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the passing of Elaine H. Stamas, cherished wife of our beloved Trustee Emeritus Stephen Stamas. We are heartbroken for Steve over the loss of his dearest companion for more than half a century. Elaine was the embodiment of the very best that human nature has to offer. We will remember her kind and gentle spirit, her keen intelligence, her enormous warmth and great integrity, and above all the love she felt for her family. It was clear to all that her close-knit and vibrant family was her proudest accomplishment. While her own passion was for music, a field in which she enthusiastically participated both as performer and advocate, her generosity of spirit allowed her to embrace Steve's interest in the biomedical sciences and, in particular, The Rockefeller University, which Steve has served in many leadership capacities, including Vice Chair of the Board, for more than 25 years. It was always a pleasure to welcome Elaine to our campus, and we will miss her very much. We extend our deepest condolences to Steve; to their children Heidi and Ted; to their daughter-in-law Katrina; to their grandchildren; and to everyone who loved her. Russell Carson, Chair David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Richard Furlaud, Chair Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus

For the past two months, Chinese authorities have been trying to deal with a string of vicious attacks on young children in rural elementary schools. They have clamped down on news coverage, citing fears of copycat crimes and called for heightened school security. But on May 12, a man stormed a village school in Shaanxi Province and hacked to death seven children and two adults. It was the fifth attack since March, all involving middle-aged men using knives, cleavers or tools. Seventeen people have been killed and nearly 100 wounded in the attacks.
Facebook has unveiled new features to help protect your account from getting taken over by cybercrooks, bitter ex-boyfriends or anyone else who might want to impersonate you to do you wrong.

People close to "Law & Order" were told Thursday afternoon that the pioneering NBC drama had been canceled. But the network has not yet confirmed the decision, and there were indications late Thursday that talks about its fate were continuing.

I had an article today about structural unemployment -- the idea that some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets don't match what employers want (for example, they are highly specialized auto workers, but the only local job opening is for an oncologist). The typical causes of structural unemployment are the three T's: trade, technology and changing tastes (e.g., consumers want more iPods and fewer C.D. players).

The Flatiron district, home of its namesake skyscraper and the jewel-like green space known as Madison Square Park, is a place of endless reinvention. Later this year, for example, Mario Batali's Eataly, an emporium of upscale restaurants and food markets, is scheduled to open at 200 Fifth Avenue, and the owner of the iconic Flatiron Building plans to convert it into a luxury hotel. For a close look at this always-morphing area, take the N, R or W line to the 23rd Street subway stop. And come hungry. In another of its incarnations, the district is a restaurant destination.

Small businesses may have caught a break in the swiftly moving negotiations over the Senate financial reform bill. On Wednesday, Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois offered an amendment to the reform bill that would loosen the hold that credit card networks like Visa and MasterCard now have over merchants. Senate leaders are expected to bring the amendment up for a vote - an important milestone, because in major bills, most amendments never get this far.

The Avis Budget Group moved closer on Thursday to making a bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, saying it was seeking federal antitrust approval of its potential acquisition. The move is somewhat unusual in that Avis has not yet made a formal offer, while Dollar Thrifty has already agreed to be acquired by Hertz Global Holdings for $1.2 billion in cash and stock.

Senator John McCain has a new ad out to show Arizona voters that he is serious about stopping the flow of illegal immigration, and it has drawn snickering from many quarters. The ad, which Steve Benan at Political Animal wrote about the other day, shows Mr. McCain walking along the border in Arizona, with a sheriff in uniform complaining about illegal immigrants. Mr. McCain says, "Complete the danged fence.''

Tickled as we were by the sight of Mikhail Gorbachev in a Louis Vuitton ad, we're glad that LV stopped using world leaders as luxury pitchmen before Ban Ki-moon showed up in a monogrammed thong. In its latest promotional essay, out today, the French juggernaut teams up with the at-home photographer Todd Selby, who calls himself just "The Selby." Given that name, and considering all the Louis Vuitton bootlegs, one could easily have called this project "The Genuine Article Meets the Definite Article." Alas,Â "The Journey of a Man's Wardrobe" showcases the fall/winter collection through Selby's portraits of Vuitton-ified style icons in New York (Ruben Toledo, AndrÃ© Balazs and Waris Ahluwalia), along with others from Shanghai, London and Tokyo. Perhaps most interesting for diehard Vuitton fans are Selby's photos of the Vuitton family home in AsniÃ¨res, France, the place where Monsieur Vuitton moved his workshop in 1859. Visit the site for a peek.

Apparently the theater gods and goddesses were listening when we noted earlier today that there was still one more gavel yet to fall in the re-casting of the Broadway play "Race": When James Spader leaves that David Mamet drama after June 20, he will be replaced by Eddie Izzard, its producers said. Mr. Izzard, the comedian and actor who will take over in the role of the lawyer Jack Lawson, made his Broadway debut in the 2003 revival of "A Day in the Death of Joe Egg," the Peter Nichols comedy; he's also an Emmy Award winner for his comedy special "Eddie Izzard: Dress to Kill," and looks smashing in drag (which he won't be doing for "Race," alas). "Race" is slated to run through Aug. 21 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater with a cast that will include Dennis Haysbert and Afton C. Williamson, as well as Richard Thomas, who has been in the play since its opening.

Are theatergoers ready to forgive - or, at least, revisit - "The Capeman"? Students of Broadway probably know its back story better than its music by now: this notorious musical about the gang member Salvador Agron, with a book and lyrics by Paul Simon and Derek Walcott, and music by Mr. Simon, went through five directors en route to its opening at the Marquis Theater in 1998, where it lasted all of two months. But a concert production, "Songs From the Capeman," presented by Mr. Simon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2008, drew better notices, and now the Public Theater will provide the musical with another step on its road to rehabilitation.

Directors, actors, screenwriters, producers: with their first film project, the twin brothers Noah and Logan Miller have checked off just about every box on the credits list. Their movie, "Touching Home," is a semiautobiographical look at the brothers' relationship with their father (played by Ed Harris). In addition to the film, the brothers wrote a book about their experience called "Either You're In or You're In the Way." Here, the two talk about their unlikely journey from working at a car wash in Tucson to making a feature film with no experience or industry contacts. View a trailer for "Touching Home" here.

The banks made hundreds of millions of dollars marketing mortgage-backed securities to their clients during the boom times, but Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, who is questioning the actions of eight banks, is giving them cause for second thoughts.

Overview | What are the qualities of good expository writing? What is process analysis, and how can it help us write for clarity? In this lesson, students examine and evaluate a Times slide show that explains how to pack 10 days' worth of clothes in a carry-on suitcase. They then generate qualities of good process analysis or procedural writing and create their own physical, video or explanatory, audio demonstrations or explanations.

White Houses traditionally put a muzzle on their Supreme Court nominees, to keep them from saying anything that might jeopardize Senate confirmation. But the Obama White House has taken it one step further. It is limiting, if not blocking, access to the nominee's family.

Once upon a time, back when international travel was a novelty rather than a nuisance, and the Internet was nothing but a sci-fi fantasy, world expositions had a certain cachet. Countries competed to showcase the latest advancements in technology, science and culture in swanky national pavilions. As a young child visiting Expo '67 in Montreal, I was dazzled by the U.S. Pavilion, a sparkling geodesic dome designed by Buckminster Fuller. Perhaps those expos were so exciting because they were all about the promise of the future. But now that we're living in that future, the idea of an international exposition doesn't have the same allure.

The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Goodwin Liu to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, sending him to the full Senate for consideration after a party-line vote of 12 Democrats in favor and seven Republicans opposed.
On Thursday, Scvngr (pronounced scavenger) introduced a new set of features and mobile applications that it hoped would become a location-based game for consumers.

Following is the second set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, "The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs," which looks at New York's urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs.
Americans spend more time researching a car purchase than they do researching a home mortgage, according to a survey that the online lending marketplace Zillow Mortgage Marketplace recently released.

As Swiss lawmakers lock horns over a bill to resolve a thorny tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the country's pre-eminent financial sector, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

The Spanish language broadcast network Telemundo is not waiting until the 2010-11 season starts in September to offer its viewers something new. Beginning on Monday, Telemundo will be all telenovelas in prime time, replacing a game show that has been running from 7 to 8 p.m. with a Spanish-language version of the ABC series "Grey's Anatomy."

In a week that's seen strong comments from Pope Benedict and a wonderfully clear-eyed address from Dublin's Archbishop Diarmuid Martin on the sex abuse scandal and the future of Catholicism, Joseph Bottum's call for a house-cleaning within the Vatican deserves particular attention, because it cuts to the heart of what remains undone in the church's response to the scandal.

MONACO -- It is well known that Monaco is one circuit where the driver can make a difference. That is to say, if at most of the high-speed circuits of the Formula One calendar the car accounts for 95 percent of the lap time and the driver's skill accounts for the other 5 percent, at Monaco the driver might account for a larger percentage of what will make a car do a good lap.

The singer and songwriter Silvio RodrÃ­guez, the Cuban artist who is probably most closely identified with the Cuban Revolution and Fidel Castro's half-century in power, has been granted a visa to perform in the United States for the first time in more than 30 years, according to his American immigration lawyer. Mr. RodrÃ­guez plans to tour the United States next month, the lawyer, William Martinez, said, and is scheduled to perform at Carnegie Hall on June 4 with his seven-piece band.

"In recent years, many families have embarked on international adoptions not for humanitarian or religious reasons but out of a more utilitarian calculus of supply and demand. Since the seventies, the supply of healthy infants available through domestic adoption has contracted sharply. Birth control, legal abortion, assisted reproduction, and the fading stigma of single motherhood have drastically reduced the number of infants given up for adoption in the U.S. In 1970, a hundred and seventy-five thousand newborns were adopted; by 2002, that number had dropped to under seven thousand. Most of the fifty thousand domestic U.S. adoptions each year are of older children in foster care."

7:12 p.m. | Updated For theater critics, acquiring tickets to the hot new show, or the cold new turkey, is as easy as falling off that proverbial log. You make a phone call (or send an e-mail message) in response to an invitation, you show up at the theater and find the publicist standing helpfully outside the doors with your tickets in hand, and you head on in. If you are not attending a designated press performance, you may have to endure the indignity of standing in line at the box office for a minute or two.

The United States Championship begins tomorrow at the Chess Club and Scholastic Center of Saint Louis. My last post created a bit of a stir. As you may recall, I'm subletting new office space and was referred to a firm that specializes in real estate law by another lawyer who had done some personal work for me. My legal needs were simple: I just needed a lawyer to review a standard sublease agreement given to me by my new landlord. The post recounted how the real estate lawyers requested a $2,500 retainer and said that the total fee probably wouldn't exceed that amount. In the end, however, the fee was $6,450 -- including $60 for sending me this courtesy e-mail: "I hope everything is O.K. Take your time."
This will not end without a broken heart.

Updated, 11:48 a.m. | Eight electric minicars used by Parks Department workers caught fire while they were being charged at a maintenance yard in Orchard Beach in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx on Thursday morning. Early reports -- relayed in an earlier version of this post -- that the carts were golf carts and that the fire was at the golf course at the park were inaccurate. It took 60 firefighters about half an hour to extinguish the carts, which were reported burning just after 9 a.m. While fire marshals are investigating, the blaze "doesn't appear to be suspicious," a fire official said. Six of the carts were totaled.

Spirits were buoyed on Wednesday after the monthly meeting of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. Some of the latest city budget news was in, and the board, an independent agency charged with investigating allegations of police officer misbehavior, was trumpeting the fact that it had been, at least for now, spared the ax.

With the Yankees playing the Detroit Tigers this week, there has been a lot of talk about the former Yankees Austin Jackson and Johnny Damon shining with their new club. It got us thinking about whether you could fill a respectable 25-man roster entirely with Yankees castaways just by going back a few seasons. It turns out you can, sort of, if you can live with Jason Giambi as your starting first baseman.

In an article in this Sunday's issue of The New York Times Magazine, Andrew Rice writes about Sam Apple, a writer and Web site director who quit his job to become a latter-day newspaper entrepreneur. Using customized open-source software, he started an online publication he calls The Faster Times, an attempt to keep newspaper-style journalism alive in a Web-only version. Instead of paying his writers a salary or a flat freelance fee, Mr. Apple shares advertising revenue with them -- a small amount at the moment, but potentially more lucrative if the enterprise takes off.

We're not sure why Adam Sandler, who has played a series of not-fully-formed adults in movies from "Billy Madison" to "Funny People," would have an inherent interest in the boxy video game characters of his 1980s-era youth, but there you go: Mr. Sandler, the actor and comedian, will help produce a film adaptation of "Pixels," an animated short by the French filmmaker Patrick Jean that became a viral sensation last month, The Hollywood Reporter said.

There's been some bad blood between Athens and Berlin lately, with the latter city holding the economic fate of the former in its less-than-forthcoming hands. Whether or not "The Addams Family" is still running on Broadway in September, one of the franchise's most famous alumnae will be making her Rialto debut that month: Christina Ricci, the "Monster" and "Ice Storm" star whose Hollywood career got a ghoulish push from her performances as Wednesday in Barry Sonnenfeld's "Addams Family" movies, will join the cast of "Time Stands Still" when it returns to Broadway on Sept. 23, its producers said. Ms. Ricci will enter the cast of that Donald Margulies play as the friend of a photojournalist played by Laura Linney. Brian d'Arcy James and Eric Bogosian, who appeared with Ms. Linney when the play was presented earlier this year by Manhattan Theater Club, will also rejoin the production when it resumes performances at a Shubert Theater to be determined. "Time Stands Still" is nominated for a Tony Award for best play, and Ms. Linney is nominated for best leading actress in a play.

California Gas Prices Are Expected to Fall | Plan to pay less at the pump by Memorial Day. Prices for a gallon of gas in California will dip below $3 a gallon and are likely to remain there through June, according to petroleum analysts. On Wednesday, gas was selling for an average of $3.15 across the state, but it's expected to slip to between $2.90 and $2.65 soon. Despite the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, other factors, like the economic turmoil in Europe, have pushed wholesale prices down recently. Some locals won't need to buy gas at any price on Thursday: Tens of thousands of Bay Area commuters will strap on their bike helmets for the 16th Bike to Work Day. [The San Jose Mercury News]
