The Preakness Stakes has been a Maryland tradition for 135 years, but something was missing in 2009: the cooler-toting public. When organizers barred coolers filled with alcohol, a Preakness mainstay, attendance fell from 112,222 to 77,850, the lowest figure in more than 20 years. The Preakness is the largest single-day sporting event in Maryland and has exceeded 100,000 people in 8 of the past 10 years.

When business owners visit our firm to discuss the sale of their businesses, they are often accompanied by another person. Typically that person is a spouse, lawyer, accountant, partner with an equity stake or family member who works in the business. But every so often the other person is introduced as ''a friend.'' At this point I hope for the best but prepare mentally for the worst. I sometimes refer to these people as an F.O.B. (friend of the business). More often than not, the F.O.B. and the owner were friends in another life -- high school, college, church or a stint with a previous employer. It usually takes a few probing questions to decipher the role of the F.O.B. in the organization.

COPELON--Rhonda. The Board and Staff of the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved friend, colleague, and Board Vice President, Rhonda Copelon. Rhonda's key roles in the struggle for reproductive rights and justice against human rights abusers the world over made her a role model for legions of colleagues and students. She was a fierce advocate for women's rights and opened new opportunities in the international law arena for challenging violence and other gender-based abuses. In 1980, Rhonda was a central lawyer in two landmark cases, Harris v. McRae, which took a challenge to the Hyde amendment to the Supreme Court, and Filartiga v. Pena-Irala, which ruled that cases involving human rights abuses committed abroad could be brought in U.S. courts. We have lost an irreplaceable force and a very dear friend. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 80 W. 76th Street, on May 21 at 11:45am. Rhonda's wishes were that donations may be made to the Copelon Fund for Gender Justice at CCR, 666 Broadway, 7th floor, New York, NY 10012. For more information on the Fund call 212-614-6489 or email development@ccrjustice.org

Once upon a time - in the 1990s- e-books for children came on CD-ROMs, and for digital wizardry, offered only mouse clicks and hidden pop-up-like animations. Not anymore. Touch-screens and app stores have given new tricks to old books, and the number of new titles is blossoming. Still, a parent has many choices with no frills. Apple's iBook store includes ''The Berenstain Bears,'' ''Winnie-the-Pooh'' and ''The Mouse and the Motorcycle'' -- all with just original text and scanned illustrations. There is also a suite of simple tools, like the ability to bookmark a page, or to look up the definition of a hard word, say, with a right click. For the iPad, ''How To Train Your Dragon HD'' ($1.99, FrogDogMedia LLC) has a strong 37-page storyline, but there is no interactivity other than a cool page flip. So far FrogDogMedia lists 34 children's books that follow this format.

I have been introduced to a woman named Marilyn Jones who owns Consolidated Printing in Chicago. She has been credited with being a pioneer in the ''green'' printing industry. As a matter of fact, Debra Jacobson of the Printer's National Environmental Assistance Center has called her the ''mother of the green printing movement.'' Like many things in business, Marilyn's pioneering came in part by accident. When she started her company in 1973, printing was one of the most toxic industries around. But she became friendly with a customer who owned a vitamin company and who espoused his belief that everything people touch and feel affects their health. Marilyn decided to try to replace the toxic chemicals in the printing process with common household products. There was a lot of trial and error and calling of vendors to ask them if they could try something other than benzene. Long before the green movement took off, this was the start of a 37-year quest to change the industry.

I went running with Scott Jurek on a clear, chilly morning last month, an easy four-mile loop in Central Park. He ran another few miles with 50 or so adoring fans, then another few by himself, for a total of about 15. After that he showered and came to my house to cook lunch before going for a late-afternoon jog of another 10 miles or so. That's an easy day for Jurek, 36, an accomplished ultramarathoner. But one might say he has been in a slump: he has not won a major race since the 2008 Spartathlon. On the other hand, he set a personal record there, it was his third consecutive victory on the 153-mile course between Athens and Sparta, and he holds the fifth-, sixth- and eighth-fastest times in race history.

Even though I've worked with hundreds of business owners over the years, I recently learned something about them that took me by surprise: for many, self-promotion is as uncomfortable as wearing their underwear backward. I never realized how common this reluctance is -- until I had a series of conversations. I recently met up with Renee Trudeau, a work-life balance coach and president of Career Strategists, based in Austin, Tex. Renee told me she believed that one of the main reasons businesses failed was that their owners didn't embrace marketing. Why don't they? There are several reasons, Renee believes: some are intimidated by marketing, some say it makes them feel false or insincere, others fear being visible.

Perhaps the most memorable image from the Times Square car-bomb attempt was those men in the bulky green suits who walked right up to the smoking, sparking Pathfinder on West 45th Street and peered into it to find an elaborate assemblage of explosives.''It is a lonely walk, going into a situation like that,'' said Sgt. Joseph Hourihan of the New York Police Department's Bomb Squad. ''You never really know if you're walking down to the last thing you'll ever do on earth.'' He added that while the bomb suit offered protection from smaller blasts, it would not save one's life -- no suit would -- standing next to your basic car bomb. As I found out on Tuesday, aside from the terror of dealing with a bomb, simply wearing the suit is a pretty taxing endeavor in itself.

FIVE or six years ago, men made a deal. In the name (and spirit) of dressing well (and up), they would embrace the soignÃ© glamour of the tuxedo. Velvet and satin details, shawl and peak lapels: bring it on. But they would deep-six the entire lot of maddening tuxedo minutiae, which are as easy and festive to manage as a year's worth of tax receipts. Cummerbunds. Studs. Cuff links. Patent-leather slippers. PiquÃ© bib-front shirts. Bow ties. Those were the terms -- the 2004 Oscars swarmed with handsome actors in tuxedos, white dress shirts and black four-in-hand neckties -- and they were crucial to the tuxedo's resurgence not only as a feature of dinner-dress events but also as a fashion influence in its own right. Stylish clothes began turning up with tux touches: a satin stripe on a pair of charcoal pants, a dinner sport coat made in black velvet, a pastel dress shirt with a pleated front.

OBITUARIES A picture caption on Friday with an obituary about Robin Roberts, the Hall of Fame pitcher, using information from The Associated Press, misidentified the player shown greeting Dick Sisler at home plate after Sisler's home run won the 1950 National League pennant for the Philadelphia Phillies. It was Bob Miller, not Roberts.

They are so cute, these 16-inch-tall fellows in their floppy robes. Shuffling two by two, 36 strong, behind a choirboy on a black runway in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's cavernous Medieval Hall, they're like a troop of fairy-tale dwarfs turned to stone by an evil sorcerer. Unhappy campers, they weep, sigh, gesture sadly and pray, mourning the demise of their liege, John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy (1371-1419). They are a long way from home, and it will be a while before they can return. Lovingly carved from alabaster by Jean de la Huerta and Antoine Le Moiturier, they hail from the MusÃ©e des Beaux-Arts in Dijon, France. There they usually occupy niches in an extravagantly ornamental, Gothic arcade beneath the slab on which lies an effigy of the duke and his wife, Margaret of Bavaria. As the French museum is currently undergoing restoration, it was decided that the sorrowful gang of monks, clerics and sundry laymen would be liberated from the duke's tomb and sent on a journey around the United States. This is the first stop on the eight-city tour, and anyone who cares about the art of sculpture should pay them a visit, for each is a small masterpiece of stone carving and humanist realism.

BALTIMORE - He ran away with the Kentucky Derby and has trained in the days since like his mile-and-a-quarter victory on the first Saturday in May has taken little out of him. So why is Super Saver merely a lukewarm 5-2 morning-line favorite to capture the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes? Super Saver's Derby victory is partly suspect because it came on a rain-soaked and sloppy racetrack. He is a proven mudder, winning twice and finishing second on wet tracks.

INTERNATIONAL The Jerusalem Journal article on Friday, about literature festivals by Israelis and Palestinians held simultaneously without mutual awareness or acknowledgment, misstated part of the title of a narrative poem read at the Palestinian festival by its author, Adam Foulds, a British Jew who expressed support for Palestinian independence aspirations. It is ''The Broken Word,'' not ''Broken Words.'' The article also misidentified the owner of Mishkenot Sha'ananim, a Jerusalem guesthouse for writers and artists where the Israeli festival was held. It is the Jerusalem Foundation, a private group -- not the city of Jerusalem.

Roberto Alagna is Don JosÃ©, the soldier obsessed with Carmen; Barbara Frittoli is the good-hearted MicaÃ«la, the emissary of Don JosÃ©'s mother; Teddy Tahu Rhodes, filling in for an ailing Mariusz Kwiecien, is the dashing toreador Escamillo; and Yannick NÃ©zet-SÃ©guin, also in his Met debut, conducts. JALALABAD, Afghanistan -- Nearly a year into a new war strategy for Afghanistan, the hardest fighting is still ahead, but already it is clear that the biggest challenge lies not on the battlefield but in the governing of Afghanistan itself. That has been the early lesson of the American-led offensive in February in Marja, in Helmand Province, where most Taliban insurgents either were beaten back or drifted away. Since then, Americans and Afghans have struggled to establish a local government that can win the loyalty of the Afghan people, something that is essential to keeping the Taliban at bay.

DETROIT -- As better times return, the United Automobile Workers is not the union it was before Detroit's carmakers hemorrhaged billions of dollars. The union is now a part owner of General Motors and Chrysler through a union trust fund, and its members are barred from striking against the two companies over compensation for the next five years. All told, hourly workers gave up pay and benefits worth $7,000 to $30,000 each a year during the downturn, the union estimates.

The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of ''Ragtime'' because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production of ''Ragtime.'' The theater and film designer Santo Loquasto created the costumes for the original ''Ragtime'' and for this season's revival, and several of the costumes in both productions bore similarities. Costume designs that ''substantially duplicate'' work from a prior production are not eligible for Tony Awards, according to the Tony rulebook, but no one involved with ''Ragtime'' or the Tony Awards made a determination about Mr. Loquasto's designs before they were announced on May 4 as among the four nominees for best costume design of a musical.

BUSINESS DAY The Patient Money column on May 1, about health care providers' billing patients for the balance of fees not covered by insurance, described Medicare rules on the practice incorrectly. While federal law generally prohibits balance billing by providers paid under Medicare, it does not forbid it in all instances. (A doctor who is not formally part of the federal Medicare system, but who treats a Medicare patient and submits a claim to the federal government, is allowed to bill that patient for a small portion of the unpaid balance.)

PHILADELPHIA -- The Philadelphia Flyers, a battered team seemingly held together only by an inexhaustible supply of athletic tape and resolve, defeated the Boston Bruins, 2-1, on Wednesday to tie their Eastern Conference semifinal series, which looked all but over seven days earlier. After losing the first three games of the series, the Flyers have won three games in a row to force a deciding seventh game Friday in Boston. Philadelphia will try to join the 1942 Detroit Red Wings and the 1975 Islanders as the only playoff teams to overcome a 3-0 series deficit.

Cherished and adored mom of Jill Karen, beloved sister to Patty and Peter Silverberg, Ken Rand and Laura Rodgers, proud aunt of Amy, Emily and Andrew Silverberg, Reid and Mia Rodgers, loving daughter of the late Martin and Ruth Goldenberg and Ralph Rodgers. Nancy touched the lives of so many with her altruism, kindness, her genuine spirit and love for life. A true and faithful friend, she was a shining example of perseverance, not letting anything, including her brave and courageous struggle with Multiple Sclerosis, get in the way of good and happy times.

CARTER--David L.,82, of Hopewell, NJ on April 30, 2010. Princeton University Class of '49, 35-year career in Municipal Bonds in NYC. Retired Senior Vice President of Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico. Survived by his wife, Hope, children Ann, Stephen, Alantha and grandchildren, Lane and David, as well as his brother Burnham Carter and his sister, Alison Carter Mitchell. He loved hiking, tennis, sailing and above all his family.

WASHINGTON -- Midshipman Jessica Wilcox, who graduates from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis this month, said she first pictured herself aboard a submarine when she was a ''dreamy young person,'' long before women were allowed to join the nation's nuclear submarine service. After spending the last six months on the road talking to hundreds of business owners around the country, I have come to a conclusion that might surprise you: the economic recovery is already well under way. And, if you don't start putting a strategy in place to take advantage of it, you're risking the future of your company. Especially given all of the turbulence out there related to the debt problems in Europe and the ups and downs of the stock market, I know the idea that things are already turning around might shock some of you. I'm pretty sure my message surprised the folks who heard my speech at the Gathering of Games conference last week in St. Louis.

In the past few years, farmers' markets have experienced a resurgence in the Bay Area and across the United States as consumers have sought ways to connect with their meals and an alternative to large grocery chains. A new generation wants to know where its food comes from, how long it is in transit and what techniques are used to grow it - information individuals can get from their growers but not from their local chain stores.

Shirin Neshat's "Women Without Men," which opens Friday in New York, represents this experimental photographer and video artist's first venture into feature filmmaking, and it's already proven to be an auspicious start. Neshat won the Silver Lion for Best Director at the Venice Film Festival last year for her exploration of political and religious oppression in her native Iran. And given the increased international attention to Iranian politics in recent months, the New York-based artist's work - much of which deals with gender and identity in the Muslim world - is more in demand than ever. A comprehensive monograph of her work is out this month from Rizzoli, and she has just optioned the novel "The Palace of Dreams," by Ismail Kadare, for her second film.

Ever since the economic crisis began there have been two schools of thought about inflation prospects. One school basically has a Phillips curve, aggregate demand view: because major economies are operating far below full employment, we should expect disinflation, and possibly deflation. The other is basically monetarist with a touch of Austrianism: look at all the money central banks are printing and governments are borrowing, it says, inflation -- maybe even hyperinflation -- is just around the corner.

Damaged by a flood two weeks ago, country music's mecca, the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, is in the midst of major repairs. The hall has been stripped to its concrete foundation, The Associated Press reported. Overview | What is art? Do contemporary installations challenge student notions of what art is "supposed" to be and do? After calling for a boycott of Newsweek, Ryan Murphy, a creator of the Fox television series "Glee," has invited the writer of a piece about gay actors published on the magazine's Web site to watch the show's writers and its casting process at work. Mr. Murphy called for the boycott after Ramin Setoodeh wrote that gay actors should not portray heterosexual men because they were not believable in such roles. According to Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Setoodeh contacted Mr. Murphy and is going to meet with the show's writers to discuss why they found the piece so offensive and watch the creative process. In a letter Mr. Murphy sent to EW, he said that Mr. Setoodeh felt misunderstood and was receiving anonymous attacks.

As a non-surgeon practicing at the busiest orthopedic surgery hospital in the country, Dr. Vijay Vad stands out. Instead of sending his patients to surgery, his goal is to keep them out of it. A sports medicine specialist at New York's Hospital for Special Surgery who regularly works with professional golfers and tennis players, Dr. Vad is a believer in the power of the mind-body connection and regularly prescribes yoga exercises and other alternative strategies for his patients. He is also the author of the new book "Stop Pain: Inflammation Relief for an Active Life,'' which is packed with practical advice and self-care options to help chronic pain patients reduce their dependence on narcotics and avoid additional medical procedures.

In "Operation Mincemeat," reviewed in this Sunday's issue by Jennet Conant, Ben Macintyre tells the story of how British intelligence used a corpse with a trumped-up military identity to convey spurious documents to fool the Nazis ahead of the Allied invasion of Sicily. William Martin," the nonexistent officer wrapped in the corpse.

Senators Propose Ban on Drilling Off the Pacific Coast | Six West Coast senators, including both of California's, proposed on Thursday a permanent ban on coastal drilling in the Pacific. "We simply cannot afford the risk posed by oil drilling of our magnificent coast," Senator Barbara Boxer said in a statement. The proposal is largely symbolic because there are no plans right now to open the West Coast to drilling. After the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger shelved an offshore drilling proposal that would have provided money to the state's struggling park system. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

I've been spending early spring in Berkeley, Calif., where butchers, bakers and beeswax candle makers are greenwashing farm life for city folk. This spring, all of the menu boards in the Gourmet Ghetto (a stretch of restaurants and purveyors offering the latest in food fashions) are listing Goldbergian variations of lamb, an animal I like in the fields and on my fork.

Running out of hip things to say in your Facebook status line? If words escape you, try mixing things up with alt-code characters like hearts, music notes, and weather symbols. Alt codes provide alternative characters on a keyboard and are typically activated by turning on the NumLock key, holding down the Alt key and typing a number from 0 to 255. The Facebook Symbols site has a full explanation, videos and characters you can cut and paste into your status line.

From Floyd Norris in his latest High & Low Finance column:

Does a Stint as Facebook's Sheriff Help or Hurt a Politician? | Social media companies like Facebook are at the heart of intense debates over what privacy means in the 21st century, and how well Facebook users can be protected from predators of all sorts. As a Facebook executive, Chris Kelly confronted these policy choices daily. But the changes in online practices may be out of synch with public attitudes. If so, reports Chase Davis of California Watch, Mr. Kelly, a Democratic candidate for Attorney General who used to be charged with protecting security and privacy on Facebook, may soon be confronting some backlash. And while high-tech politicians are not much of a novelty these days, Mr. Kelly is among the first to emerge from the lightly regulated world of social media, where companies that collect and disseminate huge amounts of personal data from millions of users have been the focus of highly publicized privacy and security controversies.A Vineyard-Centric Bike Trail Is Born | One mile down, 43 to go.The Vine Trail in Napa is taking off thanks in large part to the leadership of Chuck McMinn of Vineyard 29, who spent 25 years in Silicon Valley at Intel and running start-ups. At a cost of roughly $1 million a mile, it will take years to complete the full length from the ferry terminal in Vallejo north to Calistoga. Mr. McMinn is applying the same energy to this project as he did to leveraging his high-tech skill and start-up fearlessness to build a gravity-flow winery with microturbine technology allowing it to generate its own electricity with extreme efficiency. Vineyard 29 became one of the hottest high-end wine brands. Then he turned his attention to philanthropic projects like the Vine Trail. It turned out that Mr. McMinn's vision and expertise were the exact requirements to build the low-tech Vine Trail, which Mr. McMinn hopes to see finished within 10 years.

Whether or not ''The Addams Family'' is still running on Broadway in September, one of the franchise's most famous alumnae will be making her Rialto debut that month: Christina Ricci, above left, the ''Monster'' star whose Hollywood career got a ghoulish push from Barry Sonnenfeld's ''Addams Family'' movies, will join the cast of ''Time Stands Still'' when it returns to Broadway on Sept. 23, its producers said. Ms. Ricci will enter the cast of that Donald Marguliesplay, which centers on a photojournalist played by Laura Linney. Brian d'Arcy James and Eric Bogosian, who appeared with Ms. Linney when the play was presented this year by Manhattan Theater Club, will also rejoin the production when it resumes performances at a Shubert Theater to be determined. ''Time Stands Still'' is nominated for a Tony Award for best play, and Ms. Linney is nominated for best leading actress in a play. ... Elsewhere on Broadway the producers of David Mamet's ''Race'' said that when James Spaderleaves the play after June 20, he will be replaced by Eddie Izzard, above right. Mr. Izzard made his Broadway debut in the 2003 revival of ''A Day in the Death of Joe Egg,'' the Peter Nichols comedy. Dennis Haysbert (''24,'' ''The Unit'') will take over from David Alan Grier starting June 15, when Afton C. Williamson (''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'') will also replace Kerry Washington.

The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of ''Ragtime'' because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production of ''Ragtime.'' The theater and film designer Santo Loquasto created the costumes for the original ''Ragtime'' and for this season's revival, and several of the costumes in both productions bore similarities. Costume designs that ''substantially duplicate'' work from a prior production are not eligible for Tony Awards, according to the Tony rulebook, but no one involved with ''Ragtime'' or the Tony Awards made a determination about Mr. Loquasto's designs before they were announced on May 4 as among the four nominees for best costume design of a musical.

An obituary in some editions on Monday about the singer and actress Lena Horne included a number of errors. Nina Mae McKinney, not Ms. Horne, was the first black performer signed to a long-term contract by a major Hollywood studio. (Ms. McKinney signed a five-year contract with MGM in 1929, more than a decade before Ms. Horne joined the same studio.) Ms. Horne's son, Teddy, died in 1970, not 1971. And besides her daughter, Gail Lumet Buckley, Ms. Horne is survived by six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. At the time Ms. Horne was hired by the Cotton Club in Harlem, in 1933, Duke Ellington was no longer performing there. The 1951 movie version of the musical ''Show Boat'' -- in which Ms. Horne had wanted to be cast -- was the third film version, not the second. (That error was repeated in an updated version of the obituary that ran in some editions on Tuesday.)

The global war on AIDS has racked up enormous successes over the past decade, most notably by providing drugs for millions of infected people in developing countries who would be doomed without this life-prolonging treatment. Now the campaign is faltering. Donations from the United States and other wealthy countries have leveled off while the number of people infected with H.I.V., the AIDS virus, grows by a million a year. By one informed estimate, only $14 billion will be available of some $27 billion needed this year to fight the disease in the developing world. Fewer than 4 million of the 14 million people infected with the AIDS virus are getting drug treatment -- far short of the goal of universal access set by the United States and others.

DETROIT -- The Yankees challenged the Detroit ace Justin Verlander on Thursday with a lineup ending with Juan Miranda, Randy Winn and Greg Golson. They rested the banged-up Nick Swisher, and Derek Jeter, their leadoff hitter, is slumping, not that he would call it that. It was all a blueprint for trouble, and the outcome played true. The Yankees are the highest-scoring team in the majors, but they have not acted that way since setting foot inside Comerica Park. Their 6-0 defeat to the Tigers, the Yankees' second shutout loss in two days, capped a losing seven-game trip that accentuated the extremes of their offense. The Yankees scored 24 runs in their first two games in Boston, but strip away their six-run ninth-inning outburst in the second game of Wednesday's doubleheader, and they have scored six runs over their last 35 innings.

An article last Friday about continuing opposition to new cellphone towers in the Bay Area, misstated where AT&T will be making capital investments of $18 billion to $19 billion this year. That figure reflects investments nationwide, not investments in California.

PEARL--Michael, 74, born in St. Louis, August 8, 1935 died in New York May 2, 2010. Son of the late David and Elizabeth Pearl and brother of Eugene Pearl who also predeceased him. Survived by his wife of 39 years, Erika, his sister-in-law Patricia Pearl, nephew Mark Pearl (Kathy) of Arlington, TX and niece Davina Pearl Tripp of Keller, Texas; by his grand-nephews and grand-nieces Stuart, Stacey, Caitlin and Brady and great-great-nephew Kane; cousins Eva, Anne and Elizabeth Foltin and Lottie, David and Robert Miklos. The cause of death was pulmonary failure and in keeping with his character Michael stubbornly fought his illness for a long time. His wife Erika and good friend Patrick Mullen were at his side when he closed his eyes for the last time. Michael attended Brentwood High School and Washington University in St. Louis and graduated from the University of Texas, Austin. He was a gifted, exceptionally smart, unique man with a great sense of humor. He made people laugh and his own laughter was exuberant. He was a complex man who could also be difficult and at times explosive but never dull. Among his many interests was a love of history, sports, building and restoring furniture, collecting old cast iron toys and old maps and prints which he framed himself. He also was a fine Friday night poker player. More than most anything Michael loved to work at his job. He was a Senior Vice President of Gould Paper Corporation where he celebrated his 50th anniversary in the spring of 2009. He was a dedicated, loyal, trusted employee and friend and in turn was much respected and appreciated by his colleagues who were also his friends. Special thanks to his "bosses" both current and past, Mr. Harry E. Gould Jr., Mr. Carl Matthews, Mr. Danny Lala and Mr. Peter J Gould, for their loyalty and generosity throughout Michael's career and extraordinary caring during his disability and illness. Peter and Michael started almost at the same time at Gould in 1959 and ever since their friendship endured. Michael and Gerry Malia, another long-time colleague and friend shared many coffees and chats in the early morning hours as the first arrivals at the office. Among his friends three are from Michael's youth in Texas, - Jan Buckaloo, Mel Pekarsky and Audrey Brians. Very special thanks to Jan and Sloane Shelton, another long-time friend, for bringing Michael and Erika together all those years ago. Michael's family and all his friends loved and admired him and feel fortunate to have shared their lives with him. Much appreciation to Michael's physicians and caregivers who were so dedicated to him. Special thanks to Dr. Joseph Lowy, Michael's pulmonary doctor and Dr. Hillel Tobias, his physician for 35 years. Burial was private. Contributions in Michael's memory may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center, c/o Development Office, 1 Park Avenue, 17th floor, New York, NY 10016 or to a charity of your choice.

ART AND ONIONS AT HOUSING WORKS It is safe to say that by the end of the evening on Friday, the radio producer and writer Starlee Kine will be inclined to shed a few tears. She'll start on a high note, with a cutting board and a few ingredients within reach. But if all goes according to plan, Ms. Kine will scarcely start chopping away before becoming misty-eyed as she voices words of heartache.

Ratings for Fox's ''American Idol'' recovered somewhat on Tuesday after falling to an eight-year low last week, but CBS won the night over all by a thin margin. According to Nielsen's estimates, a movie-theme episode of ''Idol,'' with guest-mentoring (and T-shirts) from Jamie Foxx, remained the night's top-rated show, earning 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., up from 17.5 million a week ago, but CBS's ''NCIS'' was close behind in the time slot with 16.9 million viewers. The CBS shows ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (15.9 million) at 9 p.m. and ''The Good Wife'' (12.9 million) at 10 won their time slots as well. ABC placed third on the night and NBC was fourth. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WASHINGTON -- The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to BP and dozens of other oil companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency that assesses threats to endangered species -- and despite strong warnings from that agency about the impact the drilling was likely to have on the gulf. Those approvals, federal records show, include one for the well drilled by the Deepwater Horizon rig, which exploded on April 20, killing 11 workers and resulting in thousands of barrels of oil spilling into the gulf each day.

The singer and songwriter Silvio Rodriguez, the Cuban artist who is probably most closely identified with the Cuban Revolution and Fidel Castro's half-century in power, has been granted a visa to perform in the United States for the first time in more than 30 years, according to his American immigration lawyer. Mr. Rodriguez plans to tour the United States next month, the lawyer, William Martinez, said, and is scheduled to perform at Carnegie Hall on June 4 with his seven-piece band. Other tour stops will include San Juan, Puerto Rico, the San Francisco Bay area and Los Angeles. A show in Miami, where Mr. Rodriguez is reviled by many people because of his fervent support of the Castro dictatorship, ''is one of the things that might be happening as well,'' Mr. Martinez said.

A year after moving into a sparkling new $800 million stadium, the Mets have the most home victories in the major leagues, but neither their stadium nor their record is translating into box-office success. After 22 home games, attendance at Citi Field is down 6,852 fans a game, the largest decline by number in Major League Baseball. That translates to an average of 31,892 fans at games this season compared with 38,744 last season.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the United States Navy's assigning women to submarines described incorrectly the first submarines on which they will serve. Two will be ballistic missile submarines and two will be guided missile submarines; they are not all ballistic missile submarines, which carry long-range nuclear-tipped missiles and are known as ''boomers.''

A Slap Shots note with an article in some editions on Wednesday about the emergence of P. K. Subban of the Montreal Canadiens erroneously attributed a distinction to the Boston Bruins. While they reached the N.H.L.'s conference finals for a third consecutive year in 1992, they were not the last team from either conference to do so. The Detroit Red Wings reached four consecutive Western Conference finals from 1995 to 1998 and three from 2007 to 2009.

A report in some editions of the National Briefings column on Tuesday about violent storms in Oklahoma misidentified the type of weather alert issued by the Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Okla. The alerts that were issued over a 25-county area were tornado watches, which cover larger areas -- not tornado warnings, a more serious, localized alert.

An article last Friday about suburban Chicago communities' receiving no federal stimulus money to rehabilitate foreclosed homes despite coordinating their applications, described incorrectly the application procedure for the Neighborhood Stabilization Program. Staff members at the Department of Housing and Urban Development did take into account the fact that communities jointly applied, even though collaboration was not included as a specific scoring criterion.

LEVITES--Barry. We mourn the unexpected passing of our dear friend, Barry Levites. Barry was a real estate icon, an industry pioneer, and a self-made business leader. His legacy is visible in properties throughout the tri-states, and in the hearts and minds of all who had the privilege to work with him and to know him. Barry is a special person, a philanthropist and a mentor, whose generosity and guidance has benefited many. Barry was brilliant; he could quickly assess all situations, comprehend the most complex real estate, financial, and legal issues, and saw countless deals through from start to finish. He was trustworthy and honest in all dealings and showed unbreakable loyalty to those in his life. Barry was a great man, and his insights, friendship and passion for life will be dearly missed. Baron Associates, Levites Realty, Mgmt.

LaMOTTA--Richard Edmund. Born in Brooklyn, New York on May 20th, 1942, Richard Edmund LaMotta was a larger-than-life unique man, and a true "social entrepreneur". He is best known as "Mr. Chipwich", the inventor of the original Chipwich, the ice cream cookie sandwich, of which he was so proud, and which came from a love of dunking cookies in milk. He worked hard his whole life, attending the prestigious Brooklyn Tech High School, and Brooklyn College and New York Law School at night over many years while working jobs at AT&T and CBS. Chipwich Chippoppity, a cookie candy, came out of the Chipwich brand and at its second release functioned in conjunction with MyStudentBiz, a business which allowed students to earn money, scholarships, and own a part of the company. His goal was to pass on the entrepreneurship skills he had learned, by mentoring students and helping anyone who asked for his advice. He loved helping people in any way he could, notorious for giving a helping hand to the homeless, and teaching his children to do the same. His generosity was outstanding, and a large part of his life. He created companies that would help people, like his current company, The MD System, an all-natural pain relief system, which will continue on. He loved reading and music, talking sports, car rides, having dinners with his older daughter, watching his younger daughter play sports, always an incredibly devoted family man. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Richard Edmund LaMotta Foundation at P.O. Box 309, Mount Kisco, NY 10549. Survived by his wife, son, two daughters, and a granddaughter. Pre-deceased by son and brother. The wake will be at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY on Saturday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm and Sunday from 2-4pm.

Two weeks ago, the government put out a round estimate of the size of the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico: 5,000 barrels a day. Repeated endlessly in news reports, it has become conventional wisdom. But scientists and environmental groups are raising sharp questions about that estimate, declaring that the leak must be far larger. They also criticize BP for refusing to use well-known scientific techniques that would give a more precise figure.

White Houses traditionally put a muzzle on their Supreme Court nominees, to keep them from saying anything that might jeopardize Senate confirmation. But the Obama White House has taken it one step further. It is limiting, if not blocking, access to the nominee's family. The New York Times received permission on Tuesday from Hunter College High School in Manhattan, Elena Kagan's alma mater, to observe a constitutional law class there taught by her brother Irving. We thought it would be intriguing to watch the give and take between Mr. Kagan, who is known as a passionate and interactive educator, and his students on his first day back after witnessing his sister's nomination in Washington.

LEVITES--Barry. We mourn the sudden and heartbreaking loss of our dearest friend, Barry Levites. Barry was a man among men, a real estate magnate, and a leader in all endeavors he pursued, and he earned the respect and admiration of all who knew him. Barry was a self-made man with an unrivaled street-sense. As he progressed as a business leader, he always maintained his sense of self and remembered his humble beginnings. As an industry leader and a true entrepreneur, Barry was brilliant, creative, fair-dealing, and had the foresight to anticipate and rectify potential hurdles at their origins. Barry was a spirited negotiator, full of boundless energy and fueled by the excitement of the deal. His passing is a great loss to the real estate community. Beyond decades of working side-by-side, we had the privilege and honor of knowing Barry as a best friend. We have seen Barry's philanthropy and mentorship change lives and communities. He was guided by never-ending loyalty and treated those close to him as family. Barry's love of family, community and business were at his core. Our hearts go out to his wife, Janice, his three daughters, sons-in-law, sister and grandchildren. We are lucky to have had Barry in our lives for over thirty years. To our dearest friend, you will forever be missed. Karen & Ron Rettner and Family

MERRIN--Seymour, died Wednesday at his home in Santa Fe. He had a Ph.D. in Geochemistry and pursued a career as a consultant, an expert in the marketing of computers and was one of the first in the field. He was interested in many museums and projects of the Native Americans. A charitable man. MURPHY--Charles E. "Ted", 52, manager of digital archival resources, died April 5 at his home in Cambridge, MA after a brief illness. He was born in Providence, RI. A trustee Scholar at Boston University, he earned joint baccalaureates, magna cum laude, in English and History in 1976. He started archival training as a BU undergrad. After graduation he became exhibit coordinator and junior archivist and assisted Taylor Branch in research for Pulitzer Prize winning Studies of Civil Rights Movement, becoming deeply versed in BU's collection of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers. In 1984, he earned MBA from BU in marketing and finance and moved to Manhattan, his home for over two decades. He worked for American Theatre Wing; The Foundation Center; Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives: The 1960's writing essays on Lady Bird Johnson, philanthropist Stewart Mott and former Yale president Kingman Brewster Jr. From 1995-2002 he was editor and writer at online journal Baseline where he wrote over 600 film reviews and interviewed more than 100 celebrities. He collaborated with Microsoft writing and editing over 400 entries for CD-Rom "Cinemania". He established his own film review website and became a founder of New York Film Critics Online. In 2007 he returned to BU as manager of Gotlieb Center's Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Archival Collaborative creating an online finding aid for the King papers in Boston and Atlanta using a new computer application he helped develop. Survivors include his sister, Mary G. Murphy of New Hampshire and cousins in Rhode Island. A.J. Spears Funeral Home of Cambridge handled services. There is a 4pm memorial service on May 22 at The Algonquin Club in Boston. RSVP 617-353-1225 or cfgately@bu.edu.

He was 84. The cause was cancer, said his daughter Menina Givens.

When the idea of the euro was first broached, there was extensive debate about whether Europe constituted an "optimum currency area"; the key question was whether European nations would have an adequate way to adjust to "asymmetric shocks", which left some economies more depressed than others. When countries have their own currencies, they can deal with such shocks, at least in part, by devaluing -- an argument made most eloquently by none other than Milton Friedman (pdf). Lacking that alternative, something else is needed.

MERRIN--Seymour, died Wednesday at his home in Santa Fe. He had a Ph.D. in Geochemistry and pursued a career as a consultant, an expert in the marketing of computers and was one of the first in the field. He was interested in many museums and projects of the Native Americans. A charitable man. He leaves a loving wife, Helene, two children, Charles and Mariamne, five grandchildren and a brother, Edward.

LEVITES--Barry. We mourn the sudden and heartbreaking loss of our dearest friend, Barry Levites. Barry was a man among men, a real estate magnate, and a leader in all endeavors he pursued, and he earned the respect and admiration of all who knew him. Barry was a self-made man with an unrivaled street-sense. As he progressed as a business leader, he always maintained his sense of self and remembered his humble beginnings. As an industry leader and a true entrepreneur, Barry was brilliant, creative, fair-dealing, and had the foresight to anticipate and rectify potential hurdles at their origins. Barry was a spirited negotiator, full of boundless energy and fueled by the excitement of the deal. His passing is a great loss to the real estate community. Beyond decades of working side-by-side, we had the privilege and honor of knowing Barry as a best friend. We have seen Barry's philanthropy and mentorship change lives and communities. He was guided by never-ending loyalty and treated those close to him as family. Barry's love of family, community and business were at his core. Our hearts go out to his wife, Janice, his three daughters, sons-in-law, sister and grandchildren. We are lucky to have had Barry in our lives for over thirty years. To our dearest friend, you will forever be missed. Karen & Ron Rettner and Family

The red brick building at 548 W. 22nd St., which was home to the Dia Art Foundation from 1987 to 2004 and more recently to a temporary project called the X-Initiative, is about to enter a new era. The art dealer Zach Feuer signed a lease this week on half of the ground floor; CRG Gallery is in negotiations for the other half. Mr. Feuer, who is currently on West 24th Street, will more than double his space in the new building. Mr. Feuer said that he needed more room to show his current artists, including Dana Schutz, Nathalie Djurberg, and Phoebe Washburn, and he also plans to take on new ones.

7 P.M. (HBO2) STUDS TERKEL: LISTENING TO AMERICA For more than six decades, Terkel, right, the author and media personality, celebrated the experiences of ordinary (''a word I don't like,'' he would note) Americans through radio and television interviews and in his writing. This documentary from Eric Simonson looks at Terkel the storyteller -- from his award-winning radio show, ''The Studs Terkel Program,'' to his books on jazz, the Great Depression, World War II, race relations and the American Dream -- whose greatest talent may simply have been listening. The driving force behind his desire to tell these stories: a belief that the culture was ''suffering from national Alzheimer's disease,'' Terkel, who died at 96 on Oct. 31, 2008, says in the film. Holding up a picture of his younger self, he explains the deterioration. ''It's not aging, it's not illness,'' he says. ''It's too much Paris Hilton.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro reports from Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on the trial of Kaing Guek Eav, the commander of the notorious Tuol Sleng prison, where more than 15,000 people were reportedly tortured and executed, and the first Khmer Rouge leader to be tried since that group's deadly reign in the 1970s. In another segment Bob Abernethy visits the Shalem Institute for Spiritual Formation in Washington.

Updated at 1:05 p.m. to account for annual fee in Chase calculation. Back in December, I listed my personal finance resolutions for 2010. Among them was to get a better interest rate at a better bank. On Tuesday, I received an e-mail from my bank, Chase, offering me an upgrade to the new Chase RealCash Debit Card. The card offers up to 3 percent cash back on everyday purchases like groceries, gas, coffee and fast food.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Philadelphia Flyers' third consecutive victory over the Boston Bruins, who once led their series, 3-0, misidentified one of the only two N.H.L. teams to recover from a three-game deficit and win a playoff series. Besides the 1975 Islanders, the other team was the 1942 Toronto Maple Leafs -- not the 1942 Detroit Red Wings, whom the Maple Leafs beat.

A map on Wednesday with an article about contrasting immigration policies in New Mexico and Arizona misidentified the capital of New Mexico. As a listing of state facts with the map correctly noted, the capital is Santa Fe -- not Albuquerque, which is about 60 miles southwest of Santa Fe.

An article on Page 54 this weekend about personal net-worth comparisons misidentifies one of the factors typically used as an asset in such calculations. It is home value, not home equity.

MURPHY--Charles E. "Ted", 52, manager of digital archival resources, died April 5 at his home in Cambridge, MA after a brief illness. He was born in Providence, RI. A trustee Scholar at Boston University, he earned joint baccalaureates, magna cum laude, in English and History in 1976. He started archival training as a BU undergrad. After graduation he became exhibit coordinator and junior archivist and assisted Taylor Branch in research for Pulitzer Prize winning Studies of Civil Rights Movement, becoming deeply versed in BU's collection of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers. In 1984, he earned MBA from BU in marketing and finance and moved to Manhattan, his home for over two decades. He worked for American Theatre Wing; The Foundation Center; Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives: The 1960's writing essays on Lady Bird Johnson, philanthropist Stewart Mott and former Yale president Kingman Brewster Jr. From 1995-2002 he was editor and writer at online journal Baseline where he wrote over 600 film reviews and interviewed more than 100 celebrities. He collaborated with Microsoft writing and editing over 400 entries for CD-Rom "Cinemania". He established his own film review website and became a founder of New York Film Critics Online. In 2007 he returned to BU as manager of Gotlieb Center's Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Archival Collaborative creating an online finding aid for the King papers in Boston and Atlanta using a new computer application he helped develop. Survivors include his sister, Mary G. Murphy of New Hampshire and cousins in Rhode Island. A.J. Spears Funeral Home of Cambridge handled services. There is a 4pm memorial service on May 22 at The Algonquin Club in Boston. RSVP 617-353-1225 or cfgately@bu.edu.

STAMAS--Elaine. The Board of Trustees and the staff of The American Assembly mourn the loss of their dear friend. The wife of Stephen Stamas, our chairman, Elaine will always be remembered for her devotion and kindness. Our sincere condolences to Steve and the Stamas family. David H. Mortimer, President

Americans spend more time researching a car purchase than they do researching a home mortgage, according to a survey that the online lending marketplace Zillow Mortgage Marketplace recently released. The survey results show that, on average, borrowers who obtained a home in the past five years spent five hours researching a mortgage, half the amount of time they spent researching a new car and the same amount of time they spent researching a vacation. The five-hour average research time was unchanged since March 2008.

LEVITES--Barry. We mourn the unexpected passing of our dear friend, Barry Levites. Barry was a real estate icon, an industry pioneer, and a self-made business leader. His legacy is visible in properties throughout the tri-states, and in the hearts and minds of all who had the privilege to work with him and to know him. Barry is a special person, a philanthropist and a mentor, whose generosity and guidance has benefited many. Barry was brilliant; he could quickly assess all situations, comprehend the most complex real estate, financial, and legal issues, and saw countless deals through from start to finish. He was trustworthy and honest in all dealings and showed unbreakable loyalty to those in his life. Barry was a great man, and his insights, friendship and passion for life will be dearly missed. Baron Associates, Levites Realty, Mgmt.

BURNS--Suzanne. Beloved wife of Frank, cherished mother of Jeremy, devoted grandmother of Sammy and Mia, loving daughter of Margie, and sister of Gail Hyman and Michelle Miller, died suddenly on May 13, 2010. Active member of the Fair Harbor, community. Suzanne will be in our hearts forever. Service Sunday, 6pm at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

FLESCHNER--Lucille, on May 12, 2010 at the age of 92. Devoted wife of the late Cecil Fleschner, beloved mother of Alan Fleschner and Susan Semel, and their spouses; and loving grandmother of John Semel, Margaret Semel, and Samantha Fleschner.

An article last Saturday about the records of several potential Supreme Court nominees on the issue of executive power overstated Judge Merrick B. Garland's connection to a detainee's appeal in 2005 about the Bush administration's military commissions. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on which Judge Garland sits referred the case to a panel of three of its judges; Judge Garland and the entire court never took up the appeal. (The panel upheld the military commissions, a decision that was appealed directly to the Supreme Court.)

Malawer (Michelle), and his cherished grandchildren, Jack, Sydney and Kate. Services to be held on May 16 at 11am at "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY.

CARTER--David L.,82, of Hopewell, NJ on April 30, 2010. Princeton University Class of '49, 35-year career in Municipal Bonds in NYC. Retired Senior Vice President of Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico. Survived by his wife, Hope, children Ann, Stephen, Alantha and grandchildren, Lane and David, as well as his brother Burnham Carter and his sister, Alison Carter Mitchell. He loved hiking, tennis, sailing and above all his family.

CUTTING--George W. Jr. of Oyster Bay, NY and Homer, Alaska died after a long illness on May 13, 2010. Born on July 13, 1932, the son of George W. Cutting and Mary Converse Cutting of Warrenton, Virginia, he graduated from Fessenden School, Brooks School, and Yale University. A former stock broker and portfolio manager, he was an active volunteer for many non profit organizations including: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross, The Nature Conservancy of Alaska, The Community Foundation of Oyster Bay, Youth and Family Counseling of Oyster Bay, Rotary Club of Oyster Bay, and Pratt Museum of Homer, Alaska. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Lucy Pulling Cutting and his children, George W. Cutting III of Glenwood Springs, Colorado, Lucy Cutting of Greenwich, Connecticut, Cynthia Cutting Robinson of Moultonborough, New Hampshire, Susan Cutting of Belfast, Maine, and five grandchildren; also survived by his sisters Martha McDuffie of Bailey, Colorado, Dorothy Cutting of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, and those deceased: John P. Cutting, John A. Hinckley, Elizabeth Cutting Carrigan, and A. Neville Cutting. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 20, 2010 at 11:00am at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory www.cshl.org or Pratt Museum www.prattmuseum.org.

MANDEL--Carolyn Kiblinger. Beloved wife, mother, sister, aunt and grandmother. Died May 13 at home in Port Washington, NY at age 72. Second child of John and Carol Carey Kiblinger of Flint, MI. Graduated 1959 from The University of Chicago and married fellow alumnus Maurice Mandel. Settled in Port Washington, NY where she taught English, raised a family and applied her artistic talents to local theater and choral groups and homes and gardens in Port Washington and Monterey, MA. Her floral design business created arrangements for weddings and other occasions. She helped lead the reclamation and beautification of Baxter's Pond Park. She was active in The Community Synagogue choir for many years and spearheaded the restoration of the old sanctuary in this landmark Sands Point building. She sang in the Berkshire Choral Festival, was a long time patron of the Metropoli- tan Opera and member of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club. She is survived by her hus- band of 51 years, sons David (Kathie) of Wilton, CT, Jack (Tina Eck) of Cabin John, MD and Paul (India Wood) of Boulder, CO, brothers Stephen and David, sister Katherine Gottschalk and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in her memory to Baxter's Pond Fountain, Port Washington Library Foundation. or Carolyn & Maurice Mandel Scholarship Fund at The University of Chicago.

There are as many definitions of philosophy as there are philosophers - perhaps there are even more. After three millennia of philosophical activity and disagreement, it is unlikely that we'll reach consensus, and I certainly don't want to add more hot air to the volcanic cloud of unknowing. What I'd like to do in the opening column in this new venture - The Stone - is to kick things off by asking a slightly different question: what is a philosopher?

Even before Thales fell into the well, and the ancient Greeks laid the foundation for Western philosophy, humans were engaged in the search for wisdom - a deeper understanding of their world, the universe and their own minds. Despite the rapid changes to our society and daily life, that pursuit continues. But what does philosophy look like today? Who are philosophers, what are their concerns and what role do they play in the 21st century?

CANNES, France- The French actor Mathieu Amalric has appeared in at least one movie at the Cannes Film Festival every year since 2006 (among them major attractions like Alain Resnais's "Wild Grass" and Julian Schnabel's "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly"). Best known as the longtime muse and alter-ego of the director Arnaud Desplechin, Mr. Amalric is a live-wire screen presence and a habitual scene stealer who has enlivened a few Hollywood movies as well (he played a Bond villain in "Quantum of Solace"). But he has also had a quieter parallel career as a director, and his fourth feature, "TournÃ©e" ("On Tour") - the first in which he also stars - had its premiere Thursday as part of this year's competition lineup.

Another Triple Crown quest ended after Super Saver finished eighth at the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, beaten by more than 10 lengths. Before the race his connections had assured us he was training well coming into his second start in two weeks. I was at the stakes barn as they left to walk over for the Preakness. Super Saver looked light. He looked like the Kentucky Derby may have taken a toll on him. Other observers noted that he always looks light and perhaps it was not an indication of things to come. But it raises the question, can a horse that is typically less robust return after such a short break and run his best?

An article last Sunday about the Rev. Robert J. Bowers, a former parish priest who works at a Catholic community center in downtown Boston, referred incorrectly to Pope Benedict XVI and clergy sexual abuse that occurred while he was archbishop of Munich. At the time, he was involved in handling the case of one priest-- not ''priests. '' (He approved psychiatric treatment for a German priest accused of sexual abuse who was then immediately returned to his ministry while the abuse was kept a secret.)

A rusty racecar that has been sitting under a tarpaulin in the yard of an Arlington, Va., home for close to 47 years is apparently a long-lost classic. The auction house Bonhams says its research shows that the vehicle is a Vauxhall 30-98, which once raced with distinction at the Brooklands circuit in England. Rupert Banner, a Bonhams vice president, says the company was contacted last fall about the car, when they were asked if the car had any value. The car's pre-World War II provenance had been erased in a 1948 title change.

It's not easy to choose a single moment of chemical connection from Twyla Tharp's swinging celebration of Frank Sinatra's music, ''Come Fly Away.'' Ms. Tharp uses a dance vocabulary mixing ballroom and ballet to explore so many facets of the man-woman thing that to select a single pas de deux seems almost arbitrary. Still, for sheer sizzle nothing beats the tempestuous duel performed by Karine Plantadit and Keith Roberts, above, to Sinatra's recording of ''That's Life,'' a defiant anthem about soldiering on in the face of adversity. That erotic attraction can be a fierce adversary is illustrated with electrifying aplomb by these two remarkable dancers in a breathtaking duet that begins at high intensity and builds from there. He's a tough guy who doesn't want to acknowledge the power this particular woman holds over him. She likes to play the field and doesn't care that he's singled her out for attention. But their limbs don't seem to want to obey their wills and keep entangling themselves in ways that appear to defy the limits of human physics. Ms. Tharp's intricately choreographed battle for supremacy ends in a draw but not before both the magnificently limber Ms. Plantadit and the commanding Mr. Roberts have demonstrated how the powerful connection between two performers can ignite a stage without a word being spoken. CHARLES ISHERWOOD
Television Neil Genzlinger

WALKING AMONG GIANTS IN MUIR WOODS NATIONAL MONUMENT, CALIF., MAY 2, 2010. Carrie Terraferma, 31, a paralegal from Latham, N.Y., celebrates her first anniversary with her husband, Eric, on a morning hike through the redwoods. ''Neither of us had seen the redwoods, so it was beautiful to share the experience together on our anniversary, walking along the path, holding hands. They were so much larger than I expected, and the woods themselves are so dense -- the way the light comes in, it doesn't shine directly in, it just filters through in pieces. You read the placards as you walk along, and I guess most of the coast was covered with redwoods at one time, but they've been destroyed to make way for people. It's just a shame. But it's wonderful that Muir Woods has been preserved for future generations. Because they're absolutely magnificent -- I mean they're more than just trees. They're just so impressive when you're standing there, and you feel a centimeter tall. You look up and you can't even begin to see the tops of them.'' As told to Austin Considine

An article on Friday about Iranian Kurds' staging a strike to protest the executions of five activists described incorrectly the Human Rights Activists News Agency, which reported on the strike. The agency is run by a human rights group, not an opposition group.

AMONG the Japanese directors who came of age after World War II, Nagisa Oshima is perhaps the most provocative. Mr. Oshima achieved worldwide fame with the 1976 release of his sexually explicit art-house hit ''In the Realm of the Senses.'' Based on a true incident from the 1930s, it tells the story of a couple who withdrew from the increasingly authoritarian culture of imperial Japan into a private world of nearly constant sexual stimulation. The idyll comes to an end when the male partner dies during an act of erotic asphyxiation, and the woman, refusing to relinquish her happiness, cuts off his penis as a keepsake.

It's not as if anyone is ever at a loss for words in John Logan's ''Red.'' So many of them are uttered, with such sharpshooting intensity and theatrical flourish, you wouldn't think there would be much room for the unspoken. But there comes a moment in this concentrated study of artistic creation when the painter Mark Rothko (Alfred Molina) and his young assistant, Ken (Eddie Redmayne, far right, with Mr. Molina), lay down their words, pick up their brushes and get physical. If the play has been acted at a fever pitch up to that point, it now rises to a level of heat that thermometers can't measure. What these men are doing here is a workaday task for an artist. They're priming a canvas -- that is, applying the undercoat on which Rothko will subsequently paint. But there's nothing workaday about the fury with which these actors attack their job. They do it with a speed and intensity that suggests both rage and ecstasy, antagonistic competitiveness and familial collaboration. The primer, by the way, is red, and it gets all over these guys' clothes and skin, and they're soon looking like desperadoes at the end of a Sam Peckinpah movie. Are they making love or war? The mood music that Rothko has put on, a soaring aria from Gluck's ''IphigÃ©nie en Aulide,'' is equally appropriate to either activity. And all the talk that has preceded this scene -- about the Dionysian spirit and the Oedipal clash of artistic generations -- and the implicit mutual resentment and fascination that has been festering between the men find a pulse-quickening, visceral outlet. The director, Michael Grandage, and his actors have given us a physical -- and triumphantly theatrical -- correlative for intellectual tensions. Mr. Molina and Mr. Redmayne are breathing hard by the end of this scene. So is the audience, which probably feels as one that a post-coital cigarette wouldn't be inappropriate. BEN BRANTLEY

The field of invitation-only travel sites, which promise chic and cheap vacations for insiders, gets more crowded. Vacationist - a new venture between LuxuryLink and Travel + Leisure magazine - started this month with flash sales of high-end hotels and resorts. Recent sales included the James hotel in Chicago, which was offered from $125 per night, about 55 percent off the usual price.

NILSEN--Harriet I, died March 10. She is survived by her husband of 40 years Lars and their daughter Ingrid. Active for many years in the Scandinavian community a memorial service will be held May 19th at 4pm at Scandinavia House, 58 Park Ave, New York City. Donations can be made to the Harriet Nilsen Winter Concert Fund of the American Scandinavian Society 317 East 52nd Street, New York City, 10022.

The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is already causing more than environmental damage. It is disrupting the region's economy, and far beyond the oil industry. Fishing and shrimping boats that normally ply the gulf's waters have been idled amid a fishing ban. And, not surprisingly, charter excursions have plummeted. As a result, companies that normally make money in other ways have tried to make up their losses by offering services to people who have descended on the area to contain and explain the spill.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Super Bowl Bid Exalts New York, and Winter,'' May 12: Football is traditionally a cold-weather sport. But if the founding fathers of the N.F.L. wanted their crown jewel, the Super Bowl, to be played under frigid conditions, why did they stipulate that the game must be played only in warm-weather sites or under a dome?

Two weeks ago Harlem lost one of its most stylish and most respected residents in Evelyn Cunningham. She was 94. Ms. Cunningham attracted this photographer's eye with her style, her sense of proportion and her balance of color, which she used to elongate her 5-foot-8 stature. Her hands gave her the expressiveness of a Giacometti sculpture, not unlike the style of Diana Vreeland. The thoughts and works of Ms. Cunningham were even more decorated. She began her career at The Pittsburgh Courier, at a time when most female journalists were limited to the women's pages, and became a chronicler of the civil rights movement. In the 1960s, Gov. Nelson Rockefeller made her an adviser, and she later followed him to Washington when he became vice president under Gerald R. Ford. Ms. Cunningham's fashion message set a standard for women in Harlem, from her long dangling earrings, to her playful use of scarves, right. But most important were the length of jackets and coats, used to stretch her figure. A perfect example was the short bolero jacket worn with a floor-length Pucci evening dress. The same dress was worn to a garden luncheon with a knee-length coat. She also wore dresses with a print on the bias. Equally notable was her enthusiasm for the Saint Laurent smoking pantsuit. 1. Ms. Cunningham, second from right, was a mentor to young people. 2. Inger, left, and Osborn Elliott with Ms. Cunningham. 3. The artist Barkley L. Hendricks with Ms. Cunningham.

THE Wet Look -- the sexy, slicked-down hairstyle that was big in the '80s and now, thanks to Gucci, MaxMara, Calvin Klein and Dries Van Noten, is back in fashion -- is not the easiest 'do to pull off. Take, for instance, the online stir last month when Heidi Klum stepped out in Hollywood with straight-from-the-shower hair. ''Jeez, Heidi,'' blasted the British gossip rag Heat, ''as if your soccer mom haircut wasn't bad enough, you've now started using lard as a styling product.'' So not everyone's a fan. On the flip side, we found it rather fetching. ''It gives women a modern elegance in a very chic way,'' said Luigi Murenu, the stylist and global creative consultant at John Frieda who created the look for the MaxMara (left) and Gucci (right) spring shows. To achieve it, he suggests using John Frieda Root Awakening Strength Restoring Gel on the top and sides of the head, then combing the hair back, leaving the ends alone to allow for movement. ''The best part about the look,'' he added, ''is it works well with all hair textures.'' The worst? See lard reference above.

A chart last Sunday with an article about Teva Pharmaceutial Industries mislabeled the scale for the number of United States prescriptions filled with drugs from various companies in 2009. The figures should have been in millions, not billions. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/businessday.
CASCARDI--Matthew. I'm so sad that my buddy is gone. Barneys will never be the same for me.Steve Madden

SILVERMAN--Margo of New York City, on May 13, 2010. Beloved wife of Ted; cherished mother of Michael (Randi), Lauren (John), and Peter (Zhennia); adored grandmother of Max, Reece, and Marguerite. Margo (nee Rieberg) survived Theresienstadt and moved to New York, where she never missed a chance to vote in an off-year election and always teared-up at the national anthem when watching "her Mets." Margo graduated from Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University. She built a successful career as a psychoanalyst, but never skipped one of her children's school plays, a chance to buy vegetables in Chinatown, her favorite operas at the Met, or a Channel 13 art auction. Dinner with Margo was always an opportunity for a memorable debate and an even more memorable meal. She will be missed.

HAFNER-BILTCHIK--Gaylen Dorothy, of Los Altos, CA, died on April 7, 2010 after a long struggle with depressive disorders. Gaylen was born in 1983 in Danbury, CT. She received a BS in Psychology from Santa Clara University in 2007 and was a second-year nursing student at DeAnza College. Gaylen loved working with children, and displayed particular patience and skill toward those with developmental delays and Autism. She was known for her compassion and was deeply loved by the children she worked with and their families. Gaylen is survived by her mother, Jan Hafner, and her sister, Marta Hafner-Biltchik. Her father, Jonathan Biltchik, died in 1997. Donations in Gaylen's memory can be made at: www.autismspeaks.org.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Diet and Exercise to the Extremes,'' May 13: As a dietitian and a runner, I'm thrilled that the vegan ultramarathoner Scott Jurek just broke the American record in the 24-Hour Run world championship in Brive-la-Gaillarde, France. It's clear that his diet isn't slowing him down. In fact, it may explain why he is so fast and full of energy.

AFTER six twisty seasons filled with time-traveling castaways, mysterious happenings on a tropical island, fervid arguments about faith versus reason and enough hook-ups and smackdowns to rival Craigslist and ''Raw,'' ''Lost'' comes to an end on May 23. And on the first Monday of May, with just hours to go before the show runners Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse have to finish the final cut of the two-and-a-half-hour finale, the bungalow that houses the creative team of ''Lost'' on the Disney lot here had a forlorn air to it.

DAITSMAN--Frank, age 81, passed away peacefully on May 8, 2010. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Marilyn. He was the proud father of Mark, William (Marlene) and Alec (Tess). He was the proud grandfather of Brian and Matthew, and also the step-grandfather of Melissa and honorary grandfather of Erin and Meghan. Frank was a lifelong Yankees fan and also made a great deli sandwich, but most of all he was a great humanitarian who fought for peace and justice.

Though essential cast members are missing, above all Usain Bolt and Yelena Isinbayeva, track and field will start its latest road show Friday in Doha, Qatar. The spectacle is called the Diamond League. It is an expanded, reimagined version of the Golden League, which was for 12 years the standard for one-day meets before being scrapped for this more ambitious marketing concept.

Sometimes (as Blanche du Bois said in one of her few hopeful moments in ''A Streetcar Named Desire'') there is God so quickly. The god, in this case, is Eros, who makes a delayed but galvanizing (and hilarious) appearance at the beginning of the second act of Rob Ashford's revival of ''Promises, Promises,'' the 1968 musical about the dangers of interoffice bed hopping. A production that has thus far lacked sexual energy suddenly wakes up and turns frisky. So does its leading man, Sean Hayes, who -- despite being cast opposite the appealing Kristin Chenoweth -- has given the impression of someone still waiting for a playmate to bring out the devil inside him. Enter Katie Finneran, below with Mr. Hayes, wreathed in black owl feathers and the haze of too many cocktails to count. Ms. Finneran, who won a Tony as the nearsighted ingÃ©nue in the great backstage farce ''Noises Off,'' is this time playing someone whose myopia is alcohol-induced. But if her vision is as fuzzy as her molting jacket, her presence couldn't be sharper. Portraying a barfly whose pickup shtick is insisting that she is not a pickup, Ms. Finneran turns the state of being lonely, randy, sloppy and drunk into a precise comic ballet. Make that a double, or do I mean, pas de deux? Because Mr. Hayes, whose character has been slinging back a few himself, matches Ms. Finneran stumble for stumble, hiccup for hiccup and slurred innuendo for slurred innuendo. And a show about the desperation of the Swinging '60s comes to full, uninhibited life for the first time. The loopy, forward-rushing, blissfully idiotic complicity between Mr. Hayes and Ms. Finneran here will be familiar to all survivors of bad one-night stands that seemed like such good ideas before those rotten mornings after. BEN BRANTLEY
