MANDEL--Carolyn Kiblinger. Beloved wife, mother, sister, aunt and grandmother. Died May 13 at home in Port Washington, NY at age 72. Second child of John and Carol Carey Kiblinger of Flint, MI. Graduated 1959 from The University of Chicago and married fellow alumnus Maurice Mandel. Settled in Port Washington, NY where she taught English, raised a family and applied her artistic talents to local theater and choral groups and homes and gardens in Port Washington and Monterey, MA. Her floral design business created arrangements for weddings and other occasions. She helped lead the reclamation and beautification of Baxter's Pond Park. She was active in The Community Synagogue choir for many years and spearheaded the restoration of the old sanctuary in this landmark Sands Point building. She sang in the Berkshire Choral Festival, was a long time patron of the Metropoli- tan Opera and member of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club. She is survived by her hus- band of 51 years, sons David (Kathie) of Wilton, CT, Jack (Tina Eck) of Cabin John, MD and Paul (India Wood) of Boulder, CO, brothers Stephen and David, sister Katherine Gottschalk and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in her memory to Baxter's Pond Foundation, Port Washington Library Foundation or Carolyn & Maurice Mandel Scholarship Fund at The University of Chicago.

MILLER--Joan L.,died on May 8, 2010 at the age of 79. The cause of death was an esophageal tear. Joan was born September 29, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of Ida and Harry Lubell. She attended Fort Hamilton High School and Brooklyn College, where she studied English and Mathematics. She was a pioneer in the infancy of the computer era, and worked as a programmer and data processing manager for firms including Computer Usage, BBD&O and Arizona State University. In the early years, she learned to program computers in hexadecimal codes and assembler language. She worked on one of the earliest computer language compilers prior to her work in data processing applications. Joan survived husbands Julius Korein, Fred Miller and Rick Castro. After spending the first part of her life in New York, Joan moved to Tempe, Arizona for 30 years, returning to New York in 2007. She is survived by her sister, Alice Schlessinger, her three children, Jim Korein, Jon Korein and Amy Caldwell, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was also very close to her nieces, Lilian Meyers and Esther Mita-Schlessinger, and her cousin Donna Freireich. Joan was a warm and loving person, and an avid reader, bridge and scrabble player. She was much beloved by her family and many friends and will be greatly missed.

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions last Sunday gave an incorrect telephone number and Web address for information about an organ recital today at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City. It is (516) 746-2955; the Web site is incarnationgc.org.

When Thomas Olbricht needed a place to display his extensive private art collection, he simply had a building constructed (it also houses several apartments) next to the KW Institute for Contemporary Art. The result is the Me Collectors Room Berlin (Auguststrasse 68; me-berlin.com), a two-story showroom that opened to the public on May 1. ''Art has to come to people,'' said Mr. Olbricht, referring to the need for the new space, where pieces from his collection and the private collections of others will rotate regularly. Art by big names like Cindy Sherman and Andy Warhol hang alongside that of lesser-known international contemporary artists. And the Collectors Room has a decidedly irreverent tone: One of the primary works in the opening exhibition is Kehinde Wiley's giant Baroque-style portrait of Michael Jackson on a horse; another is a sculpture of phalluses that casts a shadow in the form of a human head.

NATHAN--Joseph, of Hollywood, FL, on May 12, 2010. Devoted husband of Wendy, his wife of 55 years. Father of Andy and Holly Nathan, Melissa and Robert Krieger, Randi and David Kalish. Beloved grandfather to Lauren, Erica, Matthew, Jake, Scott, Tyler and Alyse. Joe quietly touched the lives of many with respect, kindness and generosity.

PERKIEL--Frank Efraim, 85, passed away on April 10, 2010. Frank was born and spent his youth in Warsaw, Poland. Upon Nazi Germany's invasion of Poland on September 1, 1939, Frank took up arms in defense of Warsaw against the German army. In the ensuing months following Poland's occupation, Frank remained in Warsaw as a volunteer for the Joint Jewish Distribution Committee. Between 1940 and 1943, Frank lived in the Warsaw Ghetto, active in its Zionist organization, and was secretary of a Jewish Youth Committee, an underground elementary school teacher, and a member of the Jewish resistance smuggling food into and messages in and out of the Ghetto, culminating in his leading the escape of 20 Jews from the Ghetto, following which he secretly lived for a time outside the Ghetto, working with the Polish Jewish underground. In May, 1943, Frank surrendered himself to the Nazi SS to rejoin his father and brother, who remained incarcerated in the Ghetto. After his arrest and deportation, and in the ensuing three years up to his liberation on May 5, 1945 by American invasionary forces from the Mauthausen death camp, Frank miraculously survived eight Nazi labor/concentration camps in Poland, Germany, Czechoslovakia and Austria. Between the end of the war and 1949, Frank lived in US-occupied zones in Austria and Germany, was employed by the UN Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, served the American military in the covert intelligence activities, and headed the Immigration Department of Jewish Agency for Palestine. In April, 1949, Frank and his now-deceased wife, Ella Zlotnik, herself a survivor of Nazi atrocities, immigrated to New York City where he remained and raised his family. He became a successful businessman and in 1966 founded Galaxy Metals Inc. Frank epitomized the human spirits of strength, defiance of evil, survival and hope...his forever enduring legacy. Frank is survived by his son Mitchel H. Perkiel and daughter-in-law Lois Perkiel, and his daughter Anita Perkiel Sarna and son-in-law Mark Sarna, and his six grandchildren, Joshua, Alexa and Griffin Perkiel and Danielle, Ilana and Ari Sarna.

THE NEWS Blacks and Latinos were nine times as likely as whites to be stopped and frisked by the New York City police in 2009, but, once stopped, were no more likely to be arrested. BEHIND THE NEWS Police officers cited ''furtive movements'' as a reason for nearly half of the stops and ''casing a victim or location'' for nearly a third of them. Only about 6 percent of stops resulted in arrests. Civil liberties advocates said the statistics showed prejudice on the part of officers; police officials defended the stop-and-frisk effort as an effective way to deter criminals from carrying weapons on the street.

NISHIDA--Kenichi Shining Star December 1, 1967-May 12, 2010 Loved New York. He is survived by his parents, Masaharu and Sachiko Nishida, sister Mayumi Sakakibara, aunt Ritsuko Takeishi, nephews, cousins and lots of friends USA/Japan. Rest in peace. You will always be with us. Love, Yuki.

SPELLMAN--Stanley, M.D.,87, of Pompton Plains, NJ, formerly of Roslyn, NY, died on May 14 from Alzheimer's Disease. He was a physician and an inventor; a man of decency and honor (Purple Heart and Silver Star in World War II); full of hobbies and of great humor. He is survived by his wife Betty (m. 1952); two sisters: Loretta Nelson and Harriet (Harvey Stack); four children: Barbara (Fred Schauer), Judy (Matt Green), Jay (Amy Silverstein), and Carol (Rob Shulman); six grandchildren: Max Green, Josh and Sarah Spellman, and Jamie, Jake, and Jessica Shulman; many adoring nieces and nephews; and generations of grateful patients and their families. Memorial service will be Monday May 17, 11am, at Temple Beth Haverim Shir Shalom, Mahway, NJ. Contributions may be made to Indiana University School of Medicine, the Alzheimer's Association (alz.org donate, tributes, find a tribute, Spellman), or the charity of your choice.

ESTREN--Solomon, MD. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Estren came to Mount Sinai in 1947 after graduating from The New York University School of Medicine. He was a superb clinician in the field of Hematology and was nationally known for his research in vitamin B12 and metabolic disorders. In 1964 he translated and edited "Thannhauser's Textbook of Metabolism" from German into English. He dedicated more than 60 years of service to the institution and the care of his patients and trained several generations of Hematology residents. He will be remembered as an outstanding researcher and practitioner and a wonderful man. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD President Gila Leiter, MD Vice President Amy J. Weinstein Administrator

RUDMAN--Shirley A.,81, of Hollis, NH died peacefully, surrounded by her husband and children on Friday, April 30, 2010 following a very brief illness. Mrs. Rudman was born in Utica, NY, graduated Phi Beta Kappa, summa cum laude from Syracuse University majoring in mathematics and chemistry. She also received a Masters in Computer Science from the University of Lowell and an MBA from Georgetown University. During her lifetime, she served on the faculty of Rivier College and Daniel Webster College. She also worked for Norden Systems in the public relations field, and had a successful real estate career. She was an avid instrument-rated pilot. She is survived by her husband, former U.S. Senator Warren B. Rudman, her two daughters, Laura Rudman Robie and Debra Gilmore, and a son-in-law Daniel Gilmore. She was preceded in death by her son, Alan H. Rudman. She is also survived by three grandchildren, Benjamin, Rebecca and Sarah Gilmore, and a brother, Edward Cobb and his wife, Jacqueline. Services and interment will be private. The family will hold a memorial service for invited guests later this month. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society of Bedford, NH.

SHERAK--Bernard (Bud), 91, died May 9 after a rich and fulfilling life. He retired as Chairman of the Board of Market Facts, Inc. and is survived by his wife, Gladys, his brother Marvin and sister-in-law, Helen, his sister, Janet and his children, Donald, a forensic psychiatrist in Brookline, MA and Nina, an Associate Director in Regulatory Affairs of AstraZeneca, wellness coach and dancer in Wilmington, DE. A third child, Lucy, an occupational therapist, flautist and composer, died of breast cancer in 1998. He is also survived by two sons-in-law, Todd and Ken, and six grandchildren, Greg, Gina, Matthew, Raffi, Rachael, and Ben. Those wishing to honor his memory may contribute to the National Resource Defense Council, WNYC Public Radio, Breast Cancer Action or Earthjustice. Those wishing to share memories may do so at the website http://www.ilasting.com under Bud Sherak.

REID--John N. 94, died May 13, 2010 of Ridgewood, NJ. Born December 2, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY. He earned a BA and MA from St. John's University, a MA from Fordham University before enlisting in the U.S. Navy in September 1941. He was commissioned 2nd Lieutenant in the U.S. Naval Intelligence and served until October 1946. After graduation from Columbia Law School in 1948 he joined the law firm of Watters & Donovan in New York City. He later was appointed Vice President and General Counsel of the American Insurance Assn. and retired in 1989. A fifty year resident of Ridgewood, he was active as a Little League coach in the Ridgewood Baseball Association. Survived by his wife of 59 years, Mary B.; two sons, Thomas (Kim) in Connecticut, Paul in Georgia, and one daughter, Adrienne Cole (Ed) in New Hampshire, four grandsons Michael, Brian, Scott, and Kevin Reid, one granddaughter Abby Cole. Memorial Mass to be offered at later date. Funeral services Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home, Ramsey, NJ.

As a general rule, marriage isn't sexy on Broadway. True, there is the occasional exception, like Stanley and Stella Kowalski in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' but they're still virtually newlyweds, for whom the first erotic blush has yet to fade. When it comes to watching the portrayal of middle-aged couples who have been together for years, no one expects fireworks. Yet as the careworn, penny-counting Troy and Rose Maxson in Kenny Leon's warm revival of August Wilson's ''Fences,'' Denzel Washington and Viola Davis, left, light up the sky pretty much every time they touch. Troy, a sanitation worker, and Rose have been together for almost two decades, and they fall easily into the ritualistic, Punch-and-Judy squabbling common to couples of long standing. But from the opening scene, when Rose walks onto the sagging back porch of Santo Loquasto's set and hears her husband talking big, as usual, to his best friend (Stephen McKinley Henderson), you sense an electric current running between this husband and wife.

Sometimes all it takes to get electricity going onstage is a little actual electricity. Sarah Ruhl's smart comedy ''In the Next Room, or the vibrator play'' examined the divide between women's lives and men's perceptions of them at the turn of the 20th century, when electric currents in the home were brand new. Laura Benanti starred as a loving wife and new mother who nevertheless felt lonely and unsatisfied, locked away from the busy, intriguing world of her husband, a doctor played by Michael Cerveris, who specialized in treating women's ''hysteria.'' His instrument of choice: a peculiar-looking electrical contraption that few would recognize today as the apparatus of the title. In a larger sense Ms. Benanti's character was also locked outside her own deeper emotional and sexual feelings. While the play culminated in a mystical communion between doctor and wife, the most charged scene of erotic -- and comic -- connection was the passage in which one of his patients, an emotionally frail young woman played by Maria Dizzia, above right with Ms. Benanti, turned the doctor's wife on to the pleasures afforded by that fancy, um, stethoscope.

BOSLOUGH--John Irvan. June 18, 1942 - May 4, 2010. Author, former Denver Post reporter, died at his home in Snowmass Village, CO. May 4 with his closest family and friends by his side. He is survived by his wife, Susan, his two daughters Sophie and Jill, son in-law Jack and grandchildren Damon, Drew, and Olivia, and his brother Jim. John graduated from Princeton University in 1967. John wrote "Beyond the Black Hole-Stephan Hawking's Universe"; "Masters of Time-Cosmology at the End of Innocence" and "The Very First Light-The True Inside Story of the Scientific Journey Back to the Dawn of the University" with astrophysicist and Nobel Prize winner, John C. Mather. A memorial service will be held, June 26th on the back of Aspen Mountain.

One fate the conservative commentator Daniel Pipes doesn't have to worry about is drowning in conceptual complexity. He keeps his theories simple. His theory about why Faisal Shahzad tried to blow up a bomb in Times Square last week is ''jihadi intent.'' Pipes writes dismissively of other explanations - that Shahzad is emotionally unstable, say, or that the bomb was payback for American military action in Pakistan. In Pipes's universe, apparently, these explanations are rivals to the ''jihadi intent'' explanation, and couldn't figure in an account of how Shahzad came to have jihadi intent in the first place.
LOW--Ernest of Maplewood, NJ. Service Monday, May 17, at Noon in Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ.

SIMOTAS--Chrysoula Kounelakis, was born in Chania, Crete, Greece on January 24th 1936. Raised in a home adjacent to the Acropolis in Athens, she graduated with honors from Pierce College and won a Fulbright scholarship to continue studies in the US. At Cedar Crest College, she graduated second in the class of 1956, with a BA in American Literature and met her future husband, Athos Simotas, a medical student in NYC. After completing an MA in Linguistics from the Univ of Michigan, she returned to Athens to teach English to Greek students for a year at Pierce College, Athens. Married in 1958 , she settled in the US with her husband, a physician, where she taught school and raised a family in Teaneck, and later Alpine, NJ. Chrysoula was an early champion of local environmental causes, supporter of the underprivileged, and a friend of educators and schools. Chrys and Athos were married for 52 years. Their four children: Alexander (50), Daphne (49), Philip (45), and Jason (43), along with 13 adoring grandchildren, all live in the NY metropolitan area. Chrysoula died of cancer at home at age 74. She was surrounded by friends and family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors without Borders (Medicine sans Frontieres) or Habitat for Humanity.

Following is the second set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, ''The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs,'' which looks at New York's urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

There's seasonal cooking and, at least during spring in Turkey, there's micro-seasonal cooking. As if waiting for the arrival of summer and its bounty of fresh fruit is too much to bear after a long winter, this time of year sees Turkey's fruit and vegetable stands filling up with produce - tangy, unripe green plums, fresh almonds still in their fuzzy pods, loquats both tart and sweet - that offers a glimpse of coming attractions. Turkish cooks, particularly those from the area around the city of Gaziantep, in southeast Turkey, have long incorporated these first fruits into soups, stews and kebabs that can be had only during spring.Fortunately, there are several spots in Istanbul where some of these seasonal dishes can be sampled - at least until the full heat of summer hits.

COPELON--Rhonda. The Board and Staff of the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved friend, colleague, and Board Vice President, Rhonda Copelon. Rhonda's key roles in the struggle for reproductive rights and justice against human rights abusers the world over made her a role model for legions of colleagues and students. She was a fierce advocate for women's rights and opened new opportunities in the international law arena for challenging violence and other gender-based abuses. In 1980, Rhonda was a central lawyer in two landmark cases, Harris v. McRae, which took a challenge to the Hyde amendment to the Supreme Court, and Filartiga v. Pena-Irala, which ruled that cases involving human rights abuses committed abroad could be brought in U.S. courts. We have lost an irreplaceable force and a very dear friend. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 80 W. 76th Street, on May 21 at 11:45am. Rhonda's wishes were that donations may be made to the Copelon Fund for Gender Justice at CCR, 666 Broadway, 7th floor, New York, NY 10012. For more information on the Fund call 212-614-6489 or email development@ccrjustice.org

Q.A friend and I are planning to travel to Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks in early to mid-September. We will fly into either Jackson or Cody, Wyo., and rent a car. Can you suggest an itinerary? We can spend a week to about 10 days there. Are there guided tours? Can you suggest reasonably priced hotels? We are women ''of a certain age,'' but physically active. Barbara Herman,Fairfield, Conn.A.Consider visiting the two parks after Labor Day, when prices drop and crowds lessen. One option might be to fly into Jackson Hole Airport, inside Grand Teton National Park, and spend several days exploring the park. You can stay at the lovely Jackson Lake Lodge, with wonderful views of the lake and mountains (rooms from $224), or rent the more affordable cabins at Colter Bay Village (rates from $60). Each can be booked with the park's concessionaire, the Grand Teton Lodge Company (gtlc.com), which offers additional places to stay and eat, and half-day and full-day bus tours of the park.

Sure, sure. And send Mount Rushmore and the Tower of London on a traveling tour, ending with their painstaking reconstruction and permanent display, in Dubai. Because culture doesn't stand still! BRIAN HOGAN of Philadelphia, responding to Michael Kimmelman's article about where the Elgin marbles should reside.

Here are some connections. (No word yet on any ties to Kevin Bacon.) - Kagan and Breyer taught at Harvard Law School; both worked for the Justice Department.

CUTTING--George W. Jr. of Oyster Bay, NY and Homer, Alaska died after a long illness on May 13, 2010. Born on July 13, 1932, the son of George W. Cutting and Mary Converse Cutting of Warrenton, Virginia, he graduated from Fessenden School, Brooks School, and Yale University. A former stock broker and portfolio manager, he was an active volunteer for many non profit organizations including: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross, The Nature Conservancy of Alaska, The Community Foundation of Oyster Bay, Youth and Family Counseling of Oyster Bay, Rotary Club of Oyster Bay, and Pratt Museum of Homer, Alaska. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Lucy Pulling Cutting and his children, George W. Cutting III of Glenwood Springs, Colorado, Lucy Cutting of Greenwich, Connecticut, Cynthia Cutting Robinson of Moultonborough, New Hampshire, Susan Cutting of Belfast, Maine, and five grandchildren; also survived by his sisters Martha McDuffie of Bailey, Colorado, Dorothy Cutting of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, and those deceased: John P. Cutting, John A. Hinckley, Elizabeth Cutting Carrigan, and A. Neville Cutting. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 20, 2010 at 11:00am at St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory www.cshl.org or Pratt Museum www.prattmuseum.org.

Getting involved in a minor auto accident can be a hassle, what with juggling alternate transportation and insurance claims, but even more annoying is the aftermath: the deluge of letters and calls from lawyers and medical professionals seeking to profit from your trouble. My husband was driving our daughter to the train station one recent morning when another driver swung out from a side street and clipped his car's left rear panel and bumper. There were no injuries -- the air bags did not deploy -- and no question that the other driver was at fault. Our car was in the body shop within days, and the whole episode was mostly behind us in a little over a week. Then came the offers of ''help.''

Of course Robin Hood can be an astronaut. Maybe even a girl astronaut. Why not. He has already been a Chicago gangster (that would be ''Robin and the 7 Hoods,'' with Frank Sinatra as Robbo) and a duck (that would be Daffy). Lots of actors have played him, most immortally Errol Flynn, but Douglas Fairbanks, Kevin Costner and Sean Connery (not the laddish version) have also taken an arrow from the quiver. Last week, Ridley Scott's ''Robin Hood'' opened, with Russell Crowe as Robin. The film is something of a prequel to the tale of the band that roams the Sherwood Forest. But it doesn't matter who inhabits the shape-shifting myth or what the setting. There's apparently a Robin Hood for everyone, in these hard times or any other. You don't have to be a socialist intent on relieving the rich of their plunder and redistributing it to the deserving poor. You can be a libertarian or a tea partier, relieving a sprawling government of its extra power and returning it to the people. In the future, perhaps when most of the world is ocean, there might be a band of mermen who raid yachts to provision our dinghies and fatten up the obesity-free friar. Just guessing.

ALEXANDRA CASSANITI, a New York designer transplanted to Los Angeles, has a fine philosophy for her surf-inspired line of clothing and accessories: If you can't make it to the beach, she'll bring it to you. Which is to say, her cool neoprene bralettes and bodega bags, and nubby T-shirts cut from flax and cheesecloth, are intended as much for, say, brunch on the Bowery as for a day at Ditch Plains. ''You don't have to be at the beach to have a positive, sunny mentality,'' Ms. Cassaniti says. Hear that, all of you stuck in the city on Memorial Day weekend? Alexandra Cassaniti clothing and accessories are sold at Steven Alan, 103 Franklin Street, Manhattan; and Mollusk Surf Shop, 210 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn. Flax and cheesecloth top, $115, and neoprene bralette, $120, at alexandracassaniti.com.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on April 18 with an article about historic quarrels between Russia and Poland referred incorrectly to an early-20th-century war fought between Bolshevik and Polish forces. The fighting was in 1919 and 1920, not 1921. The war also followed, rather than preceded, the creation of an independent Polish state, which Poles defended and expanded during the war. (The independent state had been established at the Versailles peace conference of 1919, which ended World War I.)

ZELON--Allen. Loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather. With his thirst for new challenges he accomplished what few could: a 53-year marriage to his beloved wife Zaneta, successful careers as a teacher and lawyer, whitewater adventures, excellence in photography, and lifelong friendships. A man of great principle and a voice of reason he fought passionately to ensure segregation be banished forever from the NYC public school system. All who knew him loved him; we miss him greatly.

ATTAWAY--LeRoy Banks, Jr, writer and photographer, died suddenly on May 9, 2010 in Kansas City. Born in 1937 in Walterboro, SC and educated at UNC Chapel Hill, Roy was Editor-in-Chief of Boating, Yachting, and Motorboating & Sailing magazines, a writer and director for ABC's The American Sportsman, and author of A Home in the Tall Marsh Grass. His photographs were shown in various galleries and often accompanied his writings. In 2001 he and his wife Robyn Gill Attaway moved from New York to Kansas City. He is survived by his wife, three children by his first marriage, and his former wife Jane Conklin. Interment will be at the Church of St. Helena, Beaufort, SC. Donations in his memory may be made to the Sports Communication Program, UNC School of Journalism, Campus Box 3365, Chapel Hill, NC 27599.

(13, 49) FOYLE'S WAR, SERIES VI In ''The Hide,'' the season finale in this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' series, a newly retired Detective Chief Superintendent Christopher Foyle (Michael Kitchen, right) puts his dreams of sailing to America on hold as he investigates the case of James Devereaux (Andrew Scott), a former prisoner of war and a member of a prominent family in the seaside town of Hastings, who has been charged with switching sides to aid the Nazis and condemned to death. After several jail visits, Foyle suspects Devereaux of concealing evidence that will exonerate him. So why isn't the guy talking? CUTTING--George W.,Jr. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Board of Trustees, faculty, and administration mourn the passing of George W. Cutting, Jr. "Butch" Cutting was a cherished member of our CSHL family, contributing in so many ways to the growth of our research and education programs and the enrichment of campus life. He was instrumental in the formative years of the Long Island Biological Association, which under his leadership was renamed the CSHL Association. He served on the CSHL Board of Trustees from 1986-1993. Butch's unrelenting support for cancer and neuroscience research and graduate education will be remembered always in programs and facilities dedicated in the names of his family: The George W. Jr. and Lucy Cutting Lectureship in the Watson School of Biological Sciences; the "Cutting House" residence for graduate students; and the Lucy and Edward Pulling Conference Room in the Neuroscience Center. Most recently, Butch and Lucy supported the CSHL Fellows Program as members of the President's Council and gave generously to support the CSHL Association and the Double Helix Medals Dinner. We express our deepest sympathy to Mrs. Lucy Cutting, and to the couple's children and grandchildren. Eduardo G. Mestre, Board Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Phillies Are Accused of Stealing Signs Illegally,'' May 13: The Rockies are accusing the Phillies of unfairly stealing signals. Bolder measures were used during the golden age of baseball.

ALLEN--Truett Evans. Truett Allen passed away on Sunday May 9, 2010, surrounded by friends and family, after a brief struggle with complications from a variety of medical conditions. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, his sons Jefferson and Riley, and four grandchildren. Truett was born in 1933 in Sparta, Virginia to Ruth Cutts Allen and Thomas Cheek Allen, ThD., a Baptist minister. He attended Mars Hill College and graduated from the University of Richmond in 1954. Truett then served in the United States Army from 1956 to 1958, receiving an honorable discharge as Specialist First Class. Truett began a banking career with the Federal Reserve in Richmond, Virginia prior to obtaining his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1962. From Harvard, Truett moved to New York and began a nearly thirty year career at Irving Trust Company, where he served as Vice President Western and Southern Districts and Senior Vice President Securities Industry Division. He developed lifelong friendships with his colleagues in the Wall Street banking and finance community. Truett concluded his banking career at Security Pacific Trust Company, as Senior Vice President of the Securities Industries Group, and then as Chief Credit Officer, before retiring in 1992. Truett cherished his family in New York, Virginia and Georgia, as well as friendships developed while residing in Manhattan, Vermont and Quogue, Long Island. Spirits soared each year as former Irving Trust colleagues graciously organized "Irving Alumni" gatherings in his honor. A private memorial in Manhattan will celebrate the altruistic, lifelong impact on all who knew and loved "True" Allen.

There's not a whole lot of grass in Manhattan, so the men's golf team at Columbia University has to be resourceful in finding practice space. The golfers hone swings in a converted squash court for much of the year and occasionally take a van across Harlem to the driving range on Randalls Island.

KNOWN for her richly textured, towering shoes that are made by hand to order, the Miami-based artist and Bastion designer Ramona Boucher has become a go-to for stylists and fashion editors looking for a little oomph. Basic flats are simply not her thing. ''There's something that comes out that's pure romance when you're wearing heels,'' said Ms. Boucher, who swears to spending 10 hours a day in her own 7 1/2-inch creations -- designed, she notes, with gel insoles. Her platform sandals and wedges, which were seen most recently at the Suno fall fashion show, can be custom-ordered in a range of materials (suede, velvet, snakeskin) and take two to four weeks to make. As for height, 3 1/2 inches is as low as she'll go. Bastion shoes, $950 and up, can be ordered starting May 23 at Visual Therapy, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 315-2233; visual-therapy.com.

Malawer (Michelle), and his cherished grandchildren, Jack, Sydney and Kate. Services to be held on May 16 at 11am at "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY.

READ--Frederick Harvey. Frederick Harvey Read the eighth son of the late Vice-Admiral USNR and Mrs. William A. Read, of Purchase, NY died suddenly, May 13, 2010 in Malibu, CA. Fred attended Buckley School in New York City, St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, graduated from Lawrenceville School and attended the University of Colorado. He then joined the Marine Corps where he was the outstanding marine in his division at Camp Pendleton and learned how to sky dive with Jacques Istel at Hemet, CA. After his military service he married the former Deborah Smith of Centre Island and had two daughters, Cornelia L. Read, the author, and Freya Read Read, a designer for The Pottery Barn, who survive him. He then became a Junior Partner at the Wall Street firm of Hayden Stone. In his early years, he was a member of The Brook Club in New York. He also sailed at The Seawanaka Yacht Club. That marriage ended in divorce and after a brief stint in Chandolin, Switzerland, Fred moved to Malibu to be near his children. During his years in Malibu, he was a short order cook at The Net, a taxi driver and a master Volkswagon mechanic. A fine hockey player, he played with Charles Schultz's pick up team. He married Bonna Newman and had their daughter, Elena Jean Read, both surviving. A loving father, he is also survived by four grandchildren, Lila and Grace Eggert and Indy and Sasha Read, his eldest brother, William A. Read, Jr. of Palm Beach, FL, his other brothers, Peter B. Read of Jaffrey, NH, Donald B. Read of Old Lyme, CT, his sister, Jean Read Knox of Williamsville, NY, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by four other brothers, Curtis S. Read, David W. Read, Roderick F. Read, and Alexander D. Read. Fred was a wonderful trout and salmon fly fisherman, a lover of nature and beautiful green places, and a very talented artist. His work showed in 2009 in Toronto, Ontario, and at The Library in Malibu, CA. He was also noted for his scrimshaw which is in many private collections. Until recently, Fred was a 17 year employee of the United States Post Office in Malibu, CA. Fred will be missed by all who knew and loved him and his many friends. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

An article last Sunday about David Gelbaum, an investor in green technology, misstated his description of his philanthropy. Mr. Reuss is a career G.M. engineer and accomplished amateur racecar driver, who was made president of the automaker's North American business last December. On a chilly afternoon at G.M.'s proving ground north of Detroit this week, he was casually clad in a fleece jacket, blue jeans and western boots, but the expression on his face was dead serious as he turned the ignition on and listened to the Cruze's turbocharged 1.4-liter engine come alive.

Q.I am planning a trip for me and my four siblings (ages 28 to 42) to celebrate our father's birthday in November. He lives in northern Florida and loves boats and kayaking. Budgets are not rock bottom but not luxury, either. We're thinking about a long weekend in the Southeast. Any thoughts on hotels, resorts, home rentals, towns? April Sellers,Indianapolis A.In ''Florida Glide'' (Jan. 30, 2009), Christopher Percy Collier took guided kayak day-trips in the Florida Keys. Mr. Collier noted that kayaking is one of the best ways to traverse the shallow waters of the 1,700 or so islands in the Keys, hence the plethora of outfitters, most found on or near U.S. 1. They offer affordable guided trips, from two hours to five-day trips into the Everglades. Read Jennifer Conlin's ''In Everglades, Lunchtime with an Extra Guest'' (June 8, 2008) for more on kayaking in that national park. And check out Tristram Korten's ''Gliding Along the 'Forgotten Coast' of Florida'' (May 3, 2009) for his account of a three-day kayak trip along the Florida Panhandle. He included suggestions for lodging and dining, as well as outfitters.

Haggling for a lower room rate works about 80 percent of the time, and the walk-up rate at a hotels is about $20 less than advance bookings. Those were among the findings in a new survey by Consumer Reports about the hotel industry, which is still saddled with low occupancy and a rough economy.

Oakland, Calif. IN the last 20 years or so, ''engage the public'' has become one of the most common mantras of the museum business, an injunction to curators and designers to court their audiences with ever more seductive video displays, computer interactives and exhibition architecture. But here in a crime-challenged corner of the Bay Area, a modest civic institution dedicated to the art, history and natural sciences of California has been focused on its own version of that mission for a good deal longer.

LaMOTTA--Richard Edmund. Born in Brooklyn, New York on May 20th, 1942, Richard Edmund LaMotta was a larger-than-life unique man, and a true "social entrepreneur". He is best known as "Mr. Chipwich", the inventor of the original Chipwich, the ice cream cookie sandwich, of which he was so proud, and which came from a love of dunking cookies in milk. He worked hard his whole life, attending the prestigious Brooklyn Tech High School, and Brooklyn College and New York Law School at night over many years while working jobs at AT&T and CBS. Chipwich Chippoppity, a cookie candy, came out of the Chipwich brand and at its second release functioned in conjunction with MyStudentBiz, a business which allowed students to earn money, scholarships, and own a part of the company. His goal was to pass on the entrepreneurship skills he had learned, by mentoring students and helping anyone who asked for his advice. He loved helping people in any way he could, notorious for giving a helping hand to the homeless, and teaching his children to do the same. His generosity was outstanding, and a large part of his life. He created companies that would help people, like his current company, The MD System, an all-natural pain relief system, which will continue on. He loved reading and music, talking sports, car rides, having dinners with his older daughter, watching his younger daughter play sports, always an incredibly devoted family man. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Richard Edmund LaMotta Foundation at P.O. Box 309, Mount Kisco, NY 10549. Survived by his wife, son, two daughters, and a granddaughter. Pre-deceased by son and brother. The wake will be at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY on Saturday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm and Sunday from 2-4pm.
'I don't have an answer. Sometimes, it was goaltending, sometimes, they blocked shots. It wasn't a constant thing. If it was, we would have found a way around it.'

MERRIN--Seymour. August 13, 1931- May 12, 2010 Seymour passed away in his Santa Fe home after a year-long battle with cancer. Seymour was born in Brooklyn, NY. He studied geology at Tufts University, and was drafted into the army during the Korean War. After his first wife, Elaine Cohen, died tragically from cancer, he went on to earn his Masters and PhD degrees in geology, and work as a miner and researcher in the southwestern US. Seymour then married Elizabeth Jenifer Slack, had two children, and moved into the exploding field of semi-conductors and integrated circuits, ultimately ending his career as a respected and outspoken pundit in the personal computer industry. He earned numerous patents, industry awards, and formal recognition for his myriad accomplishments. After losing Elizabeth to cancer, Seymour fulfilled a life-long dream to return to the Southwest, settling in Santa Fe, NM thirteen years ago. He fell in love with and married Helene C. Singer, paraded his Great Dane, Sabrina through town daily, and helped finance and guide non-profit projects involving crypto-Jewish history and Native American arts and scholarship. Seymour is survived by Helene; his son Charles and daughter-in-law Ivonne; his daughter Marianne Weights; five grandchildren, Bryan, Sydney, Alexander, Siena, and Mateo; his brother Edward and wife Vivian; numerous step children, step grandchildren, nieces, nephews, and loving friends; and his beloved dog, Sabrina. Seymour would be honored with remembrances to The Museum of New Mexico Foundation- Crypto-Jewish Project (P.O. Box 2065, Santa Fe, NM 87504-2065) or PMS Hospice (1400 Chama Avenue, Santa Fe, NM 87505-3372). A memorial service will be held at 2pm, 24 May 2010, at the New Mexico History Museum in Santa Fe.

Great chemistry usually requires two or more actors, but Christopher Walken is expert at playing solitary souls whose deepest emotional connections are with unseen characters (a fellow soldier in ''Pulp Fiction,'' a dead Irish boy in ''James Joyce's The Dead''). As the mysterious, obsessive one-handed man Carmichael in Martin McDonagh's play ''A Behanding in Spokane'' Mr. Walken is never more engaging or empathetic (or hilarious) than during his five-minute conversation -- unusually long for Broadway -- with his offstage, elderly mother. Carmichael has lived most of his life with this woman, and Mr. Walken is by turns annoyed, aghast and revealingly tender during this one-sided conversation about his mother's fall out of a tree. ''I'll tell you what your problem is, Ma, you wanna know what your problem is? You're anal, that's what your problem is,'' Mr. Walken says into the phone. After a beat his voice adopts an edge of weary frustration that you imagine is as old as Carmichael. ''Yes, you are anal.'' The mother-son talk is not only a key plot point -- she inadvertently turns him away from killing one of the other characters -- but also a master class by Mr. Walken on how to play a confrontation all on your own.PATRICK HEALY

CANNES, France - If I am remembering clearly - and my head is filled with so many densely layered words and images, it is hard to unpack them - the first image in "Film Socialism," the new movie by Jean-Luc Godard, is of two red-headed parrots, side by side on a tree limb. The parrots are among a handful of animals that appear in the movie, which had its press premiere Monday morning at the Cannes Film Festival, including a pair of hilariously talkative cats (whose meows are, in turn, parroted by a young woman watching them on a laptop), as well as a llama and a donkey. Surrounding these animals is a menagerie of talking, quoting, babbling human beings, speaking in French, German, Russian, English and Arabic, among other tongues.

The musical, which was presented in Australia and New Zealand before it reached London, is written by Stephan Elliott, the writer and director of the film, and Allan Scott, and directed by Simon Phillips. A Toronto run is scheduled to begin in October before the production moves to a yet to be determined Broadway theater next spring.

Tough economic times have kept the Metropolitan Opera to a reduced summer season for the third year in a row. The Met said on Monday it would put on six free recitals in parks across New York's five boroughs, July 12 to July 29. It called the performers, to be accompanied by piano, "rising stars"; the established star Nathan Gunn will sing on the first program. The Met stopped its tradition of presenting full-length operas in concert after the summer of 2007 for budgetary reasons, presenting a gala concert in 2008 and recitals in 2009.
This weekend, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, became the first Republican to formally enter the crowded field for New York attorney general.

Biologists braved flash floods and torrential storms on an expedition to Indonesia's Foja Mountains, a remote area on the island of New Guinea.

While NBC and Fox are announcing new schedules on Monday, CBS is notifying producers about which new shows it is ordering for the fall. So far, it has given series orders to three dramas: "Hawaii 5-0," "Defenders" and "Blue Bloods."

In this week's installment of my column, The Appraisal, I explore how and why New Yorkers rent and buy apartments in terrible locations with terrible drawbacks -- an elevated train rumbles past your bedroom window; drivers on the B.Q.E. gaze into your kitchen while you peel carrots for a stir-fry; you wake up each morning to a coughing bus bleeping louder than any alarm clock.

Updated: President Obama signed legislation on Monday intended to promote free press around the world, a bipartisan measure inspired by the murder in Pakistan of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter, shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

Christiana Figueres of Costa Rica has been appointed to succeed Yvo de Boer as the head of the United Nations climate secretariat. The Green blog spoke with her recently about her candidacy and how she might jump-start negotiations toward a meaningful climate accord.

At last we have barbecue weather here in the Northeast, and doubtless many of you have started dusting off the old grill in preparation for Memorial Day. If you are considering ribs, we have a perfect set of problems for you, conceived and linked to grilling ribs by our graphic genius Justin Thyme.
Shares of Virtual Radiologic jumped about 30 percent on Monday after the health care company agreed to be taken private by Providence Equity Partners.

We publish many striking images in the arts feature that accompanies our fiction and nonfiction Chronicle columns. But "I Am Its Secret," by the Iranian-born photographer and artist Shirin Neshat - which shows a veiled Muslim woman (who is Neshat herself) staring intently into the camera, her skin covered with a swirl of black and red Farsi script - attracted more than the usual attention during our production cycle for Sunday's issue as editors checked the copy.

How often do you get a half-hour or so to poke around the head of Mike Myers? Almost never. Mr. Myers, the soft-spoken "Saturday Night Live"-performer-turned-"Austin Powers" star, can be press shy and tends to let his characters do the talking for him. He also hasn't had a major screen role since "The Love Guru" in 2008.

Ford has spent years prepping the North American market for its Ford Fiesta subcompact, which was conceived in the automaker's British studios nearly three years ago. It is a testament to the British team's Kinetic Design language that the Fiesta, which arrives in United States showrooms this summer, looks fresher than anything in its segment. And according to Ford, the Fiesta returns better mileage, too.

Much prognosticating about the world's ''emerging'' destinations is pure speculation, but consider where the airlines are placing their bets. New routes point to where the money is - and provide a glimpse into travel's crystal ball. Case in point: Lufthansa is now flying from Frankfurt to Iraq's newly expanded Erbil airport for the first time in 20 years, catering to workers in the oil and gas industry. So what do the airlines' latest touch-downs tell us about where to go next?

Hotels in Istanbul tend to be either touristy affairs in the Old City or splashy (and pricey) luxury digs that hug the shores of the Bosporus. The House Hotel Galatasaray, which opened last month in Beyoglu, is aiming for the space in between: it's a short stroll from the popular and central Taksim Square, but with rates starting at a fairly reasonable 120 euros (about $150).

Pressing the reset button after a few years it would like to forget, NBC unveiled a bevy of new dramas and sitcoms to advertiser clients Monday morning. The network impressed the hundreds of assembled media buyers with previews of the high-octane drama "The Event" and the married spy caper "Undercovers," among others.

When there is a government change in Britain, it is customary for the outgoing ministers to leave a note to their successors, offering some advice. But when David Laws, the new chief secretary of the Treasury, arrived at his desk, he found some unexpected words.

Laura Bush's memoir, "Spoken From the Heart," debuts at No. 1 on this month's Caucus list of political best sellers. While she reveals little in the way of surprising details, the former first lady writes about the fatal car accident she was involved in as a youth that killed her friend. She also discusses some of her husband's presidential decisions, noting a key split over gay marriage, which she advised him to play down as a political issue.

The country singer Brad Paisley donated $100,000 of his own money at a Sunday telethon and concert that raised more than $1.5 million to benefit people affected by the recent flooding in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. The telethon, shown on the Great American Country television channel, began with Mr. Paisley's performance of his song "Welcome to the Future," after which he announced his donation. "If there is a silver lining," he said, "it's that the world is getting to see Nashville at its best through this tragedy." The concert also featured performances by Sheryl Crow, Kellie Pickler and Lady Antebellum, as well as Keith Urban, who played the Beatles' "Help" while his wife, Nicole Kidman, watched. Scott Borchetta, the chief executive of Big Machine Records, which releases music by Taylor Swift and other artists, also donated $100,000 to the telethon, which will benefit the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee.

After months of controversy, a review of the workings of the United Nations' main scientific body on climate change has just gotten under way in Amsterdam. Over the next few months, a 12-member panel of scientific experts will analyze the makeup, procedures and conduct of the body, known as the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

Inter Milan won the scudetto in Italy. Barcelona won another La Liga title. And Chelsea won the F.A. Cup, 1-0, completing a commendable double. But the real news from the final weekend of league soccer was a loss -- for Germany. The Mannschaft captain Michael Ballack will miss the World Cup.
Roger Cohen reported from Ramallah and Taybeh village in the West Bank about the hope that is buzzing and the businesses that are booming despite enormous challenges.

A tie in an awards category is a sufficiently infrequent event, ties in two categories are astronomically rare, and when you have ties in three categories -- as happened with the 60th Annual Outer Critics Circle Awards -- it may be time to start playing the lottery.

Only 12 of the 24 cars that started the Formula One Grand Prix of Monaco finished the race on Sunday. There were several crashes and four safety car periods. But through it all, the order at the top remained unchanged after the first corner, as the Red Bull cars of Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel finished first and second. It was Webber's second straight victory.

As oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill spreads around the Gulf of Mexico, many people wonder if it will eventually enter the Atlantic and travel up the Florida coast. Brian N. Toder, a lawyer in Minneapolis who was involved in the Exxon Valdez case, says he is certain that it will. Yet his view is based not on the science of winds or ocean currents, but personal experience.

That is evident again in a campaign scheduled to get under way on Monday from a new brand under the Sprint Nextel banner, Common Cents.

Perhaps the most startling and frustrating thing about the debate over the fate of the euro is the way almost everyone avoids confronting the core issue -- the elephant in the euro. With a unified currency, adjustment to differential shocks requires adjustments in relative wages -- and because the nations of the European periphery have gone from boom to bust, their adjustment must be downward. At this point, wages in Greece/Spain/Portugal/Latvia/Estonia etc. need to fall something like 20-30 percent relative to wages in Germany. Let me repeat that:

For his show "On The Road" at Artpace in San Antonio, curator Jens Hoffmann got behind the wheel himself, traveling through the southwest from Del Rio, Tex., to White Sands, New Mexico. "There's such a romantic notion of the open road in this region of the country," says Hoffmann, who serves as the director of the CCA Wattis Institute for Contemporary Art in San Francisco. To supplement the exhibit's iconic images of America's car culture - Ed Ruscha's gas station photos, Mary Heilmann's abstract paintings of highways - Hoffmann gathered his own artifacts during a week long journey. He tried to buy a gun near Amarillo, Tex., at a pawn shop, but instead ended up with a ring in the shape of the lone star state. He attempted to finish off a 72-ounce-steak in one hour at Big Texan restaurant in Amarillo. "If you do, they comp your meal. I couldn't do it but there was an episode of 'The Simpsons' where Homer did," says Hoffmann, who decided to forego the doggy bag for a menu. The show features souvenirs like a rusty license plate from 1941, vintage rodeo photographs and even some regional flora and fauna. "I got stuck in a sandstorm in the Texas plains so we have some original Texas panhandle tumbleweed in the show." The show is up through Sept. 5.

For a guy who sang about tigers, demons, wizards, evil and hell, Ronnie James Dio had a pretty good sense of humor about himself. Mr. Dio, the onetime lead singer of Black Sabbath and front man of his eponymous heavy metal band, died on Sunday at 67. But over the years he threw his devil's horns in approval of a few satirical tributes in his honor.

In his Media Equation column on Monday, David Carr mentions Taylor Momsen, whom he doesn't know, except that she is a mean character on "Gossip Girl" and one of the most frequently used search terms on the Web. While the rest of East Asia erupts in celebrations to honor the Buddha's birthday, residents of the small dumbbell-shaped island of Cheung Chau - less than an hour's ferry ride from Hong Kong's Central district - literally march to their own tune. The annual five-day Cheung Chau Bun Festival culminates this year on May 21. Nearly 40,000 people are expected to flood this fishing haven, then to make merry and enjoy the holiday's namesake steamed buns, filled with sweet paste and stamped with the crimson Chinese character for "peace."

BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about structural weaknesses in Portugal's economy misstated, in some copies, the country's deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product, after the adoption of proposed austerity measures. It would be 4.6 percent, not 5.1 percent. The article also misstated, in some copies, the 2009 budget deficit of Spain as a portion of G.D.P. It is 11.2 percent, not 12.2 percent. The article also omitted the given name of a Portuguese landlord in some copies. He is JosÃ© Gago da GraÃ§a.

David Randolph, a choral conductor whose performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' with the Masterwork Chorus were for decades a mainstay of New York's holiday season, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95. The cause was complications of pneumonia, said Sheridan Chapin, a friend of many years.

Even among the Nepalese -- who always seem to be attempting strenuous feats to promote world peace -- a 33-year-old former teacher named Lok Bandhu Karki stands out. Mr. Karki traveled the 53 districts of Nepal by bike for the noble mission, but then decided to extend his trip. He left Nepal on Dec. 7, 2004, and has visited 79 countries so far, traveling a distance of 90,000 miles, he estimates.

CTIA, the wireless industry association, reported last week that the amount of data in text, music, e-mail and other activities surpassed voice calls on mobile devices in 2009. According to comScore, total cellphone subscribers from 2009 to 2010 is about the same, but the number of users going online is up across almost all Web categories. Visitors to social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter increased 78 percent. Many more users are going to reference sites like Answer.com or Wikipedia (shown above with a Matisse entry), up 46 percent and banking sites, up 45 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Big Blue laid out its ''Roadmap to 2015'' today at its yearly investors gathering, and Wall Street applauded. I.B.M. confidently predicted that it would deliver earnings per share of ''at least $20'' in 2015, or double last year's performance. The company said it intends to generate $100 billion in free cash flow over the next five years, leaving plenty of money for investment. That includes $20 billion in acquisitions, or double the pace of the last five years.

TRENTON, N.J. -- Since moving to this city from her native Guatemala a decade ago, Herlinda, an illegal immigrant, has supported her family with restaurant work, but has had no way of proving that she lives here. Without government-issued photo identification, like a driver's license or a passport, she said, she could not get treatment at most medical clinics, borrow a book from the library, pick up a package from a mail center or cash a check. But this month she discovered a solution: a community identification card issued by a coalition of civic groups and endorsed by Trenton and Mercer County officials.

Grab the flak jackets: Allan Mayer, a partner in the public relations powerhouse 42 West, has joined in a lawsuit against his old associate Michael Sitrick, the Hollywood crisis king. Mr. Mayer on Friday aligned with an earlier plaintiff, Richard Wool, in filing an amended complaint in the United States district court for the central district of California. It says Mr. Sitrick and others violated federal law by manipulating an employee stock ownership plan before Mr. Sitrick's 2009 sale of his namesake public relations company to Resources Connection Inc.

The Pound Ridge Golf Club became the first Pete Dye-designed golf course in the New York area when it opened in 2008. It was a public daily fee golf course just over the New York border from Stamford, Conn., which put it in the heart of an area replete with well-known and established private golf courses. The peak cost to play Pound Ridge, which has all the devilish approaches, colossal bunker complexes and strategic mounding you would expect from a Dye design, was $235. That was considerably more than the peak cost to play other high-end public courses in the region like Bethpage Black State Park on Long Island ($150), Ballyowen Golf Club in New Jersey ($135) or the Centennial Golf Club ($135) in Carmel, N.Y.

Google's flagship Nexus One phone debuted earlier this year to much fanfare. The phone was not only flashy -- evocative of Apple's iPhone in many respects -- but Google was also using it to try to change the dynamics of the wireless industry by selling it directly from its Web store and bypassing the powerful wireless carriers. On Friday, Google admitted defeat in that pursuit. In a blog post, Andy Rubin, chief of its Android division, said the company will now focus on selling the Nexus One through existing retail channels -- and would soon stop selling the handsets online altogether.

MUNICH -- Hesham Shashaa looked twice at the display on his cellphone, staring at the number. ''It's either a person who needs help or someone who wants to kill me,'' he said. Mr. Shashaa, an imam at the Darul Quran mosque in Munich, follows the strictest form of Islam, Salafi. But the people who want to kill him are Muslims.

An article on Thursday about Scott Jurek, a vegan who runs ultramarathons, included an outdated reference to another athlete who consumes no animal products. The athlete, Georges Laraque, was released by the Montreal Canadiens in January; he does not play for the N.H.L. team.

For people trying to figure out where to get a deal near their home, the sudden outpouring of options is a bit overwhelming. Web sites publishing local deals are popping up everywhere, from Groupon and its imitators to Twitter and Foursquare to super-local neighborhood sites. That's on top of offers that appear in the mail and newspaper ads. A new site aims to fix that problem by aggregating all the nearby deals in one place. It is called the Dealmap, and is an offshoot of Center'd, the local search engine start-up that is backed by $8.8 million in venture capital from Norwest Venture Partners and other investors.

When Hank Haney resigned last week as Tiger Woods's coach, he said he had spent 110 days a year with Woods, including 50 nights at Woods's home. Haney kept this schedule for six years. FLORENCE, Ky. -- Rand Paul grabbed a microphone, climbed onto a short brick wall and told a gathering crowd of supporters to brace for an Election Day uprising on Tuesday. ''There's a Tea Party tidal wave coming. It's already hit Utah and it's coming to Kentucky,'' Mr. Paul said, delivering a confident pep talk here in the closing hours of the Republican primary for a United States Senate seat. ''The day of reckoning is coming. We cannot elect the same old politicians without getting the same old mess.''

NURNBERG--Joseph, died May 16, 2010, age 97. A resident of New York City since his family emigrated from Budapest in 1921, he brought enthusiasm, energy and optimism to every aspect of life. A graduate of St. John's University Law School, he passionately practiced law in Manhattan for more than 60 years, the last 25 as a partner at Kane Kessler, P.C., retiring in 2003. He loved to regale his family with tales of his most challenging trials and business negotiations. Mr. Nurnberg was a founder and past President of the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale. He is survived by his adored, and adoring, wife of 66 years, Rita; his three children, Ronald (Fran Luckom-Nurnberg), Aileen (Stephen) Schreiber and Leslie (Charles) Saber; his six grandchildren, Carolyn, Jason, Jeff, Peter, Amanda and Jennifer; and his 100 year old sister, Rose Kresler. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (90th St) at 12noon on Tuesday May 18. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale 475 West 250th St, Riverdale, NY 10475.

BERLIN -- European privacy regulators and advocates reacted angrily Saturday to the disclosure by Google, the world's largest search engine, that it had systematically collected private data since 2006 while compiling its Street View photo archive. After being pressed by European officials about the kind of data the company compiled in creating the archive -- and what it did with that information -- Google acknowledged on Friday that it had collected snippets of private data around the world. In a blog post on its Web site, the company said information had been recorded as it was sent over unencrypted residential wireless networks as Google's Street View cars with mounted recording equipment passed by.

MONACO -- Twenty minutes before the start, the stars flocked to the grid of the most illustrious, glamorous race of the season, among them Mick Jagger. As the crowd got progressively larger, tighter and more rambunctious, the Rolling Stone turned to his companion and exclaimed with a laugh: ''What a madhouse!'' His words turned out to be the perfect description for the race that followed as the usual procession through the streets of the principality turned into a series of accidents, car breakdowns and loose drain covers, which caused the action to be suspended four times - including three laps from the end of the 78-lap race - as the messes were cleaned up.

Hank Haney's split with Tiger Woods last week reflected Woods's penchant for tinkering with his golf swing and was to be expected, several of Haney's coaching brethren said in interviews last week. ''A guy like him, his mind gets bored,'' said David Leadbetter, who pioneered the golf coach role on the professional golf tours 20 years ago. ''When he was young, he had one swing and played very well. Then he changed his swing with Butch Harmon and played great. So then he went to Hank, and while he didn't do everything right, he still played great.

All across the United States, college students are graduating and, in many cases, planning summer trips. Some will go abroad; some will road trip through the States; most, it seems safe to say, will be on a low budget. Which is where the Let's Go guidebooks step in. For 50 years, the series has been aimed at Â college students setting off to see the world, whether for a semester, a summer or the indefinite future. What's more, the books - more than 50 guides covering six continents - are written and edited by the people who understand college students best: other college students.

It's that time of the month again. Yes: it's time for Life-form of the Month. Since 1976, John Ameroso has been showing New Yorkers how to grow what they eat. As the first and, probably last, extension agent in the city focused on farming, Mr. Ameroso is more responsible than anyone for the rise of urban agriculture in the city and the tons of produce now raised in plots big and small. He's recently retired, but is still winding down his work in the five boroughs, making sure his legacy will continue. While he's at it, he will also answer questions from Diner's Journal readers about city farming and growing food. Post your question as a comment below he'll respond in later posts this week.

Clothes may perform as fashion statements but that's hardly all they're good for. On a live body they also shelter and expose, enhance and diminish, challenge and flatter, instantly telegraphing taste, class, style and sense of self. Discarded garments tell another story - especially when 30 tons of them are tossed willy-nilly into a twenty-five-foot high, bonfire-like pyramid surrounded by a mass grave of 60,000 pieces of apparel in every size, shape and color. Then they speak for the dead.

If you're looking for an activity for your children or grandchildren, you might try geocaching, a treasure-hunting game played by using GPS devices to find hidden containers, or geocaches, outdoors and then sharing the experiences online. A typical geocache treasure is an inexpensive but intriguing object, like a tiny Rubik's cube, a postcard or a coin from a different country. Sometimes the caches contain a Travel Bug with a code that can be tracked, so you can see where it's been.

Captiva, Fla., has long been a place of refuge for no-nonsense Midwesterners - the anti-Palm Beach, even the anti-Naples. But the understated charm of the island off of Florida's Gulf Coast (which I've been assured has seen no effects of the oil spill) is not for lack of achievement. When I was there for a week not long ago, I met international litigators, art directors for major ad agencies and artisanal cheese sellers, all drawn to Captiva's gorgeous beaches and profound sense of ease. The island has no celebrity chefs, no flashy main drag, no late night boÃ®tes - and that's exactly how locals and regular visitors like it.

A man driving a minivan crammed with explosives steered into an American convoy, Dexter Filkins of The Times reported from Kabul, killing 18 people, including five American soldiers and one from Canada. At least 47 people were wounded, nearly all of them civilians caught in heavy traffic during the morning rush. The blast sent a fireball billowing into the air, set cars aflame and blew bodies apart. Limbs and entrails flew hundreds of feet, littering yards and walls and streets. The survivors, many of them women and children, some of them missing limbs, lay in the road moaning and calling for help.

The Department of Buildings has lifted the stop-work order on the Brooklyn Grange farm in Queens, a department spokesman said. The installation of the venture's rooftop farm on an industrial building in Long Island City had been halted Friday for not filing permits or plans. Representatives of the farm have now filed plans, including a "structural analysis showing how the weight of the farm will be supported," which the department approved, said Tony Sclafani of the Buildings Department. That, plus a $5,537 fine the farmers paid for working without a permit, will allow installation to resume immediately. A stop-work order for some construction inside the building, unrelated to the farm, remains in effect.

A Kiwi by birth, a New Yorker by inclination, the 26-year-old is a devotee of the byzantine echo chamber known as "social media," with 10,320 followers on Twitter and 4,357 friends on Facebook. "Inside Job," which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival last weekend and is scheduled for a fall release in the United States, offers a similarly lucid and outraged analysis of another complicated catastrophe: the global financial crisis of 2008.

If you missed your favorite barkeep last Monday or Tuesday, it was quite possible he or she was packed into the Hiro Ballroom at the Maritime Hotel for what constituted the can't-miss event of the year for the shake-and-stir set, a gathering that had cocktailian tongues wagging for months beforehand. Kazuo Uyeda, the reigning patriarch of Japanese bartending and self-professed inventor of the controversial "hard shake," was making his first United States speaking appearance at a two-day seminar on Japanese bartending methods. As American cocktail culture has exploded over the past decade, cycling through every trend - from resurrecting 19th-century recipes and ingredients to molecular reinterpretation of drinks - a communal grasping has remained to understand the fastidious Japanese scene, which is focused in the tiny bars that dot Tokyo's nightlife centers like Roppongi and Ginza, where Uyeda's bar, Tender, is located. In the more recessed aeries of cocktail culture, an intense curiosity about and mimicry of the Japanese interpretation of the cocktail exists. It is safe to say that this fixation is almost entirely due to Uyeda's reputation, and collective puzzlement over the hard shake.

An article on Monday about cities that have issued identification cards to illegal immigrants misstated the nature of a challenge to New Haven's program. Opponents filed a state open records request for the names and addresses of all ID card applicants or recipients; they did not file a lawsuit. And because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the authority that upheld the city's decision not to release the names; it was the Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission, not the state government.

It's decision day for voters in Pennsylvania, Arkansas and Kentucky, where the outcome of Senate primary contests on Tuesday will deliver more clues to the puzzle that is the midterm election of 2010. Two Democratic senators, with combined Washington experience of nearly 50 years, will discover if they have assembled strong-enough coalitions to withstand an anti-incumbent surge or if their careers will effectively end. And an open Senate seat in Kentucky will help show whether Tea Party advocates can produce an electoral victory.

ENGLE--Morton, 86, of Cedarhurst, NY on May 15. Avid Mets fan. Was an Adjunct Professor at Queens College and guidance counselor at Campbell Junior High. Owned Camps Skybird and Tunis Lake. Executive Director Emeritus of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst. Loving husband to Marcia Hain Engle and the late Janet Engle and brother to Barney Engle. Beloved father of Mindy, Lawrence, Howard and Adam and their spouses Eliot, Bethany, Trude and Ellen. Loving grandfather to Shira, Arielle, Benjamin, Leigh, Allison, Jeremy, Rachel, David, Seth and Zachary.

DAVIS--Paul, will be remembered as a Master Builder and Developer of the Watergate in Washington, DC, the Charleston Navy Yard in Boston and the Westside rail yards in Manhattan. To his wife Sally, his children Ashleigh and Julia, sons-in-law Michael and Michael, his grandchildren Bailey, Page and Alma, and his friends and associates, Paul's generosity of spirit, brilliance, passion and ability to translate his vision into design and then a building, and especially his love for his family will be cherished. Paul possessed an intense curiosity, and asked all of us who had the privilege of working with him to aim high. While we can only hope to attain his level of accomplishment and integrity, when we walk by one of his buildings, we will be reminded to say a prayer of thanks for having known such a blessed soul and wonderful man.

After years of studying the ill effects of workplace stress, psychologists are turning their attention to its causes. Along with the usual suspects - long hours, bad bosses, office bullies - they have identified some surprising ones. The focus on workplace health comes as worker satisfaction in the United States appears to be at an all-time low. The Conference Board reported recently that just 45 percent of workers are satisfied with their jobs, down from 61 percent in 1987. The findings, based on a survey of 5,000 households, show that the decline goes well beyond concerns about job security. Employees are unhappy about the design of their jobs, the health of their organizations and the quality of their managers.

TENNENBAUM--Abraham. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of our long time member and former First Vice President, Abraham Tennenbaum, father of Gilda Chodosh and Nancy Sklarin. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Yosie Levine, Rabbi Steve Graber, President

GREENBERG--Rabbi Moshe. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family and the Jewish people in mourning the loss of Rabbi Moshe Greenberg, distinguished professor emeritus of Bible at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem (HU) and recipient of the Pras Yisrael. One of the greatest biblical scholars of our time, Rabbi Greenberg was the son of longtime JTS professor and vice chancellor Simon Greenberg, and received rabbinical ordination from JTS before making aliyah and joining the faculty of HU. May his wife, Evelyn, and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

FREEDMAN--Millicent (nee Fidler) of Rockville Centre, NY died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on Sunday, May 16th. She is survived by her loving husband Herbert of 63 years, her children Robert (Ann), Wendy (Jed), James (Holly), and her four adoring grandchildren Jessica, Joanna, Isaiah and Roy. Millicent was a woman of grace and style. She loved art, theatre, fashion and design, read avidly and was socially active. Most of all she cherished her family and legion of friends. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am Tuesday, May 18th at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516-295-3100). In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Millicent's memory to: Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medical College, 425 E. 61st Street, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10065.
