WHITLEY--Robert E. The United States Tour Operators Association mourns the passing of Robert E. (Bob) Whitley, longtime president, who died in Norwalk, Connecticut, May 13 following complications from abdominal surgery. He was 66. Whitley's distinguished career in the tourism field spanned more than 40 years, including both private sector and government positions. His association with USTOA dates back to 1978 when he was selected to head the national nonprofit organization. During his tenure, the organization grew to become the leading tour operator association in the U.S. Mr. Whitley was the recipient of numerous awards for travel promotion, and has been recognized for his achievements by all the leading travel trade publications. He served on the Board of Directors and advisory boards of many travel industry associations, including the Association of Travel Marketing Executives, American Tourism Society, The German National Tourist Office, ATOUT France, Starwood Hotels & Resorts, Tourism Cares, VisitBritain, and SKAL, the worldwide fraternal club of the travel industry. As an expert spokesperson for the travel industry, Whitley appeared on television and radio stations throughout the U.S. and the U.K. During his tenure at USTOA, he traveled to more than 100 countries and visited with numerous presidents, royalty, and dignitaries. Before joining USTOA, Whitley held positions as director of the Florida Department of Tourism, director of the Pennsylvania Department of Tourism and director of the Virginia Beach Convention and Tourist Bureau. Among Whitley's passions were the New York Yankees, golf, travel, his family and his homes in Ridgefield, Connecticut and Playa del Carmen, Mexico. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Carol (nee Collmus), and three children: Kelly Brock and her husband, Andrew, of Chatham, New Jersey; Scott Whitley and his wife, Tara, of Moorestown, New Jersey; Shaun Whitley of Manhattan; and five grandchildren. Bob was an inveterate traveler who served as a goodwill ambassador throughout the world. He was the driving force behind USTOA's success, and he will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in Whitley's name to an organization he helped create to restore the past and preserve the future, Tourism Cares: (www.tourismcares.org/ donate). Memorial services will be held in Connecticut Wednesday, May 19. Details are available through: www.ustoa.com.

KALEKO--Jerome D. Died May 17, 2010. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Garb) for 58 years. Proud father of Michael and Daniel and their wives Wendy and Linda. Adoring grandfather of Jason, David, Sarah, and Elizabeth. Co-founder of Kaleko Brothers with his late brother Robert. His kindness and great sense of humor will be missed. We will love him always. Services will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett May 18, 2010 at 9:30am.

JACOBSON--Charlotte. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the passing of Charlotte Jacobson, one of the towering figures of the Zionist movement, who died Friday, May 14, in Florida. In addition to serving as Hadassah's National President from 1964 to 1968, over the course of the past 60 years she occupied a vast range of key positions in the American and world Zionist leadership. "The Jewish people, Israel and Hadassah have lost a monumental figure, a role model that virtually every Zionist activist has tried to emulate for more than half a century," said Nancy Falchuk, Hadassah's current president. "We are tremendously sad at her passing but also incredibly grateful for the legacy she left us." Ms. Jacobson served as Hadassah's President during the momentous period of the Six Day War. After the fighting stopped, she was able to reclaim two key pieces of ground in Jerusalem that Hadassah had lost 19 years earlier, during Israel's War of Independence. One was the Hadassah Hospital on Mount Scopus. The other was the gravesite of Henrietta Szold, Hadassah's founder, on the Mount of Olives. One of the key positions she held after her presidency ended was chair of Building and Development for the Hadassah Medical Organization. In that post she supervised the rebuilding of the Mount Scopus Hospital as well as the building of the Moshe Sharett Institute of Oncology. Born into a Zionist family in New York, Charlotte Jacobson grew up with the movement to create a Jewish state. She made her first visit to Israel in 1951, three years after independence. Though much of her contribution to Israel and the Zionist movement came through her leadership of Hadassah, she also served on the board of directors of the Hebrew University, the Jewish Agency, the Jewish Telegraphic Agency and the American Zionist Youth Foundation. From 1971 to 1982 she served as chair of the American Section of the World Zionist Organization. In 1981 she became the first woman elected to the presidency of the Jewish National Fund. She traveled the world in defense of Jewish rights, meeting with refuseniks and facing commissars in the Soviet Union, and advocating freedom of worship and emigration in front of the leaders of Syria and Egypt. She also defended Israel and the Jewish people in the halls and overseas conferences of the United Nations. Within Hadassah she held a wide range of leadership positions during the course of her career. Among many other posts, she served as chair of the Hadassah College of Technology (today Hadassah College Jerusalem) and Hadassah Magazine. She chaired the Young Judaea Alumni Association, the committee to observe the Zionist movement's 100th anniversary and the Jerusalem 3000 Special Events Committee. She was also responsible for the first USAID grant of $1 million to Hadassah in 1968. She was also a long time member of Hadassah's national board and a mentor of Kibbutz Ketura, where a building and plaza bear her name. In 1998, Ms. Jacobson received Hadassah's coveted Henrietta Szold Award, becoming the first Hadassah leader so honored. Reserved for world leaders, previous Henrietta Szold awardees included Eleanor Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Golda Meir, Yitzhak Rabin, Simon Wiesenthal and Elie Wiesel. Charlotte Jacobson was a leader for all seasons. Hadassah mourns her today, but we know that generations after we are gone, our descendants will know her name and benefit from its blessings. Donations in her memory may be sent to Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Hadassah House, 50 West 58th St., New York, NY 10019.

WOLFERT--Pearl. Died peacefully on May 15. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of David and Jonathan and devoted mother-in-law of Laurie and Susan. Adored grandmother of Samantha Grefe (Justin), Benjamin, Eric, and Adam Wolfert. Cherished sister-in-law, aunt, friend. Donations to the Hospice Care Network or the charity of your choice will be warmly appreciated. Funeral service Tuesday, May 18, 11:30am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at the Beth Moses Cemetery.

JACOBSON--Charlotte. The Jewish Agency for Israel and the World Zionist Organization mourn the passing of Charlotte Jacobson, past Chair WZOAmerican section, for her lifework on behalf of Israel and the Jewish people. Natan Sharansky, Chair of the Executive Kalman Sultanik, Chair, WZOAmerican Section

YERKES--Harry Estile III, of New York and Fishers Island died peacefully at home on May 15. He was 83. Born in Scranton, PN, Yerkes graduated from Saint Benedict's Preparatory School in Newark, NJ and served in the U.S. Army from 1944 to 1946 as a counterintelligence Japanese language interpreter. At Princeton University, he majored in politics, played squash, performed with Theater Intime and the Triangle Club, and was voted "Funniest Man in the Class." Yerkes was president of Quadrangle Club and served on the Tiger Magazine Editorial Board. He graduated Magna Cum Laude in the class of 1948. His career began at Marsh & McLennan in New York. In 1979, he formed an insurance brokerage firm specializing in ocean marine insurance and reinsurance, H. E. Yerkes and Associates. He retired in 2004. With his wife Nancy, Yerkes sang with the Blue Hill Troupe, and on Fishers Island, played tennis and golf. He belonged to the Union Club, Downtown Association, Hay Harbor Club and Fishers Island Club. Until the mid-1960s, Yerkes played competitive squash for the Downtown Athletic Club on its "A" team. A newspaper reporter once asked him, to what did he attribute his rapid ascent in the league? "Being the last man to hit the ball back," he replied. Harry Yerkes was predeceased by his son, J. Nicholas Yerkes and is survived by his wife Nancy Spofford Yerkes, children Elizabeth Tyson Yerkes, Harry Estile Yerkes IV, Nathalie Yerkes George, and 12 grandchildren. Friends may call Tuesday, May 18 from 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday, May 19 at 10:30am at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th St., New York City.

OSTWALD--Lore. Student of human nature, art, music and so much more, died May 14, 2010 on the heels of the man she made whole. She is survived by sons Mordecai and David, and grandchildren Madeleine, Joseph and Olivia. Her open ears and eyes gave meaning to every moment. Contributions may be made to American Red Magen David for Israel, 352 Seventh Avenue, Suite 600, New York, NY 10001. www.afmda.org.

NURNBERG--Joseph, died May 16, 2010, age 97. A resident of New York City since his family emigrated from Budapest in 1921, he brought enthusiasm, energy and optimism to every aspect of life. A graduate of St. John's University Law School, he passionately practiced law in Manhattan for more than 60 years, the last 25 as a partner at Kane Kessler, P.C., retiring in 2003. He loved to regale his family with tales of his most challenging trials and business negotiations. Mr. Nurnberg was a founder and past President of the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale. He is survived by his adored, and adoring, wife of 66 years, Rita; his three children, Ronald (Fran Luckom-Nurnberg), Aileen (Stephen) Schreiber and Leslie (Charles) Saber; his six grandchildren, Carolyn, Jason, Jeff, Peter, Amanda and Jennifer; and his 100 year old sister, Rose Kresler. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (90th St) at 12noon on Tuesday May 18. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale 475 West 250th St, Riverdale, NY 10475.

OPPENHEIM--William Jay, passed away on May 16th, having recently celebrated his 90th birthday. We mourn the loss and honor his life. The son of the deceased Charles Jay and Marjorie Burgunder Oppenheim and brother of the late Charles Oppenheim. Devoted husband of Paula Klau Oppenheim for 60 years and loving father of Bill Jr., David, Alan and Lisa Schultz. He was a warm, proud and doting grandfather of Jocelyn, William III, Jaymie, Annie, Sadie Rose, Matthew, Mark and Margaret Oppenheim and Katherine and Reed Schultz: caring father-in-law of Ellen, Louise, Moira and Robert Schultz. Bill was born in New York City on April 21, 1920 and for almost fifty years lived in Greenwich, CT. He attended The Collegiate School and Cheshire Academy before studying at New York University School of Retailing. He served in WWll from 1942-45, rising to the rank of Captain in the Quarter Master Corps. His career began at Jay Thorpe, a prominent women's speciality store. He subsequently became vice president of The Weiss and Klau Co. Thereafter he was a General Partner with the investment firm if Wertheim & Co, and concluded his career at Smith Barney. Bill devoted over 40 years of time and energy as a member of the board of Greenwich Hospital. During his retirement, he was a dedicated volunteer in the hospital's emergency room. Bill cherished the simple pleasures of life. First and foremost, his large and loving family. His favorite pastime was boating on the Long Island Sound, often with Murphy, his gentle and ever-present Wheaton Terrier. We remember Bill with joy and sadness, a caring husband, concerned and wonderful father and grandfather. He will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Greenwich Hospital, Development office, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, Ct. 06830. A memorial service is planned for Sunday, May 23, 4:30pm at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY, 10580.

SCHUBIN--Milton J.,died May 16 at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT, which he chaired. Beloved and loving husband of Myra; father of Wendy and Eitan Haber and Peter and Rachel; grandfather of Daniel, Brian, and Jason Haber and Claire Schubin; and brother of Harriet Hughes, Naomi Greenberg, and Mark Schubin. Graduate of City College, Columbia Law School, clerk for Judge Irving Kaufman, and long-time partner at Kaye, Scholer. Active in many community and Jewish organizations, including past-President of Temple Beth El, Chappaqua, NY, the American Friends of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, American Friends of Hebrew University, Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, and the Jewish Conciliation Board of America. Lover of music and trumpet player at the Jewish Home, the Volunteer Fire Department of Old Greenwich, and the Mamaroneck Community Band. Maintained his good humor and keen intellect to the end. Funeral will be at Temple Sholom 300 E. Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT, Tuesday, May 18 at 10am. Donations can be made to The Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT.

SMITH--Ardelle. Wife of the late Gordon Dean Smith and mother of the late Douglass Dean Smith. A service will be held on Wednesday, May 19, 2010 at 11:30am at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street. DAVIS--Chermaine R. of Greenwich, CT and Jupiter, FL passed away peacefully on May 12, 2010. Chermaine was born February 23, 1929 in Mt. Horeb, WI. She was the daughter of the late Werner and Viola Ryser, beloved mother of Susan Davis, and sister of Vivian Jansen. Chermaine graduated from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL in 1950. She started as a fashion model in Chicago, appearing in ads for Marshall Field & Co. and on the cover of Seventeen magazine. In 1952 she married William H. (Bill) Davis, founder of Golf Digest magazine. In 1956 the couple moved to Greenwich. Bill eventually sold Golf Digest to the New York Times and became a senior vice president of the New York Times Co. and chairman of its magazine group. Chermaine was an avid golfer and played regularly at the Milbrook Country Club in Greenwich, CT, Jupiter Hills Golf Club in Florida and Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, NY. She was also a member of Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, CT. Chermaine was an active bridge player, artist, and traveler. Her adventurous spirit will be missed by all. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 27, at 11am at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, 1 West Putnam Ave. Greenwich. Memorial contributions may be made to Greenwich Emergency Medical Services, Inc. 111 E. Putnam Ave., Riverside, CT 06878.

NEWMAN--Jack, age 100, on May 16, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Betty, devoted father of Harvey, and Linda. Cherished grandfather of Chuck and Elysa, and Pamela. LaMOTTA--Richard. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of Richard LaMotta, Class of 1975, creator of the popular Chipwich ice cream sandwich and founder of myStudentBiz. Mr. LaMotta was an innovative businessman who gained success in a number of industries. He invented the Chipwich in 1981 and served as president and CEO of Chipwich Inc. until he sold the company in 2002. Mr. LaMotta shared his business expertise with young people as the founder, chairman, and CEO of myStudentBiz, a mentoring program that helps students finance their education by putting them into business for themselves. His most recent venture, The MD System, is an all-natural pain relief system. Mr. LaMotta attended New York Law School as an evening student, and remained a generous supporter of the School as an alumnus. The Law School is grateful for his generosity and proud of his creativity, dedication to his family, and many accomplishments. We extend our condolences to his wife Elaine, his three children, and his granddaughter. Arthur N. Abbey, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, and Richard A. Matasar, Dean and President

A map on Wednesday with an article about New York's bid to play host to the N.F.L.'s 2014 Super Bowl at New Meadowlands Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., gave an incorrect location for the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers, the proposed site of a news media center. LYNE--Eugene, 86. Passed away peacefully at home May 13 in Ocean Ridge, FL. Son of Boston, proud Marine, paterfamilias of the Lyne Clan, our Crown Prince, he will be remembered as a magnificent father, grandfather, husband, brother, and uncle; a joyful competitor and fiercely loyal protector of those he loved. We were all better people in his presence. Born Boston, MA, (1924), attended Boston Latin, Andover, Harvard College (1946) and Boston College Law School (1951). He enlisted in the Marine Corps and served in Tiensen, China. Admitted to the Mass Bar (1951) and practiced law 16 years as a partner at Lyne, Woodworth and Everts. Joined Teradyne (1967) as its first General Counsel, Treasurer and Director of international operations. Chairman of Minico Systems and later President of Lyne-Nicholson, Inc., until his retirement. He served on numerous boards in the Boston area, including the Provident Savings Bank, Faulkner Hospital, and YMCA of Greater Boston. Married for 55 years to Ruth Lally Lyne, together they had five children: Susan, Barbara, Daniel, Diana and Abigail. In addition to his children he is survived by his wife, Mary Lloyd Lyne; sister, Sheila Lyne; brother, Austin Lyne; 11 grandchildren; 13 nieces and nephews. A Mass of the Christian Burial will be held 9am Saturday, May 22 at St. Mary of the Assumption Church in Brookline, MA. Interment with Military Honors immediately following. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the YMCA of Greater Boston, 316 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

A chart on Saturday with an article about the potential risks of air bags for drivers wearing seat belts misstated the total time from the point of impact to the air bag's recoil in the example given. It would be three-tenths of a second, not three one-hundredths. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/businessday.

SCHUBIN--Milton J. With deep sorrow, Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Milton J. Schubin. Milt was recognized as one of the leading antitrust lawyers in the country and his contributions to the firm spanned forty years: he joined the firm in 1958, and became Partner in 1966. Milt was a Law Clerk to Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman (1956-57), received his LL.B. from Columbia Law School (1956), where he was Research Editor of the Law Review, and received his B.S.S. from the College of the City of New York (1953). We extend our deepest condolences to Milt's wife Myra and the rest of their wonderful family. Services will be held at Temple Shalom in Greenwich, CT on Tuesday at 10am.

This week, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut found himself in the hot seat. In fact, he received five military deferments between 1965 and 1970, when he landed a coveted spot in the Marine Reserve, which allowed him to avoid combat overseas.

"Cultures change. What is overlooked about the Crusaders, and the knights and nobility of the 10th century and thereabouts, is that they were very bloody-minded. They had been raised since infancy to devote themselves to fighting. They were very sinful. They particularly were into coveting wives. And they were very religious. The fact that these things can be combined strikes the modern mind as bizarre. But you have to deal with it if you're going to understand these people. They would commit a horrid crime, and their confessor would say, 'I don't know if you can ever get over that one. I don't know if atonement is in the books for you. But you better walk barefoot to the Holy Land and hope that that works.' And they'd go. And then come back and sin some more."

Long before the festival opened, this 5 hour 33 minute movie about the Venezuelan-born terrorist, international man of mystery and brutishly committed ladies' man, Ilich RamÃ­rez SÃ¡nchez - i.e., Carlos the Jackal - was a must-see. The movie, which screened just once, and out of competition, is scheduled to play on French television this week. It is likely to pop up in the United States this fall at the New York Film Festival before it plays on-demand and in good old-fashioned theaters.

If you've ever looked askance at a piece by the Brazilian designers Humberto and Fernando Campana and wondered what they were thinking -or what you're supposed to be thinking - you're not alone. Their new monograph, Campana Brothers: Complete Works (So Far), which is published by Rizzoli, may help explain the method behind what often seems like madness. The hefty book was published with three different covers, each of which is a different color and embellished with circular patterns that look hand stitched. "Our work is very texturized, so we wanted to bring an element of this to the book - to make it an object in itself, to make it feel handmade," Humberto explained. He likes the black cover best because it "shows the lines, the color becomes much more alive." His brother Fernando prefers the green.

Birds may prefer conventionally grown seed over organic seed, according to a new study in the Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture. Wild birds visiting more than 30 gardens across the north of England consciously chose to stick with conventional seed after eating both varieties, said Ailsa McKenzie, the study's lead author and a research associate at the School of Biology at Newcastle University.

Sadly, for me at least, the new Robin Hood movie is bereft of tights. It's got grit. It has a vibrant undertone of socioeconomic injustice. Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett are great; praise the Lord and pass the Oscar campaign. But there are no tights in this Nottingham, alas. Despite being an unapologetic old school swashbuckler, Crowe recently apologized in The Chicago Tribune, "to everybody who wants tights." They, he said, "never made sense to me you're a bloke, you live in the forest, and you wear tights?" Well, yeah, what's the problem? Tights were developed precisely by blokes on horses in forests. (They are cousins of riding breeches.) What's the worst that can happen? You pass a briar, a burr is buried and you get a run in your tights? Man up, Robin Hood, you live life on the run. Crowe should not have cowed from the challenge of tights but since he has, we've compiled some great moments of men in tights.

CANNES, France - A onetime enfant terrible and a central figure of the 1990s New Queer Cinema, Gregg Araki seemed to inaugurate a new phase of his career in 2004 with "Mysterious Skin," a tender story about two young men haunted by a formative sexual trauma. He followed that film, which many critics considered his best and most mature, with the eccentric stoner comedy "Smiley Face" (2007), which has become an underground hit on DVD.

There are not a lot of places to go for small-business advice. One of the places most frequently mentioned on this blog and in other business venues is Score, an organization that is affiliated with the Small Business Administration. If you go to the Web site, you will find that Score is a nonprofit 503c organization that was started in 1964 and has 364 offices and about 12,400 volunteers who help small businesses succeed. Its slogan is "Counselors to America's small business." If you go through the Web site, you will find an impressive board of directors, a variety of ways to get advice and lots of success stories.

Overview | How are scientific discoveries, such as the discovery of a new species, made? Have you ever wondered about the adventures of scientists working "in the field"? In this lesson, students explore their associations with the phrase "Scientist at Work," and then read the digital field notes of researchers in the field on The New York Times's new blog by the same name. Students develop questions for featured scientists by drawing on information in the text as well as their personal experiences and connections to the world around them. Finally, students apply what they learn about field research to other scientific topics of interest or their own investigations.

From my standpoint, New York City's farmers' markets are in a holding pattern, even though there's plenty to eat on the growers' stands. The subject today is bodily fluids, and their use and abuse in the theater. Blood, sweat and tears have of course been staples of world drama for centuries. What would "Macbeth" be without a few buckets of stage blood? Or Ophelia without tears, be they real or glycerine? As for sweat, well, you try standing under a ceiling of thousand-watt bulbs in full costume and keeping your powder dry. (I have been dripped upon by heavily perspiring actors in intimate environmental productions.) Add to this trio of effluvia projectile spitting, which often accompanies fierce diction in emotional scenes and can be a hazard for front-row audience members.

Photographic evidence - say, the kind of indefatigable proof that one has, in fact, visited the Great Wall of China - typically suffices as testament to having actually been there and done that. The photographer Gregory Krum (who is also the director of retail for the shop at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum) has been to the base of the Matterhorn and has seen the tombstones erected there in a climbers' cemetery. The photos he took areÂ on display as part of his first solo exhibition, "...Practice...," at Jen Bekman Gallery in SoHo. These images, along with shots of flowers, dust, still-lifes and interiors also seek to illuminate something inherently more tenuous: devotion. "The idea behind the show is those things that become true solely by belief," he says.

It wasn't a good night for Republicans. Yes, the G.O.P. can theoretically retake the House of Representatives without winning races like Pennsylvania's 12th district (which has been solidly Democratic for years, after all). But at the very least Mark Critz's relatively easy victory in yesterday's special election should throw some cold water on the more optimistic conservative visions for how this November will shake out. Yes, Pat Toomey polls almost as well against the victorious Joe Sestak as he did against against Arlen Specter. But given the mood in the country these days, I bet that Toomey would have preferred to campaign against a turncoat five-term incumbent this autumn, rather than a fresh-faced (by political standards) former rear admiral. And yes, Rand Paul will probably be the next United States senator from Kentucky - but he's clearly less of a shoo-in for the G.O.P. than Trey Grayson likely would have been, had matters been arranged differently.

The permit issued to BP by the Minerals Management Service for the well that blew out on April 20 in the Gulf of Mexico carried a notation: "Exercise caution while drilling due to indications of shallow gas and possible water flow.''

Considering how long stylish travelers have had to cart around less-than-beautiful electrical doohickeys, it's a wonder that fashion hasn't come to the rescue sooner. The Yves Saint Laurent travel adapter ($450) is a one-piece electrical dual-voltage plug adapter that connects gadget to outlet in any combination in more than 150 countries (Japanese cellphone to American outlet, German shaver to Australian socket). The circular device swivels to each region's plug, and a leather bag available in fuchsia, black and violet provides the panache.

Combine the downward trend of album sales with a week of no major releases and what do you get? The fewest number of total album sales, 5.3 million, in a single week since Nielsen SoundScan started its tracking in 1991. Topping this week's Billboard chart is Justin Bieber's "My World 2.0" (Island), its fourth time in the spot, with sales of just over 60,000, barely escaping the specter of being the lowest selling No. 1 album in SoundScan's history. (The "Dreamgirls" soundtrack sold about 300 fewer copies in January 2007.) Lady Antebellum's "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville), the year's most consistent seller, stayed at No. 2 for the fourth straight week, moving 54,000 copies.

Kickstand, a collapsible coffee stall that's wheeled around on a pair of salvaged bikes, made its public debut last Saturday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Market in McCarren, the outdoor arm of Artists and Fleas. The brainchild of Aaron Davis and Peter Castelein, both employees of Gimme! Coffee, and Neal Olson, formerly of Gimme! Coffee, Kickstand brings fresh, hand-crafted coffee to the grassy splendor of a public park. Weather permitting.

Can typing on a keyboard make coldness in the fingers feel worse? How about biking or vigorous exercise? Those are among the questions posed by readers about Raynaud's phenomenon, the mysterious ailment that causes painful feelings of coldness in the fingers and toes. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School explores the links between exercise and Raynaud's. For more information, see Dr. Wigley's earlier responses in "How Serious Is Raynaud's Phenomenon?" and "Ask the Expert: Raynaud's Phenomenon," as well as The Times Health Guide: Raynaud's.

Is the urge to exercise bred in our bones? That's the intriguing question that European researchers recently set out to examine by looking at the activity habits of 37,051 sets of twins. Twins are popular with geneticists, because they provide a neat statistical model for determining whether a behavior is influenced by genetics or exclusively by environment. Identical twins share 100 percent of their genome, fraternal twins share 50 percent. All twin pairs, if raised together, share approximately the same early environment. So if a behavior is more common between identical twins than between fraternal twins, it is presumably being directed to some degree by genes.

FREEDMAN--Millicent (nee Fidler) of Rockville Centre, NY died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on Sunday, May 16th. She is survived by her loving husband Herbert of 63 years, her children Robert (Ann), Wendy (Jed), James (Holly), and her four adoring grandchildren Jessica, Joanna, Isaiah and Roy. Millicent was a woman of grace and style. She loved art, theatre, fashion and design, read avidly and was socially active. Most of all she cherished her family and legion of friends. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am Tuesday, May 18th at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516-295-3100). In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Millicent's memory to: Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medical College, 425 E. 61st Street, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10065.

RAFAH, Gaza -- Nidal Eid was praised by Hamas officials as an example of anti-Zionist resistance when he managed to build a house here last year despite an Israeli blockade that barred the import of any building materials. But earlier this week, his house was the first to be demolished by the Hamas government, which said it had been illegally built on public land. Bulldozers, accompanied by Hamas forces and police officers who beat residents with sticks, razed at least 25 houses, including some concrete structures here in Rafah, the southernmost city of Gaza.

Talk about being late with your census forms. Curators at Kean University in New Jersey recently found a population count of the United States from an ''actual enumeration'' conducted at least four years before the country's first official census in 1790. The handwritten tally was found among the papers of John Kean, a delegate to the 1787 Constitutional Convention, which met in Philadelphia and gave birth to the Constitution. A central issue delegates tackled was how to configure a new Congress that would more fairly represent the disparate populations of the 13 states. Kean was later appointed by President George Washington as the first cashier, in essence president, of the Bank of the United States.

HAUSER--Baron Bernhard Dominik, 97, died of heart failure on May 12, 2010, following a brief illness. Predeceased by his wife Elisabeth in 1995, he is survived by his daughter, Beatrix, and son-in-law, Gregor Medinger. Born on July 17, 1912 in Vienna, Austria, he graduated from the Theresianum Academy and came to America on a scholarship to attend Rollins College. Following graduation '36, he embarked on a 41 year career as an executive at IBM, with postings in Bucharest, New York, and Brussels at his retirement. A lifelong avid sportsman, his discipline, energy, optimism, and marvelous sense of humor helped him survive five years of incarceration as a political prisoner in Communist Rumania, and he was an inspiration to all who had the privilege of knowing him. A memorial service will be held at the end of August in Austria. In lieu of flowers, kindly direct contributions to the foreign student scholarship fund at Rollins College, 1000 Holt Avenue, Winter Park, FL.

Hank Jones, the legendary jazz pianist, led an oddly bifurcated existence toward the end of his 91 years on earth. He stayed active till the very end, collecting a Grammy last year and touring the world. But when he wasn't on the road, he lived in near isolation in a 12-by-12-foot room at 108th Street and Broadway, ordering in three meals a day from the diner downstairs and practicing incessantly on an electric keyboard plugged into headphones.

BAUMAN--Judah, MD, died on May 16 at age 82. Dr. Bauman was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Jersey Homesteads, a cooperative factory and farming community established in 1936. He served in the U.S. Army in Japan from 1946-1947 in a microbiology laboratory. Judah Bauman was graduated from Rutgers University and Hahnemann Medical School in Philadelphia. Following residency at Brooklyn's Maimonides Hospital, he established his medical practice in obstetrics and gynecology in Commack and Huntington, NY. Dr. Bauman was a physician of the old school, treating each patient as an individual. A devoted father, grandfather and husband, he was married to the former Rhoda Wexelman for 57 years. He was an avid traveler, photographer, gardener and reader. Judah Bauman is survived by his wife, Rhoda, his son David Bauman and daughter-in-law Amy Cohen Bauman, his daughter Jennifer Bauman Crosson and son-in-law Dan Crosson, and his loving grandchildren Sam, William and Rachel. A memorial service will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY at 11am on Thursday, May 20, with interment immediately following at Mt. Eden Cemetery, 20 Commerce Street, Hawthorne, NY. Donations in memoriam may be sent to The Jewish National Fund, 78 Randall Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570

PHILADELPHIA -- Just because the Canadiens took three times more shots in the first period than the Philadelphia Flyers did not mean Montreal had a better chance to win Tuesday. Michael Leighton was in goal for the Flyers, and he calmly withstood barrage after barrage. Aided by a defensive corps that helped prevent second chances, Leighton stopped all 16 shots in the first period -- and 30 over all -- to boost the Flyers to a 3-0 victory and a two-games-to-none lead in the Eastern Conference finals.

ATLANTA -- In their almost 50 years of existence, the Mets have had more knuckleheads than knuckleballers, but the gap will be closed slightly Wednesday when R. A. Dickey throws his version of the pitch for the Mets against the Washington Nationals. He will supply the unpredictable pitch and the glove that will catch it. Virtually every knuckleball pitcher is expected to supply the oversize glove that catchers usually use to receive the pitch, and Dickey, who is starting in place of Oliver Perez, is no exception.

SLATTERY--Thomas J.,on May 14, 2010 of Baldwin, NY, formerly Merrick, NY. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Esterkamp. Dear father of Mark Liam Slattery. Former husband of Cindy Slattery. Retired editor and publisher of National Underwriter. A prolific writer, reader and loved to travel. A Vietnam era Army veteran discharged as 1st LT. Memorial visitation N.F. Walker, Inc., 2039 Merrick Avenue, Saturday May 22 from 9-11am. Funeral Mass at Cure of Ars R.C., 2323 Merrick Ave., Saturday, May 22 at 11:30am. By now, every theatergoer on Broadway has heard of the Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Jojo Kuo, 50, an Afropop drummer from Cameroon, played with Fela - twice. He shared his recollections with Ozier Muhammad for the seventh installment of ''Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.'' His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity. I met Fela in 1979 in Lagos, Nigeria, on a gig there. When I first tried to play with Fela, I didn't know exactly what was going on with the music. I couldn't get it psychologically, and the language was difficult because it was a pidgin English. So I often would get fined for my mistakes.

GARTNER--Audrey Joseph, died May 16 in New York City, age 74. Audrey graduated from Antioch College with a BA and Wellesley College with a MA. Audrey retired from her positions as Director of the New York Self-Help Clearinghouse and as Managing Editor of Social Policy Magazine. Audrey served as Chair of the Northport, School Board. She is survived by her devoted children Jonathan (Pam), Rachel (Suzanne Seay), and Daniel. She was a loving grandmother to Eleanor and Simon, Henry and Charlie, and Spencer. Survived by her brother Hal (Mary Angela) Joseph, her sister Sheila (Les) Groynom, her dear friend Marge Hendler and many others. A memorial service will be held later.

LILLIENSTEIN--Maxwell J.,beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, passed away peacefully on May 13th at his home, in Boynton Beach, Florida. He was a graduate of City College (CCNY) and Columbia Law School. A prominent Constitutional Law attorney, partner in a New York City law firm, and General Counsel to the American Booksellers Association, he submitted briefs as amicus curiae in several important First Amendment cases decided by the United States Supreme Court. He was an active member of the Freedom To Read Committee, and frequent author of articles on the First Amendment and antitrust issues affecting the bookselling industry. He served as Village Trustee and Village Attorney for the Village of Ardsley, New York, and served on the Board of Directors of Indian Spring Country Club, Inc. in Boynton Beach, Florida. He was a loving husband to his late wife Janet. He is survived by his sister Bernice Hogan, his sons Steven and Robert, his daughter Carol Kizer, and five grandchildren.

PARIS -- A day after Tehran freed a young French academic accused of spying, France prepared on Monday to release an Iranian serving a life sentence for assassinating an exiled former Iranian prime minister, Shapour Bakhtiar, in August 1991. French and Iranian authorities denied any quid pro quo, but the timing was considered suspicious by French opposition legislators and the French media.

If you wake up to WINS-AM (1010) every morning, you may have noticed an adjustment this week in the staccato clacking of xylophones and teletype keys that has been the all-news radio station's sonic trademark since the 1970s. On Monday, a more musical lead-in to each 20-minute news cycle was introduced. The sound is more tonal than teletype.

He was an irreverent teenager with a pregnant girlfriend when the idea first crossed his mind: Join the Army, raise a family. She had an abortion, but the idea remained. Patrick S. Fitzgibbon, Saint Paddy to his friends, became Private Fitzgibbon. Three months out of basic training, he went to war. From his outpost in the Kandahar Province of Afghanistan, he complained to his father about shortages of cigarettes, Skittles and Mountain Dew. But he took pride in his work and volunteered for patrols. On Aug. 1, 2009, while on one of those missions, Private Fitzgibbon stepped on a metal plate wired to a bomb buried in the sunbaked earth. The blue sky turned brown with dust.

OPPENHEIM--William Jay, passed away on May 16th, having recently celebrated his 90th birthday. We mourn the loss and honor his life. The son of the deceased Charles Jay and Marjorie Burgunder Oppenheim and brother of the late Charles Oppenheim. Devoted husband of Paula Klau Oppenheim for 60 years and loving father of Bill Jr., David, Alan and Lisa Schultz. He was a warm, proud and doting grandfather of Jocelyn, William III, Jaymie, Annie, Sadie Rose, Matthew, Mark and Margaret Oppenheim and Katherine and Reed Schultz: caring father-in-law of Ellen, Louise, Moira and Robert Schultz. Bill was born in New York City on April 21, 1920 and for almost fifty years lived in Greenwich, CT. He attended The Collegiate School and Cheshire Academy before studying at New York University School of Retailing. He served in WWll from 1942-45, rising to the rank of Captain in the Quarter Master Corps. His career began at Jay Thorpe, a prominent women's speciality store. He subsequently became vice president of The Weiss and Klau Co. Thereafter he was a General Partner with the investment firm if Wertheim & Co, and concluded his career at Smith Barney. Bill devoted over 40 years of time and energy as a member of the board of Greenwich Hospital. During his retirement, he was a dedicated volunteer in the hospital's emergency room. Bill cherished the simple pleasures of life. First and foremost, his large and loving family. His favorite pastime was boating on the Long Island Sound, often with Murphy, his gentle and ever-present Wheaton Terrier. We remember Bill with joy and sadness, a caring husband, concerned and wonderful father and grandfather. He will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Greenwich Hospital, Development office, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, Ct. 06830. A memorial service is planned for Sunday, May 23, 4:30pm at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY, 10580.

We will miss Burt's presence on our campus. Our deepest sympathy to Rita and her family. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

KAMAIKO--Emanuel (aka Manny), age 98, died peacefully at his Chelsea home on May 17, 2010. Husband of Florence (nee Geller); father of Toni, Wendy and Laurie; father-in-law of Frank R. Solano and Anthony Hairston; grandfather of Ian Solano-Kamaiko and uncle to many nieces and nephews. He was a resident of New York City since he emigrated with his family from Poland after World War I. Manny worked for the NYC Housing Authority and was a professional photographer. He volunteered many years of his life to civil rights groups and unions. A wonderful man Manny was supportive of progressive causes. He is remembered by his loving and extended family and many friends of all ages. A Memorial Service will be announced. Please make donations to the International Essential Tremor Foundation in his name (essentialtremor.org). The family is receiving friends and family at the home of Laurie Kamaiko and Tony Hairston at 132 E. 35th Street on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 3 to 8 pm.

INTERNATIONAL An article on May 10 about spending on AIDS misstated the size of the United States' contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. Over the past six years it has amounted to 27 to 31 percent of worldwide contributions, not one-third. And a chart with the article, comparing an advocacy group's projections for spending authorized under a 2008 federal law and under a more modest plan from the Obama administration, labeled the figures incorrectly. The figures were for total federal spending on foreign aid to combat AIDS -- not just for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, known as Pepfar.

There were, in hindsight, plenty of reasons for the admissions office at Harvard to be suspicious of Adam Wheeler. When Mr. Wheeler, now 23, applied as a transfer student in 2007, for example, he sent along fabricated transcripts from Phillips Andover Academy and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In fact, he had graduated from a public high school in Delaware and had attended Bowdoin College, in Maine.

ZILUCA--Tony Garibaldi, 80, died May 15th. Born in Greenwich, CT to the late Joseph and Josephine Garibaldi Ziluca September 26, 1929. He was the great-grandson of Giuseppe Garibaldi, liberator of Italy. Mr. Ziluca had a successful 23 year career on Wall Street as a floor broker with Bache & Company. When he retired in 1981, he was Sr. Vice President and head floor broker. Tony is survived by his brother, his five children and 12 grandchildren. A memorial reception will be held on Friday May 21st at 4pm at Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich CT. A private burial is planned.

SCHMUTZ--Roger Clayton, died on Monday, May 17, at the age of 77 in Naples, FL, after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Mr. Schmutz, son of Charles A. and Helen R. Schmutz, was born in New York City. After graduating from Bates College (Maine), he earned a masters degree from the Columbia School of Journalism. He started out as a reporter at the Worcester Telegram-Gazette (MA) and soon moved to Standard and Poor's where over 26 years he rose to Group Vice President for Financial Publishing. He retired in 1982 and moved to the Maine coast. Mr. Schmutz served on the board of trustees of Bates College for 31 years, playing various roles including Secretary of the Corporation. In 2004, he was awarded Helen A. Papaioanou '49 Distinguished Alumni Service Award for his extraordinary service to Bates. His love of the school is reflected in his quote on the college web site, "the Bates attitude is, if you want to do it, do it! Do it with passion and enthusiasm, and if you develop talent and excellence, you will succeed, without feeling fettered by convention or attitude." For many years Roger and his wife, Elizabeth, enjoyed wintering in Marco Island, FL. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth (Fleet), his daughter Anne and her husband Donald Hovey his granddaughter Lila. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Bates College, Lewiston, ME 04240-6028 (www.bates.edu) or 1-888-522-8371.

CONKLIN, Alberta -- Beneath the subarctic forests of western Canada, deep under the peat bogs and herds of wild caribou, lies the tarry rock that is one of America's top sources of imported oil. There is no chance of a rig blowout here, or a deepwater oil spill like the one from the BP well that is now fouling the Gulf of Mexico. But the oil extracted from Canada's oil sands poses other environmental challenges, like toxic sludge ponds, greenhouse gas emissions and the destruction of boreal forests.

BREIER--Marcus I.,97, former Mayor of Amsterdam, NY, former President of one of the largest men's outerwear companies in America and major force in the men's apparel business for decades, died Saturday, May 15, at his home in Miami, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, November 2, 1912, he was son of the late Benjamin and Golda (Stern) Breier. Known as "Pop" to his loving six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren, he is also survived by wife of over 68 years, Eleanore (Cramer) Breier, his sons, Robert G. Breier, Richard Breier and his wife, Alyson, and his daughter, Joan Brodsky and her husband, William. A 1934 graduate of Cornell University, receiving a Bachelor of Science, he was also a 1936 graduate of the Cornell School of Law and Treasurer of the Class of 1934 Alumni. He was CEO of Breier of Amsterdam, Inc., and its forerunner, Marcus Breier & Sons, Inc., a manufacturer under the internationally known trade name of "Bantamac". The company was formed in 1898 by his grandfather also named Marcus. Mr. Breier began his professional career as an attorney in NYC, after which he followed his father into the outerwear apparel manufacturing business, and played a significant part in its growth. He built a company that supplied the military with flying jackets in WWII and the wars that followed. In 1963, Mr. Breier entered politics and was elected Mayor of Amsterdam, beginning his term in 1964. While Mayor, Mr. Breier, was the first public official to recognize the need for urban renewal. His alliance with former Congressman Samuel Stratton and former Governor Nelson Rockefeller, led to a substantial expenditure of funds in Amsterdam for urban renewal. Services at Congregation Sons of Israel Synagogue, Guy Park Avenue, Amsterdam, NY. Burial in Temple of Israel Cemetery, Cranesville, NY. Contributions in Mr. Breier's memory can be sent to: Breier Fund, Congregation Sons of Israel, 355 Guy Park Avenue, Amsterdam, NY 12010.

OBITUARIES An obituary in some copies on May 9 about Walter J. Hickel, the former governor of Alaska and United States secretary of the interior, included several errors. Mr. Hickel graduated from Claflin High School in Kansas; he was not a high school dropout. The 1994 book ''The Wit and Wisdom of Wally Hickel'' was a collection of quotations from Mr. Hickel, not his autobiography. After being dismissed as interior secretary and returning to Alaska, he ran for governor four more times, not three. And while a federal judge did initially reject an agreement proposed by Governor Hickel to drop all state and federal lawsuits against Exxon in the Valdez oil spill case in exchange for the company's paying for cleanup and restoration, a revised version of that agreement was later accepted.

According to Patrick Parrish, the co-founder of the inspired TriBeCa design gallery Mondo Cane, that's what people say when they find themselves pulled into the strange and luminous world of the Viennese designer Carl AubÃ¶ck (1900-57). A master of elemental materials like brass, leather, wood and horn, AubÃ¶ck had a flair for exquisitely turned curios - paperweights, corkscrews, pipe holders - that still exert a magnetic pull, as the 300 or so objects now on view at Mondo Cane amply attest.

For my parents' 50th wedding anniversary, our family went to Ireland to discover our roots and had the best sleep of our lives in a little town in County Sligo. Ten years later, we're still talking about that incredible night. Forget the windblown scenery, the pink salmon, the monastic ruins and the wild swans at Coole. Forget my daredevil sister practically dangling off the Cliffs of Moher. "Remember that sleep," we say, shaking our heads. "Wasn't it just amazing?"

The summer fighting season has returned to southern Afghanistan, which means the Obama administration's and Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal's counterinsurgency effort here will face some of its most difficult tests. Our school district's budget passed this week, as did 92 percent of those in New York State, but it is a shell of its former self. While my tax rate will increase about 3 percent under the new budget, the district will actually decrease its spending by 1.1 percent, leading to the dismissal of seven teachers and 34 aides and assistants. The cuts come in the wake of the $1.4 billion the state plans to cut from the education budget, leading districts to cut their own.

Astoria, perhaps best known as the Mediterranean hub of Queens, brims with life on warm evenings, as the cafes flicker with lights and laughter fills the streets. There are pockets of Greeks and Arabs in the area, women rustle by covered head to toe in burqas, and some of the buildings are painted white and turquoise, just like the island houses of the Aegean. But hurry. The neighborhood - just 15 minutes from Midtown on the N or W line - is changing as other ethnic groups arrive and chain stores supplant little shops.

Marco Velardi, Omar Sosa and Nacho Alegre, the trio of twenty-somethings behind the Milan- and Barcelona-based indie design magazine Apartamento have a flair for celebrating the reality of everyday life. And for just plain celebrating. The magazine is an invitingly DIY affair, and so was Tasca, Apartamento's three-night pop-up food event at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which, true to form, seemed to take its cue from an inescapable reality of all design fairs: that while it's stimulating to take in the latest Kartell creation or to shake hands with a Bouroullec, the most pressing issue on everyone's overloaded mind - particularly after a forced march through an arena-sized exhibition hall - isn't rapid prototyping or just how post postmodernism is. It's dinner: Where it's going to happen, when and with whom.

A judge issued a warrant for Lindsay Lohan's arrest and set bail at $100,000 on Thursday after the actress failed to show up for a mandatory court hearing in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan had gone to Cannes for the film festival there and, according to her lawyer, Shawn Chapman Holley, her passport was stolen, preventing her from returning to the United States in time for her hearing. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court also revoked Ms. Lohan's probation, which she had been on after two arrests in 2007 on charges of drunken driving. Mr. Holley said Ms. Lohan would be back in the United States by Friday evening. If she makes bail, the judge has stipulated that she will be prohibited from drinking alcohol and required to wear an alcohol monitoring bracelet and undergo weekly drug testing.

CANNES, France - As the title suggests, "The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu" is hardly a conventional historical documentary. Andrei Ujica's three-hour-plus found-footage epic, screening out of competition at the Cannes Film Festival, recounts the life of the Romanian dictator as Ceausescu himself saw it - or, as was often the case, stage-managed it. Devoid of explanatory titles and voice-overs, the film assembles a composite portrait of Ceausescu solely through the existing visual record: the speeches he gave, the parades thrown in his honor, the state visits he made (to the United States, China, Britain and, most memorably, North Korea) and the home movies of family vacations and hunting expeditions.

Bad news for those who were hoping to see a new theatrical work by the Georgian puppeteer Rezo Gabriadze at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer. However, there is a silver lining: to replace the canceled show, Mr. Gabriadze's company, the Tbilisi Municipal Theater Studio, will revive a past work, "The Battle of Stalingrad," about the Nazi siege. WASHINGTON -- James E. Burnett Jr., who, as chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board in the 1980s, led a campaign against drunken driving and fought to curb drug and alcohol use by railroad workers a, died Saturday at a hospice in Clinton, Ark., his hometown. He was 62. The cause was complications of diabetes, said his mother, Hazel Burnett.

Back in 1960, Barbra Streisand -- then still Barbara -- was 18 and unable to find acting work when a friend told her about a weekly talent contest at the Lion, a gay club in the West Village. Uninterested in singing but hungry, she gave it a try, as much for the free dinner (they had a great London broil, she recalls) as for the paid gig that came with placing first. She won that prize, a standing ovation and her first big break. Like so many of the city's legendary nightspots, the Lion disappeared, replaced by a series of other restaurants on the ground floor of a brownstone on Ninth Street. It reopened last week, as a tavern and restaurant whose owners have labored to restore the spirit of its early-1960s heyday.

If you're looking for an activity for your children or grandchildren, you might try geocaching, a treasure-hunting game played by using GPS devices to find hidden containers, or geocaches, outdoors and then sharing the experiences online. A typical geocache treasure is an inexpensive but intriguing object, like a tiny Rubik's cube, a postcard or a coin from a different country. Sometimes the caches contain a Travel Bug with a code that can be tracked, so you can see where it's been. Groundspeak, which creates location-based technology and has commercialized geocaching, offers a free iPhone app, Geocaching Intro. But if you don't have an iPhone, there is Apishere's Geomate.jr, a $70 hand-held GPS receiver that can lead a child to one of 250,000 geocache locations in the United States, preloaded in memory from Groundspeak's database.

The construction maze around Lincoln Center will become a lot more navigable on Friday, when several areas will be opened to the public. Visitors can once again use the Grand Stair, the primary entry from Columbus Avenue, which will now have informational LED displays; the new Benenson Grove, which allows access from 62nd Street; and the Jaffe Drive/Toll Porte-cochere, a fancy name for a driveway. The new spaces are part of Lincoln Center's $1.2 billion renovation, which began in 2006 and is scheduled to be completed in the next two years, according to center officials. To celebrate, Lincoln Center will host a party on Friday from noon to 3 p.m., with free lemonade, gelato and ticket giveaways to summer programs.

Norman Hand, a defensive tackle who played for five National Football League teams and helped the 2000 New Orleans Saints gain the first playoff victory in their history, died Friday in Walterboro, S.C. He was 37. The cause was cardiovascular disease, said Richard M. Harvey, the Colleton County coroner. He said that Hand had an enlarged heart resulting from high blood pressure. He collapsed at his home in Walterboro and died at a hospital soon afterward.

SLAVIN--Catherine Ferris. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Slavin, loving mother of Constance, Deborah and Jean and grandmother of Kristin, Erin, Patrick, Brendan, Ryan and Timothy, sister of the late Helen F. Neary, the late Nancy F. McHale and Miriam F. Walsh. Born and raised in New York City, she died peacefully in her home in Tuckahoe, NY on May 18, 2010. She led an exemplary life and will be greatly missed by those who knew and loved her. We will remember the extraordinary love, kindness, compassion and consideration that she bestowed on all who came in contact with her throughout her life. Calling Hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY from 3pm to 9pm on Friday May 21st. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Saturday May 22nd at 10am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her name to the St. Jean Baptiste Scholarship Fund. It will be a financial aid scholarship for this all girls Catholic high school in Manhattan. (www.stjean.org)

Hedge funds have found a new market to invest in: whistle-blowers. Informants who turn in tax cheats have to wait years to get their share of any reward from the I.R.S.'s recently expanded whistle-blower program. So hedge funds, private equity groups and other big investors are offering an alternative. They are essentially agreeing to buy a percentage of those future payouts in exchange for a smaller amount upfront to the whistle-blowers.

The Board of Trustees of Long Beach Medical Center records with profound sorrow, the passing of Eleanor Portnof, a benefactor of the Medical Center and the mother of James Portnof, a senior vice president of the Board. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jim and to his entire family. Alfred I. Osterland Chairman, Board of Trustees Bernard Kennedy President, Board of Trustees Douglas L. Melzer Chief Executive Officer

Tivoli Audio, a maker of high-end table radios, is celebrating its 10th year in business with a new clock radio that's clad in aluminum, the material from which traditional first-decade anniversary gifts are made. Actually, the aluminum casing is faux, covering the so-called Model 10's furniture-grade wood, because real metal would present serious challenges to radio reception. The new radio also will be available in a range of other finishes, including one that mimics the irregularity of natural wood grain and one that is frost white, a glossy finish achieved with nine layers of lacquer.

Roggenburg Sr. who was founding member and sixth president of the Security Traders Association of New York City and the former Chairman of the Board of Deltec Securities New York City. Survived by wife Janet, three daughters, four grandchildren. Please visit Stanley's memorial website at johnedayfuneralhome.com

Just in time for Bike-to-Work Week, May 17 to 21, Google has added bicycling directions to its Maps application. The app allows you to get navigation for bikes in a couple of different ways.

Perhaps no day in the life of Guns N' Roses is complete without news of both a new ''vook'' and a mud-slinging lawsuit. Axl Rose has filed a $5 million lawsuit against his former manager, Irving Azoff, saying that he sabotaged sales of Guns N' Roses' comeback album and lied about a potential ''super tour'' with Van Halen (which Mr. Azoff manages) as part of a plan to force Mr. Rose to reunite with his estranged former band members.

ARAKAWA--Shusaku. We mourn the loss of our friend, the dedicated and always surprising artist Arakawa. Through the years, his work has sought to convey the idea of a Reversible Destiny. All of us at our galleries will miss him. Ronald and Frayda Feldman, Marian Goodman

KAMAIKO--Emanuel (aka Manny), age 98, died peacefully at his Chelsea home on May 17, 2010. Husband of Florence (nee Geller); father of Toni, Wendy and Laurie; father-in-law of Frank R. Solano and Anthony Hairston; grandfather of Ian Solano-Kamaiko and uncle to many nieces and nephews. He was a resident of New York City since he emigrated with his family from Poland after World War I. Manny worked for the NYC Housing Authority and was a professional photographer. He volunteered many years of his life to civil rights groups and unions. A wonderful man Manny was supportive of progressive causes. He is remembered by his loving and extended family and many friends of all ages. A Memorial Service will be announced. Please make donations to the International Essential Tremor Foundation in his name (essentialtremor.org). The family is receiving friends and family at the home of Laurie Kamaiko and Tony Hairston at 132 E. 35th Street on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 3 to 8 pm.

A news analysis article on May 4 about the severity of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, using information from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, misstated the amount of oil that was spilled in 1991 into the Persian Gulf by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. The agency now puts the figure at 252 million to 336 million gallons -- not 36 billion gallons, as it initially estimated.

HASCOE--Suzanne. This is in memory of Suzanne Hascoe, who passed away Friday, May 14. For more than 20 years our memories have been a wonderful blend of fun and laughter, joy and sometimes sorrow, but always better because of each other. We will miss you, but remain enriched by the relationship we have shared and will always treasure. Love to your great family. Einbender and Silverstein families

An article on Wednesday about the United States' increasing reliance on petroleum from Canadian oil sands misidentified the party affiliation of Senator Jon Tester of Montana, who likened the safety waivers being granted to pipelines from Canada to waivers granted to offshore oil wells. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

GOLDBERG--Burton A.,May 18, 2010, World War II Veteran, aged 86. Survived by Rita Goldberg, his wife of 61 years, and children Andrew, Suzan, Joshua and Mitchell, and grandchildren Martin, Jonathan, Mollie, Scott, Alexander and Elizabeth. He was involved in the real estate business in New York, and in his retirement became a patron of the performing arts, especially in the field of dramatic writing, with involvements at NYU Tisch School of the Arts, Hunter College, The Lark Theatre Company, and The Jewish Museum. He also served on the board of The Academy of American Poets. Known for his lively sense of humor, he combined remarkable savvy as a businessman with a poetic spirit. He was a man of considerable substance. Memorial service to be held on Friday, May 21, 1:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

Devoted grandfather of Brittlyn, Spencer, Abigail and Casey. Services: Friday, May 21, 2010 at 9:30am, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Combine the downward trend of album sales with a week of no major releases and what do you get? The fewest number of total album sales, 5.3 million, in a single week since Nielsen SoundScan started its tracking in 1991. Topping this week's Billboard chart is Justin Bieber's ''My World 2.0'' (Island), its fourth time in the spot, with sales of just over 60,000, barely escaping the specter of being the lowest selling No. 1 album in SoundScan's history. (The ''Dreamgirls'' soundtrack sold about 300 fewer copies in January 2007.) Lady Antebellum's ''Need You Now'' (Capitol Nashville), the year's most consistent seller, stayed at No. 2 for the fourth straight week, moving 54,000 copies. The top new album was ''High Violet'' (4AD) from the National, selling 51,000 copies, good enough for No. 3. Other new releases in the top 10 were Dead Weather's ''Sea of Cowards'' ( Warner Bros. ), and Charice's self-titled album (Reprise). ''The Oracle'' (Universal Republic), by the metal band Godsmack, dropped from its top spot last week down to No. 9, with sales of 43,000, 63 percent less than the week before. ''While there's a lot of talk of declining album sales, a number of highly anticipated albums are scheduled for release in the next few months and we expect sales to trend upward,'' Eric Weinberg, president Nielsen Entertainment, said in a statement.

BURTON--John C. Columbia Business School mourns the loss of Professor Emeritus John C. "Sandy" Burton, who served as dean from 1982 to 1988. An alumnus of both the MBA and PhD programs, Professor Burton joined the faculty in 1962, and later worked as chief accountant of the SEC and deputy mayor of finance for New York City. In 1997, he was inducted into the Accounting Hall of Fame. Professor Burton had a powerful and lasting impact on Columbia Business School, and heartfelt condolences go out to his wife of more than 50 years, Jane Burton, his two children and his six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University on June 17 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests donations to the JCB Memorial Fund at Columbia Business School. For information, contact Rebekkah Brown at 212-854-3427.

She is survived by her children, Janet, Robert, Andrew, and James, her mother Janet Kramer, sister Ann Ross, and husband Mark. A memorial service is planned.

An article on Monday about two journeyman forwards who are trying to make the United States soccer team referred imprecisely to the source of the given names in the family of Herculez Gomez, one of the players. While he, his brother Ulysses and his other siblings take their names from Greek mythology, each was not named after a Greek god.

The producers of the Broadway-bound ''Scottsboro Boys'' musical plan to begin performances in October at the Lyceum Theater, shortly after the show concludes an out-of-town run at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, according to Barry Weissler, one of the lead producers. While noting that plans could change, Mr. Weissler said in a phone interview that he and his colleagues believed the Beaux Arts style of the 107-year-old Lyceum -and its relatively intimate size for a musical, with 902 seats - with ''a good fit for a show that takes place in the 1930s and tells a story of rich history.'' With music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb (''Cabaret,'' ''Chicago''), the musical centers on a group of black men who are convicted in Alabama on false charges of raping two white women.

FRIEDMAN--Edith, 84, died peacefully in New York City on May 19. She is survived by her devoted daughter Susan Oppenheim and son-in-law Stanley Oppenheim; and two beloved grandchildren Daniel and Joshua Oppenheim who were immeasurably enriched by her deep involvement in their lives. Born in Kralovsky Chlmec, Czechoslovakia in 1925, she was a victim of the Holocaust, surviving internment in Auschwitz. She returned from the camps at the age of 19 having lost her entire family. Her life was marked by a wonderful 62-year marriage to Herman Friedman who died in December 2008. Known to an extended network of family and friends as "Emma" she dedicated her life to love and care for those around her. Services will be held Friday at 9:45am, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th St. Contributions in Emma's memory can be made to The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, Attn: Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471, a wonderful institution that cared for her with dignity in the last months of her life.

An obituary on Friday about the Cuban percussionist Francisco Aguabella misattributed a quotation about Mr. Aguabella. The description was not by Les Blank, the director of that film. (The quotation was taken from Mr. Blank's Web site, where it appears without attribution.)

A dance review on Wednesday about American Ballet Theater's 70th anniversary gala, at the Metropolitan Opera House, misidentified the act in ''Lady of the Camellias'' from which a pas de deux was performed. It was Act III, not Act II.

BREIER--Marcus I.,97, former Mayor of Amsterdam, NY, former President of one of the largest men's outerwear companies in America and major force in the men's apparel business for decades, died Saturday, May 15, at his home in Miami, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, November 2, 1912, he was son of the late Benjamin and Golda (Stern) Breier. Known as "Pop" to his loving six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren, he is also survived by wife of over 68 years, Eleanore (Cramer) Breier, his sons, Robert G. Breier, Richard Breier and his wife, Alyson, and his daughter, Joan Brodsky and her husband, William. A 1934 graduate of Cornell University, receiving a Bachelor of Science, he was also a 1936 graduate of the Cornell School of Law and Treasurer of the Class of 1934 Alumni. He was CEO of Breier of Amsterdam, Inc., and its forerunner, Marcus Breier & Sons, Inc., a manufacturer under the internationally known trade name of "Bantamac". The company was formed in 1898 by his grandfather also named Marcus. Mr. Breier began his professional career as an attorney in NYC, after which he followed his father into the outerwear apparel manufacturing business, and played a significant part in its growth. He built a company that supplied the military with flying jackets in WWII and the wars that followed. In 1963, Mr. Breier entered politics and was elected Mayor of Amsterdam, beginning his term in 1964. While Mayor, Mr. Breier, was the first public official to recognize the need for urban renewal. His alliance with former Congressman Samuel Stratton and former Governor Nelson Rockefeller, led to a substantial expenditure of funds in Amsterdam for urban renewal. Services at Congregation Sons of Israel Synagogue, Guy Park Avenue, Amsterdam, NY. Burial in Temple of Israel Cemetery, Cranesville, NY. Contributions in Mr. Breier's memory can be sent to: Breier Fund, Congregation Sons of Israel, 355 Guy Park Avenue, Amsterdam, NY 12010.

An article on Wednesday about R. A. Dickey and former knuckleball pitchers for the Mets misspelled the surnames of two of them in some copies. They are Bob Moorhead, not Moorehead, and Rich Sauveur, not Saveur.

HASCOE--Suzanne Vertun, passed away on Friday, May 14, 2010 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. She was predeceased by her husband of 52 years, Norman Hascoe. She is survived by her beloved children: Stephanie and Mark, Lloyd and Abbe, Andrew and Stacey, and her nine grandchildren. Suzanne was a former biochemist in cancer research. She worked for the Burroughs Welcome Company, which under a grant from Sloan Kettering, developed the first chemotherapy drug for treating childhood leukemia. She worked directly for the scientists who received the Nobel Prize for this breakthrough medical treatment. Reflecting her interests in art, antiques and medicine, she was a member of the Chairman's Council as well as a Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She also sat on the Board of The Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Connecticut and was an Associate Member of the Board of the Whitehead Institute for Genetic Research at MIT. In 1955 she married Norman Hascoe and worked closely with him as they started a business that manufactured advanced materials and other high technology components for the semiconductor industry. The company, Semi-Alloys Inc., was sold to Allied Signal Corp. in 1983. She will be remembered by family and friends for her keen intellect, engaging personality, incredibly warm smile, elegant taste and exquisite style. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Thoracic Research Fund Attention: Vincent A. Miller, M.D., 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

CANNES, France- On Thursday, the day after "Carlos" had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, I was surprised to learn it had been shot on 35 millimeter film. Here's why: Directed by Olivier Assayas, the film is a 5-hour, 33-minute portrait of the terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. It will be shown on French television this week and is scheduled to open in the United States in the fall. It's a fascinating work about an uninteresting brutish historical figure and I haven't stopped thinking about it since I saw it. The thin visual quality of the images and occasional tell-tale splotches of yellow in white images strongly suggested that we were looking at a movie that had been shot in digital, perhaps with the RED, the camera which Steven Soderbergh used to shoot "Che," his movie about Che Guevara, which played at Cannes in 2008.

The latest travel issue of T magazine starts off nice and easy - just the way summer's supposed to be. For the cover story, we get lost in time in Portugal's sun-soaked Alentejo region. Then we head to the quiet coastline of Dorset, England, and to the shores of Lake Michigan for a classic American summer sojourn. We're big on tradition this season, and you'll find us visiting old-fashioned country ham makers in Kentucky and Tennessee, an expertly restored 18th-century palace hotel in India, and a vintage kids' camp in France that's been transformed into a chic retreat. We also lay out an insider's guide to Napa Valley, that blue-chip destination right here at home - but we don't shy away from places on the edge: The souks of Damascus get a thorough exploration, and we party till the sun comes up in the buzzing nightlife capital of BogotÃ¡.

Since we're talking about core inflation lately, I should give a shoutout to recent work by Bryan and Meyer. In my post on core inflation, I explained the Platonic ideal of what we're trying to measure: it's prices that aren't revised often, and are therefore set with future inflation in mind. The standard measure of core inflation tries to get at this ideal in a rough and ready way, by excluding food and energy; other measures exclude all prices that have changed a lot in any given month. But Bryan and Meyer use a more direct approach, looking at goods whose prices can be shown directly not to change very often; these core goods make up about 70 percent of the CPI.

"A Bitter Spring for Mongolia's Nomads" (02:33)The wind lashes the camera as the pile of dessicated animal corpses grows. The scene is one of obvious tragedy, in a place both bleak and beautiful. In Mongolia, a terrible summer drought was followed by a brutal winter that wiped out more than 8 million animals on the steppe. The deaths played havoc with a place where food is scarce and where people already suffer from severe poverty. Andrew Jacobs, a Times correspondent, shot a video that captures heart-rending desperation. (E.O.)

Yesterday was a bit of a crazy day so I didn't get a chance to talk about the new Jil Sander Navy line. There's not much to say, really. It's a minimalist line aiming for friendlier prices in a world saturated with them. The standout piece among those presented was the print scarf dress, and I liked the crisp look of the trench skirt and the flattering cut of the slim pants. The kelly-green trench dress was cute, too. Though I saw connections to the Jil Sander aesthetic, past and present, those design values can be found in many places-Uniqlo, Calvin Klein, Banana. Last year, I bought a Jil Sander pre-season draped-front dress in navy cotton jersey for about $590. I've gotten lots of mileage out it, and it's probably less money than some of the Navy pieces. So what am I getting? We're all making those kinds of decisions about clothes. Is a $200 pair of leggings or pants really worth it or will I trade up to something with a little more design? Will I stick with a trusty designer label and just buy less? Clearly a task before the team designing Navy-which is not Raf Simons' team for the main Jil collections-is to create smart, useful pieces that are a skip ahead of the "lifestyle" miasma.

The Falaknuma Palace in Hyderabad, India, nearly bankrupted Prime Minister Nawab Vikar-ul-Umra when he built it in 1884. A mix of Italian and Tudor architecture, the project took 9 years to build and 22 years to decorate. This summer it will reopen as a hotel from the Taj Group after a restoration that was nearly as ambitious as the original plan.

Lance Cpl. Travis F. Vuocolo was with Company K (Kilo Company), Third Battalion, Sixth Marines on their initial assault of Marja in Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan. He was shot through the shoulder by a Taliban fighter on Feb. 14 when the company, accompanied by an Afghan army platoon, fought to gain a foothold in territory long under insurgent control. Lance Corporal Vuocolo has recovered and is now working at the battalion command post. Friday was his first time "outside the wire" - off the base - since he was shot. He is seen here in a bazaar in Marja. Tyler Hicks of The Times photographed the firefight in which Lance Corporal Vuocolo was wounded and his return. Mr. Hicks described the experience of being embedded with Kilo Company in "Into the Maw at Marja."

Overview | What events and trends both reflect and shape each generation? In this lesson, students compare their generation with one or more older generations and the reasons for differences between them. They generate defining events they have experienced and consider how those events have shaped who they are - and will become. They then interview a member of another generation about his or her own defining experiences.

What misconceptions do you think older generations - such as your parents', teachers' or grandparents' - have about your generation? What do you wish you could explain to them to dispel some of these beliefs? How do you think the time and place in which those generations were raised have influenced them? How do you think you're being shaped differently by growing up today?
