Telsa and Toyota to Build Electric Cars at Nummi Plant | Electric car manufacturing is coming to Fremont. Tesla Motors announced on Thursday that it would work with Toyota to build its Model S sedan, an all-electric vehicle, at the shuttered Nummi plant. The deal is expected to create more than 1,000 jobs. Toyota will invest $50 million in Tesla, which will buy the plant, where it plans to produce 20,000 electric vehicles a year. The cars are to have a range of 300 miles and sell for $50,000. The operation will occupy a small part of the plant, leaving room for more models to be made there in the future. [The San Jose Mercury News]

Thinking about a restaurant name as a logo can get you into trouble. You start turning a simple "H" into an upside down fork, or you see a sailor's compass and imagine the "S" as the first letter of Southfork. You start looking at every word on every billboard, letterhead, article of clothing or jar in your refrigerator. And then the logo of the refrigerator itself. Logos are baffling little critters; they can mislead, they can please or they can cover the globe like a virus -- Samburu tribesmen in Kenya sport the Nike swoosh.

Establishing a Bring-Your-Own-Bag Ethic Is Not Easy | Three years after San Francisco enacted a pioneering plastic-bag ban, Bay Area jurisdictions have developed a patchwork of rules to indicate exactly what carriers are appropriate for consumers to use when schlepping purchases home. After Oakland's law was successfully challenged - its analysis of the environmental dangers of plastic bags did not encompass the potential problems with paper replacements - San Jose began a comprehensive analysis of both before moving forward. The idea is to encourage people to bring their own reusable bags when they shop, but anecdotal evidence gathered by Sabra Chartrand, who reported this article, indicates that is a quixotic goal.

FELLER--Benjamin. The Brooklyn Technical High School Alumni Foundation mourns the passing of Benjamin Feller, Brooklyn Technical High School Class of 1964; a longstanding and devoted member of the Alumni Foundation and Treasurer of Alumni Foundation's Long Island Chapter. We express deep appreciation for his outstanding service to Brooklyn Tech and its students over many years. He is survived by his wife Sue and daughters Amy, Stephanie, Allison and Merridith.

ARAKAWA--Shusaku. We mourn the loss of our friend, the dedicated and always surprising artist Arakawa. Through the years, his work has sought to convey the idea of a Reversible Destiny. All of us at our galleries will miss him. Ronald and Frayda Feldman, Marian Goodman

SCHARF--Henry, of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Marilyn, father of Jillian, Marc, Lori, Michael and the late Marissa, and five grandchildren. For information "Eden Memorial Chapels" Fort Lee (201) 947-EDEN.

DARVIN--Renee, 80, passed away on May 19, 2010. Beloved wife of Jerry, loving mother of Debbie, Michael and Peter, mother-in-law to Mark, Linda, Marisol, grandmother to Michael, Liza, Emily, Theo, Henry, Mariana and Julia, sister of Marcia and Barbara, sister-in-law of Neil. Devoted over 60 years of her life to teaching Art and Art Education, most recently at Teachers College at Columbia University. Former Director of Art for the Department of Education of NYC. Former Chair of Art Department at Beach Channel High School. Former Art Teacher at Tilden High School. President of the Student Art and League. As her former students and colleagues would attest, teaching was a joy and a privilege she cherished. She leaves behind a family, large circle of friends and colleagues and students who will forever be graced by her legacy. We will always love and miss you. Funeral services May 21st at 10am Riverside Memorial Chapel. 180 West 76th St. Contributions can be made to: Renee Darvin School Art League Scholarship Fund, The School Art League, 137 East 25th St, 7th Fl, NYC 10010 or Art Education Scholarship, Dr. Judith M. Burton - Box 78, Columbia University Teachers College, West 120th St. NYC 10027.

GOLDBERG--Burton. Goldberg Weprin Finkel Goldstein mourns the loss of our long-standing dear friend and esteemed client, Burton Goldberg. We will remember his real estate acumen, insightful analytical mind, zest for living, compassion and generosity, and his unending love for his family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Rita, and the entire Goldberg family.

SLAVIN--Catherine Ferris. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Slavin, loving mother of Constance, Deborah and Jean and grandmother of Kristin, Erin, Patrick, Brendan, Ryan and Timothy, sister of the late Helen F. Neary, the late Nancy F. McHale and Miriam F. Walsh. Born and raised in New York City, she died peacefully in her home in Tuckahoe, NY on May 18, 2010. She led an exemplary life and will be greatly missed by those who knew and loved her. We will remember the extraordinary love, kindness, compassion and consideration that she bestowed on all who came in contact with her throughout her life. Calling Hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY from 3pm to 9pm on Friday May 21st. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Saturday May 22nd at 10am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her name to the St. Jean Baptiste Scholarship Fund. It will be a financial aid scholarship for this all girls Catholic high school in Manhattan. (www.stjean.org)

GOLDBERG--Burton. Mary Schmidt Campbell and the entire Tisch School of the Arts community deeply mourn the death of Burton Goldberg-a major benefactor and a name sake of our School's Department of Dramatic Writing. He has left an indelible mark on the Department and beyond with the transformational gift he and his wife, Rita, made to support playwriting- a product of their knowledge of the American theatre and lifelong passion for playwriting. Thanks to their generosity over the years the Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing and the Goldberg Prize in Playwriting have not only supported talented writers but also encouraged others to support the art of playwriting and the aspirations of our young playwrights. We extend our profound sympathy to his beloved wife Rita, and the entire Goldberg family. Mary Schmidt Campbell Dean, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts

Managers love to talk about the little things, like team chemistry and moving runners over. All of these things have value, but statheads usually take these statements to mean: ''My team isn't very good and I'm trying to save my job.'' Little things do matter, but as the term implies they aren't as important as big things like hitting home runs and striking out lots of batters.

FRIEDMAN--Edith, 84, died peacefully in New York City on May 19. She is survived by her devoted daughter Susan Oppenheim and son-in-law Stanley Oppenheim; and two beloved grandchildren Daniel and Joshua Oppenheim who were immeasurably enriched by her deep involvement in their lives. Born in Kralovsky Chlmec, Czechoslovakia in 1925, she was a victim of the Holocaust, surviving internment in Auschwitz. She returned from the camps at the age of 19 having lost her entire family. Her life was marked by a wonderful 62-year marriage to Herman Friedman who died in December 2008. Known to an extended network of family and friends as "Emma" she dedicated her life to love and care for those around her. Services will be held Friday at 9:45am, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th St. Contributions in Emma's memory can be made to The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, Attn: Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471, a wonderful institution that cared for her with dignity in the last months of her life.
WALDMAN--Marian (Mickey), 8/12/42-5/21/08. I never realized how much I'd miss you. Laura

GOLDBERG--Burton A.,May 18, 2010, World War II Veteran, aged 86. Survived by Rita Goldberg, his wife of 61 years, and children Andrew, Suzan, Joshua and Mitchell, and grandchildren Martin, Jonathan, Mollie, Scott, Alexander and Elizabeth. He was involved in the real estate business in New York, and in his retirement became a patron of the performing arts, especially in the field of dramatic writing, with involvements at NYU Tisch School of the Arts, Hunter College, The Lark Theatre Company, and The Jewish Museum. He also served on the board of The Academy of American Poets. Known for his lively sense of humor, he combined remarkable savvy as a businessman with a poetic spirit. He was a man of considerable substance. Memorial service to be held on Friday, May 21, 1:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

FRARY--John E. died at home on May 18, 2010. He is survived by his wife Jean, son John, daughter Cindy, five grandchildren, brother William and sister Betty Jo Deedrick. Memorial service will be held at Valhalla United Methodist Church on May 24 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Hospice.

DRUMS ALONG THE HUDSON When the word powwow is used in conversation, chances are it is either referring to a meeting or being used as a verb, as in ''Let's powwow about this later.'' But the term, which comes from American Indian culture, has a different primary meaning: ''A powwow is basically a celebration,'' said Kamala Cesar, the founder and artistic director of Lotus Music & Dance. ''It's a way to come together to share your culture and your dances. You're giving thanks for everything that you have: your family, the food that we eat, the clothes that we wear. You're saying thanks to the creator by dancing.''

Deborah Remington, a New York painter who countered the accepted trends of her time by incorporating a sense of real light and space into her abstract images, died April 21 in Moorestown, N.J. She was 79 and had homes in New York and Chester County, Pa. The cause was cancer, her cousin Craig Remington said.

A chart on May 13 with an article in the Personal Tech pages about Facebook's privacy settings labeled one setting incorrectly. The setting labeled ''The 'Like' Button'' actually controls the site's ''Instant Personalization'' feature. The description also referred incorrectly to the function of the Instant Personalization feature. It personalizes Web sites based in part on your friends' activity on those sites; it does not use your friends' browsing habits. And the description erroneously listed a company among Facebook partners using the feature. Yelp and Pandora use the feature to personalize their Web sites; CNN does not.

DETROIT -- During the last two weeks at a large assembly plant here, the first glimpse into Chrysler's future has been zipping through production. The redesigned Jeep Grand Cherokee, a crossover vehicle with a $31,000 price tag, is being lauded by the troubled automaker as the ''symbol of the new Chrysler.'' It will be officially unveiled on Friday in a ceremony typically reserved for much bigger occasions, like the opening of a plant.

8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER CBS has canceled this series, though it hasn't taken its final breath quite yet, as its producers shop it elsewhere. In this season -- and, perhaps, series -- finale, Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt, above, with George Wendt) investigates a poltergeist in the hospital and winds up in a showdown with the supernatural forces that are terrorizing her and her son. In the Season 6 finale of ''Medium,'' at 9, Allison (Patricia Arquette) learns that her brain tumor has returned, which could alter the lives of her friends and family. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP Lory Herrington, who performs as part of a squeaky-clean stage show with her husband and four children, and who spends most of her time living in an RV, trades places with Tera Trevino, who fancies low-riding cars and seductive clothing -- and who doesn't mind if her five daughters do, too. But if she's going to live with the Herringtons, she may have to lose her piercings.

An article on Thursday about restaurants in the West Village inspired by eras of history erroneously included one such restaurant. While the Strip House takes its inspiration from the 1920s, it is located in the East Village, not the West Village.

A report in the Reuters Breakingviews column on Tuesday about options packages at Psychiatric Solutions just before news of a leveraged buyout misstated the size of the package provided to four top executives. It was $30 million, not ''more than $1 billion.''

An article on Wednesday about Adam Wheeler, a student accused of fabricating documents to get into Harvard and obtain financial aid, misstated the name of the prep school from which he claimed to have graduated. The school, in Andover, Mass., is Phillips Academy -- not Phillips Andover Academy. (Mr. Wheeler actually attended Caesar Rodney High School in Camden, Del.)

FLAXMAN--Bertram E. Passed away on May 19, 2010 in Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of the late Dolores Flaxman, loving father of Susan (Henry) and William (Judith), devoted grandfather of David, Nicole (David), Jonathan and Samantha. Services are private.

LEIGHT--Lillian B.,died in New York City, May 15th, 2010, aged 95. We mourn the passing of our dearest friend, able bookkeeper and accountant. Both her friends and former associates shall miss her greatly! In her long career she served well-known architects Herbert Beckhard, Edward Knowles, Jack Masey, Richard Stein and Marcel Breuer. Mr. Breuer was so pleased with her work and loyalty he made her an associate with the firm, an honor usually reserved for architects. Lillian lived frugally herself but gave generously to Charities. She helped young people, mostly in the architectural and construction fields, with sound advice to enable them to stand on their own two feet. All her well-managed wealth shall go to the Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center in Jerusalem, Israel for research in cardiology. This is the hospital she admired because both Arab and Jewish patients were cared for there. Contributions can be made to the Lillian B. Leight Research Fund and sent to The New York Region of Hadassah, 50 West 58th Street, NYC, 10019. Burial 1pm Sunday, May 23rd at Union Field Cemetery, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Flushing, NY. Meet at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th Street, NYC for transportation to the cemetery.

MADRID -- The man accused of being the military leader of the Basque separatist group ETA was arrested early on Thursday by French security officials in a joint operation with their Spanish counterparts. The suspect, Mikel Kabikoitz Carrera Sarobe, known as Ata, was arrested with two other people suspected of being ETA members in an apartment in Bayonne, near the Spanish border, by French police officers. A fourth man was arrested in a different town.

We extend our heartfelt sympathies to their children, grandchildren, and the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Managers love to talk about the little things, like team chemistry and moving runners over. All of these things have value, but statheads usually take these statements to mean: ''My team isn't very good and I'm trying to save my job.'' Little things do matter, but as the term implies they aren't as important as big things like hitting home runs and striking out lots of batters.

Mariano Rivera has given up runs in three straight games, only the sixth time he has done so as a reliever. Therefore some are thinking his aura of invincibility is waning, his career is winding down, his age is catching up, and something must be wrong. Except every year Rivera seems to encounter a rough patch, and every year he rebounds and regains his indomitable form.

In the various responses to my posts on libertarianism, here and here, some commenters have made a point that sounds reasonable, but actually isn't. I pointed out that the libertarian alternative to regulation -- just use tort law to make people pay for the damage they cause -- doesn't work in practice, because when push comes to shove politicians will shield the rich and powerful from paying the real cost. Commenters say, but isn't that an equally strong reason to believe that regulation won't work either?

There's an interesting war of words in Chicago. In one corner are Gale Sayers and Dick Butkus. In the other is Brian Urlacher. The argument's merits aren't worth debating (what both sides are saying is correct). What is worth debating is whether both sides are speaking within their boundaries. Should former players criticize current players and teams? Should current players criticize former players? LEIGHT--Lillian B.,died in New York City, May 15th, 2010, aged 95. We mourn the passing of our dearest friend, able bookkeeper and accountant. Both her friends and former associates shall miss her greatly! In her long career she served well-known architects Herbert Beckhard, Edward Knowles, Jack Masey, Richard Stein and Marcel Breuer. Mr. Breuer was so pleased with her work and loyalty he made her an associate with the firm, an honor usually reserved for architects. Lillian lived frugally herself but gave generously to Charities. She helped young people, mostly in the architectural and construction fields, with sound advice to enable them to stand on their own two feet. All her well-managed wealth shall go to the Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center in Jerusalem, Israel for research in cardiology. This is the hospital she admired because both Arab and Jewish patients were cared for there. Contributions can be made to the Lillian B. Leight Research Fund and sent to The New York Region of Hadassah, 50 West 58th Street, NYC, 10019. Burial 1pm Sunday, May 23rd at Union Field Cemetery, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Flushing, NY. Meet at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th Street, NYC for transportation to the cemetery.

9 P.M. (Starz) UP (2009) Ed Asner lends his voice to Carl Fredricksen, above right, a widower and former balloon salesman who, at 78, is sent sky high when thousands of balloons carry him and his house aloft. Jordan Nagai is Russell, above left, the rotund boy who hitches a ride. And Christopher Plummer is Charles Muntz, a world-famous aviator and explorer and the childhood hero of Carl. Carl happens to run into Muntz, now a very old man, when his house floats back down to earth in South America. Writing about this animated film in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said, ''Though the initial images of flight are wonderfully rendered -- the house shudders and creaks and splinters and groans as it's ripped from its foundation by the balloons -- the movie remains bound by convention, despite even its modest 3-D depth.'' The film was nominated for Academy Awards for best motion picture and won for best animated feature film and best original score. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Betty Rollin looks at how young people are being victimized by anonymous gossip Web sites and visits the Manhattan High School for Girls, a private Jewish school in New York, where students learn the Jewish teachings on gossip, known as lashon hara. Robert J. Serling, an aviation writer known for the best-selling novel ''The President's Plane Is Missing,'' died on May 6 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 92 and a longtime Tucson resident. His daughter, Jennifer Serling, confirmed the death.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said on Friday it had agreed to settle a dispute with Washington Mutual over the bank's failure. The F.D.I.C.'s board approved a global settlement that resolves claims over its role as receiver in the September 2008 takeover of the Washington Mutual Bank, the agency said. The agreement also settles claims between Washington Mutual and JPMorgan Chase & Company, which acquired the failed bank. The settlement requires approval from a federal bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., the F.D.I.C. said. Washington Mutual said in court documents that under the agreement, the F.D.I.C. would get up to as much as $850 million from tax refunds worth as much as $5.8 billion. WaMu, its bondholders and the official committee of unsecured creditors support the proposed settlement that would split the tax refunds and other assets with JPMorgan Chase and the F.D.I.C. Shareholders would get nothing under a proposed liquidation of most of the company's remaining assets, which include $4 billion in cash in addition to the tax refunds.

GOLDHIRSCH--Fred P.,died on May 15, 2010 in New York City. He is survived by his soul mate Nobuko Mogi, his sons Bob and Douglas, his daughters Susanna and Katherine, daughter-in-law Sharon, grandson Rafael, brother Henry and sister Trudy Schwartz. Born in Vienna, Austria, July 20, 1925, he came to America with his family in 1938. As soon as he was of age to volunteer, he joined the U.S. Army and served overseas in WWII. He later earned a civil engineering degree from CCNY where he was a star soccer player. He went into business as a builder, and over the next 50 years became a well-respected real estate developer in Queens and Staten Island. A long-time summer resident of Fire Island, Fred has a life-long love of tennis and was an avid skier and fierce chess player. He was a generous friend and an ardent supporter of many causes, among them the State of Israel. He was also the proud founder and for 20 years the primary financial supporter of The Right Move, the longest running free scholastic chess tournament program in New York City history. Donations in Fred's memory can be made to The Right Move, 303 East 57th St., Suite 42F, New York, NY 10022.

Before many provisions in the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act took effect earlier this year, credit card companies routinely applied customers' payments first to balances with the lowest interest rates. For instance, before the new law, if you had a balance of $5,000 at a 0 percent A.P.R. for 12 months and a balance of $500 at a 15 percent A.P.R., you generally wouldn't be able to pay off the $500 until you had first paid off the $5,000. ''They would lock in your highest A.P.R. for the longest period they could,'' said Odysseas Papadimitriou, chief executive of credit card comparison site CardHub.com.

CANNES, France - At 8:30 a.m. on Friday at the Cannes Film Festival, just before the first daily screening, attendees were greeted with a disquieting sight: four police vans were parked in front of the festival headquarters and numerous gendarmes, some in riot gear, had taken up position on the street and even next to the red carpet. We festival-goers are used to security checks at Cannes. Guards electronically check your bags whenever you enter the headquarters, a massive building called the Palais. Another guard checks or rather glances at the contents of your bags, while a third passes an electronic wand over your body, rituals that grow lax as the festival wears on. (Similar security checks are common at studio screenings in the United States.)

The casting and performances on "Friday Night Lights'' are so famously top-notch every week that the slightest deviation from the sublime can really irritate (see my harping about Kyle Chandler last week) and, at the same time any moment can get lost in the whole. So let's take some time to celebrate Brad Leland as Buddy Garrity, the most purely avid patron of high school football in all of Dillon (O.K. maybe all of Texas). I say "purely'' because Buddy has been supplanted this season and last by the twisted Panther fanatic Joe McCoy whose interest in Panther football is more or less entirely a function of his obsessive control of his star quarterback son. Except for Julie Taylor no kid in Dillon really avoids abuse of some kind - mostly it is the abuse of absent parentage - but in young J.D. McCoy's case the abuse is both emotional and physical. Joe McCoy is a really, really awful guy - venal, entitled, misogynistic- - and Buddy has finally had enough of him. Poolside at Joe's giant house - a house that seems like one big wet bar - Buddy gives it to him and calls him a cancer for poisoning the well of Dillon football love with his base antagonisms and threats and psycho micro-managing.

The perfect cardigan for Memorial Day is the white openwork design embroidered with cornflowers and poppies by Chanel, a favorite with many women.

After what seems like ages, a portion of scaffolding has been removed from the interior of the Hagia Sophia, the church-turned-mosque-and-museum, allowing the best view in years of the soaring arches and colorful domes inside the sixth-century architectural gem. But the biggest change involves the roughly 700-year-old face of a mosaic angel. It is visible, high above the building's central hall, for the first time since 1849, when Italian restorers concealed it in compliance with the Islamic ban on praying before human images.

GREER--Dr. Melvin, 80, of Gainesville, FL and native of New York City, died Wednesday, May 19, 2010. Dr. Greer began his career at the University Of Florida College Of Medicine in 1961 with his joint appointment as assistant professor of pediatric neurology and medicine (adult neurology.) He became Chief of the Division of Neurology, and when neurology achieved full department status in 1974, he became its first Chairman, a position he held until he stepped down in 2000. Dr. Greer's greatest joy was teaching. He was well known as a brilliant diagnostician. Among the prizes he won, were the Hippocratic Award and the Lifetime Achievement Award from the UF College of Medicine. He was President of the American Academy of Neurology from 1986 - 1988. He belonged to the ANA and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and AOA. He is survived by his wife, Arline Ebert Greer; one daughter, Alison E. Cohen,; three sons, Jonathan M. Greer, Richard A.(Shirley Holland) and David M. (Stephanie Kwei); Eleven grandchildren also survive. Funeral services will be conducted Sunday, May 23, at 1:00pm, at Congregation B'nai Israel, Gainesville. Interment will follow in B'nai Israel Cemetery.Williams-Thomas Funeral Home, Gainesville, FL. Donations should be made to the Melvin Greer Academic Endowment Foundation, P.O. Box 100236, Gainesville, FL 32610.
CLIFFORD--Wynanda Bulkley. Daughter of Duncan and Wynanda Bulkley, w/o Gilman D. Blake (d '45), Thomas C. Clifford (d '89).

Where was I on the day that ''hihowareya'' became one long word devoid of meaning? I must be asked at least 10 times a day how I am, but I have yet to find one person who actually wants to know. This drives me absolutely crazy. I had not realized how much the pointlessness of this much-repeated phrase annoyed me until last summer, when I came upon a lady on the street who was walking with her head down. As we approached each other, she suddenly looked up and asked ''Hihowareya?'' I was pleasantly surprised by this sudden inquiry about my well-being. But before my brain could conjure up an answer, she had walked right on by.

Ten years ago, Alex Atala's D.O.M. broke the tradition in SÃ£o Paulo of culinary colonialism -- French, Italian and Japanese were good; Brazilian was bad. Now, after so many bowls of feijoada, a young class of chefs is mixing cuisines and techniques and taking Brazilian cooking to a higher level. Checho GonzÃ¡les, 44, the heavily tattooed chef at the year-old restaurant AjÃ­ (Rua Bela Cintra, 1709; 011-55-11-3083-4022; entrees $17 to $27), fuses the flavors of his native Bolivia with the classics of Brazilian cooking. (Each of his knuckles is inked with the image of a popular local bar snack.) The meat stew cozido, for example, is made with tender chunks of picanha braised in red wine, and the caipirinhas are flecked with bright red ajÃ­ peppers from the mountains of his homeland. At Marakuthai, tucked away in a house in Jardins (above; Alameda Itu, 1618; 011-55-11-3062-7556; entrees $20 to $29), the 21-year-old Renata Vanzetto takes inspiration from Thai food for her cooking, which is based on fresh local fruit and produce, for dishes like shrimp in curry sauce with coconut-crusted banana. And at KaÃ¡ (Avenida Presidente Juscelino Kubitschek, 279; 011-55-11-3045-0043; entrees $22 to $37), a high-design Jardins hot spot, Paulo Barros uses Amazonian ingredients like star fruit and bacuri to localize his French-Italian menu. ''Brazil is now being looked to as a global economic player,'' says Barros, 37. ''So why not bring its power into the kitchen, too?'' JOSHUA DAVID STEIN

McNEIL--Robert L.,Jr., 94, of Wyndmoor, PA., entrepreneur, innovator, philanthropist, patron of the arts and a founding father of the modern pharmaceutical industry, died of heart failure on Thursday, May 20, 2010 at his home in the company of his loving family. Mr. McNeil began his illustrious career when he joined, part-time in 1936 and full-time in 1938, the family pharmacy business founded by his grandfather, Robert McNeil. Together with his father, Robert Lincoln McNeil, and his brother, Henry, he expanded and developed the business into McNeil Laboratories, now a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, based in Fort Washington, PA. Early in his tenure at McNeil Laboratories, Mr. McNeil spearheaded the development of the Butisol family of drugs and, anticipating the world-wide demand for non-aspirin pain relievers, led the team that created Tylenol, including conceiving of the name Acetaminophen, the generic term for the drug. As McNeil Laboratories grew, so did Mr. McNeil's responsibilities. In 1956, he was named Chairman of the Board and Senior Officer. Aware that a privately held, medium-sized pharmaceutical company would have only limited opportunities for further growth, the McNeil family accepted a purchase offer for McNeil Laboratories from Johnson & Johnson in 1959. Mr. McNeil remained with the J&J subsidiary as Chairman until 1964 to ensure a smooth transition and integration. A major influence within the pharmaceutical industry, Mr. McNeil served as a Director of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, President of the Philadelphia Drug Exchange, President of the Philadelphia branch of the American Pharmaceutical Association, and a member of the Pennsylvania Drug, Device and Cosmetic Board. In 2005, Mr. McNeil received the prestigious American Institute of Chemists Gold Medal as part of Heritage Day at the Chemical Heritage Foundation. "Retirement from McNeil Laboratories marked the start of a whole new adventure," said his son, Rory McNeil. "He was able to devote more time to our family, to the arts and to various philanthropies. He was always into something." A long-time supporter of the Philadelphia Zoo, Mr. McNeil recently provided funding for the renovation of the McNeil Avian Center. Vikram H. Dewan, President and CEO of the Zoo commented on Mr. McNeil's longstanding support, "Bob McNeil's philanthropy was both abundant and visionary the McNeil Avian Center exists as a result of his generosity and farsightedness, changing the way visitors think about the Zoo. His commitment to preservation helped maintain the architectural integrity of the existing building while creating a state-of-the-art exhibit and implementing leading-edge energy conservation strategies. The McNeil Avian Center at the Philadelphia Zoo has served as an important catalyst for raising the Zoos attendance levels, positively impacting the Zoo's financial transformation and increasing the Zoo's visibility as a leading conservation and wildlife organization." An avid supporter and collector of American fine and decorative arts, Mr. McNeil served as a Commissioner of the National Portrait Gallery, a member of the White House Preservation Committee, and a Trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. His commitment to American culture was underscored by his championing of The Center of American Art at the museum through endowing the chair of Dr. Kathleen A. Foster, the Robert L. McNeil, Jr. Senior Curator of American Art and Director of the Center. As founder of the Barra Foundation, his devotion to Philadelphia arts and culture was further demonstrated through the Foundation's publication of 39-books, including Philadelphia: A 300 Year History published in 1982 and the trilogy by Roger Moss with Tom Crane: Historic Houses of Philadelphia, Historic Sacred Places of Philadelphia and Landmarks of Philadelphia in 2008. Also through the Barra Foundation, Mr. McNeil contributed to promoting education throughout Southeastern Pennsylvania, and provided funding for programs serving the homeless and disadvantaged. More recently, Mr. McNeil's longtime love of the Academy of Music was demonstrated by his generous support of the refurbishment of the Academy's central chandelier and those in the ballroom. Mr. McNeil was born in Bethel, Conn., during a family trip to visit his maternal grandparents. His immediate family resided in Germantown, PA., where he began his education at Germantown Academy, beginning a more than nine-decade relationship with the school, from which he was graduated in 1932. He attended Yale University and was a proud member of the Class of 1936, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree. In 1938, he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Pharmacy from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science (now USP) while simultaneously doing graduate work in Pharmacology at Temple University. He received an honorary Doctor of Science degree from USP in 1970. Mr. McNeil, and his brother Henry, supported the construction of a new building at USP in honor of their father, Robert Lincoln McNeil. A similar donation to the University of Pennsylvania also honored their father with a structure. A resident of Wyndmoor since 1963, Mr. McNeil had been a member of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, The Philadelphia Club, The Union League of Philadelphia, the Jupiter Island Club (Fla.), and a member of the board of Germantown Academy. He also was a former President of the Sons of the American Revolution, and, ever proud of his family's Scot's heritage, he was a member of the St. Andrew's Society of Philadelphia. In addition to his wife, Nancy, he is survived by his sons, Collin Farquhar McNeil and Robert Lincoln McNeil III (Rory), and daughters, Victoria McNeil Le Vine and Joanna McNeil Lewis, and 11 grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday June 5th, 2010 at 11:00am in The Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill, 8855 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118. Donations in memory of Mr. McNeil may be made to Center for American Art at the Philadelphia Museum of Art or the Community Partnership School, 1936 North Judson St., Philadelphia, PA 19121. Interment will be held privately at the families request. www. kirkandnicefuneralhomes.com

Never mind the bikinis -- the beach towns around Punta del Este, Uruguay, offer up a different kind of eye candy. A nascent art scene has sprung up all around the so-called St.-Tropez of South America, putting a more highbrow gloss on all the hedonism. The area's latest endeavor is an oceanfront eco-retreat where guest rooms double as art installations. GENEVIEVE PAIEMENT PLAYA VIK JOSE IGNACIO: Set to open next month, Playa Vik (left) is the beach-side sister hotel to Estancia Vik, the luxurious ranch on 4,000 inland acres nearby. The sculptural glass-and-titanium main building has a cantilevered pool that juts out toward the ocean and is surrounded by six green-roofed casitas. As at the Estancia, Uruguayan artists were given free rein: Pablo Casacuberta's colorful suite is graffiti-inspired; Eduardo Cardozo's minimalist casita centers on a fireplace formed out of mud and hay. playavikjoseignacio.com; estanciavikjoseignacio.com.

THE exhibition ''Roy McMakin: When Is a Chair Not a Chair?,'' now showing at the Cristina Grajales gallery in SoHo, coincides with the publication of a monograph of the same title from Skira Rizzoli. Mr. McMakin, an artist and designer, is known for his embrace of ambiguity and subversive humor in the design of seemingly mundane objects: a chest of drawers, for instance, that has no drawers; a teapot with the vestiges of a broken handle; the artist's dog, Joan, serving as the pudgy model for a lamp base. While Mr. McMakin designs perfectly functional interiors and furniture, he does it with an artist's eye, eschewing conventional ideas of perfection or comfort. Until July 2. 10 Greene Street, (212) 219-9941. PILAR VILADAS

Peter Max The psychedelic art guru Peter Max's 25,000-square-foot studio in New York City is part nightclub, part 19th-century salon. A D.J. spins fusion jazz records nonstop and luminous personalities are always dropping by -- not just arty types but astrophysicists like Michio Kaku and Neil deGrasse Tyson. At 72, Max is still wowed by the cosmos. ''Guess how many galaxies there are?'' he asks, giddily. ''About 350 billion!'' You can see some of that stardust sprinkled on this issue's ''T'' logo (''Tripping Out,'' Page 101). Born in Germany, Max lived a peripatetic youth, with stops in China, Israel, France and Africa. He first heard bebop on the radio in Shanghai. ''I just thought it was Chinese music.'' Max is now working on his first animated film, tentatively titled''You Can Trust a Universe That Creates Flowers.''
Art Holland Cotter

Though she's seen a lot of this world during her 27-year marriage to U2's frontman, Ali Hewson's favorite journeys have been her own humanitarian missions. She's done relief work in Ethiopia; delivered truckloads of medicine to Chernobyl victims; and co-founded Edun, a socially conscious clothing line that promotes fair trade in Africa. On a recent trip to an organic cotton facility in Uganda, she stopped in Kenya and purchased this recycled glass and brass necklace, which was handmade by locals, many from the Kibera slums. For Hewson, the piece serves as a small reminder of the continent's struggling masses who remain nameless. ''We carry the stories of the people who make our clothes and jewelry with us,'' she says. ''It gives new and different value to each piece.'' Upon learning that the London jeweler Pippa Small designed the necklace in conjunction with Made (made.uk.com), a jewelry company with a charitable arm that promotes education and training in Africa, Hewson dreamed up another way to help. Edun teamed up with the charity to create T-shirts that feature drawings by the children of Kibera (edun.com); all profits will go toward their schooling. WHITNEY VARGAS

THERE must be times when Donatella Versace and Christopher Kane, her young collaborator on the newly revamped Versus label, cannot understand each other. For instance, Mr. Kane, a Scot from outside Glasgow, will say his aim is to produce fashion hits, except it will come out as ''fashion hex.'' Ms. Versace, whose voice makes a sharp, speeding racket, will say of her protege, ''He's like a Vulcan of ideas.'' Meaning he spits them out like a volcano. They are an odd couple, Mr. Kane and Ms. Versace, in an industry of convenient marriages. Who in the fashion world could compete with her view of glamour? He, on the other hand, grasps the Versaces mentally - through pictures. He can't help it, being born in 1982, when Gianni Versace did his first metal-mesh dresses.

Is the urge to exercise bred in our bones? That's the intriguing question that European researchers recently set out to examine by looking at the activity habits of 37,051 sets of twins. Twins are popular with geneticists, because they provide a neat statistical model for determining whether a behavior is influenced by genetics or exclusively by environment. Identical twins share 100 percent of their genome, fraternal twins share 50 percent. All twin pairs, if raised together, share approximately the same early environment. So if a behavior is more common between identical twins than between fraternal twins, it is presumably being directed to some degree by genes. In the study, scientists looked at the decision to exercise or not. They turned to survey data covering twin pairs ages 19 to 40 in Australia, Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and the United Kingdom. Although the researchers set a very loose standard of one hour per week of light jogging or an equivalent activity to classify someone as an ''exerciser,'' only about 44 percent of the males and 35 percent of the females met the standard. Across the board, however, the identical-twin pairs were more likely to share an exercise pattern than the fraternal twins.

GETTING A FISH PEDICURE IN SIEM REAP, CAMBODIA. Lizzie Bott, a 22-year-old waitress from Brisbane, Australia, and her 19-year-old brother, Michael, Feb. 1, 2010. ''I had been living in London and on my way home traveled through Russia, Mongolia and China on the Trans-Mongolian Railway. I met my brother in Ho Chi Minh City and we went from there into Cambodia. In Siem Reap, there are a few different little fish spas on the main tourist street. The fish just come up and start nibbling your feet, and then eventually you get a pretty big swarm of them biting in between your toes and on the dead skin. We had an underwater camera so we were sticking it in there and getting photos of our feet with the fish. I guess it lasts maybe 10 or 15 minutes, and then they get a little bit bored of you and finish nibbling. The next day it felt like you'd had a pedicure -- or that someone had given your feet a bit of a scrub. There were definitely a few bigger fish that everyone was worried about when they came swimming toward us: you could really feel them biting more than the others. We called them the Loch Ness Monsters.''

He proved that Friday with six shutout innings against the Yankees, making their intimidating hitters look awkward and frustrated at times with his six pitches coming in at various speeds, angles and locations.

Considering how long stylish travelers have had to cart around less-than-beautiful electrical doohickeys, it's a wonder that fashion hasn't come to the rescue sooner. The Yves Saint Laurent travel adapter ($450; ysl.com) is a one-piece electrical dual-voltage plug adapter that connects gadget to outlet in any combination in more than 150 countries (Japanese cellphone to American outlet, German shaver to Australian socket). The circular device swivels to each region's plug, and a leather bag available in fuchsia, black and violet provides the panache. ADAM KEPLER

SHOOMAN--Sylvia Bashoff, on May 20, 2010. Beloved wife of Martin. Dear mother of Andrew (Tzippy), Alice (Mark) Lebowitz. Adored grandma of Danielle, Aviva, Natan, Alex and Elie. Devoted daughter of Ruth Bashoff and loving sister of Allen Bashoff. She gave generously of herself to all. We will miss her greatly. Services Sunday, May 23, 2pm at "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI. Shiva in Glen Cove.

HASCOE--Suzanne Vertun, passed away on Friday, May 14, 2010 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. She was predeceased by her husband of 52 years, Norman Hascoe. She is survived by her beloved children: Stephanie and Mark, Lloyd and Abbe, Andrew and Stacey, and her nine grandchildren. Suzanne was a former biochemist in cancer research. She worked for the Burroughs Welcome Company, which under a grant from Sloan Kettering, developed the first chemotherapy drug for treating childhood leukemia. She worked directly for the scientists who received the Nobel Prize for this breakthrough medical treatment. Reflecting her interests in art, antiques and medicine, she was a member of the Chairman's Council as well as a Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She also sat on the Board of The Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Connecticut and was an Associate Member of the Board of the Whitehead Institute for Genetic Research at MIT. In 1955 she married Norman Hascoe and worked closely with him as they started a business that manufactured advanced materials and other high technology components for the semiconductor industry. The company, Semi-Alloys Inc., was sold to Allied Signal Corp. in 1983. She will be remembered by family and friends for her keen intellect, engaging personality, incredibly warm smile, elegant taste and exquisite style. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Thoracic Research Fund Attention: Vincent A. Miller, M.D., 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

''Just make the score, do the deal. Move on to the next one. That's the trader culture.'' -Cornelius Hurley, director of the Morin Center for Banking and Financial Law at Boston University, amid questions on Goldman Sachs's short selling during the financial crisis. ''Information technology and manure have a symbiotic relationship.'' -Chandrakant D. Patel, director of Hewlett-Packard's sustainable information technology laboratory. Dairy farmers could soon find themselves in the computer business, with the manure from their cows powering vast data centers.
'My goal is to create a dynasty team, and I'm not in a hurry.' MIKHAIL D. PROKHOROV,

If you still think of Boston as the land of ribbon belts and cable knit, the city's high-profile neighborhood-of-the-moment will come as a surprise. Perched along the edge of the South Boston waterfront, the modern-industrial boutiques, restaurants and galleries in and around Fan Pier deliver a destination that's fully shed of preppy pomp, if not pricey yachts. ALYSSA GIACOBBE

Let's just say I saw it coming. When the waitress at the furiously fashionable Ralph's, the restaurant at the new Ralph Lauren boutique in Saint-Germain-des-Pres, threaded her way through the tight maze of brown leather armchairs in the snug, beamed dining room - complete with hunt-themed oil paintings and a gas fire - and placed a small bowl of deep-fried olives on the table, my friend Marie-Odile, a chatelaine in town for the day from Bordeaux, rolled her eyes. ''Deep-fried olives!'' she said. ''Only you Americans would think of doing such a thing. You deep-fry everything, don't you?'' Er, well, not really, since the inspiration for these olives, which were actually rather tasty, doubtless came from Puglia. One way or another, it was too much to expect that the French would interpret them as a sign of the cosmopolitan diversity of the contemporary American kitchen.
Theater Charles Isherwood
Dance Jack Anderson

ROWLANDS--J. Peter, an art dealer and longtime resident of London, d. at Ossining, age 88, on May 14. He is survived by his three children, Eliot, Penelope, and Richard, and four grandsons. Memorial Service: Grace (Episcopal) Church, 33 Church Street (at Main Street), White Plains, Friday, May 28, 11am.

Edward George rode his Titan folding bike, with its twin mirrors pointing up like antennae, from his apartment on 110th Street and Madison Avenue to the Gabaron Barber Shop on Second Avenue and 119th Street. But, as he often does, Mr. George, 82, took to the sidewalk for the trip because he feels unsafe in the fast-moving traffic. Bike lanes make him feel more secure, ''but there's just a few,'' he said, adding, ''I've gotten a couple of tickets.''

BAUER--Richard J.,a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of Newburgh, entered into rest on Friday, May 21, 2010 at St. Luke's Cornwall Hospital, Newburgh Campus. He was 85. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bauer, he was born on May 9, 1925 in Queens, NY. He was married to Anita Henning Bauer, who predeceased him on July 2, 2007. He is survived by his loving son, Richard H. Bauer and his wife, Mary Jane of Balmville; grandchildren, Elizabeth Bauer, Kathryn Bauer, both of Manhattan, and Court Bauer and his wife Sarah of Larchmont, NY; great-grandchildren, Sabrina Bauer and John Bauer; and daughter-in-law, Carolyn Bauer. He was predeceased by his son, Jonathan Bauer. Richard proudly served in the U.S. Navy from 1943-1946; from 1947-1950, he was a student at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, now known as Polytechnic University. Concurrently, while attending school held a full-time position with the New York Telephone Company in their testing division; from 19511965 he was employed with a firm in Brooklyn, NY, manufacturing non-ferrous metal alloys. During that period of time he rose from Plant Metallurgist to Executive Vice President and General Manager. He was the founder of Eastern Alloys, Inc. in Maybrook, NY and co-founder and chairman of Service Aluminum Corporation in Ellicott City, MD. He was also the co-founder, former Director, Treasurer, and past President of the Independent Zinc Alloyers Association, former director of the Zinc Institute, and former director of the American Die Casting Institute, a past member of the Board of Trustees of St. Luke's Hospital since 1974, serving as past vice-president, past president and past Chairman of the Board, a member of the Board of the Kaplan Foundation, a member of the American Institute of Metallurgical Engineers, the American Society for Metals, and the Mining Club in New York. He was the recipient of the Doehler Award in 1982 in recognition of accomplishments in the service of the die casting industry, and the Gullo and Treiber Award in 1997, both by the North American Die Casting Association, recipient of the Americanism Award by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in 1989 in recognition of his excellence in industry and his leadership in the community, elected Fellow of Polytechnic University in 1981 where he graduated with a degree in Metallurgical Engineering in 1951, received the Distinguished Citizen Award, 1991, given by the Boy Scouts of America, Hudson-Delaware Council, for outstanding service to both the Boy Scouts and the community, Mr. Bauer, on behalf of the zinc industry and the Independent Zinc Alloyers Association, and the Washington Conference for Zinc, has appeared before many congressional committees in support of vital issues affecting the supply of zinc and alloy to the die casting industry. He is currently Chairman of the Washington Conference for Zinc. Visitation will be held from 2-5pm on Sunday, May 23 at Brooks Funeral Home, 481 Gidney Ave., Newburgh. A funeral service will take place at 11:30am on Monday, May 24 in the funeral home. Burial will follow in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Newburgh. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Richard's memory may be made to the Kaplan Family Hospice Residence, 1 Sunrise Lane, Newburgh, NY 12550. To send a personal condolence or for directions, please visit BrooksFH.com or call 845-561-8300.

As the world rediscovers the allure of city living, abandoned districts that once would have met with the wrecking ball are being revamped into cultural hot spots. From Cleveland to Hong Kong, artists, gallery owners, hoteliers and chefs are turning erstwhile areas of urban blight into thriving destinations, reclaiming factories, docklands, even entire industrial zones. It's the meatpacking-district-Tate Modern-Bilbao effect, and it's reached critical mass. ''Artists bring tremendous energy to any community,'' says Flavio Misciattelli, the president of the Fondazione Pastificio Cerere, a contemporary art center inside an old pasta factory in Rome's San Lorenzo neighborhood. Now, what was a dangerous industrial slum, Misciattelli says, ''is someplace vibrant and safe.'' Likewise, the iconic Red October Chocolate Factory, having sat empty and foreboding on Bolotny Island in central Moscow for years, houses cutting-edge cultural enterprises like the Baibakov Art Project and the Pobeda Gallery. And in Istanbul, a former power station on the city's fringe is now the Santralistanbul museum, a nexus of both contemporary art and waterside hobnobbing.

A picture caption last Sunday with the ''Living In'' article about Wakefield, the Bronx, misstated part of the name of the street typical of the greener and more suburban areas the farther you walk from White Plains Road. It is Carpenter Avenue, not Carpenter Street.
Nap of luxury

7 P.M. (ABC) LOST It's not over till it's over, and even then, questions are sure to linger. The series concludes on Sunday night with five and a half hours of special programming, starting with ''Lost: The Final Journey,'' a two-hour, six-season primer starting with the crash of Oceanic Air Flight 815 in 2004 and continuing through the parallel existence after the explosion of the hydrogen bomb. Cast members past and present will also share their experiences on the show's set before the two-and-a-half-hour series finale begins at 9. ''Jimmy Kimmel Live: Aloha to 'Lost,' '' at 12:05 a.m., a post-show discussion and celebration, features three alternate final scenes created by Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse, the show's executive producers, and appearances by Naveen Andrews, Nestor Carbonell, Alan Dale, Jeremy Davies, Emilie de Ravin, Michael Emerson, Matthew Fox, Daniel Dae Kim, Terry O'Quinn, Harold Perrineau, Jorge Garcia (above), Josh Holloway and Evangeline Lilly. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, debate the ramifications of the Democratic victory in Pennsylvania for the midterm elections. Both men also appear with Sarah Palin on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10. The discussion continues with Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary; Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee; and Representative Joe Sestak, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who beat Senator Arlen Spector in the state's Democratic Senate primary on Tuesday, on ''Face the Nation'' at 10:30 on CBS. Mr. Sestak appears with Rand Paul, the Republican nominee from Kentucky for the United States Senate, on ''Meet the Press'' at 10:30 on NBC.

The ''In the Region'' article in Long Island copies last Sunday, about the use of residential real estate as the setting for films, misstated the planned broadcast time for an HBO series, ''Mildred Pierce,'' starring Kate Winslet, which is being shot at the Woolworth Mansion in Glen Cove. It is spring 2011, not February 2011.

Q.My husband and I plan to spend 10 days in the eastern provinces of Canada with our 5-year-old daughter. We'd like to include a visit to the Bay of Fundy and Cape Breton Island. We are interested in hiking, biking and camping. Can you suggest an itinerary? We will have our car and plan to drive from Philadelphia. Naomi H. Shapiro,PhiladelphiaA.Consider driving to St. John, on the southern coast of New Brunswick, on the Bay of Fundy (above). (Be warned that the drive from Philadelphia, while scenic, will take upward of 12 hours, so you may want to plan stops along the way.) Stroll along the waterfront of this hilly town with 19th-century brick and stone buildings; visit the Old Burial Grounds, a cemetery that dates from 1784; and hike, bike or drive the seven-mile Fundy Trail Parkway (fundytrailparkway.com), with lookouts that offer spectacular coastal views. From St. John, head to Fundy National Park (pc.gc.ca/eng/pn-np/nb/fundy/activ/camping.aspx; about 90 minutes northeast), which offers kayaking, biking along scenic roads, and 65 miles of coastal and inland hiking trails that range from 20-minute loops to three-day backcountry hikes with camping; reservations are required (cabins or ''chalets'' are also available). Don't miss the Hopewell Rocks, partly eroded formations where you can witness the power of the Fundy tides. For more information, read Karen Houppert's ''In New Brunswick, Where Surf Becomes Turf'' (Aug. 31, 2007), her account of a visit to the park, which she described as one of ''Canada's best-kept secrets.''

THE NEWS After several false starts, BP engineers succeeded in inserting a 4-inch-wide tube into a broken 21-inch well pipe in mile-deep water in the Gulf of Mexico, capturing some of the crude oil gushing from the stricken well. BEHIND THE NEWS The company has been trying for four weeks to stop the oil leak, caused by an explosion on a drilling rig 50 miles off the Louisiana coast. Its first stopgap measure, an improvised lid, failed. BP now plans a ''top kill,'' which involves pumping heavy drilling mud into the well to seal it, or perhaps a ''junk shot,'' injecting solid debris like golf balls to clog up the well.

An article last Sunday about the ways in which soccer teams are preparing for the high altitudes they will face at the World Cup in South Africa misidentified, in some copies, one opponent of the United States in the first round in June. Besides England and Slovenia, the Americans will play Algeria, not Egypt.

Hotels in Istanbul tend to be either touristy affairs in the Old City or splashy (and pricey) luxury digs that hug the shores of the Bosporus. The House Hotel Galatasaray, which opened last month in Beyoglu, is aiming for the space in between: it's a short stroll from the popular and central Taksim Square, but with rates starting at a fairly reasonable 120 euros (about $150). The 20-suite hotel (19 Bostanbasi Caddesi, Galatasaray, 90-212-244-3400; thehouse-hotels.com), in a handsome structure built in the 1890s, is the result of a two-year renovation by the folks who created the city's House Cafe chain. Polished wood floors and fine linens raise the comfort factor, and original touches, like the central marble staircase and original floor tiling in common areas like the rooftop lounge, add character. Each room includes a stand-alone shower and a separate toilet and sink area.

STANLEY FISH It is certainly possible to teach the literature and history (including the history of marginalization and discrimination) of ethnic traditions without turning students into culture warriors ready to man (and woman) the barriers. To be sure, the knowledge a student acquires in an ethnic studies course that stays clear of indoctrination may lead down the road to counterhegemonic, even revolutionary, activity; you can't control what students do with the ideas they are exposed to. But that is quite different from setting out deliberately to produce that activity as the goal of classroom instruction. However, Arizona House Bill 2281, which bans from the public schools ethnic studies courses that promote race consciousness, is one case where the remedy is worse than the disease, or rather is a form of it.

JAY LENO Well, that's the big story in Connecticut. Their attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, who was considered a shoo-in for his race for the U.S. Senate, is now under fire for claiming that he served in Vietnam when he really didn't. Turns out he has no war record at all. In fact, only combat experience? Shooting himself in the foot.

KELLEY--Edmund. With sadness we announce the death of Edmund (Ned) R.T. Kelley on Tuesday, May 18 in Hartford, CT. A resident of Colebrook, CT, Ned was born in 1922 in Stamford, CT, and graduated from the Taft School in 1940. He went on to Princeton University, class of 1944. After service with the American Field Service, Ned joined the wine importing firm of Frederick Wildman & Sons. Ned also had a long association with the Tweedy & Barnes Co., grower of cranberries in Wareham, MA. He is survived by his five sons, Rick, Philip, Peter, David and Ted, ten grandchildren, three nieces, a nephew and four great-nieces and nephews. Friends and family are welcome at a Memorial Service on Monday, May 24 at 2:00pm at Colebrook Congregational Church, 471 Smith Hill Rd., Colebrook, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to www.AFS.org.

PARIS -- She was once banned from Roland Garros stadium after she and her father got into a shouting match there with a French tennis coach. Relations with the French tennis federation were once so embittered that she was refused financial help and was obliged to qualify for the French Open instead of being offered one of the wild cards routinely reserved for talented young French players like her. But Aravane Rezai should feel much more welcome this year at the tournament that matters most to her country, or one of her countries. After winning the tour event in Madrid last week -- out-slugging the former No.1 players Justine Henin, Jelena Jankovic and Venus Williams along the way -- she is now ranked 16th in the world and is one of the French Open's main attractions.
Pop/Jazz Nate Chinen

Seeking to bolster its flights out of New York City, Delta Air Lines announced plans to expand service from there to nearly 30 cities worldwide, including major business destinations like Chicago, St. Louis, London and Tokyo. Airline experts say the move is partly in response to the announced merger between United and Continental, which threatens Delta's efforts to build a larger presence in the lucrative New York City market.

WHY IT'S HOT: The Chinese city's willow-fringed West Lake and terraced tea plantations have long inspired painters, poets and travelers. New hotels and the fall debut of a high-speed train from Shanghai (travel time: 38 minutes) are putting Hangzhou on travelers' must-see lists. SLEEP WELL: Opened in January, Amanfayun (above; 22 Fayun Nong, Xihujiedao; 011-86-571-8732-9999; amanresorts.com; doubles from about $580) occupies a Tang dynasty village, with 42 luxe rooms, suites and villas -- along with a spa and restaurants -- set along a monks' pathway. And Banyan Tree (21 Zijinggang Road; 011-86-571-8586-0000; doubles from $450) has 72 villas and suites and a decadent spa within the mangroves of Xixi National Wetland Park.

A report on Page 90 this weekend in the feature ''The Place'' about five vintage wines to seek out in Napa Valley refers incorrectly to one from the Storybook Mountain Napa Estate. Its ''Eastern Exposures'' Zinfandel 2006 is a red wine, not white.

Eternal/ (e tur$(4$) nl) / adj. / Forever the same; unchanging, as in places that seem to exist outside time and are immune to the forces of gentrification and globalization, e.g., 'Even though gastropubs and McMansions have cropped up on the coast, Dorset feels totally eternal. You're more likely to see fishermen than footballers' wives. First Responders/ (furst ri spÃ¤n$(4$) ders) / n. / Travelers who rush to former danger zones or rogue states, like Colombia or Syria, thereby anointing these spots as cutting-edge destinations, as in, When it comes to shopping, she's always a first responder. She just spent a week on her own scavenging the souks of Damascus. Repurpose/ (r pur$(4$) pes) /v. / To use or convert for use in another format, specifically old buildings and neighborhoods, which revitalizes and gives new significance to neglected places, e.g., 'The hottest neighborhood in Rome right now is San Lorenzo, where a bunch of artsts have repurposed an old pasta factory as studio space. JEFFRIES BLACKERBY AND MAURA EGAN

COLEMAN--Ann Borowik. Born July 4th, 1928 - died May 17th, 2010 after a brave struggle. American author of "How Many Miles to Babylon" and "Lions 3 Christians 0". An early feminist writer who appeared in Cosmopolitan Magazine frequently during the 60's. She had a unique, lively and touching style. Ann was a caring mother, proud New Yorker, political activist, artist, runner, avid Mets fan and great judge of horse flesh. She is survived by her daughter, Bunny; son, Charles; and husband, Val.

FATHER KNOWS BEST: Last August, Justin Halpern was a 28-year-old semi-employed comedy writer living with his parents in Los Angeles when he decided to start posting his 73-year-old father's irascible, foul-mouthed wisdom on a Twitter feed that we'll call ''Stuff My Dad Says.'' Nine months later, he has more than a million followers, a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner (tentatively titled ''Bleep My Dad Says'') and a book at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list. It's tough to quote from the book in a family newspaper, but a few recent nuggets from the Twitter feed give a bit of the flavor. On being a proud papa: ''A parent's only as good as their dumbest kid. If one wins a Nobel Prize but the other gets robbed by a hooker, you failed.'' On marriage: ''Pressure? Get married when you want. Your wedding's just one more day in my life I can't wear sweat pants.'' Samuel Halpern, a Southern sharecropper's son and retired doctor of nuclear medicine with a penchant for walking around the house naked, doesn't seem to have granted any interviews (on Bob Saget: ''Remember that face. That's the face of a man who hates himself''), but the old man seems to be taking his newfound celebrity in stride. After Justin worked up the nerve to tell him about the Twitter feed, he laughed and said (more or less): ''I don't care what people think of me. Publish whatever you want. I just got two rules: I'm not talking to anyone, and whatever money you get, keep. I got my own money. I don't need yours.'' The book might make a good Father's Day present, but not for Samuel Halpern, who has a staunchly traditionalist view of gift-giving: ''If it's not bourbon or sweat pants, it's going in the garbage. . . . No, don't get creative. Now is not a creative time. Now is a bourbon and sweat pants time.''

The Yankees skipped one of Javier Vazquez's starts because of ineffectiveness. They skipped another because they needed him in the bullpen. It is too early to tell, Manager Joe Girardi said, if they will skip Vazquez a third time, this one because of injury. Vazquez was forced to leave his start Friday night after six shutout innings after bruising his right index finger on a bunt attempt in the seventh. The X-rays were negative, but the finger remained a bit swollen Saturday, Girardi said.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday exploring whether college is the right path for everyone misspelled, at one point, the surname of the president of Northwestern University, who said that a few years of college can be valuable, even if no degree is earned. As the article noted elsewhere, he is Morton Schapiro, not Shapiro.
1. Auberge du Soleil 180 Rutherford Hill Road, Rutherford; (707) 963-1211; aubergedusoleil.com; doubles from $575. Look Provence in California, with hillside stucco cottages shaded by olive trees.

MILLER--Adelaide Smither Barth, died May 9, 2010. A graduate of The Spence School and Stanford University, where she earned a Bachelor of Arts Degree in Economics in 1950, Mrs. Miller held several positions in marketing and public relations with Lord & Taylor, National Selected Products and The Borden Company in New York. She married Norman Albert Miller in 1952, and was widowed in 2000. An active volunteer in charitable causes, Adelaide Miller served as the Chairman of a residential housing project managed by the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City, and she was a Director of the YWCA of New York City and also the YWCA of the United States of America. She was a member and Vice President of the Junior League of New York City. She also served two terms on the alumnae board of The Spence School in New York. She lived for many years in Tuxedo Park, New York, where she was an active member, and for four years President, of the Tuxedo Park Garden Club, and an active parishioner of St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church, having been the Chairman of the St. Mary's Guild. Mrs. Miller was an enthusiastic traveler throughout her life. She visited almost every state in the Union and many Provinces of Canada and traveled extensively in the British Isles, Continental Europe and South America. She was active for many years in the work of the Orange County Republican Party, of which her husband was a committeeman and a Town chairman. She will be remembered by many in New York City and Tuxedo Park as a true and constant friend and as one who never spoke ill of another. Interment will be private. There will be a memorial service in celebration of Adelaide Miller's life at 1:00pm at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo, May 27, 2010. In lieu of flowers, a donation to St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo or to the Tuxedo Park Garden Club, Tuxedo Park, New York 10987, or to the charity of one's choice, would be an appropriate remembrance.

Much prognosticating about the world's ''emerging'' destinations is pure speculation, but consider where the airlines are placing their bets. New routes point to where the money is -- and provide a glimpse into travel's crystal ball. Case in point: Lufthansa is now flying from Frankfurt to Iraq's newly expanded Erbil airport for the first time in 20 years, catering to workers in the oil and gas industry. So what do the airlines' latest touch-downs tell us about where to go next? ANDREA BENNETT

DUDDLESTEN--Wayne B, noted national developer, peacefully entered into rest while surrounded by his family, on Thursday afternoon, the 20th of May 2010, at his home in Houston. The Hunt column last Sunday, about Andrea Syrtash and Michael Paoli's search for an apartment in New York City, misstated the city in Canada that is home to Queen's University, which Ms. Syrtash attended. It is in Kingston, Ontario -- not Toronto.

BERDON--Matthew A.,of Quogue, NY and Palm Beach, Florida died Saturday, March 27, 2010 at the age of 90 in the Peconic Bay Medical Center, Riverhead, NY following a long illness. Mr. Berdon joined Ferro, Berdon & Company, a New York based accounting and business advisory firm, at the end of the Second World War and became its senior partner. It became a hugely successful international firm under his leadership. Subsequently, as a result of a merger, Mr. Berdon was chairman of the New York operation of Urbach, Kahn & Werlin, now known as UHY Advisors. Mr. Berdon was a great friend and a trusted advisor to many clients. He also served on the Board of Directors for Barnes & Noble and Beth Israel Hospital in New York. Mr. Berdon acquired ownership of a wide range of business around the world. He sold his Marlboro Bookstore chain to Barnes & Noble which led to a long relationship with the bookseller and its chairman, Leonard Riggio. Mr. Berdon was born in Manhattan to Sadye and Harry Berdon on July 31, 1919. He graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School and the City College of New York. During the Second World War, Mr. Berdon was commissioned as an officer in the US Army Air Corps. He flew 30 missions over France, Germany, Holland, and Belgium. He served as lead navigator of the 453 bomb group of the 8th Air Force. His military awards and decorations included the Distinguished Flying Cross and four Air Medals. In 1950, he met his future wife, the former Laura Miklasz of Chester, PA. The two were married on March 31, 1951. The couple never had children. However, the Berdons formed a deep loving relationship with their nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Peconic Bay Medical Center, Riverhead, NY or East End Hospice of Westhampton Beach, NY. A memorial reception will be held on Monday, May 24, 2010 at the Metropolitan Club of New York from 5pm-7pm.

In anticipation of next month's World Cup in South Africa, FIFA has commissioned 17 artists to create limited-edition soccer-themed prints. The Cup organizers initiated the art-for-athletics program back in 2006, printing posters by the likes of Andreas Gursky to promote the German games. This year's portfolio includes a drawing by the South African artist William Kentridge of a player in midkick (right); a latex sculpture of an elephant, its trunk wrapped around the ball, by the German-born Isolde Krams; and a colorful embroidered work by the Sudanese artist Hassan Musa, who reimagines Jacob's tussle with the Archangel as a center-field struggle. The original artworks were auctioned at New York's Phillips de Pury, but the signed and numbered prints -- 2,010 of each image -- go for as little as $121. Go to 2010artedition.de. JILL SINGER (PHOTOGRAPH BY BRANDS UNITED)

WHEN an opera company performs an opera in concert, it is cutting to the bone. When a symphony orchestra does the same thing, it is reaching for the stars. The players can spread their wings in glamorous regions they rarely get to explore. Audiences share the thrill of fresh discovery, whether the repertory is standard or the rarest of the rare. Does it matter if the singers are barricaded behind music stands? Or should the concert hall simulate the production values of an actual opera house? Over the years many symphonic institutions have tried, with inconclusive results. In his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert is pursuing a more experimental, potentially more exciting, agenda. For the New York premiere of Gyorgy Ligeti's ''Grand Macabre,'' opening a three-night run on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, he has opted for a portable multimedia staging by the diminutive production company Giants Are Small, based in Sunset Park, a blue-collar neighborhood in Brooklyn.

9:39 p.m. | Updated For a response from my colleague David Leonhardt to some of the economists quoted in my article (and commenters on this blog), see ''The Value of College'' on the Economix blog. Earlier this month, David examined trends in college attendance and completion rates through an economic lens in a piece in The Times's Sunday Magazine. Finally, our colleague Floyd Norris examines all of this evidence and renders his own verdict. My article in Sunday's Week in Review, ''Plan B: Skip College,'' has drawn nearly 400 comments from Times readers. In the process, readers underscored the polarizing emotions surrounding the question of whether some students would do well to avoid, or at least delay, enrolling in traditional bachelor's degree programs, in favor of obtaining experience more directly related to the jobs they might do.

There's been some bad blood between Athens and Berlin lately, with the latter city holding the economic fate of the former in its less-than-forthcoming hands. ''Berlin-Athens, Why So Much Hate?'' read a recent French headline. Could there be an element of jealousy? Despite being in the red (or perhaps because of it -- cheap rents!), the Greek city is starting to steal the cultural spotlight from the increasingly gentrified Berlin, which seems more interested in spawning an outpost of London's Soho House than in nurturing the careers of creative types. Athens's Kerameikos/Metaxourgeio neighborhood -- which still has its share of drug dealers and prostitutes, like any good arty neighborhood should -- along with the run-down Kypseli district have become the new home for influential galleries like the Breeder and Rebecca Camhi, as well as the biannual ReMap art festival, which included installations in abandoned buildings last summer. And the whole scene just got the stamp of approval from Larry Gagosian, who opened a gallery to cater to the needs of a circle of billionaire Greek collectors.

''I really feel it was a bargain,'' said John Reznikoff. The bargain Mr. Reznikoff was speaking of is a 2000 Jeep Grand Cherokee with about 133,000 miles on the odometer that he purchased at auction on May 1.
Classical Steve Smith

LEIGHT--Lillian B.,died in New York City, May 15th, 2010, aged 95. We mourn the passing of our dearest friend, able bookkeeper and accountant. Both her friends and former associates shall miss her greatly! In her long career she served well-known architects Herbert Beckhard, Edward Knowles, Jack Masey, Richard Stein and Marcel Breuer. Mr. Breuer was so pleased with her work and loyalty he made her an associate with the firm, an honor usually reserved for architects. Lillian lived frugally herself but gave generously to Charities. She helped young people, mostly in the architectural and construction fields, with sound advice to enable them to stand on their own two feet. All her well-managed wealth shall go to the Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center in Jerusalem, Israel for research in cardiology. This is the hospital she admired because both Arab and Jewish patients were cared for there. Contributions can be made to the Lillian B. Leight Research Fund and sent to The New York Region of Hadassah, 50 West 58th Street, NYC, 10019. Burial 1pm Sunday, May 23rd at Union Field Cemetery, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Flushing, NY. Meet at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th Street, NYC for transportation to the cemetery.

The minimalist Duchamp Hotel (421 Foss Street; 707-431-1300; duchamphotel.com; doubles from $350) has six cottages with Donald Judd-inspired wooden beds.
