For something low-key, check out Barndiva (231 Center Street; 707-431-0100; barndiva.com; entrees $20 to $32), where Ryan Fancher uses exclusively local ingredients.

BARBATELLI--Lovedy Louise Nee Pedlow, died on May 8, 2010 at her home in Palm Beach, FL at the age of 85. The cause was Alzheimer's disease, after the onset of dementia spanning more than a decade. She is survived by her husband of 61 years Ettore "Barb", their four children and seven grandchildren. Mrs. Barbatelli attended high school in Washington DC, graduating from University of Maryland cum laude and first in her class in her Accounting major in 1946. She was president of her sorority, Kappa Delta. She pursued her career with the CPA firm of Pogson, Peloubet and Company, in New York City. Mrs. Barbatelli married Ettore Barbatelli on November 6, 1948, at St. John Wilmot Episcopal Church in East Chester, N.Y. following his return from the Asiatic Pacific theatre (U.S. Army) and graduation from Yale. Mr. and Mrs. Barbatelli lived in Morristown, N.J., relocating to Milwaukee WI, in 1963. She co-founded Valuation Research Corporation with her husband in 1975, serving as the Controller, and was Secretary/Treasurer for over 15 years. Mrs. Barbatelli served as treasurer for numerous organizations including her Junior League chapters; the Antiquarian Society of the Milwaukee Art Museum; Milwaukee Repertory Theatre, and the Florentine Opera Company in Milwaukee. She was a member of the Society of the Four Arts and a docent at the Norton Museum of Art in Palm Beach, FL, where they were active donors and a pocket gallery is named in their honor. Mrs. Barbatelli was an accomplished oil painter. Special thanks to the caregivers helping Mrs. Barbatelli with her at-home care. She will be interred in the memorial garden at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in River Hills, Wisconsin following a service on June 12. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Christopher's Episcopal Church or Hospice of Palm Beach County. Feerick Funeral Home (414) 962-8383 Milwaukee. Condolences may be sent to: www.feerickfuneralhome.com

ROUGH RIDER Who could have seen anything like a future in that drug-glutted roach motel, the San JosÃ©? It was 1995, and Liz Lambert -- a lawyer, back home in Texas after a stint as a New York City prosecutor -- stumbled out of Austin's famous rock hall the Continental Club, crossed South Congress Avenue and faced her destiny. ''The place looked empty, but it wasn't,'' Lambert says about her first hotel. ''It's just everyone who stayed there didn't have cars or luggage, or come out much during the days.'' Lambert took over the squalid spot with plans to renovate it one room at a time. For that, she needed a loan; every bank balked. ''They said, 'You can't make one room nice, charge $75 and have a hooker next door turning tricks all night.' '' So Lambert worked the front desk for nearly three years, renting rooms for $30 behind a plate-glass window. She befriended the drug addicts, street musicians and prostitutes who called the place home, and made a documentary about them. Finally, she got financing. ''We stripped the place down,'' she says. ''Down to the studs.''

FRENCH--Barbara M.,of Manhattan and Sagaponack, Long Island, died on May 14, 2010 at her Manhattan home at age 97. She was predeceased in 1995 by her husband of 56 years, James. H. French, and is survived by their two children, John R. French and Carey F. Millard, John's wife, Leigh C. French, and Carey's husband, John A. Millard. She is also survived by six grandchildren, Hilary F. Louchheim, James Alexander French, Ashley F. Weymouth, John Alden Millard, Jr., James G. Millard and Alexander F. Millard, eight great-grandchildren, a step-grandchild, Jennifer Q. Deinard, and two step-great grandchildren. She was a granddaughter of F.A.O. Schwarz who founded the toy store of that name. A graduate of The Brearley School and Vassar College, she received a Masters from Columbia University. She was active in many volunteer organizations in New York City and served as a Trustee of The Brearley School (1958-1961). She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club where she served as a Governor (1969-1972). Inspired by her love of the natural world and of Sagaponack, she was a charter member of the Group for the South Fork (now the Group for the East End). She served the Group as a Director (1972-1988), as Chairman of the Board (1987-1988) and, for 20 years thereafter, as a member of its Advisory Committee. She was beloved by her family and will be missed by all who knew her. Pursuant to her wishes, no services are planned. A private family remembrance will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Group for the East End, P.O. Box 569, Bridgehampton, New York 11932.

GOLDHIRSCH--Fred P.,died on May 15, 2010 in New York City. He is survived by his soul mate Nobuko Mogi, his sons Bob and Douglas, his daughters Susanna and Katherine, daughter-in-law Sharon, grandson Rafael, brother Henry and sister Trudy Schwartz. Born in Vienna, Austria, July 20, 1925, he came to America with his family in 1938. As soon as he was of age to volunteer, he joined the U.S. Army and served overseas in WWII. He later earned a civil engineering degree from CCNY where he was a star soccer player. He went into business as a builder, and over the next 50 years became a well-respected real estate developer in Queens and Staten Island. A long-time summer resident of Fire Island, Fred has a life-long love of tennis and was an avid skier and fierce chess player. He was a generous friend and an ardent supporter of many causes, among them the State of Israel. He was also the proud founder and for 20 years the primary financial supporter of The Right Move, the longest running free scholastic chess tournament program in New York City history. Donations in Fred's memory can be made to The Right Move, 303 East 57th St., Suite 42F, New York, NY 10022.

PARIS -- She was once banned from Roland Garros stadium after she and her father got into a shouting match there with a French tennis coach. Relations with the French tennis federation were once so embittered that she was refused financial help and was obliged to qualify for the French Open instead of being offered one of the wild cards routinely reserved for talented young French players like her. But Aravane Rezai should feel much more welcome this year at the tournament that matters most to her country, or one of her countries. After winning the tour event in Madrid last week -- out-slugging the former No.1 players Justine Henin, Jelena Jankovic and Venus Williams along the way -- she is now ranked 16th in the world and is one of the French Open's main attractions.

DENZEL WASHINGTON and Viola Davis were little more than professional acquaintances when they began rehearsing in March to play husband and wife in the Broadway revival of August Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama ''Fences.'' They had worked together briefly on the 2002 film ''Antwone Fisher,'' Mr. Washington's directorial debut, but there had been no bonding. ''Polite and formal'' was how Ms. Davis described their interaction back then. Yet now, after five weeks of performances, Mr. Washington and Ms. Davis display a warmth and playfulness with each other that reflect the essential rapport of any successful Troy and Rose Maxson, who, after 18 years of marriage, are each other's source of hope in a world of otherwise expired dreams.

SHOP: Start at the Oxbow Public Market (610 and 644 First Street, Napa; 707-226-6529; oxbowpublicmarket.com), a covered marketplace chockablock with specialty food stalls, including an organic ice cream shop and an outpost of the Hog Island Oyster Company. From there, meander over to Cake Plate (1000 Main Street, Suite 100, Napa; 707-226-2300; cakeplateonline.com) for creative cupcakes as well as bright and graphic women's clothing by the likes of Trina Turk, Orla Kiely and Leifsdottir. A report in the Rail horse racing roundup last Sunday about the attendance at Pimlico Race Course for the Preakness Stakes program on Saturday, May 15, misstated the 2009 program's total handle, the wagering on the day's races from all sources. It was $86,684,470 -- not $73,457,510, which was the total handle for 2008. The article also referred incorrectly to the change in the total handle from 2009 to 2010, when it was $79,209,170. Last year, visitors to the Hong Kong International Art Fair (hongkongartfair.com) were greeted by a scene of Martina Navratilova bouncing paint-covered tennis balls off canvases, while fashionable crowds mingled behind her at a Champagne bar. Who knows what surprises there will this time around at ART HK - the event's other moniker - on May 27, when it opens to the public. The fair, in its third year, has bulked up to include about 150 galleries from about 30 countries and states. Each will have a booth in the sprawling space at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center. Among those expected to participate are such notable names as White Cube from London, Galerie Emmanuel Perrotin from Paris and Lehmann Maupin from New York as well as ShanghART and Long March Space from China.

LAUFMAN--Harold, MD, PhD Retired vascular surgeon, professor, artist and violinist, passed away peacefully in his sleep of natural causes at his home on May 3, 2010. He was 98. Dr. Laufman was the son of the late Jacob Laufman and Sophia Pietrokowski. He is survived by his children Dionne Laufman and Laurien Laufman, three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held in New York City on June 6, 2010. Remembrances and notes may be sent to: halaufmemorial@gmail.com. Memorial donations may be made to: University of Chicago School of Medicine, Dept. of Surgery, 924 E. 57th St., Suite 104, Chicago, IL 60637; Rush Medical College, 1653 W. Congress Parkway, Suite 785, Chicago, IL 60612; or National Association for the Visually Handicapped, 22 W. 21st St., 6th Floor, New York, NY 10010.

Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.Q.My friend has a horrible habit of e-mailing, texting and using instant messenger during cocktails and dinner. It's horribly annoying when I'm speaking to her and she picks up the phone to respond to a message. What can I do?A.It's a problem that's becoming endemic and offensive. I would simply lay down the law and say, ''I am not going to socialize with you if you're going to be this rude.'' Maybe you don't want to risk losing a friend, but that's up to you to decide. Or the next time this happens, you might text your friend to say, ''Stop it!''Q.I've recently been invited to a good friend's birthday celebration planned by her boyfriend. The boyfriend put together a barbecue and sent the following request:Please bring veggie burgers, whiskey, veggie dogs, beer, veggie ribs, tequila, vegetables, ice, birthday presents/flowers. Not necessarily in that order. Oh, if you eat meat you can bring that too, no judgment! We will supply music, dancing, the birthday girl, guacamole.I believe when you host a party, you should at least provide the basics. I have to admit, the boyfriend is out of work. In this case, I think it would've been more appropriate to say, ''Hey guys, I'm throwing a barbecue, but I need some help with the fixings. Here's what I need, can you pitch in?'' His approach felt demanding and tacky, regardless of his employment status. Is my annoyance justified or am I being uptight?A.The whole thing could have been handled in a more gracious fashion. My first reaction is to wonder whether you personally have to bring all this stuff or whether it's a pick-and-choose affair, like potluck Thanksgiving at our house. I would assume you only have to bring one of these items, but usually when somebody has a potluck they assign various categories in consultation with the guests. For this affair, it's worth calling the host to nail down the specifics. We once did a potluck dinner and didn't specify, and all but one couple brought dessert. My husband was very happy but some of the guests were nonplussed. It would also have been helpful if the host had specified ''no gifts.'' I think if you're expected to bring dinner, it would have been nice to know that you don't have to go shopping for a scarf or sweater, too.Q.I was raised to believe it was polite to offer a tablemate a taste but rude to request one. I eat out once a week with a friend. She always asks to try my selections, even for pretty basic dishes like a Caesar salad. If I offer to split our orders, she always demurs, saying she just wants ''a little taste.'' Then she shovels a heaping forkful into her mouth! I've started ordering identical meals to discourage this, but I am in the wrong?

Whether Eve plucked an apple or a pomegranate from the tree may be up for debate, but there's no doubt which fruit is sexier. Especially as interpreted by the New York-based jeweler Tito Pedrini, whose 18 karat gold ''Pomegrani'' earrings are as mouthwatering as the ancient superfruit itself. Comprised of pink opal, mammoth ivory or black onyx sprinkled with pink sapphire ''seeds,'' the earrings are $2,800. Call (212) 888-3355 for an appointment or go to titopedrini.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

These have been some busy weeks for Sean Hayes, the Emmy Award-winning âWill & Graceâ star: heâs been starring on Broadway in the revival of âPromises, Promises,â which netted him a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical. The South Korean president, Lee Myung-bak, said his nation would sever nearly all trade with North Korea, deny North Korean merchant ships use of South Korean sea lanes and ask the United Nations Security Council to punish the North, Choe Sang-Hun and Thom Shanker write. The steps outlined by Mr. Lee in a nationally televised speech - coupled with new moves by South Korea's military to resume "psychological warfare" propaganda broadcasts at the border after a six-year suspension - amounted to the most serious action the South could take short of an armed retaliation for the sinking of a warship two months ago, the South's worst military loss since the Korean War ended.

The American takeover market has become more active. It is a nervous time, however. The strength of any return is uncertain amid a market decline, the continuing ramifications of the Greek-euro crisis and a potential popping of a Chinese real estate bubble. Nonetheless, in this mergers and acquisitions boomlet, we are beginning to see what the takeover market will look like if and when it experiences a sustained return anytime soon.

The actor Michael McKean, the star of "Superior Donuts" on Broadway this season and a featured actor in many films, among them "This is Spinal Tap" and "A Mighty Wind," will assume the role of the Stage Manager in the Off Broadway revival of "Our Town." Mr. McKean, who is still best known in some circles as Lenny on television's "Laverne & Shirley," will begin performing on June 2, succeeding the actor Michael Shannon, who gave his final show on Sunday; Robert Beitzel will play the role in the interim. "Our Town" has been running at the Barrow Street Theater in Greenwich Village since February 2009; the production is directed by David Cromer, who also played the Stage Manager during the show's first several months. Last December, this "Our Town" became the longest-running production of the play in its 72-year history, with its record-setting 337th performance at Barrow Street.

7:23 p.m. | Updated Below The climate blogger Joe Romm and I agree (breaking news): Scientific research and assessments examining the link between human-driven climate change and malaria exposure have, for the most part, accurately gauged and conveyed the nature of the risk that warming could swell the ranks of people afflicted with this awful mosquito-borne disease. I did so last week in a piece on a new study in the journal Nature concluding that efforts to stem the disease are swamping the potential expansion of malaria endemicity from warming; he's done so today in a piece attacking those who chose to report on this news.

Two days after "Presidio Habitats" opened in the Presidio of San Francisco, a stunning 1,491-acre national park in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge, Hal Fischer took a visitor on a tour of the art installation. Fischer is the director of special projects for the FOR-SITE Foundation, the San Francisco arts nonprofit that spearheaded the show, for which 11 international architects, artists and designers created conceptual habitats for the park's animal residents. The first site-based exhibition organized for and presented in a United States national park, the pieces in "Presidio Habitats" will be up for a full year, until May 15, 2011 - unless furry and winged residents actually move into their new high-design homes, in which case their leases will be extended indefinitely, by decree of Presidio Trust naturalists. But will the Western screech owl actually find the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei's glazed blue-and-white porcelain vessels hospitable, tethered in the branches of a cypress tree?Â  Only time shall tell.

There were three reasons to watch "Lost"Â - or to stick with it, more aptly, across six immensely engrossing and immensely frustrating seasons. You could watch for the characters, who were two-dimensional and archetypal in a way, but rich and relatable and even lovable in the way that great pulp casts can sometimes be. You could watch for the thrill of it - the endless cliffhangers, the constant narrative whiplash, the mobius-strip plotting, and the way the show could blithely disassemble and reassemble its narrative architecture (flashbacks followed by flashforwards! flashforwards followed by time travel!) and somehow have the whole thing work. And of course, you could watch for the macro-plotÂ - the mythology of a mysterious island, which layered puzzle atop riddle atop intrigue like no show since "The X-Files," promising all the while (or seeming to promise, at least) to be building up to a revelatory denouement.

Newsom Will Take Sidewalk Law to Voters | Facing stiff opposition from the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, Mayor Gavin Newsom will ask voters to weigh in on his proposal to ban sitting down on sidewalks during certain hours. The so-called sit/lie law is scheduled to be heard before the board's Public Safety Committee on Monday; San Francisco voters can expect to see it on the November ballot. Advocates for prostitutes and the homeless oppose the law. While proponents say it will be used to focus on aggressive behavior by some sidewalk dwellers, others see the law as an attack on the city's most vulnerable, prohibiting them from sitting or lying down on the sidewalk from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. "It is extremely hard to stay moving your whole waking day," Neil Donovan, executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless, told The New York Times. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times]

"Art doesn't go to sleep in the bed made for it. What it likes is to be incognito. Its best moments are when it forgets what its own name is," once said Jean Dubuffet, founder of the Art Brut movement, who sought creativity anywhere but in museums. This is precisely the challenge that the new gallery Le Pied de Biche ("The Crowbar") has picked: Who says galleries ought to show strictly art? Don't books, tattoo drawings and toys also deserve an outlet? Their inaugural exhibition, "Art, Ink and Rock and Roll," which runs through June 2, addresses just these questions.

Urbanspoon made a name for itself with a mobile application that served up listings of nearby eateries after you gave the phone a hearty shake. Now, the company is hoping to make fresh ripples in the restaurant industry with a reservation system designed to work on the iPad.

ROSE--Herbert B.,80, died peacefully on May 22. He was the beloved and loving husband of Bernice Rose, and the dear son of the late Elsie and Alex Rose, legendary leader of the American labor movement, founder of the Liberal Party of New York, and an ardent Zionist. He was the brother of the late Carmi Schwartz, and an esteemed and admired uncle, great uncle, cousin, colleague, and friend. Herbert will be missed always. Professionally, he was a leading legal advisor to American Jewish communal organizations. He served with distinction for decades as general counsel to the national United Jewish Appeal. Subsequently he was also counsel to the United Israel Appeal, one of two constituent organizations of the UJA, which was responsible for funding the Jewish Agency for Israel through the UJA/federation campaign. He was legal counsel to the UJA-Federation of Greater New York for many years and was deeply involved in the historic merger of the United Jewish Appeal and the Council of Jewish Federations to create United Jewish Communities, now know as the Jewish Federation of North America. He also served as the general counsel of the American Technion Society. His long career with these organizations saw the unfolding of dramatic events in Israeli and American Jewish life, including wars and terrorism in the Middle East, unprecedented fundraising campaigns, and organizational change in the U.S. He handled his involvement on the frontlines of Jewish history with characteristic poise, equanimity, and brilliance as an attorney and advisor to leading professional and volunteer figures in American Jewish life. Herbert was educated at Harvard Law School and Syracuse University and was for nearly 50 years the senior partner of Rose and Boxer and its predecessor firms. Services will be held on Tuesday, May 25 at 10am at the Metropolitan Synagogue, 40 East 35th Street. Donations may be made in memory of Herbert B. Rose to the American Lung Association.

At a recent clinic, Annika Sorenstam said she worried that few amateur players, especially women, know that they might be using club grips ill-suited for the size of their hands. ''I see so many players, especially women, using grips that are too big for them,'' Sorenstam said. ''For the women, it might be because they borrowed someone's clubs when they started playing or maybe they are using hand-me-down clubs from their husband or boyfriend. They never thought about whether the grips mattered. But when you grip any club, your fingers should touch the other side of your hand below the thumb near the palm.
Forget the standard college sweatshirt. At Oberlin College, not many students wear college-logo clothes anyway.

Mandeep Singh Dhillon's son, Zoraver, learned how to take pictures of himself with his father's computer when he was 4 years old, and he immediately wanted to share the results with relatives online. Mr. Dhillon liked the idea of his son developing skills at an early age that he would use for a lifetime, but was also hesitant to let Zoraver loose on the open Internet. He began working on an alternative. Three years later the result is Togetherville, a social networking site intended for use by children ages 6 to 10 and their parents. It aims to keep children safe from cyberbullying and other online dangers while allowing them to become comfortable with online interaction. The site, which has been in private beta for several months, was opened to the public on Tuesday night.

While playing the fifth hole during their club's opening day tournament, Ken and Larry hit tee shots that came to rest in a bunker left of the fairway. Mike's ball landed in a bunker right of the fairway and Norm's ball stopped just outside the same bunker. While hitting his ball, Ken took too much sand and left his ball in the bunker, advancing it only 20 yards. Larry also hit a fat shot. His ball came to rest in the same bunker about 30 yards closer to the hole. Ken's caddie raked the area that Ken had played from and then gave the rake to Larry's caddie, who smoothed the sand where Larry had played from. Larry's caddie then saw that there were several footprints in the area where Larry would be standing for his next shot, so he also smoothed the sand in that area.

JOHANNESBURG -- The official mascot of Africa's first World Cup -- a stuffed leopard with spiked green hair -- was made in China. The official World Cup anthem, ''Waka Waka (This Time for Africa),'' was written by the Colombian pop star Shakira. The official restaurant? McDonald's. And with less than three weeks before the world's most watched sporting event, only 36,000 of the almost three million tickets have been sold in Africa outside of South Africa itself, the host. On a continent whose people mostly live on the wrong side of the digital divide, tickets were mainly marketed online.

MOGADISHU, Somalia -- At least 14 people were killed and more than 25 were wounded on Sunday in heavy fighting between government troops and insurgents who attacked the presidential palace with mortars, witnesses and officials said. At least six mortar shells landed near the palace, witnesses said, but the president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed, was in Turkey at a United Nations conference called to help Somalia.

McERLEAN--Thomas Michael, 51, of New York, NY and Block Island, RI (formerly of Morristown, NJ and Wilton, CT) died suddenly on May 21 in New York City. Tom graduated from Iona Preparatory School in 1976 and from Iona College with a degree in business in 1981. His successful Wall Street career spanned over 25 years beginning at Freeman Securities before joining Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, as a bond trader and UBS where he was a Managing Director. Tom was most recently a Senior Vice President and Head of Credit Trading for Alliance Bernstein. Tom will be remembered for his fabulous sense of humor, enthusiasm and energy for life which included flying his Piper Saratoga. He was a devoted husband to his beloved wife, Kathy (Wild); a loving and proud father to his daughter Elizabeth Ann and his son Charles Thomas. He is also survived by his parents John Thomas and Agnes (Inglesby), of Westerly, RI; four sisters, Ann of Westerly, RI, Marie Hunter (Kevin) of North Caldwell, NJ, Agnes Duhamel (Chris) of Westerly, RI and Catherine Francese (Carl) of New Rochelle, NY; as well as seven nieces and 12 nephews. He was predeceased by his brother, John Thomas, Jr. (Beth McCarthy McErlean Pierce). Visiting hours are Tuesday, May 25, 2-4 and 7-9pm., John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Funeral Mass, Wednesday, May 26 at 11am, St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Block Island Conservancy, PO Box 84, Block Island, RI 02807.

Late on Tuesday night Bob Arihood posted a photograph of Hare Krishnas chanting rapturously in Tompkins Square Park on his blog, Neither More Nor Less, then added a headline: ''Basta ! ... No More. This is the Final Post at NMNL.'' It seems unlikely that there will ever be a shortage of blogs focusing on the East Village, but for many longtime residents of the neighborhood, Mr. Arihood's site stood apart from dozens of others.

WANETIK--Burton M.,88, of Monroe Township, NJ and formerly of Rego Park, NY, died peacefully at home on May 22. Survived by his best friend and loving wife of 65 years, Shirley. Beloved and respected father to Abbey and David and daughter-in-law Joan Rosenberg. Adored by his grandchildren Adam and Chandra and her husband Kevin Campbell. And Pop Pop to his wonderful great-grandchildren Kylie, Kevin, Kiernan and Gracie. Graduate of Duquesne University. Very proud to have been a licensed Pharmacist for 60 years and the former owner of Alburt Pharmacy in the Bronx. A career in radio spanning from KDKA in Pittsburgh to WREB in Holyoke, MA, to WNBC in New York. A life long member of B'nai B'rith, rising to the position of International Vice President. First President of the Queens B'nai B'rith House for Seniors. Former President of Skin Culture Institute, Inc. A brilliant public speaker and the best salesman that ever lived. A mentor to many and respected by all who knew him personally and professionally. One of the really good guys from the greatest generation. Funeral scheduled on Tuesday May 25 at 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Donations in memory can be made to the B'nai B'rith Housing Foundation 138-49 Elder Ave., Flushing NY 11355.

Media criticism has been boiled down to a single, painful word: fail. The activist group Free Press has built a Digg-like Web site for such mistakes, called MediaFail, that highlights what its users think are the most egregious examples of the ''media behaving badly,'' to borrow its slogan.

Three vehicles in a motorcade taking former President Bill Clinton to Yale University to give a speech on Sunday afternoon were involved in a minor accident, the Connecticut State Police said. The vehicles from Mr. Clinton's motorcade and two other vehicles were involved in the accident, which took place on the Merritt Parkway just north of New Haven, Lt. J. Paul Vance of the State Police said. One person was taken to a hospital with a minor injury.

Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, has a vision of how the foreboding national political environment might evolve to his party's advantage. The old debate, in Mr. Emanuel's telling, pitted Big Government against Small Government. Republicans won it in 1980 when Ronald Reagan shattered the Democratic coalition that produced the New Deal and the Great Society.

SCHWARZSCHILD--Martin, 81, of New York City, son of the late Grete and Dr. Ludwig Schwarzschild died May 21, 2010 in Florida. He is survived by his sister Lore Singerman (Mark) of Annapolis, MD, his nephews Jeffrey Singerman (Dr. Ruth) of New York City, Rabbi Murray Singerman (Shifra) of Baltimore, MD and ten great nieces and nephews. He was director of Camp Pine Cone, Hancock, NY, the Roosevelt School, Stamford, Conn. and the Bronxwood Home for the Aged. He was the past president of the Jewish Center and a member of several Boards, including the Blue Card, Camp Morasha and others. He worked tirelessly on behalf of Soviet Jewery. Graveside services Monday, May 24, at 10:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery, Ordell, NJ. Donations in Martin's memory may be made to the Jewish Center at 131 West 86 Street, New York, NY 10024.

GIEL--Charles P. MD, passed away on Saturday, May 22nd at his Brooklyn home. Born in 1921 in Flint, MI.; the son of Marie Oldenbach Giel and George Giel. He was a graduate of the NYU School of Medicine where he was later Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine and President of the Alumni Association. Dr. Giel was for over thirty years the Medical Director at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, a leader in employee healthcare. He was a dedicated physician, a scholar of ancient history and a passionate gardener. Charles is survived by his companion of fifty-five years, Neil Calet, his niece, Rebecca Ferguson of Byron Point, CA., the loving and grateful Geller family and by the heroic Serhiy Mshanetskiy. Visiting at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday May 26th, 5pm-8pm. There will be a Requiem Mass at The Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Sidney Pl., Brooklyn Heights, Thursday, May 27th, 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYU School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, NY 10016.

LEVEY--Martin H.,(Marty Brayer), of Westport, CT. Beloved husband of the late Bunny. Adored father of Robin Levey and Gail Levey Schorr. Cherished grandfather of Nathaniel Schorr, Ethan Schorr and Max Kupperberg fiance of Marlene Dorison. Service Monday 11am at the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale. 3700 Henry Hudson Parkway, Bronx, NY. The family will observe the Shiva period at the home of Martin Levey in Westport, CT. Donations may be made to the Mid-Fairfield Hospice.

FRENCH--Barbara M.,of Manhattan and Sagaponack, Long Island, died on May 14, 2010 at her Manhattan home at age 97. She was predeceased in 1995 by her husband of 56 years, James. H. French, and is survived by their two children, John R. French and Carey F. Millard, John's wife, Leigh C. French, and Carey's husband, John A. Millard. She is also survived by six grandchildren, Hilary F. Louchheim, James Alexander French, Ashley F. Weymouth, John Alden Millard, Jr., James G. Millard and Alexander F. Millard, eight great-grandchildren, a step-grandchild, Jennifer Q. Deinard, and two step-great grandchildren. She was a granddaughter of F.A.O. Schwarz who founded the toy store of that name. A graduate of The Brearley School and Vassar College, she received a Masters from Columbia University. She was active in many volunteer organizations in New York City and served as a Trustee of The Brearley School (1958-1961). She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club where she served as a Governor (1969-1972). Inspired by her love of the natural world and of Sagaponack, she was a charter member of the Group for the South Fork (now the Group for the East End). She served the Group as a Director (1972-1988), as Chairman of the Board (1987-1988) and, for 20 years thereafter, as a member of its Advisory Committee. She was beloved by her family and will be missed by all who knew her. Pursuant to her wishes, no services are planned. A private family remembrance will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Group for the East End, P.O. Box 569, Bridgehampton, New York 11932.

BEIJING -- In the best of times, Chinese foreign affairs scholars here say, Beijing grits its teeth while playing best friend to Kim Jong-il, North Korea's ailing and erratic 68-year-old leader. South Korea's charge last week that North Korea sank one of its warships, killing 46 crewmen, makes that role exponentially harder. With Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and about 200 other American officials here for high-level security and economic talks, Chinese leaders face two unpalatable options. One is to mollify North Korea, and risk undermining its efforts to convince the United States, South Korea and Japan that China is a stabilizing force in East Asia.

Goldberg, mother of Maggie Bar-tura, J.J., Josh and Deb Goldberg. Mother-in-law of Amiram Bar-tura, Shifra Bronznick, Karen Goldberg, Clifford Cohen, Savta Lee to Shai, Asaf, Jordan, Arielle, Emma, Coby, Sam, Kiki. Matriarch to the Goldberg-Field-Learsi clan. May her memory be a blessing. Donations to UJA-Federation or Habonim Camp Naaleh.

MADRID -- Weaknesses in the Spanish financial sector were exposed over the weekend when the central bank was forced to rescue CajaSur, a savings bank crippled by property-related losses and unable to agree on a merger with a bigger rival. The Bank of Spain said on Saturday that it had taken over the management of CajaSur, appointing administrators and injecting 550 million euros (about $700 million) from a special restructuring fund to keep the bank afloat.

Jose Lima went 0-4 with a 9.87 earned run average in four starts for the Mets in 2006. I had to look that up. I have little recollection of how Lima fared during his brief time as a Met. My memories of Lima, who died Sunday of a heart attack at age 37, are not of him as a pitcher. For as long as I live, I will remember the look on Pedro Martinez's face when he was informed that Lima had signed a minor league contract with the Mets. Martinez, as I wrote in February 2006, ''buried his face in his hands and started laughing uncontrollably.''

In an attempt to understand the art of caddying better, I carried the bag for the L.P.G.A. star Brittany Lincicome during the pro-am tournament Wednesday at the Sybase Match Play Championship in New Jersey (a version of my article about that day is available at http://tinyurl.com/27ksylp). But looping for Lincicome was only half the experience. Just as educational may have been the hours I spent hanging around the real caddies at the tournament site, Hamilton Farm Golf Club. Some of them said they had caddied more than 7,000 rounds in their lives. And those were the young ones with good memories; the real vets gave up counting a long time ago.

Services Tuesday 11:15am at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street. Donations in Renee's memory can be made to The Legal Aid Society, Juvenile Rights Practice, Sirote-Hirsch Fund, 199 Water St, NYC, 10038.

Literary publishers and writers tend to roll their eyes at book trailers, the short videos intended to promote new books. So much so, in fact, that one book blog, MobyLives, recently started a contest for the ''Best and Worst Book Trailers,'' to ''spoof the fact that the book business too often looks to the movie business as a model,'' said Dennis Johnson, the founder of MobyLives. The winners of the Moby Awards were announced last week. Mr. Johnson said the organizers were surprised to find that there were some decent videos in the bunch.

LEDERMAN--Sol died 52/10/d. Predeceased by his wife of 66 years, Mildred. Graduated from the Columbia School of Pharmacy in 1942. Loving father of Ellen and Martin Rosenman. Devoted grandfather to Hayley and Coby Rejwan, Craig and Shira Rosenman, and Lloyd and Brooke Rosenman. Great-grandfather to four beautiful great granddaughters. A man of great strength and character. His glass was always half full. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck at 11am.

At this point, Microsoft must have developed its own seminar for employees called something like Apologizing With Optimism: How to Persuade People to Give You Another Try. It seems that one product after another -- Windows 7, Windows Phone 7, Bing and now a revamped Hotmail, due this summer -- arrive with Microsoft admitting it could have done more with previous versions of its software, while promising people that things really are better this time around -- honest. In fact, things are so good with Microsoft's latest X that you'll be willing to dump your beloved Y.

Six years ago, I had a regular job, in an office. I was there 9 or 10 hours a day, made a decent living and even found the work occasionally interesting. But I was also bored. More than bored - I was restless. Perhaps like many of you, my readers, I lived for the week or two a year when I could venture out into the world to explore, and in the intervening months at home I'd live vicariously through other people's tales of adventure.

N.F.L. owners tabled a vote on implementing the new overtime rules in the regular season. Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league wanted to see how the new rules - which call for each team to get a possession in overtime unless the team that wins the overtime toss scores a touchdown on the first possession - work during the postseason before considering whether to put them in for the regular season. Owners also wanted to consult further with the players association about the impact the new rules would have on players. They will take up the issue again after the season, even though coaches - who were not in favor of the new rules for the post-season - had hoped to have them put in for the regular season, too.

Tim Hawkinson likes to tinker. In his first solo exhibition with the Los Angeles gallery Blum & Poe, which opened on Saturday, the artist not only tinkers with scale, moving parts and myriad materials, but also grapples with big life issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time. The centerpiece of the exhibition is a monumental kinetic sculpture called "Orrery," a reference to apparatuses that represent the motions and phases of the solar system. A larger-than-life figure of a woman, at once benign and sinister - is she Mother Time, perhaps? - sits at a spinning wheel made of recycled plastic bottles. Everything about the sculpture is circular, interconnected and eternally spinningÂ  -- the woman's ears, fingers and the bun on her head;Â  the spinning wheel and the circular platform on which she sits. Even the pattern on her dress, a motion illusion designed by a Japanese psychology professor, seems to spin. The effect is hypnotic as both viewer and figure cycle between the material and cosmic worlds.

COMBAT OUTPOST LILY, Helmand Province- For Marines who have experienced combat together, the many rituals and gestures of bidding farewell to the dead, beginning from the point of medevac and continuing beyond the fallen Marine's journey to the grave, are observed with a devotion that is at once quiet, fiercely followed and unsummoned. The more formal rituals are matters of tradition, likeÂ  memorial services in the field and the escorts who accompany a dead Marine through his or her funeral back home. Some Marines are further memorialized in the names of outposts and landing zones; thus, "Combat Outpost Hanson" and the adjacent "Landing Zone Currier," named after two Marines from Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines, who were killed several hundred yards from here in fighting against the Taliban in February. Other gestures are impromptu, spontaneous and intensely personal, propelled by feelings that take hold within young infantrymen who fight through ambush after ambush together, and who find, as their tattoos often say, that they are bound by blood and then by a set of memories that will be theirs alone for the decades ahead.

Though the romantic entanglements of Liz tend not to last too long, her creator and performer is about to receive an honor that's a little more enduring. On Tuesday the Kennedy CenterÂ announced that it would present its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor to Ms. Fey, the "30 Rock" star, "Saturday Night Live" alumna and occasional cribber of punch lines from her daughter, Alice. In the 13-year history of the prize, Ms. Fey will be the third woman to receive it: it was previously presented to Lily Tomlin in 2003 and Whoopi Goldberg in 2001. The police in Iowa said that they would have more information on the death of Paul Gray, the bassist and a co-founder of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, after an autopsy on Tuesday, but that foul play was not immediately suspected, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gray, 38, was found dead on Monday at a TownePlace Suites hotel in Johnston, Iowa, north of Des Moines. In the early 1990s he helped found Slipknot, the nihilistic if highly theatrical band whose members wear gruesome masks and refer to themselves by numbers and evocative nicknames. (Mr. Gray went by No. 2 or "The Pig.") The group -- which also includes the vocalist Corey Taylor, the guitarists James Root and Mick Thomson, and the drummer Joey Jordison -- won a Grammy in 2005 for its song "Before I Forget," and its 2008 album, "All Hope Is Gone," reached No. 1 on the Billboard sales chart.

Alexandra Drane was one of the many entrepreneurs who thought she could do it all. Ms. Drane is co-founder and president of Eliza Corporation, a firm based in Beverly, Mass., that uses patented technology to communicate with health plan members, often with automated calls to encourage them to take advantage of the services their plans offer. She joined Eliza in 1999, when it consisted of just two scientists and a technology that she was charged with commercializing. She recruited the chief executive, Lucas Merrow, and by 2004, Eliza had hired engineering and operations teams. But when it came to Ms. Drane's responsibilities -- sales, marketing and account management -- she was largely a solo operator. That was around the time, she said, that a board member read her "the riot act," insisting that the company would not be able to achieve scale until she started hiring.

DAVIS--Mary Thompson, 82, died quietly after a short illness Saturday, May 22, 2010. Visitation Tuesday, May 25th 10am, Service at 11am, at R.G. Ortiz Funeral Home, 235 West 72nd St., NYC.
KLEIN--Richard L.,decorated World War II veteran, former husband of Norma, loving father of Ted and Madeline, died in New York City on May 21, age 87. Burial private.

GOLDFARB--Daniel D.,M.D., Allentown, PA, aged 62. He was dearly loved by his wife and soulmate of 40 years, Debbie, his children Lisa and Jack, and his brother Ron. He will be missed by the many people whose lives he's touched. Donations may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation.

HANDLER--Jerry S.,of New York City, West Hampton, L.I., Jackson Hole, Wyoming, died peacefully in the arms of his loving family at Mt. Sinai Hospital, on May 24, 2010, at age 80. He is survived by his beautiful wife of nearly 60 years, Lyn Handler, three children: Scott Handler, Sharon Handler and Dawn H. Harbart, and four grandchildren: Jonathan Handler, Darell Handler, Victoria Handler and Zoe Harbart, and his devoted sister, Shirley Horodas He was the son of Maurice S. Handler who built Smart Maid Suit & Co., one of America's leading coat & suit manufacturers during and after WWII. His father was also a great philanthropist and, among other things, was one of the original founders of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. After graduating from Wharton School of Finance & Commerce, Jerry founded, built and grew Newmark & Co. for nearly 40 years, along with Aaron Gural and Jack Schenker, today, one of New York City's largest commercial real estate firms. Along with his wife Lyn, he was a staunch supporter of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. They devoted over 40 years to medical research and education, as well as to the well being of the sick and less fortunate. Early on, Jerry became a "Founding Father" of Einstein's Young Men's Division; and later became a member of its Executive Board, as well as the Overseers Committee. Jerry also received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University, was the Chairman of the Board of The Yonkers Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, served as a Lt. Col. and Executive Officer of the 5th Regiment, Civil Affairs of the 56th Brigade of the New York State Guard, as well as an active member of The Police Reserve Association of the City of New York, which establishes, among other things, fellowships for children of police officers. A man proud of his roots and traditions, Jerry was a devoted husband and family man, a loyal supporter of the philanthropies to which he was committed, and all those whose lives he touched will miss him terribly and hold memories of him dear in their hearts.

HANDLER--Jerry. The Gural Family extends its heartfelt condolences to Lynn, Scott, Sharon, Dawn and the entire Handler family on the loss of their beloved husband, father and family member Jerry Handler. Mr. Handler was a former partner, esteemed colleague and cherished friend at Newmark Knight Frank. In addition, Jerry was a trusted partner and friend of Aaron Gural and the entire Gural family for over fifty years. With Mr. Handler's passing comes great loss and he will be sincerely missed by us all.

WANETIK--Burton M.,88, of Monroe Township, NJ and formerly of Rego Park, NY, died peacefully at home on May 22. Survived by his best friend and loving wife of 65 years, Shirley. Beloved and respected father to Abbey and David and daughter-in-law Joan Rosenberg. Adored by his grandchildren Adam and Chandra and her husband Kevin Campbell. And Pop Pop to his wonderful great-grandchildren Kylie, Kevin, Kiernan and Gracie. Graduate of Duquesne University. Very proud to have been a licensed Pharmacist for 60 years and the former owner of Alburt Pharmacy in the Bronx. A career in radio spanning from KDKA in Pittsburgh to WREB in Holyoke, MA, to WNBC in New York. A life long member of B'nai B'rith, rising to the position of International Vice President. First President of the Queens B'nai B'rith House for Seniors. Former President of Skin Culture Institute, Inc. A brilliant public speaker and the best salesman that ever lived. A mentor to many and respected by all who knew him personally and professionally. One of the really good guys from the greatest generation. Funeral scheduled on Tuesday May 25 at 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Donations in memory can be made to the B'nai B'rith Housing Foundation 138-49 Elder Ave., Flushing NY 11355.

WARSH--Ray, 97. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Mother of Susan and Lewis, mother-in-law of Katt Lissard, beloved grandmother of her five grandchildren and their partners, Marie (Steve Bopp), Sophia, Max (Alyssa Gorelick), Joanna Dragich (Louisa Wang) and Rose Bevans (Seth Feinberg). Ray received her BA and MA from Hunter College, where she was Phi Beta Kappa and taught in the NYC school system for 30 years. She died peacefully in her home in Chelsea.

Donald E. Lukens, who helped push his party to the right as a vigorous leader of the Young Republicans in the 1960s and who resigned from Congress in scandal two decades later, died Saturday in Dallas. TIPOGRAPH--Joan Hillary Stockhamer, loving wife, mother, daughter, sister, aunt and friend; died May 22, 2010, NYC, of complications from pneumonia. Survived by husband Peter; children, Lindsey, Austin; Parents: Nathan and Kathleen. Joan was a spirited, brilliant, creative, person and dedicated guidance counselor. Funeral Service, May 26, 11am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Ave, (20/21). In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: NYU, Att: Development, Gift Office; Donation to: 15 W. Critical Care Ctr, 560 1st Ave, NY, NY 10016.

DUPUY--Peter G. March 25, 1947--May 16, 2010. Peter G. DuPuy 63, of Keene, NH, died May 16, 2010, at Catholic Medical Center in Manchester, NH, following a brief illness. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, March 25, 1947, son of Charles M. and Lois (Graham) DuPuy. He lived in Ligonier, Pennsylvania, before moving to Greenwich, CT, at an early age. He was a graduate of the Fay School and Taber Academy in Marion, MA. He attended McMurray College in Ohio. He moved to Keene, NH in 1985. Mr. DuPuy was a renowned international collector and exhibitor of stamps, was a model railroad enthusiast, an avid chess player and a collector of antique cars. He was a long time New England Patriots and Boston Red Sox fan. Mr. DuPuy is survived by his partner and wife of 21 years, Jess DuPuy of Keene: two daughters, Juliet Rozhon of Burlington, Vermont, Jillian Reinegger and her husband Mike of Savannah, Georgia; a brother, Charles DuPuy and his wife Janet of Manchester, Maine; two sisters, Susette Lyons and her husband Charles of Northampton, MA, and Aimee Whitman and her husband Harold of Bedford Hills, New York; nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions be made in Mr. DuPuy's memory to the Keene Community Kitchen, P.O. Box 1315, Keene 03431 or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Greater New England Chapter, 101A First Ave., Waltham, MA 02451.

ROSE--Herbert B. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Herbert B. Rose. Herbert displayed unwavering commitment as a legal advisor to United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York and to many other American Jewish communal organizations. His devotion to social and humanitarian causes enriched the lives of many in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our condolences to his wife, Bernice, and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

RAVIV--Adina Judith, 67, of Maplewood, NJ, passed away on Sunday, May 23, 2010. Devoted wife of Dan Raviv, loving mother of Gil Raviv of New York, NY, excited mother-in-law to be of Emily Rukin of New York, NY and loyal sister to Gabriella Carmi of Ramat Gan, Israel, Adina was an accomplished artist in numerous media. Born in Tel Aviv, Israel, Adina served in the Israeli Air Force, studied at the Bezalel Academy in Jerusalem, and earned degrees from the London College of Printing in London, England and the New School in New York. Adina immigrated to the United States in 1967, where she and Dan lived in New Mexico for a time before settling in New Jersey. In addition to her artistic pursuits, Adina established and successfully operated for many years a floral design and event planning business, and of late had embarked on a third career in real estate. She actively volunteered with the New York Philharmonic and the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Adina was deeply devoted to her community as well as to her family and friends, and her boundless energy, intelligence, sense of humor, creativity, kindness and beauty will not be forgotten by everyone whose lives she touched. Funeral services will be held at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road in Union, NJ at 11:30 am Tuesday, May 25, 2010. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Lustgarten Foundation, Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union Counties, Arts, Drama and Music Fund or the Jewish National Fund.

BLACK--Jean Gumport, 84, died on May 22, 2010. She was a native New Yorker educated at The Birch Wathen School and graduated from Connecticut College for Women in 1947. Jean was predeceased by Sandy, her husband of 56 years, in October 2004. After raising their children in Scarsdale, New York, she returned to school to earn her MSW. Jean and Sandy moved to Stamford, CT for eleven years prior to their permanent move to Naples in 1986 to enjoy retirement and the friendships made at Beachwalk, The Vineyards, and Bentley Village. Jean is survived by her daughter Sandra "Sam" Black and her husband Jon Pipkin of St. Louis MO, and her son Gary and grandson Ray of Dallas, TX. She was predeceased by her brother Robert (Lois) Gumport of Carlsbad, CA and their family. She was also predeceased by her son Bruce in 1973. A memorial service will be held in Naples at Bentley Village, The Care Center Tuesday May 25 at 4pm.

HANDLER--Jerry S. Albert Einstein College of Medicine records with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend and Overseer Jerry Handler. Introduced to Einstein by his father, Maurice, Jerry became a passionate and lifelong supporter of the College's educational and research programs. An Einstein Benefactor along with his beloved wife, Lyn, Jerry was one of a small group of philanthropists who founded our Men's Division in 1961; he was a Division Past Chair, as is his son, Scott. He received an honorary doctorate from Yeshiva University in 1989. Jerry's warmth, wisdom and friendship will be sorely missed. To Lyn, Scott, Sharon, Dawn, and the entire family, we extend heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers

''Tech Transfer'' is the deceptively mild title of a mordant satire about scientists and universities and how they do business. The best scene in this hilarious first novel is a meeting of the trustees of Kershaw University, an elite research university only 200 years younger than Harvard. The trustees have to select a new president. They listen with mounting dismay as the professional headhunter in charge of the search reads out the polished rÃ©sumÃ©s of each candidate, but notes in each case the fatal flaws revealed by background checks, ranging from spousal abuse to bestiality and, even more fatal, plagiarism.

Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

BAKER--Collette Ramsey, Founder Deafness Research Foundation. Vero Beach, FL. On May 9, this remarkable woman passed away at 91 with her adoring husband and devoted companion of twenty-two years, Maurice Baker, constantly at her side. She was born in 1918 in Waverly, Tennessee. In her young adulthood, she became a favorite model of the renowned painter, Howard Chandler Christy. She was also a famous amateur golfer, setting the women's record at her home club, Baltusrol in New Jersey, winning its club championship for four consecutive years. After living with a substantial hearing loss for many years, at age 35 she had her hearing completely restored with an early fenestration operation. In gratitude, just over 50 years ago she founded the Deafness Research Foundation (DRF), for which she became widely known and respected, and was listed in Who's Who for Women. Under her leadership, DRF gave grants to colleges and other research institutions for research and improvement of hearing. Since 1958, DRF has given over $25.5 million and over 2,000 grants to hearing and balance research. Mrs. Ramsey Baker received letters of commendation from many leaders and well-known people including Hoover, Eisenhower, Helen Keller, Cardinal Spellman, and others. In 1960, Mrs. Ramsey Baker and the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head Neck Surgery established the National Temporal Bone Banks Program to encourage individuals with ear disorders to pledge their temporal bones at death for scientific research. The program has grown into the National Temporal Bone Hearing and Balance Pathology Resource Registry sponsored by NIH's National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders. Mrs. Ramsey Baker is survived by her husband Maurice Baker of Vero Beach, FL, her brother Charles Nicks of Hayesville, NC, her daughters Collette Wynn of Washington Depot, CT, and Janet Conrad of West Chester, PA, eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She was previously married to Hobart Cole Ramsey, a wonderful husband and father. She was blessed to have two such loving partners in her life. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her name to Deafness Research Foundation, 641 Lexington Avenue, 15th Floor, New York NY 10022-4503, www.drf.org.

The Islanders have canceled their training camp trip to China planned for this fall over a disagreement between Islanders owner Charles Wang and the N.H.L. Players' Association, sources close to the team confirmed on Monday. The nine-day trip was announced in February as a way to spread word of the game in China and at the time, the team said the N.H.L., the players' association and the Chinese government had all signed off on the details.

PARIS -- The United States on Tuesday will unveil the newly restored HÃ´tel de Talleyrand, the historic Parisian palace on the Place de la Concorde that once served as the headquarters of the Marshall Plan, the postwar American reconstruction plan for Western Europe. The restoration took nine years and cost about $5 million, financed by more than 100 donors from both sides of the Atlantic and absorbing the efforts of about 150 French artisans.

According to a 2008 study, the 10 foods that pose the highest choking hazards for young children are hot dogs, peanuts, carrots, boned chicken, candy, meat, popcorn, fish with bones, sunflower seeds and apples. Dr. Gary Smith, the lead author of American Academy of Pediatrics' policy statement on food hazards, says some foods should simply not be given to children under 4 or 5: he mentioned raw carrots, marshmallows, peanuts, popcorn, hard candies and gumballs.

Lawyers representing Michael Mineo, a Brooklyn man who said he was sodomized by a New York City police officer as he was being arrested in 2008, have filed papers in federal court alleging that police investigators tampered with an important piece of evidence -- Mr. Mineo's boxer shorts -- in order to protect the arresting officers from criminal charges. Mr. Mineo's lawyers say the investigators altered the shape of a tear in Mr. Mineo's boxers from one with an L-shaped flap to one with a square hole.

GIEL--Charles P. MD, passed away on Saturday, May 22nd at his Brooklyn home. Born in 1921 in Flint, MI; the son of Marie Oldenbach Giel and George Giel. He was a graduate of the NYU School of Medicine where he was later Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine and President of the Alumni Association. Dr. Giel was for over thirty years the Medical Director at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, a leader in employee healthcare. He was a dedicated physician, a scholar of ancient history and a passionate gardener. Charles is survived by his companion of fifty-five years, Neil Calet, his niece, Rebecca Ferguson of Byron Point, CA, the loving and grateful Geller family and by the heroic Serhiy Mshanetskiy. Visiting at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday, May 26th, 5pm-8pm. There will be a Requiem Mass at The Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Sidney Pl, Brooklyn Heights, Thursday, May 27th, 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYU School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, NY 10016.

HOLINER--Lucille, of Brooklyn, New York, died peacefully at home on May 23rd in her lifelong home in Bensonhurst at the age of 85 after a long, difficult illness. Lucy's beautiful light was cast on all around her throughout her life whether in the role of Sister, Mother, Grandmother, Wife, Kindergarten Teacher, Mentor or Friend. She was a kind, generous, wise, independent woman who cared fiercely for everyone and everything she loved. Lucy shared 56 years of beautiful partnership with her husband George who died in 2003. One of three magnificently close sisters, she lost her dear sister Dorothy Eisner in 2009 and is survived by the remarkable Julia Amgott and her husband Gilbert. She is also survived by her loving children, Hope Holiner and Tim Sultan Holiner. Hope's husband Michael Wolkowitz and Tim's wife Linda Holiner were lucky to be treated as though they were Lucy's own. Lucy utterly adored and was adored utterly by her grandchildren Sara Holiner Wolkowitz, Max Holiner Wolkowitz, Sharon Holiner, and Diana Holiner. A graduate of Hunter College who received her Masters Degree from NYU, Lucy taught at PS. 23 in Staten Island. Lucy valued family above all else and will be missed very deeply by that family she loved so well. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday May 25, at 11:30 at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapel at 1865 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. Donations may be made in memory of Lucille Holiner to the UJA Federation.
HOLINER--Lucille. With precious memories of a special person, who was loved and admired by relatives and friends. She will be missed. The Amgott Family

Because of editing errors, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the world premiere of the opera ''The Golden Ticket,'' at Webster University near St. Louis on June 13, omitted part of the name of the group that commissioned the work and failed to include that group among the producers. It is American Lyric Theater, not American Lyric, and it is producing the opera with the Opera Theater of St. Louis and the Wexford Festival Opera of Ireland.

I stare harder into the bathroom mirror these days than I ever have. Not out of some pathetic middle-aged vanity, but more out of curiosity. Two years after learning I had an aggressive prostate cancer, I want to see how my face has been weathered and sculptured by the uncertainty and wisdom wrought by the storms of serious disease. But really, what I want to check on is my hair. That's right, my hair. I've finally decided to abandon the buzz cut that I got right before my radical open prostatectomy.

An article on Saturday about merging House and Senate versions of a bill to overhaul financial regulations misstated the status of a provision that would make it easier for shareholders to nominate directors for corporate boards using company ballots. Both the Senate and the House bills contain that provision; it is not absent from the House version.

MEDNICK--Blanche Amy. On the Sunny, warm, birdsong morn of May 21, Blanche Amy Mednick died in her Monterey home, concluding a brief, heroic battle against cancer and a life dedicated to the education of children, the salvaging of forgotten pets, and the expression of thought through her poetry, prose, and playwrighting. No stranger to the worst life can offer, Blanche marshalled her son Brian through the final years of his young adult life, an early victim of the AIDS pandemic, and later co-produced the film 'Tuesday Night', a documentary about the Mothers support group she so valued. In time she left the green hills of Brooklyn's Prospect Park for the greener hills of upstate New York (which meant learning to drive at the age of forty...), and, later, for Massachusetts where she and her dog Sadie had often to fend off bears in the backyard (well, maybe once...). She never missed the city; this was home.

ROSE--Herbert B. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our dear friend and longtime legal counsel Herbert B. Rose of New York. Mr. Rose was deeply involved in the historic growth of the ATS for the last 15 years. To his wife, Bernice, his partner Barry Boxer, and the entire Rose Family, we extend our deepest sympathy. American Technion Society Joel S. An Op-Ed essay on Saturday, about the genesis of the euro, misstated the size of the rescue package for ailing European economies. It is 750 billion euros, not 750 million euros.

An article on Saturday about Dish Network's threat to drop the Weather Channel because of its nonweather-related programming misstated the price that NBC Universal and two private equity firms paid for the Weather Channel. The channel and its Web site were bought for $3.5 billion in September 2008 -- not $5 billion, which is what analysts had expected them to bring when they went on the market in early 2008.

9 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS Will the figure skater Evan Lysacek be adding a mirror-ball trophy to his Olympic gold medal? On Monday Mr. Lysacek (below with Anna Trebunskaya) and the two other remaining contestants, Erin Andrews and Nicole Scherzinger, performed one dance chosen by the judges and one ''no rules'' freestyle routine. In this two-hour finale the three will perform their favorite dance of the season (each chose the Argentine tango) and be ranked by the judges. After the third-place winner is announced, the remaining two teams will compete in a fourth dance, with the judges' scores to be added to the cumulative scores for the season as well as to viewer votes. And then a winner will be named. The show will also feature routines from the season's eliminated contestants, including a spicy gyration by Pamela Anderson, a high-wire act by Kate Gosselin and a Viennese waltz performed by Jake Pavelka and his fiancÃ©e, Vienna Girardi. Monday's episode will be repeated at 8. 7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO James Lipton talks with Sean Combs, a k a Diddy, about his staying power in the entertainment industry and the high points of his career, from his big break at 19, when he was made vice president for artists and repertory at Uptown Records, to his stints as a director, producer and actor.

IGER--Arthur L.,an advertising and publishing executive, college professor and author of a well-respected guide to American popular composers and lyricists of the 20th century, died in Port Jefferson, NY, Sunday. He was 84. The cause was a heart attack, said his son Robert. Mr. Iger, who served in the U.S. Navy aboard a submarine chaser in World War II, was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business. During the 1940s, he was a professional jazz trumpeter. Mr. Iger's professional career included stints at the advertising agency, Cunningham and Walsh, Macmillan Publishing and Greenvale Marketing Corp. After retiring, he became an adjunct professor of marketing and advertising at the New York Institute of Technology. It was Mr. Iger's deep love of jazz and Tin Pan Alley that led him to write "Music of the Golden Age, 1900-1950 and Beyond: A Guide to Popular Composers and Lyricists" in 1998. The book was praised as a valuable and engaging guide to the work of such major songwriters as Irving Berlin, George Gershwin and Richard Rogers. Mr. Iger also served as a member of the Oceanside School Board and was active in supporting Long Beach Reach and the Southern Poverty Law Center. Arthur Lawrence Iger was born April 13, 1926 in Brooklyn, the son of Joseph Iger and Eva Zwern. He is survived by his spouse Mimi, whom he married in 1947; and by his son Robert A. Iger, the president and CEO of The Walt Disney Company, and his spouse Willow Bay; and his daughter, Carolyn Iger, owner of Grapes in Port Jefferson, and her spouse, Eli Zamek. In addition, Mr. Iger is survived by his grandchildren; Jenny Gammons and her husband Matt Gammons; Katie Iger and her husband Jarrod Cushing; Amanda Iger; Jordan and Jessica Tsunis; Max and Will Iger; Colleen Matuza; Paul Winkler, and Jamie Berland. He was the great-grandfather of Bobby and Jack Gammons and Hayden Cushing. "My father was a very special man, filled with curiosity and passion and a true lover of jazz, but above all, he adored his family, his wife, his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. He was truly blessed and he will be deeply missed", said Robert A. Iger. The family will receive guests on Wednesday, May 26th from 11:00am-4:00pm with a special tribute to Mr. Iger at 11:30am at the Belle Terre Community Center, 55 Cliff Road, Belle Terre, New York. Donations in Mr. Iger's memory should be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center and Long Beach Reach.

An article on May 8 about the outcome of the British parliamentary elections referred incompletely to a proposed change in the electoral system favored by the Liberal Democratic Party known as the single transferable vote, in which voters rank candidates in order of preference. While the votes for the last-place candidates may be redistributed to the voters' second choices, the surplus votes of the winning candidates -- those votes in excess of what the candidates need to win -- are also redistributed.

McERLEAN--Thomas Michael, 51, of New York, NY and Block Island, RI (formerly of Morristown, NJ and Wilton, CT) died suddenly on May 21 in New York City. Tom graduated from Iona Preparatory School in 1976 and from Iona College with a degree in business in 1981. His successful Wall Street career spanned over 25 years beginning at Freeman Securities before joining Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, as a bond trader and UBS where he was a Managing Director. Tom was most recently a Senior Vice President and Head of Credit Trading for Alliance Bernstein. Tom will be remembered for his fabulous sense of humor, enthusiasm and energy for life which included flying his Piper Saratoga. He was a devoted husband to his beloved wife, Kathy (Wild); a loving and proud father to his daughter Elizabeth Ann and his son Charles Thomas. He is also survived by his parents John Thomas and Agnes (Inglesby), of Westerly, RI; four sisters, Ann of Westerly, RI, Marie Hunter (Kevin) of North Caldwell, NJ, Agnes Duhamel (Chris) of Westerly, RI and Catherine Francese (Carl) of New Rochelle, NY; as well as seven nieces and 12 nephews. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Funeral Mass, Wednesday, May 26 at 11am, St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Block Island Conservancy, PO Box 84, Block Island, RI 02807.

The Texas Rangers voluntarily pushed themselves into bankruptcy on Monday to facilitate the team's sale to a group of investors led by Chuck Greenberg and the team's president, Nolan Ryan, for about $575 million. The team and Major League Baseball took the unusual step so the new owners would not be saddled with much of the debt held by the current owner, the HSG Sports Group.

THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - Today's grid by Josh Knapp looks different because it breaks one of the standard rules of crossword construction. White squares must be "checked." That is, they must be part of two different answers, one Across and one Down. This grid appears to have ten unchecked squares. By convention, cryptic crosswords have unchecked squares all the time -- here's what the latest New York Times cryptic looks like: (Across Lite, Solution) -- but they're not allowed in the regular daily puzzles, right? What's going on?

In the midst of one of the most precipitous political crashes in the Mountain West, Sarah Palin made a mad dash into Boise on Friday, urging the election of a man who had plagiarized his campaign speech from Barack Obama, had been rebuked by the military for misusing the Marine uniform and had called the American territory of Puerto Rico a separate country.

More than a year after bailing out Citigroup, the Treasury Department announced on Wednesday that it had begun to sell its stake in the financial giant - and that the government was turning a profit on its investment.

If you're traveling to South Africa for the World Cup, you should worry more about mundane problems like diarrhea, measles and tick bites than you do about exotic tropical diseases like malaria and yellow fever, according to a new study in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

Jane Gross reports on the rise of a new type of health professional, the hospitalist, on Thursday in The Times. A hybrid in the health ecosystem, the hospitalist is both physician and administrator; he or she may coordinate virtually all aspects of a patient's care, an increasingly necessary function in the nation's overburdened hospitals.

Assorted pornography, native plants and the Cold War are among the subjects that fill the library of the artist Donald Judd (1928-1994). But you don't have to travel to Marfa, Tex., to browse the shelves. Today, Web visitors can click on a floor plan of his two-room library to view the 13,004 volumes arranged exactly as Judd arranged them. The virtual library has been rendered so faithfully that visitors navigate furniture and art designed by Judd and glimpse an artwork by Dan Flavin between the custom bookcases.

If you're trying to buy as much of your food as possible from producers you can look in the eye, the last couple of evenings before the next market day can present supply problems. By Tuesday the vegetable bins of our refrigerator were in a sad state of depletion.

As a rule, we avoid the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center like Chinese buffet. But for Barbra Joan Streisand, we made an exception. Overview | Where did corn, or maize, originate, and how did its cultivation contribute to civilization? Why do botanists and agronomists continue to study and selectively breed corn today? How is variation important in this process? In this lesson, students use prior knowledge to tout corn in a 30-second commercial spot. Then, using observation skills, they investigate variations in different types of corn and develop an understanding of the role natural variation plays in its selective breeding. Finally, they apply their knowledge to explain how artificial selection works and to execute a concluding project.

This week in The Times Health Guide, New York Times contributor Eric Sabo writes about genital herpes, "the largest epidemic no one wants to talk about." Here are five things experts say you should know about protecting yourself against herpes.

Reader Harold Breene tipped us off that his grandson, Jack Breene, of South Orange Troop 60, is a third-generation Eagle Scout. Besides Jack's grandfather, his father, Paul, is also an Eagle Scout. We asked Michael Wirth, the senior district executive of the Orange Mountain District of the Boy Scouts of America, how common this is. "It's very rare," he said. "We don't even keep statistics, the numbers are so minuscule." Congratulations to the family. -- The Local.

When my neighborhood was evacuated because of Delaware River flooding a few years ago, I had less than 24 hours to prepare. I packed a suitcase and grabbed important documents -- but then I suddenly realized that I didn't have a plan for my pets.

Hilde Limondjian is stepping down as the Metropolitan Museum of Art's music impresario, the Met said, ending a 41-year run that turned the Met's concert series into a New York fixture. Under her direction as general manager of concerts and lectures the Met program helped inaugurate major careers, brought back prominent performers on a regular basis and popularized now-common ideas like concerts with themes and commentary. She established lengthy residences for the Beaux Arts Trio and Guarneri String Quartet (now replaced by the Pacifica Quartet) and brought in a young Yo-Yo Ma, Martha Argerich and Cecilia Bartoli, as well as the Emerson String Quartet and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. The Met said Ms. Limondjian would depart June 30 and had already planned next season. The search for a successor is on, it said.

Think of one of the greatest branding campaigns in the 20th century, and London's subway system probably doesn't spring to mind.Â  In that case, you'll be pleasantly surprised by "Art for All: British Posters for Transport," which opens on Thursday at the Yale Center for British Art. The exhibition, which includes more than 100 posters that were designed - mostly between the world wars - for the London Underground (and, to a lesser extent, British railways), illustrates the degree to which the Underground, led by the enlightened Frank Pick, captured public goodwill, helped forge a civic identity for the city, and became a patron of modern artists. The Gleaner, a newspaper in Kingston, Jamaica, reports, "No fewer than 44 Jamaicans have been killed in the clashes between security forces and gunmen in west Kingston," according to the city's public defender. The official, Earl Witter, spoke to reporters late on Tuesday after he visited the city's Tivoli Gardens neighborhood, "to conduct an independent assessment of the operations being carried out by the security forces," who have been battling those defending Christopher Coke, the leader of the city's notorious Shower Posse gang.

The Museum of Modern Art has named Sabine Breitwieser, the founding director of the Generali Foundation contemporary art museum in Vienna, as the new chief curator of its department of media and performance. The department was created in 2006 as the department of media; its name was changed in 2009 to reflect an increased commitment to exhibiting and acquiring performance art. Ms. Breitwieser succeeds Klaus Biesenbach, who organized the current Marina Abramovic retrospective and is now the director of MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

Visiting a city like Kandahar in southern Afghanistan, the subject of human excrement is not something that ordinarily occupies much of your thinking. After all, unlike much of the rest of the country, Kandahar has toilets, even if most of them are just holes in the floor made of porcelain. As a pedestrian, the only issue that would probably prompt any thinking on this subject are the sewers that line Kandahar's dusty streets; they are the open-air type. You've got to take care to avoid them, or you'll fall in.

President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will try a make-up session next week, when Mr. Netanyahu visits the White House, per an invitation hand-delivered to the Israeli leader by a White House envoy.

And men's No. 5 Robin Soderling, looking fit for another a second-consecutive surge toward the finals, needed only 71 minutes to beat American Taylor Dent, 6-0, 6-1, 6-1.
