For her show "Too Good to Be True" at the Collette Blanchard Gallery on the Lower East Side, artist Rachel Hovnanian deals with the power and burden of beauty. Her photographs of various beauty queens (literally female trophies tops set in plaster) pose in pristine all-white scenarios- holding a bouquet in front a cabinet of donuts, perched on a bed surrounded by shopping bags from Chanel, Gucci and YSL, and standing in front of a mirror that adds pounds to the waistline.

Over at Babycenter.com yesterday, Evonne Lack wrote about her 5-year-old daughter, Anna, who was not invited to a kindergarten classmate's birthday party. Anna was the only girl, in a class of eight girls, not invited, and it left Evonne hurting for her daughter.

These have been some harrowing days for Bret Michaels, the rock musician and reality television star: since the end of April, he has had an emergency appendectomy, a hemorrhage near his brain, a transient ischemic attack (or mini-stroke) and learned he had a small hole in his heart. But now he's reveling in his victory on "The Celebrity Apprentice," and on Tuesday night he vowed to Jay Leno that he would not die on his program.

Commerce Secretary Gary Locke declared the Gulf of Mexico a national fisheries disaster area this week, citing the havoc wrought on the region's multibillion-dollar fishing industry by the Deepwater Horizon blowout. Gold Coast Homes Pay Tenement-Worthy Taxes | The Bay Citizen's Web site made its debut Wednesday with an in-depth review of the tax bills on San Francisco's priciest hilltop, showing that some of the city's wealthiest people pay among the lowest property taxes. The piece examines the legacy of Proposition 13 three decades later. As Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes, "Usually, the financial burden of owning a large and valuable house includes a hefty property tax bill." She went on to report, "Indeed, if Gladyne Mitchell had sold her house at 2901 Broadway, the new owners would have faced an annual tax of about $500,000." The actual property tax bill for the house is $7,722. [The Bay Citizen]

PLANK--Betsy, widely known and respected as the "First Lady" of public relations, passed away on May 23, 2010 at age 86. While the term "pioneer" is often loosely used, Betsy was a true trailblazer in the field of public relations. She was the first woman to: head a division of Illinois Bell, be elected president of the Publicity Club of Chicago and serve as president of the Public Relations Society of America (PRSA), the world's largest association of public relations professionals and students. During her career, Betsy won countless accolades for her dedication and service to public relations. She is the first person ever to have received three of PRSA's top individual honors: the Gold Anvil Award (1977), the Paul M. Lund Public Service Award (1989) and the Patrick Jackson Award for Distinguished Service to PRSA (2001). Betsy also received the Arthur W. Page Society's Distinguished Lifetime Achievement Award, and the Institute for Public Relations' Alexander Hamilton Medal for major contributions to the practice of public relations, in 2000. Betsy was widely recognized for her work in the area of public relations education, as well. In 1967, she helped to create the Public Relations Student Society of America (PRSSA), and in 1987, was co-chair of a national commission to develop guidelines for undergraduate public relations curricula. In 2005, she established the Plank Center for Leadership in Public Relations at the University of Alabama, her alma mater. Betsy invested equally in the PRSA Foundation, establishing its first endowed scholarship fund as a reminder to senior industry leaders of the need to leave a legacy benefitting the next generation of practitioners, in whom she so richly invested her time and affections. In 2009, the PRSA Foundation recognized Plank for her generous contribution at its inaugural Paladin Award Dinner in New York City. For Betsy, the Plank Scholarship Fund was a way of creating a lasting service to college students entering her much beloved career. Betsy also was a social activist who participated in the 1965 Civil Rights March from Selma to Montgomery. Among those organizations with which she was active, Betsy chaired the Illinois Council on Economic Education and the Citizenship Council of Metropolitan Chicago; served on the boards of the United Way, Girl Scouts USA and Girl Scouts of Chicago; and was founder of The Chicago Network, an association of Chicago professional women. Betsy was preceded in death by her husband, the late Sherman V. Rosenfield. According to her wishes, Betsy will be cremated and the internment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Plank Center for Leadership in Public Relations, University of Alabama, Box 870172, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487-0172 or online at: http://bit.ly/cAo6V8 (designate Plank Fund). The 32,000 professional and student members of PRSA mourn Betsy's passing and will forever remember her contributions to the society and to the profession she loved.

GINSBURG--David. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our dear and beloved friend, David Ginsburg, whose tireless efforts on behalf of the Weizmann Institute helped establish it as one of the world's premier centers of research. David was passionately devoted to the Jewish people, the State of Israel, and to the Weizmann Institute for over six decades. A brilliant attorney, his legal advice and advocacy during the crucial weeks preceding the U.S. government's recognition of the new State of Israel were essential to the establishment of the country. David contributed immensely to the success of the Weizmann Institute since its earliest days, and his sustained allegiance has been expressed in manifold ways. He was one of the founders of the Institute and a member of the International Board since 1964. David helped to negotiate a very significant long-term loan to the Institute from the U.S. government. Thanks to this loan, which ultimately became a gift, the Institute was able to undertake the extensive expansion that transformed the campus into a world-class research institution. David was also very instrumental in obtaining assistance for the Institute's Feinberg Graduate School. His wisdom, integrity, goodwill, and expertise have been a blessing. We send heartfelt condolences to the entire Ginsburg family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & C.E.O. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

An article on Monday about a traffic accident in Connecticut involving former President Bill Clinton's motorcade misstated the highway on which it occurred. It is the Wilbur Cross Parkway -- not the Merritt Parkway, which is the name of the same road further south.

An article on Sept. 3, 2009, recounted the prosecution of a gang that robbed a Baghdad bank and killed eight bank guards in July 2009. The article reported that testimony at the trial ''established'' that five of the nine accused were in Vice President Adel Abdul Mahdi's bodyguard battalion. While it was undisputed that two of the nine accused were in his bodyguard battalion (one of whom was acquitted), the identities of the others remained a subject of dispute. Some evidence suggested that two were not security officials and that the others had worked in security in the neighborhood but were not assigned to Mr. Abdul Mahdi's battalion at the time of the incident. Similarly, the article reported that the gang ''forgot about the security cameras'' and ''they forgot about sunrise, which came before they finished.'' The article should have noted that there was evidence that the cameras were not operational at the time of the robbery and that the gang had escaped before dawn. Finally, the article misidentified one of the accused men, Ahmad Khalaf Dhamad, as Ahmed Khalid.

An article on Friday about Chrysler's introduction of a redesigned Jeep Grand Cherokee misstated its classification and its body structure. Chrysler classifies the 2011 Grand Cherokee, like its predecessors, as a sport utility vehicle, not a crossover. It has a unibody design developed by Chrysler and Mercedes-Benz for S.U.V.'s; it is not built on a passenger-car chassis.

WASHINGTON -- North and South Korea accelerated their diplomatic confrontation on Tuesday over the recent sinking of a South Korean warship, with the South saying it would redesignate the North its ''archenemy'' and North Korea severing almost all of its remaining ties to its far wealthier neighbor. American officials were cautious in their public statements, eager to avoid giving the North reason for further escalation. Military officials said no additional American combat forces, warships or aircraft had moved into the region -- a standard practice in many past crises, including one in 2003. Officials watching activity on the ground through satellite photographs said there was no ''unusual'' activity at North Korea's main nuclear test site.

In the 1980s and 1990s, Joel Forrester, a jazz pianist and composer, belonged to the Microscopic Septet. They wrote and played the theme music for the NPR program ''Fresh Air With Terry Gross,'' which has led some to reckon that it must be the most frequently played jazz recording in history. Mr. Forrester, 63, spoke with Ozier Muhammad for the eighth installment of ''Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.'' His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity. My father was a newspaper man. He was a labor writer and editor for The Pittsburgh Press. ... When I was about 11 years old, I was just starting to get interested in jazz. ... My father went to the music critic at The Pittsburgh Press, who was a fellow who really didn't like jazz at all. He talked this fellow into giving my father all the free jazz records he was supposed to review. I inherited all those records. The first record, believe it or not was, ''Modern Jazz Piano: Four Views.'' And the pianists on there were Errol Garnor, Art Tatum, Mary Lou Williams and Lennie Tristano. That music was so weird to me, so exotic to my Pittsburgh experience, that I would hide under the cover and I would put the record player with me under the covers and I would listen to that stuff as if I were in a separate world. One of the other records I got was ''Thelonious Monk - At the Blackhawk,'' a club in San Francisco. Thelonious Monk seemed like a wizard to me.

In the hours before the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded last month in the Gulf of Mexico, there were strong warning signs that something was terribly wrong with the well, according to a Congressional committee that was briefed on the accident by executives from BP. Among the red flags, the panel said, were several equipment readings suggesting that gas was bubbling into the well, a potential sign of an impending blowout. Investigators also noted ''other events in the 24 hours before the explosion that require further inquiry,'' including a critical decision to replace heavy mud in the pipe rising from the seabed with seawater, possibly increasing the risk of an explosion.

It also became the first beacon of light that welcomed thousands of immigrants to the New World. This documentary tells the story of the treacherous waters at the eastern tip of Long Island, the struggle of the architect John McComb Jr. to build the structure, and the wrecks of the Culloden, the Flying Cloud and the John Milton in the 18th and 19th centuries. 3 P.M. HANDLER--Jerry S.,of New York City, West Hampton, L.I., Jackson Hole, Wyoming, died peacefully in the arms of his loving family at Mt. Sinai Hospital, on May 24, 2010, at age 80. He is survived by his beautiful wife of nearly 60 years, Lyn Handler, three children: Scott Handler, Sharon Handler and Dawn H. Harbart, and four grandchildren: Jonathan Handler, Darell Handler, Victoria Handler and Zoe Harbart, and his devoted sister, Shirley Horodas He was the son of Maurice S. Handler who built Smart Maid Suit & Co., one of America's leading coat & suit manufacturers during and after WWII. His father was also a great philanthropist and, among other things, was one of the original founders of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. After graduating from Wharton School of Finance & Commerce, Jerry founded, built and grew Newmark & Co. for nearly 40 years, along with Aaron Gural and Jack Schenker, today, one of New York City's largest commercial real estate firms. Along with his wife Lyn, he was a staunch supporter of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. They devoted over 40 years to medical research and education, as well as to the well being of the sick and less fortunate. Early on, Jerry became a "Founding Father" of Einstein's Young Men's Division; and later became a member of its Executive Board, as well as the Overseers Committee. Jerry also received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University, was the Chairman of the Board of The Yonkers Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, served as a Lt. Col. and Executive Officer of the 5th Regiment, Civil Affairs of the 56th Brigade of the New York State Guard, as well as an active member of The Police Reserve Association of the City of New York, which establishes, among other things, fellowships for children of police officers. A man proud of his roots and traditions, Jerry was a devoted husband and family man, a loyal supporter of the philanthropies to which he was committed, and all those whose lives he touched will miss him terribly and hold memories of him dear in their hearts.

POTEET--Russell E.,died in the early evening hours of May 14, 2010. He is now resting free from years of agony, suffering from bone cancer. He was born October 5, 1930 in Agusta, Georgia to Florence Johannsen Poteet and Russell Poteet. He was predeceased by his parents, grandparents, a niece Ann Poteet and cousin Roy Booker. He is survived by Jim Diewold, his life (civil union) partner of 41 years and his cat, Melissa. In Georgia, his brother James Poteet and his wife Frances, a nephew James Poteet and his wife Amy and their very special children Avery and Edy. Also surviving are cousins Florence Chandler, Bill Booker and Kathy Wheale, survivor of Roy Booker. While in high school, Russell got a job at "Press Radio Sales Co." doing the promotional art. Here he met life long friend Ann Brotherton of Augusta, GA. Also at this time he was given his first art commission to paint a picture of Ikes Pond, which hangs in Maimes Cabin. He received a wonderful letter of thanks from the Eisenhowers. Eileen Stulb, owner of "Press Radio" played pro woman's golf, as a result, Russell designed the first logo for the Pro Women Golf. Russell served in the US Army from 1951 1953. He graduated from the University of Georgia with a BFA degree. He moved to Atlanta to work for Mead Packaging. In 1960 he was transferred to New York City as Art Director for Mead Packaging. Later, he moved to Visual Marketing an industrial design firm, and then to Schenley Distillers as Design Director, doing packaging, labels, bottle and decanter design. In 1984 that company moved to Dallas, TX and Russell and Jim gave up their Manhattan home and moved permanently to their weekend home in Roxbury, CT. Prior to leaving the city, Russell spent carefree weekends sailing the Long Island Sound. After giving up his boat, he bought his first country house in Dover Plains, NY, which led him on a path of buying and remodeling old houses and building new ones. Russell and Jim's homes are some of Litchfield counties most beautiful and functional. Russell had an eye for perfect scale and nothing but quality would do. All their homes are a compliment to Connecticut. They were all published in Colonial Homes magazine. A new career began when in 1990 Russell was fortunate to meet two men who taught furniture making using hand tools as in the 18th century: Gene Landon, of York, PA, and Mack Headley of Williamsburg, VA. This involved commuting to New Jersey and York, PA, for classes and trips to museums and the state rooms at the nation's capital to photograph, measure and draw plans for the 18th century furniture on display, and then making exact copies of them. This is where he met his dear friend Tom DuPrex and his wife Faith. The furniture making led to building a large Georgian house in Roxbury to provide a setting appropriate for the furniture. This required elaborate millwork and carvings, faux marbre, etc. for the house, which was begun in 1997 and finished in 2002. In his spare time Russ took several courses at the New School, which include bread baking, French cooking and auto mechanics. He was also a product of Isabel Oneal. They were two peas in a pod. Russ taught at the Foundation. After a two-year course at the Bronx Botanical Gardens, Russ and Jim became certified landscape designers. No project was too big or too daunting. His entire life was an exhilarating learning process it is only natural that he would be a member of Mensa and Intertel. A memorial gathering will happen on Saturday, June 12, 2010 at 3pm. It will take place at the Watermark at East Hill, 611 East Hill Road, Southbury, CT. All are welcome to come and par-take. Memorial Contributions may be sent to Regional Hospice of Western Connecticut, 405 Main Street, Danbury, CT 06810.

WASHINGTON -- One Saturday afternoon in March 2003, Lawrence H. Summers invited Elena Kagan for a private chat in the library of Elmwood, the stately clapboard mansion he occupied as the president of Harvard. The two had been close colleagues, if not close friends, as top aides working for President Bill Clinton. But this was no social call. Mr. Summers, a brilliant but impatient economist with a bull-in-the-china-shop management style, was looking for a new law school dean. Ms. Kagan, a newly tenured professor, was thin on management experience, and her academic writings were relatively scant.

ZUCKER--Howard, MD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and long-time colleague, Howard Zucker, MD. In 1949, Dr. Zucker became a founding father of the Department of Psychiatry, teaching at Mount Sinai School of Medicine and mentoring many at The Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Zucker made the movie, Doctors' Feelings, which was shown at medical schools throughout the country. Together with his wife, Marjorie, an eminent physiologist, Dr. Zucker co-edited the book, Medical Futility, published in 1997. The Mount Sinai community extends heart-felt condolences to Dr. Zucker's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Wayne K. Goodman, MD, Chair, Department of Psychiatry, Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

BUSINESS DAY An article on May 15 about efforts by the Japanese company Sanrio to find new characters as successful as its Hello Kitty line of products misstated the recent financial performance of the Hello Kitty business in Japan. While Sanrio's overall sales in Japan have been shrinking for a decade, its sales from Hello Kitty products and licensing rights were up 9 percent in the most recent fiscal year; the sales from that franchise did not shrink at home. The article also referred imprecisely to the introduction of two other Sanrio products. Spottie Dottie was introduced in 1990 and Pandapple in 2006. While both were more recent than Hello Kitty, which was introduced in 1974, they are not ''recent'' products.

In major league baseball from 2000 to 2009, the home team won 54 percent of the time. Many cite the home team's last at-bat as the reason. At the end of games, the thinking goes, the home team can tailor its strategy to match the situation. If the team is down by three runs, it can play for the big inning. If it needs one run, it can use small-ball strategies like bunting and base stealing to get that run.

Intelligent design. That's one goal of synthetic biology, a field that was catapulted into the news last week with the announcement that a group of biologists had manufactured a genome that exists nowhere in nature and inserted it into a bacterial cell. The dream is that, one day, we'll be able to sit and think about what sort of life-form we'd like to make - and then design and build it in much the same way we make a bridge or a car.

The next James Bond book will be written by Jeffery Deaver, the best-selling thriller writer, Simon & Schuster announced on Thursday. The novel, with the working title "Project X," is expected to be set in the present day and take Bond to at least three "exotic locations around the globe." It is scheduled for publication in May 2011. Mr. Deaver, the author of "The Bone Collector" and "Garden of Beasts," said in a statement that he was thrilled to be asked by representatives of the Ian Fleming estate to write the book. "The novel will maintain the persona of James Bond as Fleming created him and the unique tone the author brought to his books, while incorporating my own literary trademarks: detailed research, fast pacing and surprise twists." The book will be published by Hodder & Stoughton in Britain and Simon & Schuster in the United States. More than 100 million Bond books have been sold.

Let me try to get this straight. The Justice Department announced last weekend that it has dropped its criminal investigation into wrongdoing by the former executives of American International Group Financial Products, or A.I.G.-F.P. - the group inside A.I.G. that foolishly decided to insure billions of dollars of risk in the mortgage market, and got paid millions of dollars for doing so. So the Obama administration, which has repeatedly pilloried banking executives in an effort to build support for its financial reform package, has in one step reduced exponentially the chances of actually holding people on Wall Street accountable for the financial crisis, which was an utterly preventable self-inflicted wound. This is simply incomprehensible.

For the first time in its history New York City Ballet will present a fall season in September and October at Lincoln Center. The company, which has previously presented a repertory season that started in November, opens its 2010-2011 season on Sept. 14 at the David H. Koch Theater, and it will feature performances of 28 different ballets, including 13 works by George Balanchine and 5 by Jerome Robbins. Other highlights of the fall run, which continues through Oct. 10, include a New York premiere by the choreographer Benjamin Millepied and a revival of "The Magic Flute" by the company's ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. The annual presentation of "George Balanchine's The Nutcracker" begins on Nov. 26 and runs through Jan. 2, and a six-week winter repertory season opens on Jan. 18. Other highlights of the season include a new work by Susan Stroman, and the previously announced new production of "The Seven Deadly Sins," by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, featuring Patti LuPone in her New York City Ballet debut. In addition, the 2010-2011 season will feature ballets by Melissa Barak, Mauro Bigonzetti, Wayne McGregor, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon and a full-length staging of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake" by Mr. Martins.

I was "Feeling For" Clark's desert boots last year and continue to wear my sand suede shoes on a daily basis, with rolled up jeans and khakis (also previously "felt for" here). Now with summer arriving next week, I'm excited about a new take on my tried and true uniform: the summer chukka boot. Keds, makers of the classic canvas sneaks, have introduced the Champion Chukka, a high-top spin on their low-top. It's a sleek take on the desert boot, done in breathable, lightweight canvas with a molded rubber bottom. The boots come in a bunch of colors, allowing you to coordinate, clash, neutralize or pop at will. I'm partial to the navy, which will blend with a rolled up jean or be a bit more of an exclamation point with a slender, rolled-up chino. The pale grey is another favorite, more akin to its tonal cousin in suede. These sneaks are also the perfect pairing for shorts, from Bermudas to cargos. Just ditch the socks.

The words still sound strange in our heads and on our tongues, hours after the 24-year-old Mr. DeWyze - hey, did you know he was once a local paint salesman? - prevailed over Crystal Bowersox to win the ninth season of "American Idol." But that's who the voters selected, and in time we'll get used to it. (Probably.) In the meantime, here are 10 lingering mysteries about Wednesday night's "American Idol" finale that we can't solve quite as easily:
What we're reading this morning:
It's been awhile, but President Obama will hold a formal news conference at the White House this afternoon.

Judge Weighs Gang Injunction | The latest effort by regional law enforcement authorities to use the court system to control gang violence will be under the microscope in Alameda County Superior Court, where officials will press for an injunction to control Oakland's North Side gang. It would restrain 15 named individuals from a variety of activities, including weapons possession, trespassing and witness intimidation. It would also keep suspected gang members from associating with one another in a 100-block swath of the city and impose a curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. In other Bay Area cities, like Fairfield, civil liberties groups have attacked such injunctions as violations of constitutional rights. In Oakland, opponents argue that an injunction would do little to curb crime and much to prompt racial profiling. A report in The Bay Citizen said that a series of at least four killings put law enforcement's focus on the north Oakland group. [The Oakland Tribune, The New York Times, The Bay Citizen]Proposition Billed as Antidote to Polarization | Proposition 14, backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is gaining traction. The initiative would replace traditional primaries in state and Congressional elections with twofold elections. All candidates would run in the first round. The top two vote-getters, regardless of party affiliation, or lack thereof, would face each other in the general election. Voters' ultimate choice could be two Republicans or two Democrats, but it is likely that they would be the best-known or the wealthiest of the original field. Supporters say the measure would empower moderates and increase turnout. The state's $19 billion deficit, high unemployment and low morale may help the measure's chances; polls show a majority of voters favor it. [The New York Times]

This week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at a new target for hackers: the car. Bettina Edelstein speaks to John Markoff, a Times reporter who has written about how vulnerable automotive computer systems are to malicious attacks. Computer security experts from the University of California, San Diego, and the University of Washington, backed by the National Science Foundation, were able to remotely take over car brakes and other critical controls. With modern vehicles increasingly dependent on computers, the researchers say, it's important to address these issues before they become a problem.

BALBONI--Marjorie Fletcher, died peacefully in Westwood, Massachusetts on May 22, 2010. Born in New York City, May 6, 1921, she was the daughter of Andrew and Dorothea Camp Fletcher of Mendham, NJ and New York City. She was predeceased by her siblings, Andrew Fletcher of New York and Anne Robinson of London, as well as by her husband, Dr.Victor G. Balboni, and their favorite dog, Reggie. She and her husband, married for 56 years, raised four daughters in Chestnut Hill and Little Compton, where they enjoyed sailing on the Sea Bird and golf at the Brookline Country Club and the Sakonnet Golf Club. Marjorie was an accomplished artist, a member of The Copley Society, who liked to paint with the Westport Art Group. She was an active member in The Junior League of Boston, The Colonial Dames, The Chilton Club, Smith Alumnae, and The Garden Club of Chestnut Hill. She was a loyal parishioner of The Church of The Redeemer. Marjorie will be missed by her daughters and their husbands, Margot Balboni of Brookline, MA, Lisa and Adolf Haffenreffer of Little Compton, RI, Christina and Robert Patterson of Atherton, CA, and Lillian and John Nolan of West Hartford, CT. She leaves seven grandchildren, Lindley Haffenreffer of New York, Adolf Haffenreffer of Newport, Andrew Haffenreffer of Boulder, Elizabeth McGrath of New York, Victor E. Patterson of San Francisco, Peter Prestley of Saipan, and Milo Werner of San Francisco, as well as three great-grandchildren, Fletcher Kathryn Werner, Rose McGrath, and May McGrath. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham on Friday, June 4th at 11am.

''Glee'' rules. This week the show is pretty much everywhere, with a sold-out concert tour coming to Radio City Music Hall and news that Fox, its network, has ordered a third season. Now the show has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the second time in a month. ''Glee: The Music, Volume 3 - Showstoppers'' (Columbia), the show's fourth release and its third full-length soundtrack, sold 136,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out a reissue of the Rolling Stones' ''Exile on Main St.'' (Universal) for the top spot. Last month a ''Glee'' mini-album, ''The Power of Madonna'' (Columbia), also opened at No. 1, and the show's first two albums remain steady sellers; the four ''Glee'' releases have sold a total of about 1.8 million copies.

Hot news from Paris: After seven years, Jean Paul Gaultier is giving up his ready-to-wear duties at Hermes and will be replaced by Christophe Lemaire, who has been designing for Lacoste since 2000. Mr. Gaultier's move was expected, but the replacement was something of a surprise, since Mr. Lemaire has always flown a bit under the radar and doesn't show his own collection on the runway. Nevertheless Hermes has a tradition of making unexpected hires in the creative department, starting with Martin Margiela, who designed the collection prior to Mr. Gaultier. Mr. Lemaire had worked for numerous French design houses, including Yves Saint Laurent, Jean Patou and Christian Lacroix, prior to joining Lacoste. He has been credited with reviving the demand for its crocodile-logo polo shirts by restyling the line with pop colors and trimmer fits, but it's hard not to picture the new job at Hermes as a big step up.

The surviving members of the heavy metal band Slipknot made a rare appearance Tuesday without their trademark masks to pay tribute to their bassist, Paul Gray, who was found dead Monday at an Iowa hotel. At a news conference in Des Moines, The Associated Press reported, the band's lead singer, Corey Taylor, said: ''Yesterday we lost our brother, and the world seems a little smaller because of it. He had the biggest heart of anyone I've ever known. The only way I can sum up Paul Gray is love.''

An article on Monday about New York City political bosses erroneously included two politicians on a list of those who wound up going to jail. Meade Esposito received a suspended sentence and Donald R. Manes killed himself in the wake of a scandal.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the top 10 choking hazards for children omitted some steps to take if a child is choking and seems unable to cough out the obstruction. Besides having someone call 911, the health authorities recommend acting quickly to remove the object. If a child is more than 1 year old, perform the Heimlich maneuver. If the child is younger than 1, rest the child face down on your knee and slap the back between the shoulder blades five times. More information can be found at healthychildren.org.

Forget about ''American Idol.'' It was BP's Web-only reality show -- live video of the oil spill from the floor of the Gulf of Mexico -- that had people fixated on their screens on Wednesday. And the episode ''Top Kill'' even had a cliffhanger: it could be days before viewers know whether the latest effort to plug the well is successful. ''BP oil spill live feed'' climbed close to the top of a list of hot searches on Google on Wednesday afternoon (''top kill video'' and ''oil spill top kill'' were also on the list). The video of a brown undulating gusher against the deep blue water has been popular since it was posted May 18. BP said that more than 300,000 people viewed it on Tuesday alone.

An article on Wednesday about the career ambitions of Elena Kagan, the Supreme Court nominee, while she was at Harvard Law School, where she was appointed dean in 2003, misstated the educational affiliation of another law professor who was considered for the dean's job. The professor, Robert C. Post, was at the University of California, Berkeley, School of Law at that time; he was not the dean of Yale Law School. (He later moved to Yale and became dean there in 2009.)

I haven't used a disc-burning app in a while, since my disc-copying needs are pretty basic and I typically can get by with Windows' built-in tools for burning photos or video to a CD or DVD. When Nero recently released its $80 Multimedia Suite 10 (Windows only), I thought I'd play around with the software to see if I've been missing something. Short answer: Yes, and no.

LOWERRE-JAMBOIS--Emilie, died peacefully at home on May 25th, her 61st birthday, surrounded by her loving family. Beloved wife of Thomas Jambois, loving sister of Mary Lowerre, Timothy Lowerre, Donald Lowerre, Thomas Lowerre (Diane), Donna Kjeldsen (Lance F.) and devoted and caring aunt of Amanda, Anna, Ben, Jayme, Katherine, Kristian and Lance G. Emilie attended Mary Louis Academy in Queens, was a 1971 graduate of the College of New Rochelle and received a masters degree in mathematics from Fordham University and an MSW from Columbia University. Emilie was passionate about everything in her life: her work in psychiatric social work, music, her family and her friends. Emilie was an extraordinary advocate for herself and others battling cancer through her work with Gilda's Club. Emilie has been an inspiration to her family, colleagues and friends and will always be in their hearts. Visitation will be on Tuesday, June 1st from 4pm to 7pm at Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place, Brooklyn. Funeral mass will be at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface, 190 Duffield Place, Brooklyn (www.oratory-church.org) on Wednesday, June 2nd at 10am. For more information, please contact Scotto Funeral Home at 718-875-2515 or at www.scottofuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Gilda's Club.

In Day 3 of the Texas Rangers' bankruptcy, creditors and Major League Baseball vied in a courtroom in Fort Worth on Wednesday to make loans to keep the team running. The unusual scene began with M.L.B. offering financing of $11.5 million at an interest rate of 5.75 percent, through Aug. 12, the anticipated closing date of the team's sale to a group led by Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan. The creditors countered with a $21.5 million loan at about 1.6 percent through the end of the season and an offer to buy out the $18.5 million loan that baseball made last year to fund the Rangers, and slash that interest rate to 1.6 percent. Baseball eventually submitted an identical bid, and the Rangers accepted that offer.

PHILADELPHIA -- By the time Djigui Keita left the hospital for home, his follow-up appointment had been scheduled. Emergency health insurance was arranged until he could apply for public assistance. He knew about changes in his medication -- his doctor had found less expensive brands at local pharmacy chains. And Mr. Keita, 35, who had passed out from dehydration, was cautioned to carry spare water bottles in the taxi he drove for a living. The hourlong briefing the home-bound patient received here at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania was orchestrated by a hospitalist, a member of America's fastest-growing medical specialty. Over a decade, this breed of physician-administrator has increasingly taken over the care of the hospitalized patient from overburdened family doctors with less and less time to make hospital rounds -- or, as in Mr. Keita's case, when there is no family doctor at all.
An article last Thursday about the popularity of growing plants upside down from holes in the bottom of containers misstated the price of the basic Topsy Turvy planter. It is $9.99, not $19.98.

Since the lamented loss of The New Yorker's free electronic cards, you may have had a difficult time finding e-cards of the noncloying variety. Now, for $1.99, you can get a rack's worth on your iPhone. An app called PixyMe lets you add words to a picture, but not with just plain type fonts. On a picture of a cake, your message appears to be written in icing. Or your message can appear to have been scraped on a snowy windshield, or to be sewn on the back of a ballplayer's jersey.

The new health care law does not allocate nearly enough money to cover the estimated 5.6 million to 7 million Americans with pre-existing medical conditions who will qualify for temporary high-risk insurance pools, according to a report scheduled for release on Thursday. The government-operated insurance plans are intended to serve as a stopgap until 2014, when insurers will be prohibited from denying coverage to people with health problems. But an analysis by the Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonpartisan research group, concluded that the $5 billion earmarked for the pools might cover as few as 200,000 people a year.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y. -- The white Long Island teenager convicted of killing a Hispanic immigrant in a 2008 hate crime attack in Patchogue was sentenced on Wednesday to 25 years in prison in a hearing that ended with the teenager's father leaving the courtroom in a tearful rage. The teenager, Jeffrey Conroy, now 19, stood next to his lawyer in State Supreme Court here as Justice Robert W. Doyle told a courtroom filled with relatives, friends and supporters of both Mr. Conroy and the immigrant, Marcelo Lucero, that the proof of Mr. Conroy's guilt was ''overwhelming'' and that he was convicted of ''senseless and brutal crimes.''

SYDOR--Elizabeth. Beloved mother of six, grandma to four, devoted friend, artful musician, and esteemed teacher for decades, passed away peacefully May 20, 2010, her family at her side. She was 74. Born to Vincent and Elizabeth in Bayonne, NJ, she received a BA from Douglass and married Harry in '58. They moved to Metuchen, NJ, where she raised the kids and taught piano. In '69 she resumed studies, earning an MEd in piano performance (Rutgers) and an MA and doctorate in music theory and composition (Teachers College, Columbia). Until a few months ago she taught, accompanied dance classes, and was a freelance organist. Early on she created scores for dancers and taught at the university level; later she focused on choral composition. She refused to let her lung disease restrict her work, countless hobbies, and lay Franciscan and church activities. All will miss her abundant enthusiasm, emotive artistry, wide-ranging intellect, and determined spirit. A mass is planned at Sacred Heart Church, Bayhead, NJ, May 28 at 11am, and a music memorial in the summer. For more info: esydor@gmail.com.

DANGELICO--Pino, of Cresskill, NJ on May 25, 2010. Beloved husband of Chiara. Devoted father of Paola Dangelico and Max Dangelico and proud grandfather of Daniel, Alex and Amber. A brilliant artist, his incomparable talent is a great loss to the art community. "I am an artist...I am here to live out loud" Zola. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly, NJ on Friday 4-8pm. Funeral Service Saturday, 10am at funeral home. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net.

The Museum of Modern Art has named Sabine Breitwieser, the founding director of the Generali Foundation contemporary art museum in Vienna, as the new chief curator of its department of media and performance. The department was created in 2006 as the department of media; its name was changed in 2009 to reflect an increased commitment to exhibiting and acquiring performance art. Ms. Breitwieser succeeds Klaus Biesenbach, who organized the current Marina Abramovic retrospective and is now the director of MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on May 14 about a decision by the Minerals Management Service to allow oil companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency misidentified the author of a letter sent to the Interior Department complaining about safety concerns at the BP Atlantis oil rig. It was written by David L. Perry, a lawyer, on behalf of Kenneth Abbott, a client; the letter was not written by Mr. Abbott. The article also misstated Mr. Abbott's occupation. He is a contractor for BP, not an agency scientist with the Minerals Management Service.

One of my spring challenges is coming up with a new artichoke recipe. This year, I browned and thenÂ braised, and was astonished at the results. This technique (it's not unlike one I've used for Brussels sprouts for about 10 years) gets rid of the choke early in the process, is only marginally more complicated and just as fast as steaming, and produces a gorgeous, easy-to-eat vegetable. It's going to become my go-to.

It's been a good week, perhaps too good of a week, for disclosure and transparency. The blogosphere has brought us more than we ever wanted to know about the telephony habits of a South Carolina legislator; we discovered that, in one case, the White House's efforts to provide employment amid a recession has gotten both the current and a former president into trouble; and we learned that we're all going get a peek over the fence and into the lives of Wasilla, Alaska's, most famous resident. There are times when more feels like less ...

One of the conceits of literary journalism is that a writer spends as much time in close proximity to his or her subjects as possible. Joe McGinniss, a veteran practitioner, has taken that approach into new realms by moving in next to Sarah Palin in Wasilla, Alaska. The former governor of Alaska and the vice presidential candidate is the subject of his book titled "Sarah Palin's Year of Living Dangerously," due out in the fall of 2011.

The Off-Broadway musical "Avenue Q," whose characters include a fictionalized version of Gary Coleman, the former child star who died on Friday, said it will pay tribute to Mr. Coleman in Friday's performance at New World Stages.

This long Memorial Day weekend will be a relatively quiet one in our area, with most folks happy to use the extra time for backyard family barbecues, sand castles and warm sun down the shore, or exhausting trips to the mall to take advantage of seemingly endless sales and discounts.

On The Times's Bay Area blog, Rachel Gross takes a comprehensive look at the changes in admissions throughout the University of California system, which is sustaining severe budget cuts. Among her findings: "Securing a seat in the system has become more difficult than ever, as 100,000 students applied this year,'' and "the number of out-of-state and international students admitted has risen by 25 percent in the past year, to 9,552 from 7,634.'' One advantage of those out-of-state students is that they pay more than their counterparts from California; collectively, non-Californians will produce about $43.5 million in nonresident fees, Ms. Gross finds.

After missing 24 games with a strained left groin, Curtis Granderson rejoined the Yankees for Friday night's game against Cleveland. His return upgrades the Yankees' outfield defense and lengthens their lineup, which over the last week has struggled to hit with runners in scoring position. Granderson batted seventh before he got hurt, but he is hitting second Friday, and Joe Girardi suggested he will continue to hit there while Jorge Posada remains sidelined.

Last Saturday, London'sSquare Mile Coffee Roastersopened their first coffee bar, Penny University, in a storefront just off of Shoreditch High Street. It's small, little more than a burnished wood counter with six stools in a warm if austere room - the decor is limited to a framed map of the world on the wall and the scuff patterns on the floor.

Our show opens amid the chaos of Friday Prayer in Lahore, Pakistan, whereÂ  gunmen and suicide bombers stormed two mosques belonging to a minority sect. The attackers seized hostages, killed at least 70 worshipers and wounded 78 others, according to the authorities (Slides 1, 2 and 3). At one mosque, dozens of men were said to have survived by scurrying down a narrow passage and hiding in the basement. The attacks were aimed at the Ahmadi community, which considers itself Muslim but is severely discriminated against under Pakistani law.In Afghanistan, Rahmat Gul of The Associated Press captured an arresting image of a boy running past a burning oil tanker. The vehicle had been carrying fuel supplies for NATO forces (Slide 5).

Venus Williams's straight-sets victory over Dominika Cibulkova was a clinic in strong serving and clean play. Cibulkova, a solid counterpuncher who reached the semifinals here a year ago, is a tough opponent, especially on a slow court, but she could never gain a toehold in the match. She did fight to gain three break points, but she only won one of them. Williams broke Cibulkova three times on five break point opportunities.

The actress Elaine Stritch said on Friday afternoon that she was talking to the producers of the Broadway revival of "A Little Night Music" about succeeding Angela Lansbury this summer in the role of Madame Armfeldt, but cautioned that no deal was in place and she was not sure if she would ultimately play the role.

When novelists write about other art forms, it can serve as a metaphor and an apologia for their own aims. In Steve Martin's lovingly precise and miniature "Shopgirl," the title character spends her nights making lovingly precise and miniature drawings, while in Don DeLillo's monumental and historically minded "Underworld," the artist Klara Sax earns her reputation with monumental, historically minded paintings that use decommissioned B-52 bombers as their canvas. (DeLillo loves to write about the arts, especially film and conceptual performance pieces, though the parallels to his own work aren't always so explicit.) Artists are at the heart of relatively recent books by Nell Freudenberger, Nick Laird, Olga Grushin and Stacey D'Erasmo, among many others. Novels about music, meanwhile, are so ubiquitous as to constitute their own genre.

As the population ages, home monitoring devices like Lifeline and others -- which keep track of your whereabouts, monitor your bodily functions and remind you to take their medicines -- have become more popular. Lifeline, made by Philips, is easy to use. By pushing a button on a pendant, you connect to a home base station, which automatically alerts a central station that there's an emergency. Trained operators with the customer's medical history can quickly call for help and alert relatives that something's wrong.

Ever notice how people typically warm up their short game before a round? They drop three balls on the putting green and putt for five minutes. Then they might hit four or five chip shots from just off the green, often practicing from the same spot. That's better than nothing - and a lot of golfers do nothing before a round - but it's not simulating the golf round that is about to begin and it's not how professional golfers warm up their short games.

Marmalade is Anglophilia in a pot: fussy, traditional and deliciously tooth-rotting. The word itself sounds like a mysterious ribbon of malaise and bonkers. In addition to bringing a blob of cheer to rainy weekday mornings, it recalls wartime London and lost toy bears, hallucinogens and manga. It is the definition of bittersweet: comforting, but with a sharp rind edge and a dark aftertaste. Watch Fry and Laurie put the "marm" in marmalade in a famous 1992 sketch.

If good fences make good neighbors, Sarah Palin and the author Joe McGinniss should get along beautifully. Ms. Palin has just had a 14-foot-high fence erected between her property and the house next door, which Mr. McGinniss has rented for the summer while he researches a book about Ms. Palin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGinniss, the author of "The Selling of the President" and "Fatal Vision," drew criticism from both the right and the left this week when Ms. Palin announced on her Facebook page that he had moved next door to her family on Lake Lucille in Wasilla, Alaska. Here at T, we consume sporting events like we do hot dogs: very infrequently, but with relish. Next up is the World Cup, and it's gonna be big. How big? That's now a fraught question. South Africa has already spent about $5 billion primping itself for the month-long soccer event, but expectations for visitors - once around 750,000 people - have dropped significantly. Blame the global recession, for sure, but the slump might also owe a bit to South Africa's location, at the bottom of a huge continent that often extends beyond most people's imaginations, and travel budgets.

It's an annual tradition with "American Idol": the finalists are named, a winner is chosen, the public expresses its outrage and questions the fidelity of the voting process, and then the top two performers are signed to record labels. Both Lee DeWyze, who won the show's ninth season on Wednesday night, and Crystal Bowersox, who came in second (but first in our hearts) are signed to 19 Recordings Limited, the label founded by the "Idol" creator, Simon Fuller. Billboard.com reported that Mr. DeWyze would release his first post-"Idol" album on RCA Records, which also put out albums by the "Idol" contestants Chris Daughtry and Adam Lambert, while Ms. Bowersox will release hers on Jive Records, which is also home to the "Idol" alumni Jordin Sparks, Kris Allen and Allison Iraheta. No release date was given for either album, though Mr. Allen and Mr. Lambert, last year's "Idol" winner and runner-up, put out their records in November. The debut singles of Mr. DeWyze (a cover of U2's "Beautiful Day") and Ms. Bowersox (a cover of Patty Griffin's "Up to the Mountain") have been released, though download results for those tracks weren't immediately available.

I'm not sure why I'm telling this story, but here goes: When we moved into our new shop in 2002, we quadrupled our square footage. So I knew overhead expenses would be going up considerably. Some of that increase was easy to predict, like more rent. Some was not so easy, like how much our electric bill would rise. Before the move, my bill was about $2,000 a month (we have some big machines). Afterward it ended up being about $6,000 a month. That didn't surprise me much -- quadruple space, quadruple lights, quadruple heat, more guys, more machines, etc., etc.

There is a lot that Hulk Hogan is willing to do in the name of comedy. He will allow himself to be bonked on the head with bowling balls or zapped with electricity, or dress up in a tutu and practice ballet moves with small children (and that's just in the trailer for "Mr. Nanny"). But what he will not allow is for an apparent cartoon version of himself to be defeated in a wrestling match by the son of a cereal-shilling caveman.

The Jump Lists feature of Windows 7 offers you a list of recently used files or tasks used by a particular program, but you can modify the Jump List to always show your favorite items. To see a Jump List from the Start menu, just move the mouse cursor over the program's name to see any recently used files or pages. You can also right-click a program's icon in the Taskbar to see its Jump List, and then select what you want from the list.

Price Tag Soars for Gubernatorial Campaigns | Meg Whitman, the former eBay chief executive, has spent about $68 million of her own money in her campaign for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, including $33.8 million in the past two months. She has said she's prepared to spend as much as $150 million and has already outspent her Republican primary opponent, Steve Poizner, $42 million to $17.9 million on television advertising. From mid-March to mid-May, according to newly released records, Ms. Whitman's campaign spent $512,121 a day; Mr. Poizner spent $252,000 a day; and the leading Democratic candidate, Attorney General Jerry Brown, spent $3,900 a day. And while the two Republican candidates have been trying to distance themselves from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, The Los Angeles Times reported that they are sounding more like him. [The Sacramento Bee, The San Francisco Chronicle, The Los Angeles Times]

The Pros, the College Standouts and the Rest of Us | While batting averages and marathon finishing times are part of the familiar background of big-time sports, a whole different class of statistics has its own resonance. Did you know that 2:20:06 is the record time in the men's challenged-athlete category of the Escape From Alcatraz triathlon? Or that more than 100 boats now compete each year in the Treasure Island dragon-boat regatta? Or how many times one woman has ridden a metric century on her bicycle in the Cinderella Classic? Look up the numbers behind the sports for the rest of us.First Local Food, Now Clothes and Furniture | With the help of the city's planning department, neighborhoods like Hayes Valley and North Beach have banned chain stores. Any formula retailer, which is defined as a store with more than 10 locations nationwide, must be approved by the planning commission before it can open. "The feeling is that potentially, if you allow a number of formula retail stores, you lose neighborhood character and locally owned businesses," said John Rahaim, director of the San Francisco Planning Department. But some residents and shopkeepers wonder if this hyper-local form of protectionism is good for residents and merchants - and who should have a say over how and where people shop.

For the first time in its history New York City Ballet will present a fall season in September and October at Lincoln Center. The company, which has previously presented a repertory season that started in November, opens its 2010-2011 season on Sept. 14 at the David H. Koch Theater, and it will feature performances of 28 different ballets, including 13 works by George Balanchine and 5 by Jerome Robbins. Other highlights of the fall run, which continues through Oct. 10, include a New York premiere by the choreographer Benjamin Millepied and a revival of ''The Magic Flute'' by the company's ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. The annual presentation of ''George Balanchine's The Nutcracker'' begins on Nov. 26 and runs through Jan. 2, and a six-week winter repertory season opens on Jan. 18. Other highlights of the season include a new work by Susan Stroman, and the previously announced new production of ''The Seven Deadly Sins,'' by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, featuring Patti LuPone in her New York City Ballet debut. In addition, the 2010-2011 season will feature ballets by Melissa Barak, Mauro Bigonzetti, Wayne McGregor, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon and a full-length staging of Tchaikovsky's ''Swan Lake'' by Mr. Martins. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

POLLOCK--Jack M.,Ph.D. died on May 26 after a long illness. Principal of Abraham Lincoln High School for twenty years. Past president of the NYC Alzheimer's Association. Beloved and cherished husband of Rose Lynn Sherr and the late Minna Pollock, devoted and loving father of David (Judy Kirpich), Faye (Dror) Cohen, and Susan Pollock (Larry Wiseman). Adoring grandfather of Max and Jody Pollock, Sam, Miriam, Gabi and Michal Wiseman, and Meromi and Miki Cohen. Shiva at the Pollock-Sherr residence until Wednesday AM. Contributions may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017 or to Leukemia Service, MSKCC, POB 27106, NY NY 10087-7105 (www.mskcc.org) or make an appointment to donate blood in Jack's name at MSKCC (212-639-7643).

Mikhail Shatrov, whose historical plays subjected Stalin and his legacy to withering scrutiny and signaled a new era of artistic freedom under Mikhail Gorbachev, died on Sunday at his home in Moscow. He was 78. The cause was a heart attack, the RIA Novosti news agency reported.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about an insurgent attack on Somalia's presidential palace misattributed a quotation about the movements of the Somalian army during the attack, which came as the government appeared increasingly paralyzed because of a longstanding rift between the prime minister, Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke, and other senior officials. It was Sheik Yusuf Mohamed Siad, the state minister for defense -- not the president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed -- who said, ''Our army withdrew from the front lines, and we have lost neighborhoods. But the prime minister is responsible for the defeat.''

In major league baseball from 2000 to 2009, the home team won 54 percent of the time. Many cite the home team's last at-bat as the reason. At the end of games, the thinking goes, the home team can tailor its strategy to match the situation. If the team is down by three runs, it can play for the big inning. If it needs one run, it can use small-ball strategies like bunting and base stealing to get that run. If only it were true. Recent research has found that having the last at-bat is not a statistically significant advantage. Three professors - Theodore Turocy, the data manager for the Society for American Baseball Research and an economist at East Anglia University in Norwich, England; and Stephen Shmanske and Franklin Lowenthal, professors at California State University, East Bay - have used simulations and examined data to debunk this myth.

6 A.M. (TCM) MEMORIAL DAY WEEKEND WAR MOVIE MARATHON Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to the troops, American and otherwise, with a 72-hour programming block of 22 combat movies. The salute begins with John Ford's ''Lost Patrol'' (1934), about British soldiers who must fight off Arab snipers while holed up at an oasis. Boris Karloff plays a melodramatic religious fanatic; Max Steiner wrote the score. A prime-time trilogy begins at 8 p.m. with ''Stalag 17'' (1953), directed by Billy Wilder and starring William Holden in his Oscar-winning role as a cynical American in a World War II prisoner-of-war camp who has to prove he's not an informer. ''The Great Escape'' (1963), in which a group of captive Allied troublemakers -- played by Steve McQueen, above, and James Garner, among others -- stage their exit, follows at 10:15, and ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' (1957), in which Holden reappears alongside Alec Guinness as World War II prisoners forced by the Japanese Army to build a strategic bridge in Burma, is at 1:15 a.m. The marathon ends on May 31 at 5 a.m. with the comedy ''Nazty Nuisance'' (1943), featuring Bobby Watson as Hitler, Joe Devlin as Mussolini and John Arthur as Suki Yaki, a Japanese general. 10:30 A.M. (TV5Monde) FRENCH OPEN Four and a half hours of live coverage from the 2010 Roland Garros French Open.

KORNBLIT--Ralph S.,passed away at the age of 92 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL, on May 27, 2010. He was the beloved husband of the late Florence Kornblit and is survived by his devoted sister, Shirley Eisenstadt; his companion, Lucille Stein; his sons, Mitchell and Peter; his daughter-in-law, Sandra; his adored granddaughter, Elizabeth; nieces, nephews and friends. A proud alumnus of Brooklyn College and a decorated WWII veteran, he will be greatly missed. Private funeral at Arlington National Cemetery.

A coalition of music groups has announced that its members will boycott all performances in Arizona to protest a tough new anti-immigration law there, and it has urged fans to sign a petition demanding the revocation of the legislation, which it calls ''an assault on the U.S. Constitution.'' The campaign, called the Sound Strike, has been organized by Zack de la Rocha, the lead singer of the rap metal band Rage Against the Machine, and is endorsed by English-language rock and rap performers like Massive Attack, Kanye West, Conor Oberst, Sonic Youth and Joe Satriani. But the signatories also include Spanish-speaking reggaetÃ³n artists and Los Tigres del Norte, perhaps the most popular and influential exponent of Mexican regional music in the United States.
A column by Nicholas D. Kristof on Thursday about the excommunication of Sister Margaret McBride in Phoenix misspelled the surname of the bishop of the local diocese. He is the Rev. Thomas Olmsted.

The next James Bond book will be written by Jeffery Deaver, the best-selling thriller writer, Simon & Schuster announced on Thursday. The novel, with the working title ''Project X,'' is expected to be set in the present day and take Bond to at least three ''exotic locations around the globe.'' It is scheduled for publication in May 2011. Mr. Deaver, the author of ''The Bone Collector'' and ''Garden of Beasts,'' said in a statement that he was thrilled to be asked by representatives of the Ian Fleming estate to write the book. ''The novel will maintain the persona of James Bond as Fleming created him and the unique tone the author brought to his books, while incorporating my own literary trademarks: detailed research, fast pacing and surprise twists.'' The book will be published by Hodder & Stoughton in Britain and Simon & Schuster in the United States. More than 100 million Bond books have been sold. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Wednesday about the findings of a BP investigation that revealed warning signals in the hours before the April 20 explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig misstated the timing, detailed in a House panel's memorandum, of a pressure test that was performed on the well. It was four hours before the explosion, not two hours.

The Bowery is expanding to Maine. In New York the Bowery Presents concert empire began 16 years ago with the tiny Mercury Lounge, and over the years it grew to include the Bowery Ballroom, the Music Hall of Williamsburg, Terminal 5 and shows at Webster Hall. Then came the Wellmont Theater in Montclair, N.J., and earlier this year the Bowery expanded to Boston.

An article on Wednesday about a major renovation and expansion at the Cleveland Museum of Art referred imprecisely to the financing of the project. While the museum has received court permission to use income from some endowments usually restricted to the purchase of art, it has not drawn on those funds.

A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about an end-of-year ritual at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., was erroneously listed under the New England heading. It should have been under Mid-Atlantic, of course.

The Colum-bia University School of Social Work community extends its sincerest condolences to Barbara Grodd, former chair of the CUSSW Development Committee, former member of the Dean's Advisory Council and active member of the Columbia Alumni Association, on the passing of her beloved husband Clifford Grodd. Clifford was a much loved friend of the School and an icon in the fashion industry. He will be greatly missed. Our thoughts and condolences go to the Grodd family. Dean Jeanette C. Takamura

Intelligent design. That's one goal of synthetic biology, a field that was catapulted into the news last week with the announcement that a group of biologists had manufactured a genome that exists nowhere in nature and inserted it into a bacterial cell. The dream is that, one day, we'll be able to sit and think about what sort of life-form we'd like to make - and then design and build it in much the same way we make a bridge or a car. Realizing this dream is still some way off. But before I get to that, let me briefly describe the state of play.

PROUNIS--Theodore O. Age 84. On May 22, 2010. Beloved husband of Lila Prounis. Father of Othon and Amelia. Grandfather of Alexa, Philip, Alexander and Karina. A native New Yorker, Mr. Prounis, a lawyer and management consultant, received B.S. and M.B.A degrees from Columbia University and a J.D. from Fordham Law School. He was President of the Board of Trustees of the Holy Trinity Cathedral from 1984-94, a founding Board Member of Columbia University's Program for Hellenic Studies, an Archon of the Holy Ecumenical Patriarchate and an officer of the Archdiocesan Council. He was a US Army Air Corps veteran of World War II and a cold war warrior in Washington, DC receiving various decorations. Mr. Prounis was also a son of the late Otto D. Prounis, owner of the posh Versailles nightclub in New York during the 1940s and 50s. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, May 31, 6pm-8pm. Funeral Services at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. 315 E. 74th, NY, NY 10021, Monday, June 1 at 2:30pm. Internment private. Memorial contributions in his memory may made be made to the Holy Trinity Cathedral (above) or to Columbia University, Program for Hellenic Studies, attn Gerry Visco, 1130 Amsterdam Avenue MC2861, 617 Hamilton Hall, NY, NY 10027.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 21 about proposals to ban plastic bags in Bay Area cities omitted the context for a quotation by Stephen Joseph, the founder of Save the Plastic Bag. When he said, ''So what is the problem you solve by banning plastic bags?'', Mr. Joseph was referring to his contention that plastic bags are not implicated in environmental damage of any sort. He was not referring solely to his contention that the bags do not harm marine mammals.

SIRULNICK--Joseph. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Joseph Sirulnick, a cherished leader and dear friend who was greatly admired for his extraordinary generosity and compassion. Joe; his late wife, Marcy; and their children have profoundly strengthened the Jewish community in Long Island, in Israel, and beyond. With true dedication and kindness, the Sirulnick family has made a lasting impact on the Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved children, Sandy Sirulnick, and his wife, Jill; Phyllis Danilow; and Carole Sirulnick; to his grandchildren, Joshua, Ross, Amy, Aaron, Joanna, Erik, Kaori, Johnny, and Sarah; to his great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

LOWERRE-JAMBOIS--Emilie, died peacefully at home on May 25th, her 61st birthday, surrounded by her loving family. Beloved wife of Thomas Jambois, loving sister of Mary Lowerre, Timothy Lowerre, Donald Lowerre, Thomas Lowerre (Diane), Donna Kjeldsen (Lance F.) and devoted and caring aunt of Amanda, Anna, Ben, Jayme, Katherine, Kristian and Lance G. Emilie attended Mary Louis Academy in Queens, was a 1971 graduate of the College of New Rochelle and received a masters degree in mathematics from Fordham University and an MSW from Columbia University. Emilie was passionate about everything in her life: her work in psychiatric social work, music, her family and her friends. Emilie was an extraordinary advocate for herself and others battling cancer through her work with Gilda's Club. Emilie has been an inspiration to her family, colleagues and friends and will always be in their hearts. Visitation will be on Tuesday, June 1st from 4pm to 7pm at Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place, Brooklyn. Funeral mass will be at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface, 190 Duffield Place, Brooklyn (www.oratory-church.org) on Wednesday, June 2nd at 10am. For more information, please contact Scotto Funeral Home at 718-875-2515 or at www.scottofuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Gilda's Club.

These days, being a writer for Conan O'Brien would seem to be as synonymous with idleness as being a Maytag repairman or a BP thank-you-note writer. But the writers for the former ''Tonight Show'' host and future TBS star are putting their downtime to productive use: after Mr. O'Brien completes his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour, his writers will perform a live show in Chicago that will be broadcast on TBS at the end of June. The show, called ''Team Coco Presents Conan's Writers Live,'' will be presented as part of the TBS Presents a ''Very Funny'' Festival: Just For Laughs (yes, that's its full title) on June 17 at the Bank of America Theater, its organizers said. The show will feature Andy Richter, Mr. O'Brien's longtime ''Late Night'' and ''Tonight Show'' sidekick, as well as Reggie Watts, a musician and comedian who has been opening for Mr. O'Brien on his tour, and will be shown June 27 on TBS. Then, before their egos get too inflated, it will be time for the writers to go back behind the cameras and help Mr. O'Brien prepare for his TBS debut on Nov. 8.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a proposal for a bank tax in Europe misspelled the surname of Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer in some copies. He is George Osborne, not Osborn.

We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Grodd family and the entire Paul Stuart organization during this time of great sadness. Peter S. Kalikow, Chairman Alfred C. Cerullo, III, President/CEO

WASHINGTON -- A senior United Nations official is expected to call on the United States next week to stop Central Intelligence Agencydrone strikes against people suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda, complicating the Obama administration's growing reliance on that tactic in Pakistan. Philip Alston, the United Nations special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions, said Thursday that he would deliver a report on June 3 to the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva declaring that the ''life and death power'' of drones should be entrusted to regular armed forces, not intelligence agencies. He contrasted how the military and the C.I.A. responded to allegations that strikes had killed civilians by mistake.

One spring day in 1976, a bedraggled pigeon traipsed through the open doorway of the Koho School of Sumi-E, a tiny, cramped Japanese brush painting school in SoHo. The bird couldn't fly. The school's owner and sole teacher, Koho Yamamoto (students call her Sensei), fed it rice and posted a sign in her storefront window that asked, ''Is anyone missing a pigeon?'' The only response came from a couple inquiring whether that was a Zen saying.

ZELKIN--Michael Edward, age 70, of Marlboro, Vermont, died in Venice, FL on May 25, 2010. He was born in Brooklyn, New York on October 5, 1939, and was a winter resident of Venice. A memorial service will be held in Moorestown, New Jersey on June 5th. Surviving family members include his wife, Emily Zelkin of Marlboro, Vermont and Venice, Florida; sons John Vogel of Greensboro, NC, Peter Vogel of New York, NY, and Kyle Vogel of Menlo Park, CA; daughter Maya Zelkin of Shrewsbury, VT; sister Sheila Siegel of Moorestown, NJ; and 11 grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. To send condolences visit: www.farleyfuneralhome.com

The Johnson & Johnson unit that recalled millions of bottles of liquid children's Tylenol and other pediatric medicines last month may face criminal penalties, product seizures or other sanctions, an official from the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday. The agency is considering further actions against McNeil Consumer Healthcare, the Johnson & Johnson unit, after a pattern of violations in manufacturing and quality control practices led to a number of recent recalls, Dr. Joshua M. Sharfstein, the F.D.A.'s principal deputy commissioner, said at a Congressional hearing on Thursday.

An article on Monday about the effort of South Africans to give the slickly marketed, corporate-branded World Cup soccer tournament splashes of African authenticity referred incorrectly to ''Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)'' by the Colombian pop star Shakira. It is the official World Cup song -- not the official anthem, which is ''Sign of a Victory'' by the American R. Kelly.

A headline on Wednesday about the case of a New York inmate who is seeking to have his murder conviction overturned overstated, in some editions, a ruling by the judge on Tuesday. As the article correctly noted, the judge said she would vacate the murder conviction, but she postponed the formal decision pending an evidentiary hearing. She did not void the conviction.
REICH--Dr. Charles, 63, died on May 26, 2010. Beloved husband of Marilyn, father of Joseph Leon, and sister of Claire (Wachtel).

Defying the protests of a conservative religious party that sought to ban his performance, Elton John played a concert in Rabat, Morocco, on Wednesday night as the headliner of that nation's largest music festival, Reuters reported. Morocco's Justice and Development Party (PJD), a fundamentalist Muslim organization, had complained that the appearance of Mr. John, who is gay, at the weeklong Mawazine World Rhythms Festival would reflect badly on the country and advocate homosexuality. ''We're a rather open party,'' Mustapha Ramid, a PJD spokesman, told The Associated Press, ''but promoting homosexuality is completely unacceptable.'' The festival's organizers said Mr. John's personal life was irrelevant, and the singer performed a show that was short on crowd banter but long on hits like ''I'm Still Standing'' and ''Candle in the Wind.'' Houda Sefriou, a concertgoer, told Reuters afterward, ''It's magical, just magical.''

Anneliese Rothenberger, an internationally known German soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera in New York in the 1960s, died on Monday in Switzerland. As befits a diva, her exact age had long been shrouded in obscurity; she was believed to have been either 83 or 85. The death, at a hospital near Ms. Rothenberger's home on Lake Constance, followed a short illness, friends told the news service Agence France-Presse.

KRUSCH--Edna G.,wife of Joseph G. Krusch died Wednesday, May 26 at New York Hospital. May the love and affection that pervaded the family continue in existence in her memory forever.

A listing in the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a recent lease at the Trump Building at 40 Wall Street referred incorrectly to the tenant, the Brokerage and Management Corporation. It is a shipping agency, not an accounting firm. The article also misidentified the tenant's broker. It is the real estate firm Studley -- not Julien J. Studley, the firm's former name.

NEW ORLEANS -- Concerns about the chemical dispersant being used to fight the gulf oil spill are suddenly spiking along the coast here, with workers fretting over exposure and health officials investigating a tiny cluster of complaints. On Wednesday afternoon, seven crew members aboard fishing vessels who had been working to clean up Breton Sound, southeast of New Orleans, blamed the chemicals for health complaints including nausea, shortness of breath and high blood pressure.

Tennis experts often describe Nadia Petrova as the best current player yet to win a major. She wallops the ball off both sides, using her height and leverage to dominate her opponents. She's beaten every big name player, but has a reputation for wilting under the bright lights of a Grand Slam. Sadly, she is known more for her memorable meltdowns (the Melanie Oudin match at last year's United States Open) than for her incredible playing.

Sharapova could not string together enough points to quell Henin's momentum.

Chris Evert won 18 Grand Slam singles championships, including seven at the French Open, during her 17-year tennis career. CHARLESTON, S.C. - If the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here were awarding a prize for the best curtain calls, it could have shut down the competition after opening night. After the performance of Haydn's puppet opera "Philemon and Baucis," by the Carlo Colla and Sons Marionette Company of Milan in the Emmett Robinson Theater at the College of Charleston on Friday evening, each of the offstage singers or actors joined his or her puppet counterpart on stage, walking with them hand in hand. The humans seemed Gullivers in the land of Lilliput, huge, hulking figures, overwhelming the stage.

The most distinctive book about Tiger Woods this spring has nothing to do with his recent life and everything to do with the college golf season of 1994-95. So "The Last Putt: Two Teams, One Dream, and a Freshman Named Tiger" (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt) is not a book written with an eye on Woods's recent tribulations. Still, Woods the teenager and collegian comes alive in new ways, teamed with Notah Begay and Casey Martin in Stanford's face-off at the 1995 N.C.A.A. championship against golf powerhouse Oklahoma State. This is a stroke-by-stroke tale by authors Neil Hayes and Brian Murphy with many subplots, on and off the golf course. The championship comes down to a sudden-death playoff, and so, you have to ask yourself: Who would you want standing over the last putt?

Here's an unlikely effect of recession: It may actually be helping some Americans improve their health. The majority of middle-class Americans say they are healthier because of frugal behaviors during the last year, including cooking at home or spending less on junk food, according to the results of a survey that the financial planning firm First Command Financial Services plans to release this week.

A bill to make playgrounds safer for children is garnering more attention as parents across New York complain about playground equipment that heats up in the summer sun and scorches their children's hands and feet. Assemblyman Micah Kellner introduced the bill earlier this year: It would require all playground equipment to be temperature tested. The Legislature may vote on the measure within two weeks.
