The University of Connecticut confirmed on Friday that it had received notice from the N.C.A.A. that its men's basketball program committed eight major rules violations, and it said that two of Coach Jim Calhoun's assistants had resigned because of them. University officials announced in a news conference in Storrs, Conn., that they were cooperating with the investigation and that they would impose their own penalties on the program.

Earlier this month, the Phoenix New Times published an expose about LifeLock, an Arizona company that recently agreed to pay $12 million to settle charges from the Federal Trade Commission and 35 states that the company used false claims to advertise its identity theft protection services. For those not familiar with LifeLock, its major offering until recently was a service that would place a 90-day fraud alert on your credit files with the credit agencies Equifax, Experian and TransUnion and then renew that alert every 90 days.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about concerns that a chemical dispersant, Corexit, being used by BP to break up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could pose health risks referred imprecisely to how forthcoming its manufacturer has been about its contents. While Nalco, the manufacturer, has not publicly disclosed the contents, it has reported them to the Environmental Protection Agency. (The E.P.A. asked BP to sharply reduce the amount it was using.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about possible criminal penalties against McNeil Consumer Healthcare, a unit of Johnson & Johnson involved in a wide recall of over-the-counter medications, quoted incorrectly from comments by Representative Edolphus Towns, who is chairman of a committee examining the recalls. Mr. Towns said the company's behavior painted a picture of a company that is ''willing to put the health of children at risk.'' He did not say ''that has risked the health of many of our citizens.''

SPELLMAN--Dr. Stanley. The Long Island Jewish Medical Center Staff Society mourns the loss of our colleague Dr. Stanley Spellman. Dr. Spellman, 87, formerly of Roslyn, NY, died on May 14, 2010 from Alzheimer's Disease. He received his MD from Indiana University School of Medicine in 1950 and practiced Internal Medicine, specializing in Pulmonary Diseases, for 40 years, in Queens, NY. He was an attending physician at Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he was the President of the Staff Society from 1971-1972. Spellman had many hobbies including growing orchids, golfing, fishing, woodworking, and inventing (two patents). He was a man of decency and honor (Silver Star in World War II) and had a great sense of humor. He is survived by his wife Betty (m. 1952); two sisters: Loretta Nelson and Harriet and Harvey Stack (Roslyn, NY); four children and their partners: Barbara and Fred Schauer (Charlottesville, VA), Judy and Matt Green (Boca Raton, FL), Jay and Amy (Woodcliff Lake, NJ), and Carol and Rob Shulman (Upper Saddle River, NJ); six beloved grandchildren: Max Green, Josh and Sarah Spellman, and Jamie, Jake, and Jessica Shulman; many adoring nieces and nephews; and generations of grateful patients and their families. Contributions may be made to Indiana University School of Medicine, the Alzheimer's Association (www.alz.org donate, tributes, find a tribute, Spellman), or the charity of your choice.

COLE--John, 59, died Wednesday after six years of fighting renal cancer. Born April 1951 in Harrison, NY to Daniel and Marjorie Cole. John was the youngest of three children. He graduated NYU in 1973 with a major in political science. In 1976 he married Rhonda Kobrin in New York City. Avid photographer, nature lover, devoted scoutmaster for 16 years; an inspiration to many. His efforts had a huge impact on the lives of his scouts. Survived by his wife, three children: James, Jackie, Michael, two sisters: Ellen and Susan and daughter-in-law Samantha. Funeral to be held Sunday at 12:45pm at Temple Israel Cemetery. 388 Sawmill River Road in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

9 P.M. (HBO) THE SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP (2010) Winston Churchill called it the ''special relationship'': the political, diplomatic, cultural and historical alliance between Britain and the United States, and between their leaders. Churchill had Franklin D. Roosevelt; John F. Kennedy had Harold Macmillan; Margaret Thatcher had Ronald Reagan. And, for a while, Tony Blair had Bill Clinton, which is the relationship at the heart of this third installment in the screenwriter Peter Morgan's trilogy about former Prime Minister Blair. Michael Sheen, above left with Dennis Quaid, reprises his role as Blair, whom he portrayed in ''The Deal'' and ''The Queen''; Mr. Quaid is Clinton; Hope Davis is Hillary Clinton; and Helen McCrory is Cherie Blair. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called Mr. Quaid's and Mr. Sheen's performances ''dazzling,'' and said that Ms. Davis ''all but steals the film.'' The movie ''provides a captivating peek into the meshing of personality and power and how easily even the strong bonds come unglued,'' she wrote. ''Or, as one British political adviser warns in the film, 'All political friendship is strategic and conditional.' '' 6:30 A.M. (TCM) MEMORIAL DAY WEEKEND WAR MOVIE MARATHON Turner Classic Movies continues its tribute to the troops, American and otherwise, in this 72-hour programming block, which picks up today with ''You're in the Army Now'' (1941), starring Jimmy Durante and Phil Silvers as incompetent door-to-door salesmen who enlist by accident. ''The Essentials,'' a prime-time segment, begins at 8 p.m. with William Wyler's ''Best Years of Our Lives'' (1946), starring Fredric March, Dana Andrews and Harold Russell as servicemen struggling to adjust to life after World War II. In ''Pride of the Marines'' (1945), at 11, John Garfield plays a blinded soldier who has returned to civilian life; in ''Birdy'' (1984), at 1:15 a.m., Matthew Modine is a shell-shocked Vietnam veteran who believes he is a bird, and Nicolas Cage is the physically wounded comrade who tries to rescue him. And in the documentary ''Let There Be Light'' (1946), at 3:30 a.m., John Huston looks at the treatment provided to soldiers with debilitating emotional trauma and depression.

TORONTO - "Let's put our tears into our Sajda and pray that God may give the Taliban hearts," the leader at my local Toronto Ahmadiyya mosque said during Friday prayer. He was urging the congregation to shed their tears during the critical Sajda step of prayer, while kneeling down and touching their foreheads to the ground.

In a remarkably prescient moment in September, 1965, James B. Stockdale, then a senior Navy pilot shot down over Vietnam, muttered to himself as he parachuted into enemy hands, "Five years down there at least, I'm leaving behind the world of technology and entering the world of Epictetus." As a departing graduate student at Stanford, Stockdale received a gift of Epictetus's famous "Enchiridion," a 1st-century Stoic handbook. The text looked esoteric, but in his long nights aboard the U.S.S. Ticonderoga, he found himself memorizing its content. Little did he know then that Stoic tonics would become his salvation for seven and a half years as the senior prisoner of war, held under brutal conditions by the North Vietnamese at Hoa Lo prison, the Hanoi Hilton.

Since the 1930s, construction workers called flaggers or signalers have used a private vocabulary of hand signals to communicate from the ground with crane operators. These hand signals ensure that loads are maneuvered, sometimes at dizzying heights, with all due regard for the safety of pedestrians, workers and cargo.Â This July, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is set to issue revised regulations for crane operations - which may include changes to the way signalers are trained and certified. Kevin McGuire, a master rigger who has worked for Con Edison for 38 years, offers a guide to what aspiring flaggers need to know.

Cook, Katherine Jenkins, Kelli O'Hara and Yolanda Adams will perform, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra (above, in 2009) under the direction of Jack Everly. Gen. Colin L. Powell and members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will make appearances, as will the United States Army Herald Trumpets, the United States Navy Sea Chanters and the United States Air Force Singing Sergeants, along with color guard and service flags from each branch of the armed services. 6:30 A.M. (TCM) MEMORIAL DAY WEEKEND WAR MOVIE MARATHON Turner Classic Movies concludes its 72-hour tribute to the troops, American and otherwise, which picks up today with ''Battle Cry'' (1955), starring Van Heflin as the commander of a Marine battalion awaiting deployment during World War II. The prime-time feature begins at 8 p.m. with ''Mister Roberts'' (1955), directed by John Ford and starring Henry Fonda as a naval officer longing for active duty who clashes with his tyrannical captain (James Cagney). ''Operation Petticoat'' (1959), starring Cary Grant and Tony Curtis as submarine officers stuck in tight quarters with a group of female Army nurses, follows at 10:15. The marathon ends at 5 a.m. with ''Nazty Nuisance'' (1943), featuring Bobby Watson as Hitler, Joe Devlin as Mussolini and Johnny Arthur as Suki Yaki, a Japanese general.

LILLIN--Charles Joseph, age 85, passed away on May 29, 2010, with his loving wife of 59 years, Marion, and their two sons, Daniel and Ethan at his side. Cooper Union School of Commercial Arts Graduate, Avid Sailor and Consummate New Yorker, Charles leaves behind many loyal and unique friends and countless memories. Known over the years as "Vitamins", "One-Armed-Charlie" and "Wormser", his favorite title was Grandpa to James, Jack and Haley. The Lillin family invites all to a remembrance of Charles' life at the Bellmore Funeral Home, 2340 Jerusalem Ave., North Bellmore, on Saturday, June 5, 2010 from 2-4pm.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''New York's Allure Overcame the Cold,'' May 26: The N.F.L. owners broke tradition by awarding the 2014 Super Bowl to the new Jets-Giants stadium in North Jersey.

FOTOUHI--Renee, owner of art galleries in Manhattan and East Hampton, an art curator and producer of performance art shows, died on May 10. She was fifty years old. She died after a lengthy battle with leiomyosarcoma. Renee began her career in the art world in the New York gallery of the London old master dealer Colnaghi, she then became a specialist in the Impressionist and Modern Paintings department at Christie's. At age twenty-seven Renee established a Madison Avenue gallery, and later went on to open two Renee Fotouhi Fine Art galleries in East Hampton. Renee also opened a Soho gallery with Karen Cramer. Renee produced a series of stage shows in East Hampton that featured appearances by performance artists Laurie Anderson and Eric Begosian, among others. Renee's galleries exhibited in the foremost trade shows in New York, Miami, and Paris. Her gallery exhibitions and shows were reviewed by the New York Times, Newsday, and other publications. Renee's residences became the subject of articles and photo essays in Interior Designs magazine, and a leading Westchester publication. Renee was born on January 13th, 1960, in Binghamton, New York. She earned a BA from Vassar College and an MA in Fine Art from New York University. Renee is survived by her beloved son Jordan, husband Henry Scholder, sisters Rebecca Lambert Bent and Deborah Monticello, and her parents Dr. Abol Hassan and Eleanor Fotouhi, as well as by nephews Maxwell S. Bent, Anthony Michael, Christopher, Alexander, and Nicholas Monticello. There will be a celebration of Renee's memory later this year on the East End of Long Island, and another in New Rochelle, New York. Contributions in Renee's memory may be made to Vassar College; Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts, 2 East 91st St., New York; and the American Cancer Society.

IN the vintage business for nearly two decades, Seth Weisser and Gerard Maione of What Comes Around Goes Around have seen a lot of things, well, come and go. But nothing has moved quite as quickly as their 20 pieces of vintage Chanel jewelry that were posted on Shopbop.com last September, and sold within 24 hours. ''When it comes to luxury brands,'' Mr. Weisser said, ''Chanel's the gold standard.'' It took some time, but WCAGA has replenished its supply tenfold, filling the SoHo shop with some 200 heavily logoed pendants, charm bracelets, clip-on earrings and quilted leather bags from the '80s and '90s. And this time, there's no chance of their being cleaned out: ''We have a ton more arriving next week,'' Mr. Weisser assured us.

THE NEWS The space shuttleAtlantis dropped out of orbit and returned to Earth to complete its 32nd and final mission, a successful trip to the space station to deliver supplies and install equipment and a research module. BEHIND THE NEWS Atlantis, in service for 25 years, is the first orbiter to reach its final scheduled flight as NASA phases out its three-shuttle fleet. It will eventually go to a museum, but not quite yet. First, it will be readied for emergency launch in case of trouble during Endeavour's last mission, late this year or early in 2011; Discovery makes its final flight in the fall.

The euro may still be dropping, but thus far, flights to Europe have been expensive enough to keep travelers looking elsewhere. If you can postpone your trip until after Labor Day, EuropeVacations.com, in conjunction with Kayak.com, is offering six-night packages to seven European cities, starting at $749 a person. Travel between Sept. 8 and Oct. 25, from airports nationwide. Plus, save an additional $50 with the promo code EVKK1.

White traditionally makes a showing at Memorial Day. This year, it's being worn in a fresh way: oversize shirts over stemlike leggings. Also appearing are neutral and off-white, and whimsical ribbon and lace creations. The straw fedora, once replacing felt hats on men at this holiday, has been adopted by women.

IF there is one thing in Givenchy's new fall ad campaign that caught our attention, it is not, alas, the presence of a transsexual model named Lea T. -- a casting decision that has caused much blog buzz. Rather, it is the traffic-stopping red. In a season full of strictly tailored pieces and stretches of noncolor (nude, blush, camel), a hot flash of the hue has quite an exhilarating effect. As we see it, red (forgive us, Mr. Valentino) has never looked so right. Fortunately, there was a lot of it on the fall runways, as well as in the pre-fall collections, with color-blocked looks at CÃ©line, Balenciaga, Sonia Rykiel and Chanel. Head-to-toe tomato too much for you? Be like the pope and sport a sublime pair of scarlet shoes.

GOULD--Laurence Jay, Ph.D.,born February 8, 1937, died suddenly on May 26, 2010. Larry was a brilliant psychoanalyst and academic in his field, loved and admired by many of his colleagues, students and friends worldwide. He was an acutely intelligent, thoughtful man, whose intellect was met, if not out- shown, by his warmth and terrific humor. He showed kindness and respect to all. He had many extraordinary accomplishments in his field, but the gift of his love, support and compassion to those in his close circle is his biggest legacy. He leaves his brother Roger, sister-in-law Pat, nephews Scott and Mahboud, nieces Nicky and Tracie, all their wonderful children, and his loving companion Ruth and her son Daniel. We will miss Larry forever.

The ''In the Region'' article in Connecticut and Westchester copies last Sunday, about cases in which some developers have decided to auction off new condominiums because of the poor sales climate, reported on an auction scheduled last Sunday for 15 unsold condos at the Stone Ridge complex in Fairfield. After the section had gone to press, the developers canceled the auction, in part because advance registrants indicated discomfort with the bidding process.

TULMAN--Lawrence D.D.S. Larry passed away May 4th. He loved and was completely devoted to his wife Natalie (Lindner). He cared deeply for his family and friends. He was very special, unique, great sense-of-humor and highly principled. A tireless worker, a gifted student, he mastered both Dentistry and Real Estate, reaching his goals successfully. He loved a good joke, a tough challenge and a long walk. He was a mentor to many, gentle, kind, generous, unassuming, asking little of others, but giving much. He will be in our hearts and thoughts forever.

Following is the second set of answers from Dr. Harold Koplewicz, a child and adolescent psychiatrist and president of the Child Study Center Foundation. This week he is responding to readers' questions about the myths and stigma surrounding psychiatric disorders of children and adolescents. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

Tennis experts often describe Nadia Petrova as the best current player yet to win a major. She wallops the ball off both sides, using her height and leverage to dominate her opponents. She's beaten every big name player, but has a reputation for wilting under the bright lights of a Grand Slam. Sadly, she is known more for her memorable meltdowns (the Melanie Oudin match at last year's United States Open) than for her incredible playing. Her victory Saturday against the crowd favorite, Aravane Rezai, could be a breakthrough for Petrova. The match had been halted at 7 all Friday in the third and resumed earlier Saturday.

In shutting out Philadelphia three straight times this week, the Mets delighted their fans and stunned the Phillies. They also brought back memories of the championship season of 1969, when Mets pitchers hurled four shutouts in a row, all of them in late September as the team clinched the first division title in its history. Those four shutouts still stand as the team record, but the Mets gave it quite a run Friday night. Johan Santana pitched eight scoreless innings against the Brewers in Milwaukee, but Ryota Igarashi allowed a two-run homer to Corey Hart with two outs in the bottom of the ninth to end the shutout streak at 35 complete innings, seven shy of the team record.

A picture credit on May 16 with an article about Rand Paul's political conservatism and his comments on the Civil Rights Act of 1964 misstated the date of the photograph showing two women outside a segregated theater in Mississippi. As the credit noted, the picture was by The New York Times, but it was taken in 1962, not 1950.

OVUNC--Dr. Bulent Ahmet A researcher and professor emeritus of civil engineering at University of Louisiana in Lafayette passed away peacefully in his sleep May 26, 2010 at the age of 82. A kind and gentle man, Dr. Ovunc was born in Samsun Turkey in 1927 and attended St. Joseph's College Preparatory School a well-established French school serving Istanbul both in the Ottoman times, and also in modern times. He began his studies in engineering at the Istanbul Technical University in 1949. While there Dr. Ovunc was awarded a scholarship from the French Government to participate in the Prestressed Concrete Course at Ecoles des Arts et des Metiers in Paris and worked on photostress at the Laboratory of Mechanics and Physics of the Sorbonne. Returning to Istanbul, Dr. Ovunc graduated from ITU in 1954 and joined the faculty as an Instructor at the Reinforced Concrete Institute. He obtained his PhD in 1963. In 1965, Dr. Ovunc was appointed Academic Research Assistant at the University of British Columbia and moved his family to Vancouver Canada. After working two years there, he joined the Civil Engineering Department of the University of Louisiana in Lafayette as Associate Professor and was promoted to Professor in 1970 and was tenured in 1972. Dr. Ovunc's career spanned some 38 years at ULL. Dr. Ovunc was an internationally renowned expert in static and dynamic finite element analysis and published hundreds of articles, book chapters and research reports in national and international journals. In addition, he served as Reviewer for the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Journal of Petroleum Division, the American Society of Civil Engineers, Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, and the Natural Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada. He also served as Associate Editor for the International Journal of Pipelines. Among his many scientific and professional society affiliations he was a member of Sigma Xi, Chi Epsilon, and Phi Kappa Phi. During his years at ULL, he was awarded the Halliburton Education Foundation Award for Excellence in Teaching, the Distinguished Professor Award, the M. Elloi Girard Professor of Civil Engineering, and the John and Joretta Achee Chance Professor of Civil Engineering. Generations of civil engineering students at ULL were touched by his dedication to teaching and to his scholarly works. Dr. Ovunc is mourned by his beloved wife of 53 years Bercis, his daughter Ayse McCracken and her husband Grant, his grandson Grant II, his brother Turgut Ovunc and his wife Nebahat and their son Mehmet Ovunc and his wife, his niece Fatma Kazdal and her husband, his brother-in-law Samim Zarali and his wife Elizabeth, his brother-in-law Ergin Zaralioglu and his wife Olcay and their son Alpin, his sister-in-law Acun Bakici and her husband, his brother-in-law Mete and his wife Semra and their daughter Cagda Atahatipoglu and her husband. Dr. Ovunc is preceded in death by his mother and father, his brother Enis, his niece Pitircik, and his nephew George. Friends and family gathered for a memorial service held in Lafayette, Louisiana on May 29, 2010. Donations in Dr. Ovunc's memory may be made to: The Hospice of Acadiana Foundation 2600 Johnson Street, Suite 236, Lafayette, Louisiana 70503. www.hospiceacadiana.com.
Theater Jason Zinoman

You can appreciate ''Exile'' as a rock LP, or you can take it seriously, treating it as one of the most enduring and complex artistic statements of Anglo-American culture in the last 50 years. Is that excessive? Yes, sir. But ''Exile'' is all about excess and layers and complexity. Yet it feels so, so good. What great music. SEAN ELDON of Ann Arbor, Mich., responding to Ben Ratliff's reassessment of the Rolling Stones' ''Exile on Main St.''

An article on May 16 about Cass Sunstein, the Obama administration's regulatory czar, referred incorrectly to the discount rate, a figure Sunstein's agency, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, considers when assessing plans to combat global warming. The rate suggests how much present value should be assigned to costs or benefits that will be experienced in the future. The discount rate is not the depreciation rate of money. (For instance, $1 million in five years and discounted at 3 percent would be considered worth $860,000 today.)

NOW that fashion blogs have made celebrities out of stylists -- and editors more interesting than their own cover stars -- there is Industrie Magazine, a publication out of London that shines the spotlight on fashion's most intriguing and influential players. The first issue, which hits newsstands next week, includes conversations with the Love editor Katie Grand, the Net-A-Porter founder Natalie Massenet, the CondÃ© Nast publishing director Tom Florio, and the Balenciaga stylist Marie-AmÃ©lie SauvÃ©, whose itinerant career of late has been rich fodder for the online gossip mills. ''We had questions that other magazines never asked the fashion industry,'' said Industrie's editors in chief, Erik Torstensson and Jens Grede (also the founders of the creative agency Saturday Group), via e-mail. ''We already know who's who, so what can the who's who tell us.'' And according to Mr. Torstensson and Mr. Grede, the answer is unanimous: ''Fashion is changing quicker than we know what to make of it.''

PARIS - As Andy Roddick was losing on one court, Serena Williams looked like she would become a bigger upset victim on another. Williams, seeded first, breezed through the first set against No. 29 Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova. But she was struggling to hold things together. Dizzy spells began in the match's second game, she said later. She was on her way to getting skunked in the second set, and an ignominious third-round loss was brewing.

A hotel row grows in Brooklyn. The 25-story Sheraton Brooklyn New York Hotel opened on May 20 in the shadow of the MetroTech Center and Brooklyn Academy of Music, the first of several hotels scheduled to open in the area. The Sheraton (228 Duffield Street; 718-855-1900; sheratonbrooklyn.com) has 321 modern rooms and suites, a large fitness center, indoor heated pool, a solarium and a 1,500-square-foot rooftop patio with fantastic Manhattan views. There is also a New American restaurant and martini bar called Grubstake. Doubles start at around $200.

The more automakers work on integrating smartphones and their apps into the dashboard, the more confusing it gets. Just about every automaker is taking a different approach, creating headaches for drivers. One problem is that there is no industry standard, so Nokia and a group of five German automakers are proposing a new way of doing things. The proposed standard was spawned from the CE4A (which stands for Consumer Electronics for Automotive), a working group composed of Audi, BMW, Daimler, Porsche and Volkswagen. The standard is supposed to be open to all automotive and mobile device manufacturers to provide a common way for handsets to work with in-dash systems. In rough terms, the goal is to make it so smartphone developers can create, say, a Pandora application that will work in all cars, and carmakers can install infotainment systems that will work with any smartphone.

Recently, as I was walking across the southern end of my college campus, I encountered a giant, buzzing swarm of bees making drunken patterns in the air. Another professor, several yards ahead of me, stopped and asked, ''What are they?'' I immediately called a friend, a tree surgeon who has relocated wild hives. His name is James Brochu, he goes by the handle Puma Ghostwalker, and I had just been texting him that morning about the island's decimated bee population.

Daimler AG announced on Thursday a joint venture with BYD, the Chinese automobile and battery manufacturer, to build a research and technology center to develop electric cars in BYD's home city of Shenzhen. The Shenzhen BYD Daimler New Technology Company, as the company will be called, will seek to strengthen each brand's position in China's electric-vehicle market. In March, the two automakers signed a memorandum of understanding to build electric cars in China. At the time, Henry Li, BYD's international sales manager, said a proposed jointly developed electric car would be positioned above the e6, the four-door E.V. that BYD displayed at the Detroit auto show in January.

Since the 1930s, construction workers called fl aggers or signalers have used a private vocabulary of hand signals to communicate from the ground with crane operators. Th ese hand signals ensure that loads are maneuvered, sometimes at dizzying heights, with all due regard for the safety of pedestrians, workers and cargo. Th is July, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is set to issue revised regulations for crane operations - which may include changes to the way signalers are trained and certifi ed. Kevin McGuire, a master rigger who has worked for Con Edison for 38 years, off ers a guide to what aspiring fl aggers need to know. HOIST Move the line directly up. Rotate upheld fi nger in circles.HOIST Move the line directly up. Rotate upheld fi nger in circles.

Hermes isn't just the gold standard for well-made products; it's also one of the few family-run companies in fashion. It can afford to do things a little differently. Yesterday's announcement that the Paris house had hired Christophe Lemaire for women's ready to wear, succeeding Jean Paul Gaultier, raised a few eyebrows. It's a bit of an unconventional choice, given that Mr. Lemaire, at Lacoste for the last decade, isn't a big name like Mr. Gaultier or his predecessor Martin Margiela. This morning I spoke to Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the general artistic director of Hermes - and a sixth-generation member of the family - about the thinking behind the choice. Q. Some people in the industry are surprised.

COE--George Vernon, III, of Middletown, NJ died Thursday, May 27th at the age of 69. He attended St. Paul's School and Tulane University. Mr. Coe, an avid fisherman, sportsman and conservationist was a member of the Boone & Crocket Club, Game Conservation International, The Philadelphia Gun Club, African Wildlife Foundation and was the chairman of the Atlantic Flyway of Ducks Unlimited and Camp Fire Club of America. Up until his death, he was an active board member of Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. He is survived by his wife Sarah; his sister Brucie; his daughters, Elizabeth, Holly and Alexandra and three grandchildren. There will be no visitation hours. A funeral service will be held at St. George's by the River Church, 7 Lincoln Ave., Rumson on Wednesday, June 2nd, 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial donations in his memory to the Monmouth County SPCA, PO Box 93, Eatontown, NJ 07724. Thompson Memorial Home, Red Bank was entrusted with his services.

Chris Evert won 18 Grand Slam singles championships, including seven at the French Open, during her 17-year tennis career. She lives in Boca Raton, Fla., where she is raising three teenage sons and has a tennis academy. Evert, 55, continues to promote her sport and was part of the United States Tennis Association's tribute to tennis mothers in May, National Tennis Month. She recently gave a lesson atop the Empire State Building to children from the Harlem Junior Tennis and Education Program. Q. You won the French Open seven times. Can anyone today equal or surpass that?A. That's a hard question. I doubt it, and it's nothing against today's players, but because there is so much more depth right now in the game of tennis, it's harder for any one person to win a lot of Grand Slams. I think it would be really hard and quite an achievement. Q. What are you doing now?A. I have three teenage boys, so my first priority is with my kids, being home with them. I also have my tennis academy in Boca Raton, and I have a hospital named after me that I do a lot of work for. I'm also the publisher of a tennis magazine, but the most important thing for me right now is to be a mom.Q. How concerned are you about Martina Navratilova, who has breast cancer?A. I think she's very optimistic. and I'm optimistic for her. She's strong and she's healthy and she's taking this like a champion, and she knows we are all thinking about her.Q. Are you still playing competitive tennis?A. Not competitive, but I do go to my academy and play there three or four times a week, and that's enough for me right now. I don't play any other sports, though I have gone skiing and I have surfed, but tennis is the main thing.Q. Who is your favorite tennis player? A. Roger Federer has always been my favorite. He's a gentleman. You would want to have him as your son, or your boyfriend or your brother. He's just a wonderful human being. Q. Tell us something no one knows about you.A. I have a dirty sense of humor.Q. Your three marriages ended in divorce. Are you dating, and would you consider marrying again?A. Right now it's the last thing on my mind. I'm not dating. I got the wind taken out of my sails on this last one and so I'm not considering it. It's the furthest thing from my mind. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

COCHRAN--Annemarie Menz, died on May 18th peacefully at her home in Southport, CT. She was 88 years old and was born in 1922 in Charlottenburg, Germany, a suburb of Berlin. In 1926, Annemarie and her brother, Frederick moved to Washington, DC with their mother, Katarina Josaphina Kemp Menz, where they became US citizens. Annemarie was a student at Sidwell Friends and later attended Hannah More Academy boarding school. Pursuing her love of art, she attended the Corcoran School of Art in Washington and then modeled professionally in New York City. Summers were spent at the family estate in Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania. After WWII, Annemarie worked for the Red Cross in the Philippines. Upon her return to the US, she met and married Worthington Johnson of Pittsburgh. They settled in Fairfield, CT and had two children, Margo Johnson and Worthy Johnson, Jr. They later divorced and she married Drayton Cochran of Oyster Bay, NY. They had one son, Gifford W. Cochran. Much of her married life to Drayton was spent sailing around the world, visiting exotic locations and living life to its fullest. Her love of art produced beautiful watercolor paintings and jewelry that she created as she traveled. Annemarie is survived by her children, Gifford Cochran of Bozeman, MT, Worthy Johnson of Jackson Hole, WY and Margo Johnson of Hobe Sound, FL, and her grandchildren, Nina Lynch, Handley and Stephanie Johnson, Drayton and Lucy Cochran. She was predeceased by Drayton Cochran and her granddaughter, Jennifer Worthington Johnson. Annemarie loved her painting and work shop projects. Her journey through life was full with friends from not only the US but also San Miguel de Allende, Mexico and the Azores. She will be missed by many and remembered fondly by all who knew her....she was a gift to all of us. A memorial will be held at Pequot Yacht Club in Southport, CT on Sunday, June 13th from 4-6pm. Online condolences to: www.shaughnesseybanks.com
To the Editor: Re ''A Fresh Look Back at Right Now'' by A. O. Scott [May 23]:

An article last Sunday about old television antennas that are still attached to houses and apartment buildings described incompletely the circumstances under which those antennas will pick up digital signals. Besides being able to receive signals with an external digital converter box, many antennas can receive signals on televisions with built-in digital converters.

In memory of our father, who took pride in his son, Sandy and two daughters, Phyllis and Carole, daughter-in-law Jill, grandchildren Aaron, Erik, Johnny, Ross, Josh, Sarah, and their spouses Joanna, Kaori, Amy and his great-grandchildren Hannah, Sarah, Ira, Noah, Sydney, Olivia, Jordan, Kate. Dad, we will miss you dearly and remember you always. Joe touched the lives of all who surrounded him through his love of art, tennis and charity. Graveside funeral at New Montefiore Cemetery Tuesday 10:30am. Memorial contributions can be made to United Jewish Appeal.

SCHNITZER--Shirley R.,retired professor of English at John Jay College, who served on the school's faculty from 1970 to 1991, died on May 27, 2010. She was 85. With her colleague, Dr. Barbara Meister, Dr. Schnitzer was also a member of the four-hand piano team of Meister and Schnitzer, which gave recitals at John Jay and other venues in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut. In addition, Dr. Schnitzer was a freelance writer, as well as a member of the Board of Directors and annotator for over a decade of the Chesnut Hill Concerts, a series of four concerts held every year in August in Madison, CT. She is the widow of Raymond L. Schnitzer, and is survived by her cherished son, Michael, by a niece and nephew and their spouses, and by four great nieces. Services will be held Tuesday at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

CROZIER--Lydia, 74, of South Palm Beach, FL passed away May 17, 2010. Born in Cuba, Lydia with her mother and brothers came to the US from Havana in 1946. She lived and worked in Brooklyn, NYC, Long Island, Virginia, Maryland, New Hampshire and Florida. When Lydia met James Crozier, the love of her life, they moved to Palm Beach where they lived until Jim's passing in 2002. Lydia was a tireless supporter and advocate for those in need and those she loved. She served on the boards of FoundCare, Hope House and CAP. For over 22 years she devoted her life to helping people living with HIV/AIDS. A mentor, teacher, philanthropist and great, unique friend; her "joi de vivre" drew all close to her. Her passion for living life fully was undeniable. Gifts may be made to CAP, 2330 S. Congress Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33406 and Hospice 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. A celebration of her life will be held June 14 at 5:30pm at Unity in West Palm Beach.
LAZER--Nathan, 99. A New York City civil engineer, he loved to walk in the Bronx and read in the library. He loved his family, who will miss him greatly.

An article last Sunday about episodes of ''Law & Order'' and the actual events they were based on referred incorrectly to an accolade earned by Julia Roberts for a guest appearance on the show. She was nominated for an Emmy, but did not win. And because of an editing error, the article misstated part of the name of an episode based on the Mayflower Madam. It was ''By Hooker, By Crook,'' not ''By Hook or By Crook.''

MORAN--Darlene (nee Whittaker). Beloved former wife of John A. Moran, loving mother to Kellie Moran Hudson, Marisa Moran Sullivan (Daniel) and Elizabeth Moran, devoted grandmother to Danielle Sullivan, Matthew Sullivan, Lily Hudson, Brittany Sullivan and John Sullivan, dear sister to Dale Whittaker. Mrs. Moran passed away peacefully at home with her family and wonderful caregivers at her side on Saturday May 29th after a long illness. Born to Howard Moroni Whittaker and Clara Schefter Whittaker on April 9, 1933 in Salt Lake City, Utah. The Moran family settled in Scarsdale, NY in 1967. Darlene was active in many volunteer organizations throughout her life. She was a gifted pianist and her artistic abilities were an inspiration to all. Her greatest joy was her family and she was their tower of strength. With her passing comes great sorrow and she will be sincerely missed and loved forever. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday 10am Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale. Visiting hours Tuesday 6-9pm only. Reposing at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY 10583. 914-725-1137

An article last Sunday about the deadly crash-landing of an Air India jetliner and the questions it raised about safety oversight and pilot training in India misstated the number of hours of flying time that the United States requires to co-pilot a passenger plane compared with the standards in India. The American requirement is 250 hours, not 1,500. (As the article correctly noted, India requires 200 hours.) The article also referred imprecisely in some editions to the width of the runway at the airport in Mangalore, India, where the accident happened, and the width recommended by the Indian government. Both figures -- 656 feet for the runway and 984 for the government standard -- include the paved runway as well as the cleared safety area on either side.

Think back to New York in the '70s and '80s - litter strewn along the streets, minefields of dog excrement, and graffiti on every surface reachable by a can of spray paint. It's almost all gone now, except for one thing, one devious little hanger-on: cigarette butts. I think most people, like me, have filtered them out (sorry, no other way to say it). But if you look down as you walk anywhere in the city, no matter how clean a neighborhood is otherwise, you will see hundreds of them, block after block - a never-ending trail to nowhere.

LEVITIN--Dr. Howard, 82, of Branford, CT, died at his home on the morning of Thursday May 27, 2010. Dr. Levitin was born February 12, 1928, in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Levitin spent fifty two years as distinguished professor and physician at Yale medical School and Hospital. Honoring the wishes of Dr. Levitin there will be no formal service, however, on Wednesday June 2 from 2-7pm the family is inviting friends and colleagues to call at 11 Debra Lane, Branford, CT. Anyone wishing to honor Dr. Howard Levitin may make a donate to the Neighborhood Music School, 100 Audubon St, New Haven, CT 06511.

PENICK--Jean, wife of Joe E. Penick, died Tuesday, May 25th at Princeton Hospital. She is survived by her husband, sons Edward and David and granddaughters Katherine and Emily. She was 88. Funeral service will be held at Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, NJ, Wednesday June 2 at 1pm. Jean also had a home in Naples, FL and previously lived in Chappaqua, NY. She will be lovingly remembered by her friends and family.

An article last Sunday about congressional fund-raising misstated the ranking of Representative John Adler, Democrat of New Jersey, among House freshmen raising the most money. An analysis by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington found that Mr. Adler placed third -- not first -- among 54 House freshmen in the 2010 campaign cycle. (Representative Alan Grayson, Democrat of Florida, ranked first.)

ZALUSKY--Ralph, MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed colleague, Ralph Zalusky, MD, who served with great distinction on our medical staff for almost 35 years. Dr. Zalusky held many important positions during his tenure, including Associate Chairman of Medicine and Chief of Hematology/Oncology. In addition, he was recognized as an astute clinical researcher. He helped to define the role of folic acid and vitamin B-12 in metabolism and blood formation, and to identify abnormalities associated with various bone marrow disorders. He also was a revered clinical instructor and mentor to three generations of physicians in training. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him, worked with him, and were treated by him. To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Harris M. Nagler, MD President Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President, Medical Board Henry C. Bodenheimer, Jr, MD Chairman Department of Medicine Michael L. Grossbard, MD Chief of Hematology/Oncology

LANDES--Irwin J.,March 6, 1926 to May 27, 2010. Irwin was born in New York City, a graduate of Lincoln High School, Harvard University and Harvard Law School. He served in the US Army during WWII. He married Alice Zigelbaum in 1944 and they lived in Great Neck until her death in 1995. Irwin served eight years in the New York State Legislature. He was well loved by all his family and friends and will be much missed. He is survived by his long-time partner and companion, Lois Ullman, his two sons, Steven and James, his daughters-in-law, Bonnie and Jennifer, his six grandchildren, Max, Douglas, Henri, Charlotte, Kyle and Sofia, and his great-grandson, Niko. Funeral service will be held at 9:45am in Great Neck at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel 55 North Station Plaza. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to The Neuropathy Association 60 E 42nd St, Suite 942, New York City, NY 10165.

Mr. Hellmann earned his bachelor's degree in civil engineering from Cooper Union in 1962 and master's degree in civil engineering from New York University in 1963. He was an environmental engineer in the private sector for 30 years. As a community advocate, he received the 2004 Van Zandt Award for community service. A picture caption with a listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions last Sunday gave an incorrect location, telephone number and hours for the exhibition of ''A Portrait of Michael Graves'' by Mel Leipzig, showing through June 30. The exhibition is at the Princeton location of Nicholas F. Rizzo Fine Arts at 8 South Tulane Street, not at the Chatham location at 32 Watchung Avenue. The phone number is (609) 430-0040 and the hours are Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.

HARRIS--Edward D.,Jr. Alpha Omega Alpha, the National Medical Honor Society, records with sorrow the death of our leader and Executive Secretary, Ted Harris. From 1997 until his death, Ted led the organization and its 120 chapters with unwavering dedication to excellence in medicine. As Editor of the Pharos, a journal published by AOA, he oversaw its transformation to a quarterly format dealing with all aspects of medicine. He also compiled an anthology called Creative Healers: A Collection of Essays, Reviews, and Poems from The Pharos, 1938-1998, published by AOA in 2004. Ted became Executive Secretary after a distinguished career in academic medicine. Educated at Dartmouth University and Harvard Medical School, Dr. Harris was a rheumatologist who was past President of the American College of Rheumatology and coauthored "Kelley's Textbook of Rheumatology," a standard in the field. He received the Presidential Gold Medal from the American College of Rheumatology in 2007. He was past Chairman of Medicine at Stanford University. At the time of his death, he was the George DeForest Barnett Professor Emeritus of Medicine. Past governor of the American College of Physicians' NJ and Northern California chapters, president of the California Academy of Medicine, he was named a fellow in the British Royal College of Physicians in 2002. Ted's intellect, wit and strong leadership are an enduring legacy.

SYDOR--Elizabeth. Beloved mother of six, grandma to four, devoted friend, artful musician, and esteemed teacher for decades, passed away peacefully May 20, 2010, her family at her side. She was 74. Born to Vincent and Elizabeth in Bayonne, NJ, she received a BA from Douglass and married Harry in '58. They moved to Metuchen, NJ, where she raised the kids and taught piano. In '69 she resumed studies, earning an MEd in piano performance (Rutgers) and an MA and doctorate in music theory and composition (Teachers College, Columbia). Until a few months ago she taught, accompanied dance classes, and was a freelance organist. Early on she created scores for dancers and taught at the university level; later she focused on choral composition. She refused to let her lung disease restrict her work, countless hobbies, and lay Franciscan and church activities. All will miss her abundant enthusiasm, emotive artistry, wide-ranging intellect, and determined spirit. A mass is planned at Sacred Heart Church, Bayhead, NJ, May 28 at 11am, and a music memorial in the summer. For more info: esydor@gmail.com.

NATHAN--Cyrus Harris (May 21, 1912-April 20, 2010). Well loved husband, father, stepfather, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend. Donations in his memory can be made to Chestnut Hill Academy, 500 West Willow Grove Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118.

All but the most squeamish should be fascinated by the exhibition ''That's Life! Vanities: From Caravaggio to Damien Hirst'' at Musee Maillol (61, rue de Grenelle; 33-1-42-22-59-58; www.museemaillol.com) through June 28. The terms vanities and memento mori have, for centuries, referred to art that represents death; the label is derived from the warning of life's fleeting nature in Ecclesiastes: ''Vanity of vanities, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.'' Skulls and skeletons make frequent appearances. The museum's art director, Patrizia Nitti, arranged the exhibition in reverse chronology, so contemporary pieces come first. For all the uproar about its extravagance, Damien Hirst's diamond-encrusted skull, ''For the Love of God,'' belongs to this tradition, and makes a sparkling appearance.

PROUNIS--Theodore O. Age 84. On May 22, 2010. Beloved husband of Lila Prounis. Father of Othon and Amelia. Grandfather of Alexa, Philip, Alexander and Karina. A native New Yorker, Mr. Prounis, a lawyer and management consultant, received B.S. and M.B.A degrees from Columbia University and a J.D. from Fordham Law School. He was President of the Board of Trustees of the Holy Trinity Cathedral from 1984-94, a founding Board Member of Columbia University's Program for Hellenic Studies, an Archon of the Holy Ecumenical Patriarchate and an officer of the Archdiocesan Council. He was a US Army Air Corps veteran of World War II and a cold war warrior in Washington, DC receiving various decorations. Mr. Prounis was also a son of the late Otto D. Prounis, owner of the posh Versailles nightclub in New York during the 1940s and 50s. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, May 31, 6pm-8pm. Funeral Services at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. 315 E. 74th, NY, NY 10021, Monday, June 1 at 2:30pm. Internment private. Memorial contributions in his memory may made be made to the Holy Trinity Cathedral (above) or to Columbia University, Program for Hellenic Studies, attn Gerry Visco, 1130 Amsterdam Avenue MC2861, 617 Hamilton Hall, NY, NY 10027.

A brief report in the Inside the List column last Sunday about ''Mom,'' a book of tributes to mothers that were recorded by StoryCorps, misstated that organization's relationship to NPR, the public radio network. StoryCorps is an independent nonprofit oral history project whose media partner is NPR; it is not ''NPR's StoryCorps project.''

'' The big takeaway is, don't mess with the privacy stuff for a long time.'' Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook. After an outcry from users over privacy settings, Facebook unveiled controls aimed at helping people better understand what they are sharing online, and with whom. Jim Breyer, a venture capitalist who has invested in some of the most successful technology businesses, after Apple became the world's most valuable tech company.

LONDON -- She was Britain's prima ballerina, an international idol of dance whose performances, with Rudolf Nureyev in particular, entranced and dazzled her audiences. But she was also a plotter alongside her Panamanian husband, seeking the support of Fidel Castro to overthrow the Panamanian government in 1959 in a conspiracy that one British official called ''highly reprehensible and irresponsible'' and another likened to a comic opera at sea aboard her yacht.

The culinary ''Taste of'' events, which take place annually, found a home in Amsterdam for the first time in 2009. This year, the Taste of Amsterdam festival, which runs from June 24 to 27, has stepped up its ambitions: enthusiasts can expect more participating restaurants and cooking schools, an organic market and an anticipated 25,000 visitors, 10,000 more than last year. The event takes place in Amstelpark, south of the city center, attracting food lovers for one of seven daytime or evening sessions. Entry costs 15 euros, or about $18 at $1.21 to the euro (tickets are sold online in advance), giving visitors access to a variety of food, wine, cocktail and coffee workshops, as well as samples from purveyors, including top Dutch names like Marqt, Jopen and Brood.

CHARLESTON, S.C. - "I'm no Charles Wadsworth," Geoff Nuttall said in an interview between concerts on Saturday. Mr. Nuttall, the first violinist of the St. Lawrence String Quartet, has just taken over Mr. Wadsworth's position as director of chamber music at the Spoleto Festival USA here. Mr. Wadsworth installed the series of chamber concerts when the festival itself was founded, in 1977, and gave them shape as combinations of performance and informal chatter about music (or whatever), in place of program notes. (The festival does not even announce what is being performed until just before each program is presented for the first time.)

But this city in western New York has a venerable new-music tradition that goes back at least to 1963, when the composer and conductor Lukas Foss took over the directorship of the Buffalo Philharmonic. A year later a Rockefeller Foundation grant helped establish the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, which lured other composers to the University of Buffalo before it folded in 1980, not least among them Morton Feldman.

It's Memorial Day. As we remember the heroes who laid down their lives for freedom, let us also spare a thought for a hero of the mind, who passed away some days ago at the age of 95. When I first encountered Martin Gardner's columns in "Scientific American" as a schoolboy many years ago, my reaction was one of awe. Here was pure intelligence incarnate, I thought, coming up with puzzles of mind-bending difficulty month after month and explaining the ideas behind them with crystal clarity. I was convinced that Martin Gardner was the smartest man in the world. The profusion of his writings, their quality and the sheer length of time that he kept on producing them, month after month, were just mind-boggling. When he retired from "Scientific American" in 1981, I was convinced that no one could fill his shoes. Although I much admired Douglas Hofstadter, who replaced him, and was a great fan of "GÃ¶del, Escher, Bach" I just knew that no one else could keep this up for as long as Martin Gardner had. And so it proved to be. It is a tribute to Martin Gardner's oeuvre that the final considered impression that he leftÂ  is not very different from the one seen through the eyes of a hero-worshiping adolescent.

A new museum for contemporary art and architecture opened in Rome on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. The more than $200 million National Museum of XXI Century Arts, or the Maxxi Museum as it is being called, was designed byZaha Hadid, who began work on the space 11 years ago with the intention of giving a more avant-garde image to a city steeped in Classical art and history. It was built in a residential neighborhood outside the historic city center and consists of white curving concrete walls, intricate black stairways and floor-to-ceiling windows. ''My work just really stems from the fact that we can make new juxtapositions with the old,'' Ms. Hadid, who in 2004 was the first woman to win the Pritzker Architecture Prize, told The Associated Press on Thursday. ''The idea of connecting between the old and new is very critical.'' One of the main inaugural exhibitions, ''Space,'' features works by Anish Kapoor, Sol LeWitt and Francesco Vezzoli, among others, blended with architectural installations. Other exhibitions include a retrospective of the Italian artist Gino De Dominicis, whose 80-foot-long plaster skeleton sculpture lies near the new building's main entrance.

Universal Studios in Los Angeles got its New York City back on Thursday when it reopened a back lot, above, that had been destroyed by a fire on June 1, 2008, The Associated Press reported. The lot, which had served as the shooting area for numerous films and television programs set in New York, including ''Seinfeld,'' underwent $200 million in renovations during the last two years. The four acres of shooting area now include new and improved sets depicting Central Park, Wall Street, part of the Broadway theater district, brownstones and a city courthouse square, as well as improved fire warning and prevention systems. The directorSteven Spielberg, who helped design the reconstruction, along with a team that included the Oscar-winning production designer Rick Carter ( ''Avatar'' ), thanked Los Angeles firefighters and police officers at the opening ceremony.

HOUSTON -- The Obama administration scrambled to respond on Sunday after the failure of the latest effort to kill the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico. But administration officials acknowledged the possibility that tens of thousands of gallons of oil might continue pouring out until August, when two relief wells are scheduled to be completed.

Ever notice how people typically warm up their short game before a round? They drop three balls on the putting green and putt for five minutes. Then they might hit four or five chip shots from just off the green, often practicing from the same spot. That's better than nothing - and a lot of golfers do nothing before a round - but it's not simulating the golf round that is about to begin and it's not how professional golfers warm up their short games. I have watched Phil Mickelson - pretty good short game, right? - warm up for tournaments dozens of times. His routine will vary a little but if possible he hits chips and putts in succession, not as separate parts of the warmup. In other words, Mickelson takes three balls and hits three chips, usually from different places, and then he putts those three balls. He then chips some more, and putts some more. He alternates short-game shots, just as he will have to during his round. If the practice area allows, and at pro tournaments it often does, Mickelson will even incorporate bunker shots into the routine.

The One Laptop Per Child project, which aims to give every child in the world a laptop, announced on Thursday that it was entering a partnership with Marvell, a computer chip and silicon manufacturer. They agreed to work together to develop a new family of tablet computers for the project. The computers will be based on Moby, an existing platform built by Marvell. The partnership hopes to allow Marvell to sell inexpensive tablet computers for education and health care in the United States while helping to reduce the cost of the project's computers for developing countries.

On a hot afternoon in 1994, Roberto Baggio stood unmoving on the Rose Bowl grass, a solitary figure on whom more than 94,000 pairs of eyes were trained. Baggio had carried Italy to that point -- a penalty-kick shootout to settle 120 scoreless minutes in the World Cup final against Brazil -- by supplying the deciding goal in three consecutive knockout-round games. Months earlier, he had been named the world's best player. But this moment would shape his legacy: as the 10th and final shooter, Baggio needed to score to make it 3-3 and keep Italy alive.

The N.B.A. Finals have historically outdrawn the Stanley Cup Finals on television. This year, Kobe Bryant, above left, led the Los Angeles Lakers into the N.B.A. Finals against the Boston Celtics. Dustin Byfuglien scored the winning goal May 23 to propel the Chicago Blackhawks into the Stanley Cup Finals against the Philadelphia Flyers. The Lakers have 15 titles and the Celtics 17, but the 2010 hockey finals promise more history. The Flyers have not won the Stanley Cup since 1975, and Chicago has a drought of 49 seasons. Going into Monday's game, the Blackhawks lead the series, 1-0. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Apple has again changed its mind. Earlier this week, it rejected the iPhone app of a Republican opponent to Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, a Democrat, saying it was a personal attack on Mr. Waxman. But on Tuesday, Apple reversed itself and approved the app.

MEMPHIS -- For two decades, Tyrone Banks was one of many African-Americans who saw his economic prospects brightening in this Mississippi River city. A single father, he worked for FedEx and also as a custodian, built a handsome brick home, had a retirement account and put his eldest daughter through college.

A warehouse fire that wiped out the entire stock of tens of thousands of costumes and props as well as scenery and archives belonging to the Musical Theater Southwest in Albuquerque has been ruled arson, according to the Albuquerque Fire Department, which declined to provide further information this weekend. The blaze on Tuesday, above, gutted the company's 8,500-square-foot warehouse, rehearsal space and offices, where it kept items used for its shows and rented to other companies. The theater still expects its next production, ''Thoroughly Modern Millie,'' to begin on July 16. The television and theater actorNeil Patrick Harris, a New Mexico native who performed with the company in his youth, said that he hoped to help raise money for the nonprofit Musical Theater Southwest so it can replenish what it lost. A board member, Rick Huff, said he planned to approach several other alumni, like the film director Penny Marshall and the actors Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Patti Cohenour, to help raise funds to replace what was lost, valued at hundreds of thousands of dollars. Mr. Huff said donations of money, props and costumes had been arriving since the fire. ''We already have a new warehouse a few blocks away from the burned-out shell of the old one,'' he said. DAVID BELCHER

Mass of Christian Burial 11am at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

You can already buy designer clothes, spa treatments and vacations on private, limited-time sale Web sites. Now you can make restaurant reservations, too. The latest start-up to join the trend is VillageVines, which opened its Web site to the public on Wednesday. It is a members-only site (though anyone can become a member) that offers reservations at trendy, high-end restaurants with discounts, starting in New York.

With the American Jobs and Closing Tax Loopholes Act, House Democratic leaders opened themselves up to both ends of Republicans' familiar ''tax and spend'' barbs. The bill, passed last week, would raise taxes on Wall Street executives and multinational corporations. And it would spend more than $100 billion in the name of creating jobs and extending federal benefits for the jobless.

The first thought that popped into David Huff's mind as he lay facedown and motionless on the Yankee Stadium mound Saturday was to ask the training staff to call his brother, Tim. Huff recited the cellphone number, then stopped to correct himself. ''I didn't say the area code,'' Huff said. ''I was like, the area code is 714.''

LANDES--Irwin J.,died on May 27, 2010 in Tequesta, Fl. at the age of 84. He graduated from Lincoln High School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School and served as an infantryman in World War II in Italy. He married Alice Zigelbaum in 1944 and they lived in Great Neck until her death in 1995. He served as counsel to the Atomic Energy Commission following his graduation. He was elected to the New York State Legislature in 1970 where he remained until 1978. During his eight years in the Assembly, he was Chairman of the Higher Education and the Corporations, Commissions and Authorities Committees. He became counsel to the New York State Commission on the Real Property Tax and Secretary to the New York State Assembly Steering Committee. From 1985 to 1994, he was a partner at the law firm of Bower and Gardner in New York City. He was well loved by all his family and friends and will be much missed. He is survived by his long-time partner and companion, Lois Ullman, his two sons, Steven and James, his daughters-in-law, Bonnie and Jennifer, his six grandchildren, Max, Douglas, Henri, Charlotte, Kyle and Sofia; his great-grandson, Niko, his brother and sister-in law, David and Sonia; and his brother-in-law and sister-in-law, Marcia and Leonard Zigelbaum. Services will be held at 9:45am Tuesday, June 1st in Great Neck at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to the Neuropathy Association, 60 E. 42 St., Suite 942, New York, N.Y. 10165.

The strangest business cards I ever saw used to be in circulation at the Paris Blues Bar & Lounge, a drinking establishment at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 121st Street in Harlem. Printed in vivid royal blue, they listed not only the proprietor's name - Samuel J. Hargress, Jr. - but the names of every member of his staff. There, in black against the background, was Sue Kelly, the day manager; a certain Mr. Wilson, the night manager; John Henry, the Disco #1 Man; and, of course, the evening's hosts: Gilda, Peanut, Yvonne, Dot and Flo.

SIRULNICK--Joseph, on May 27th at the age of 91. In memory of our father, who took pride in his son, Sandy and two daughters, Phyllis and Carole, daughter-in-law Jill, grandchildren Aaron, Erik, Johnny, Ross, Josh, Sarah, and their spouses Joanna, Kaori, Amy and his great-grandchildren Hannah, Sarah, Ira, Noah, Sydney, Olivia, Jordan, Kate. Dad, we will miss you dearly and remember you always. Joe touched the lives of all who surrounded him through his love of art, tennis and charity. Graveside funeral at New Montefiore Cemetery Tuesday 10:30am. Memorial contributions can be made to United Jewish Appeal.

A picture credit on Friday with an article about a coalition of music groups that is boycotting performances in Arizona because of the state's new anti-immigration law misidentified the photographer. The picture of Zack de la Rocha, the lead singer of the rap metal band Rage Against the Machine, who is leading the boycott, was taken by Ethan Miller/Getty Images, not by Mark Higashino/IFC Films.

In these hard economic times, when much of the country could use a walk in the woods or a night in the mountains or a wade in the river or a picnic by the lake, states across the country seem to be creating obstacles to the great outdoors. Seeking to streamline their budgets, states have made their parks easy targets. Campgrounds are closing, fees are increasing, employees have been laid off.

PROUNIS--Theodore O. To our beloved mentor, colleague and friend, our hearts are heavy over the loss of Theodore O. Prounis, who was a guiding light in our lives. We will never forget him nor be the same without him. May his memory be eternal. Law Offices of Barbara H. Katsos, P.C.

The blessings of war are few, but one hard- won result of the nation's conflicts is expertise in accounting for the dead. The Revolutionary War, the War of 1812 and the Mexican War together claimed some 58,000 lives, on and off the battlefield. But lax records and hasty on-site burials meant the number of unknown fatalities from those formative American wars remains a mystery. Record-keeping improved with the Civil War, still the nation's deadliest conflict. But because the conflict involved millions of men, shifting fronts and hurried burials, the percentage of soldiers who went to their graves without names is astounding: more than two in five were never identified.
So you think you can dance? Not unless Robyn Astaire signs off -- at least, if you are doing a toe-tap with the name or likeness of Fred Astaire.

Four tapestries designed by Raphael for the Sistine Chapel nearly 500 years ago will be on display at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London this fall, BBC News reported. The exhibition will coincide with the expected visit to Britain of Pope Benedict XVI. For six weeks, beginning Sept. 8, the tapestries will be hung next to their original, full-size designs, known as the Raphael Cartoons, which have been on view at the museum since 1865. Only 4 of the original series of 10 tapestries have survived. The tapestries were commissioned by Pope Leo X and woven in Brussels. They are owned by the Vatican Museums.

Beloved wife of the late Harold Wolf, loving Mom of Marjorie and Walter Groden, Richard and Judy Wolf; devoted Gramma to Elisabeth and Christopher Schmitz and Neil Groden; proud Great-Gramma (GG) to Eric, Ryan and Rebecca Schmitz. Helen died at her home in Rockville Centre, Long Island. She spent most of her 100 years living in Far Rockaway and Lawrence, New York. Graveside burial at Welwood Cemetery on June 1. Shiva at the home of Marjorie and Walter Groden.

PHOENIX -- In the mystical, everything-Zen universe of Phil Jackson, happenstance and happy endings are a way of life. Not long after winning the championship last summer, Jackson, the Los Angeles Lakers coach, visited his daughter's apartment complex. There, improbably, he bumped into Paul Pierce, the Boston Celtics star.

An article last Monday about the Chicago Blackhawks' series-clinching 4-2 victory over the San Jose Sharks on Sunday, May 23, in the N.H.L. Western Conference finals described incorrectly Dustin Byfuglien's third-period goal, which broke a 2-2 tie. He scored from in front of the net, not from the high slot. And the goal went through goalie Evgeni Nabokov's legs; it did not sail over his right shoulder.

Columbia University Press announced plans to publish ''Fate, Time and Language: An Essay on Free Will,'' an adaptation of David Foster Wallace's undergraduate thesis in philosophy, which was titled ''Richard Taylor's 'Fatalism' and the Semantics of Physical Modality.'' The book is scheduled to be published in January, and will be edited by Steven M. Cahn and Maureen Eckert. A companion Web site, davidfosterwallace-fate-time-language.net, established by Ms. Eckert, will feature interviews with philosophers and fans. The publisher Little, Brown announced last year that it would release Wallace's last novel, an unfinished manuscript titled ''The Pale King,'' in April 2011. Wallace, above, committed suicide in 2008.

The actor James McAvoy, below, will play the young Charles Xavier in the next installment of the mutant-loving (or hating, depending on whose side you're on) X-Men franchise, Variety reported. ''X-Men: First Class'' will finally reveal the juicy details behind the fallout between Professor X and Erik Lensherr, a k a Magneto, in a story conceived by Bryan Singer, who directed the first two X-Men films. The movie is to begin production this summer and be released in June 2011. ... Lena Meyer-Landrut, below, a German teenager, won the 2010 Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday night, beating finalists from Turkey and Romania with the song ''Satellite,'' The Associated Press reported. This year's contest was held in Oslo. Owing to financial strains on the European economy, many countries, including the Czech Republic, Montenegro, Andorra and Hungary, pulled out of the song festival, which is famous for its elaborate costumes and sets. The contest is organized by the European Broadcasting Union, and first aired in 1956.

The bill, passed last week, would raise taxes on Wall Street executives and multinational corporations. And it would spend more than $100 billion in the name of creating jobs and extending federal benefits for the jobless.

It is a subject that has come up before, but it appears the most dangerous thing you can do on the golf course has something to do with a golf cart. The number of injuries sustained by people riding in a cart, driving a cart or being struck by a cart - all while trying to relax on a golf course - is nothing short of astonishing. About two weeks ago, Matt McChesney, a reserve offensive lineman for the Denver Broncos, stepped out of his golf cart just as another cart zoomed past him and struck him in the ankle. It was the same ankle McChesney had surgically repaired in the 2009 preseason. The golf cart injury was severe, according to The Denver Post, and while the Broncos want the 28-year-old McChensey to rehabilitate his ankle, he seems resigned to another fate: retirement from pro football.

We extend our condolences to his beloved wife and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

A music review on Wednesday about the first classical music concert at the new Jerome Robbins Theater at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, which featured members of the Orchestra of St. Luke's, misstated the orchestra's relationship with the arts center. They are co-owners of the building at 450 West 37th Street that houses the center; the orchestra is not a co-owner of the arts center.

Pflaumer, a street-smart Philadelphia beer baron who turned the 116-year-old Christian Schmidt and Sons Inc. brewery into one of the nation's largest, only to see it close after he was sent to federal prison for tax evasion, died on May 22 in Philadelphia. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral services Tuesday 10am at Frank E. Campbell.

BENJAMIN--Jane S.,72, of Roseland, NJ, died Sunday, May 30, 2010 at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. A memorial service will take place at 2:00pm, on Tuesday, June 1, 2010 at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston (800)938-6372. Jane was born in Newark, New Jersey in 1937. She lived South Orange and Maplewood before moving to Roseland many years ago. She had the uncanny ability to connect with the many people that she came in contact with during her lifetime. She was considered a "best friend" by so many. There will be a void in so many lives without her friendship. She attended Simmons College and graduated fro Upsala College. She worked for The New Jersey Law Journal/Lawyers Diary for many years. She retired in 2000. During her lifetime she was an active member of the community. Jane was a lifetime Board Member of Women's Philanthropy of the United Jewish Communities of Metro West. She served in many different positions of the Women's Division UJA campaign. She was a winner of The Julius and Bessie Cohn Young Leadership Award. Jane was a member of the Board of Jespy House. She was a longtime member of Mountain Ridge Country Club where she served on the Board of Governors. Jane will be especially missed by her long time companion, Frank Goodman. For over thirty years they were travel partners enjoying worldwide adventure that included all seven continents. Their favorite city to visit was Paris. When not traveling, Jane and Frank enjoyed the arts, theatre, opera and every museum they could find. They enjoyed tennis, golf, friends and family. Grandmother and dear friend, Jane will be missed by the entire extended Goodman family. Jane is survived by her devoted and caring children Peter Benjamin and Dr. Kate Callahan of Coconut Grove, Florida and James and Jeanne Benjamin of Atlanta, Georgia. She was the cherished grandmother of Jake and Samantha Benjamin and Peter's son, Jason. She was formerly married to the late Donald Benjamin. The family has established the Jane S. Benjamin Scholarship for continuing education for hospital and hospice caregivers at Saint Barnabas Medical Center. In lieu of flowers, please send donations payable to The Saint Barnabas Medical Center Foundation c/o Peter and Kate Benjamin, 2111 Tigertail Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 33133.

An article last Monday about why the Islanders teams that won four consecutive Stanley Cups in the early 1980s are largely forgotten in debates about the greatest N.H.L. teams referred incorrectly to Game 6 of the 1980 Stanley Cup finals in which Bob Nystrom scored a goal in overtime. As a reader remembered, and pointed out in an e-mail message, the game was on a warm afternoon 30 years ago in Uniondale, N.Y. -- not on a warm night.

ZALUSKY--Ralph, M.D.,78, of Roslyn, New York, died peacefully on May 28, 2010 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan, where he had retired as chief of Hematology/Oncology after spending nearly 40 years there in dedicated and distinguished service as a physician and professor of medicine. Beloved husband of Marian (Shayon) for 51 years, Dr. Zalusky was the son of the late Elly and Minnie (Goldstein) Zalusky. He leaves behind three children, Jeff Zalusky (Katy Wheaton) of Germantown, MD, Beth Finkelstein (Stuart) of Chappaqua, NY, and Emily Weinfeld (Stuart) of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, and nine grandchildren. Born in Pawtucket Rhode Island in 1931, he was the brother of Dorothy Rodriguez and Rachel Biven, and the late Sarah Zalusky, Bella Massotti, Isaac Zale, Abraham Zale and Joe Zalusky. His early academic success led to an undergraduate degree at Brown University and the decision to pursue his two lifelong passions: medicine and teaching. He received his M.D. at the Boston University School of Medicine in 1957, and did his internship and residency at Duke University Hospital in Durham, NC, where he met and married Marian Shayon. He then returned to Boston to complete a fellowship at Boston City Hospital (Harvard University) in 1961. Subsequently, he had the privilege of working in William Castle's Thorndike Laboratory, also in Boston, where he studied pernicious anemia among many colleagues who would become deans of American investigative medicine. Fulfilling his service to the nation as a captain in the U.S. Air Force, he joined Stanley Schultz in fall of 1962 at the Department of Bionucleonics of the School of Aerospace Medicine in San Antonio (brooks AFB), and coauthored a seminal work on the physiology of membrane ion transport in 1964. Dr. Zalusky moved to New York in 1965, where he served on the staff at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens before joining the Department of Hematology at Mt. Sinai Hospital and then the Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, where he specialized in the treatment of aplastic anemia, leukemia and lymphoma. Throughout his illustrious career, he was recognized and respected as an educator, at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and most recently, from 1994 until his retirement in 2009, as Associate Chairman of Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine (Yeshiva University, Bronx, NY). He also coauthored over fifty publications in numerous medical journals. Starting this fall, an annual lecture series in his honor will be presented at the Beth Israel hospital. He will be missed by his family, his many friends, and his countless students and colleagues worldwide. By request of the family, in lieu of flowers or other gifts, please consider a donation to Doctors Without Borders, an organization strongly supported by Dr. Zalusky.

The most distinctive book about Tiger Woods this spring has nothing to do with his recent life and everything to do with the college golf season of 1994-95. So ''The Last Putt: Two Teams, One Dream, and a Freshman Named Tiger'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt) is not a book written with an eye on Woods's recent tribulations. Still, Woods the teenager and collegian comes alive in new ways, teamed with Notah Begay and Casey Martin in Stanford's face-off at the 1995 N.C.A.A. championship against golf powerhouse Oklahoma State. This is a stroke-by-stroke tale by authors Neil Hayes and Brian Murphy with many subplots, on and off the golf course. The championship comes down to a sudden-death playoff, and so, you have to ask yourself: Who would you want standing over the last putt? This is also the time of the year when people buying golf books are thinking of Father's Day, which may not immediately bring to mind golf blogger Patricia Hannigan's book ''Golf Girl's Little Tartan Book: How to Be True to Your Sex and Get the Most From Your Game'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang). Then again, it may be the ultimate Father's Day gift if you know a father who has a woman in his life that he wished played more golf. In her entertaining blog, Hannigan often writes about ''girls golf'' as opposed to ''boys club'' golf, and among the chief recommendations of her book is that women ''play golf like girls.'' The book has a lot of attitude, and that's the point, but it has keen observations, too, like an explanation as to why golf rules matter and the importance of playing from the correct tees. But this is no tutorial; it's much more fun than that.

This week's review is of ABC Kitchen, one of the roughly 6,000 restaurants that Jean-Georges Vongerichten appears to have opened on Earth and other planets in the last year. This one is an aggressively green establishment, with a position paper on the back of the menu that declares its allegiance to local farmers and sustainability and such. It draws a chic crowd of fashionable movers and shakers: the photographer Patrick DeMarchelier and his family, say, alongside another table with the actor and showman Hugh Jackman at its head. There are magazine bosses, fashion-world doyennes. It's a fun place for a summer dinner. You'll want to wear linen, highlights in the hair, a sun-kissed demeanor.
