Bowing to concerns over his appointment but fiercely defending his record, Robert M. Morgenthau stepped down on Tuesday from his role overseeing the city's efforts to increase the number of minority firefighters in response to a long running discrimination lawsuit.

The resurrection of the Pink Tea Cup in Greenwich Village, which closed in January, will soon open nearby and on a much grander scale than the venerable soul food restaurant. The new owner, Lawrence Page, has given it a polished setting with more than 100 seats, a full bar, a lounge, a cabaret and also a 600-seat catering hall. It came about fortuitously. Mr. Page, who owned the Actors Playhouse on Seventh Avenue South, had already rented the space to open a wine bar, but when the Pink Tea Cup closed he decided it had to be saved. So he moved it over to the space he already had and what had been the Actors Playhouse. The classic soul food menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner has also been expanded, with dishes like rack of lamb with lobster mashed potatoes, as well as some lighter dishes. Mr. Page has Glander Glover, who had been a chef at the original restaurant for 15 years, back in the kitchen, along with the executive chef, Angela Groover. "I want an all-female kitchen," Mr. Page said. It opens June 7.

Robin Soderling stunned the defending French Open champion, Roger Federer, in four bone-crushing sets, avenging last year's straight-sets thrashing by Federer and ending Federer's streak of 23 appearances in a Grand Slam semifinal at 23. Passengers who are bumped off an oversold flight may get more money from airlines, according to the Associated Press. Federal officials are expected to announce a plan this week to raise the maximum amount, $400 or $800 depending on how long a trip is delayed, the A.P. reported. With wedding season beginning, A. O. Scott looks back at the director Mira Nair's 2001 film "Monsoon Wedding." The movie chronicles a Punjabi family who come together in Delhi to celebrate a marriage. Mr. Scott calls the film "an especially vibrant and satisfying example of a wedding movie," a genre that often combines melodrama and farce with equal measure. Mr. Scott finds much here to admire, saying that "Mira Nair draws together an unruly tangle of plots and subplots, and handles them with clarity and grace." Have you seen "Monsoon Wedding?" CHARLESTON, S.C. -- News broke out on Monday at the Spoleto Festival USA here after a placid opening weekend. Emmanuel Villaume, the French conductor who has been the festival's music director for opera and orchestra since 2001, announced that he would leave at the end of the season. Mr. Villaume, who is also artistic director and principal conductor of the Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra and principal conductor of the Slovak Philharmonic Orchestra, cited time pressure as a major factor in his decision.

BUFFALO -- In the 25 years he has directed the new-music festival June in Buffalo, the composer David Felder has streamlined certain aspects of the program. This festival has always been as much about training young composers as about performances of music by their established elders, and it is unlikely to grow beyond its single-week format. "It's very intensive over one week," Mr. Felder said during an interview between sessions on Monday, "and what we'd like is for people to leave exhausted, and thrilled with what they got, and not ready to complain too much."

Simpson Wong, the owner and executive chef of Cafe Asean in Greenwich Village, grew up in Tanjung Malim, Malaysia, a small town of 70 houses, where the local school did not serve lunch. DAVIS--Paul VanDien, of New York City died May 16, 2010. Born in Newport News, Virginia on July 12, 1943, he earned a degree from the University of Virginia's School of Architecture in 1966 and began his career in Washington, DC. His legacy of more than forty years in real estate includes the redevelopment of the Boston Naval Shipyard and Manhattan's West Side rail yards--Riverside South (also known as Trump Place). Most recently, he served as Senior Vice President of Residential Development at Midwood Investment and Development. A true gentleman who held himself to an exacting standard, he was a generous mentor and colleague. In addition to being passionate about his professional work, he also enjoyed time on the golf course and in his kitchen, where he nourished his family with his love of cooking. He was a devoted husband and father who found great joy in his new role as a grandfather. He is survived by his wife Sally (Hyland), two brothers, two daughters Ashleigh Donovan and Julia Davis, and three granddaughters. He was beloved by his family and many friends and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Thursday, June 3rd at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the SPCA of Westchester, New York.

A picture caption on May 8 with the Patient Money column, about handling the expense of acupuncture treatments, misspelled the surname of a student of the Pacific College of Oriental Medicine in Manhattan. She is Holly Crafts Colasanti, not Crafts-Calasanti.

KING--Lisbeth McRea Kephart. On May 29, 2010 at age 84. Mother of Justin Andrew Burns King, she died peacefully near her son in Nashua, NH. A former personnel executive at J. Walter Thompson, she and her late husband Herbert owned King R.E. in Wilton, CT for 38 years. Sister. POW. Bon Vivant. Wife. Mother. Passionate enthusiast. Beautiful friend.

For the last month, Americans have watched with growing horror as a huge leak on a BP oil rig has poured millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. As I wrote on Sunday in the Week in Review section of The Times, there is also shock that technology has so far not been able to control it. But it is important to remember that this mammoth polluting event, so extraordinary here, is not so unusual in some parts of the world. In an article published Sunday in The Guardian of London, John Vidal, the paper's environment editor, movingly recalls a trip to the Niger Delta a few years ago, where he literally swam in ''pools of light Nigerian crude.''

Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about Transocean, the owner of the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April, misstated, in some editions, the year that Steven L. Newman became the company's chief executive. It was March 2010, not March 2009.

An article on Thursday about the popularity of BP's online video feed of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico misspelled the given name of a spokesman for Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who had pushed BP to make all its seabed camera angles available. Mr. Markey's spokesman, who said more than one million people had viewed the video on a House Web site, is Eben Burnham-Snyder, not Eban.

ROSS--Agnes O'Neill, 97, died in her sleep Monday, May 31, at her home in Spring Lake, NJ, to which she had retired after teaching third graders for more than 40 years at Horace Mann School in North Bergen, NJ. She was predeceased by her sister, Mary O'Neill Heitzman, by her son, James O'Neill Ross, and by her husband, Wilbur L. Ross, a lawyer who served as a Judge and was elected Commissioner of Revenue and Finance in North Bergen, where Mrs. Ross had been elected as a Democratic County Committee Woman for 45 years. She had been Valedictorian in the Class of 1930 at Sacred Heart Academy in Hoboken and was a graduate of Jersey City State Teachers College. She is survived by her son, Wilbur L. Ross, Jr., Palm Beach, FL, a prominent private equity investor, by her daughter, Karen Ross Tanzola, Spring Lake, by seven grandchildren, Jessica Ross Brown, Johannesburg, South Africa, Amanda Ross, Sag Harbor, NY, U.S. Marine Colonel Robert Tanzola III, Cedar Point, North Carolina, William Ross Tanzola, Vancouver, British Columbia, Jeffrey Ryan Tanzola, Mickleton, NJ, and by seven great-grandchildren, Alexander Ross Farris, Robert Tanzola, IV, Rachel Lauren Tanzola, Michael Kevin Tanzola, Nicholas Kyle Tanzola, John Christopher Tanzola, Luke Anthony Tanzola and Kirsty Colby Brown. The wake will be held at the O'Brien Funeral Home 2028 Highway 35, Wall, NJ from 2 until 4 and 7 until 9pm on Sunday, June 7 and the funeral services Monday, June 8 at St, Catharine Church, 215 Essex Ave, Spring Lake, at 11am. Contributions suggested to Visiting Nurses Association of Central Jersey.

Kaufman. Survived by her children, Sara Lapuk (Marvin) of Avon, CT, Daniel Wise Kaufman (Susan) of White Plains, NY; four grandchildren; and a great-grandson. Joan was an alumna of Smith College, class of 1937.

DAVIDOWITZ--Jacob Ph.D.,May 28. Beloved husband of Sara, father of Paul, Eliot, Adina, Rebecca, and grandfather of 13. Professor and research scientist, ophthalmology, NYU for 35 years. Ardent lover of Judaism and Israel. Yehi Zichro Baruch.

TULMAN--Dr. Anna T.,who died peacefully on May 30, 2010 at the age of 96, is mourned by her family and the many people she touched. Anna led an extraordinary life. In addition to her private practice, she served as a staff physician for numerous embassies in the 1940's and 1950's, Director of Planned Parenthood in Washington, D.C. during the 1940's and 1950's, Board Member of Planned Parenthood in New York from the 1950's to 1970's, professor and Director of Family Planning Activities at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Jacobi and Lincoln Hospitals in the 1960's and 1970's. As the Chairperson of the Washington, D.C. Chapter of Physicians Forum in the 1940's and 1950's, she was a passionate advocate of women's reproductive health, abortion rights, National Health Insurance and the delivery of adequate health care to all communities. Anna was committed to, and worked tirelessly for social justice and was a lifelong supporter of countless progressive causes. She is survived by and will be greatly missed by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and their families, Steven and Marlyse, Naomi and David, Deborah, Sascha, and Kalpana, Travis, Cody, Krish and Anand, by her brother Sam and sisters-in-law Adele and Jeanne, and by her nephews, niece and numerous cousins, all of whom loved her deeply. The love of her life, her wonderful husband Harry I. Rand, died in 2005. A memorial in her honor will be held on Saturday, June 12 at 3pm at her apartment, 320 West 86 Street, Manhattan.

ZALUSKY--Ralph, M.D.,78, of Roslyn, New York, died peacefully on May 28, 2010 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan, where he had retired as chief of Hematology/Oncology after spending nearly 40 years there in dedicated and distinguished service as a physician and professor of medicine. Beloved husband of Marian (Shayon) for 51 years, Dr. Zalusky was the son of the late Elly and Minnie (Goldstein) Zalusky. He leaves behind three children, Jeff Zalusky (Katy Wheaton) of Germantown, MD, Beth Finkelstein (Stuart) of Chappaqua, NY, and Emily Weinfeld (Stuart) of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, and nine grandchildren. Born in Pawtucket Rhode Island in 1931, he was the brother of Dorothy Rodriguez and Rachel Biven, and the late Sarah Zalusky, Bella Massotti, Isaac Zale, Abraham Zale and Joe Zalusky. His early academic success led to an undergraduate degree at Brown University and the decision to pursue his two lifelong passions: medicine and teaching. He received his M.D. at the Boston University School of Medicine in 1957, and did his internship and residency at Duke University Hospital in Durham, NC, where he met and married Marian Shayon. He then returned to Boston to complete a fellowship at Boston City Hospital (Harvard University) in 1961. Subsequently, he had the privilege of working in William Castle's Thorndike Laboratory, also in Boston, where he studied pernicious anemia among many colleagues who would become deans of American investigative medicine. Fulfilling his service to the nation as a captain in the U.S. Air Force, he joined Stanley Schultz in fall of 1962 at the Department of Bionucleonics of the School of Aerospace Medicine in San Antonio (brooks AFB), and coauthored a seminal work on the physiology of membrane ion transport in 1964. Dr. Zalusky moved to New York in 1965, where he served on the staff at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens before joining the Department of Hematology at Mt. Sinai Hospital and then the Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, where he specialized in the treatment of aplastic anemia, leukemia and lymphoma. Throughout his illustrious career, he was recognized and respected as an educator, at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and most recently, from 1994 until his retirement in 2009, as Associate Chairman of Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine (Yeshiva University, Bronx, NY). He also coauthored over fifty publications in numerous medical journals. Starting this fall, an annual lecture series in his honor will be presented at the Beth Israel hospital. He will be missed by his family, his many friends, and his countless students and colleagues worldwide. By request of the family, in lieu of flowers or other gifts, please consider a donation to Doctors Without Borders, an organization strongly supported by Dr. Zalusky.

STUART--Patricia Quinn, 71, passed away on May 30, 2010. Theatrical costume designer, whose Broadway credits include, "The Cuban Thing" 1968, "A Cry of Players" 1968-69, "The Me Nobody Knows" 1970-71, "The Lincoln Mask" 1972, and "Lost in the Stars" 1972. Assistant to costume designer Patricia Zipprodt for productions of "The Little Foxes" 1967-68, and "Plaza Suite" 1968-70. Graduate of Antioch College in Ohio, 1960, and taught costume design and history of fashion at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 1981-2006. Patricia leaves behind her husband, Harvey Stuart, brother, Dennis Quinn of Oak Ridge, NJ, sister-in-law, Fredda Stuart of Glen Head, NY, nephew Peter Stuart of Los Angeles, CA, and niece Jennifer Stuart Wong of New York City. Contributions in Patricia's memory can be made to The Heidi Paoli Foundation, c/o Dennis Paoli 505 West End Ave, Apt 15A, New York, NY.

SPANIER--Helen. A native of South Carolina, Helen Spanier moved to New York City immediately after graduating from the University of North Carolina, Greensboro. Helen was the beloved wife of Maury L. Spanier for 70 years. She passed away peacefully at the age of 95 on May 26th. In addition to being survived by her husband, she is survived by two loving sons and daughters-in-law, David and his wife Sheryl of New York City and Jon and his wife Jennifer of South Salem; grand children Eli and his wife Kate from Boulder, CO and Ian and his spouse Carrie of Long Beach, NY, Benjamin and Abigail Spanier of South Salem; and great-grandchildren Jake, Gwen and Cade Spanier. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the NY Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY 10458 www.nybg.org.

The creative team for ''The Hobbit,'' the long-awaited live-action film adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien's novel about the diminutive fantasy hero Bilbo Baggins, has shrunk. Over the weekend the filmmaker Guillermo del Toro said he was departing the project as its director, amid uncertainty about a start date for shooting and the future of the studio releasing it. In a statement posted Sunday on the Tolkien fan Web site TheOneRing.net, Mr. del Toro, whose films include ''Pan's Labyrinth'' and the ''Hellboy'' movies, said: ''In light of ongoing delays in the setting of a start date for filming 'The Hobbit,' I am faced with the hardest decision of my life. After nearly two years of living, breathing and designing a world as rich as Tolkien's Middle Earth, I must, with great regret, take leave from helming these wonderful pictures.''

Adored wife of the late Albert, dear mother of Dr. Donald (Jo Ann), Milwaukee, and Dr. Steven (Maggie), Great Neck, sister of Charles (Betty) Weissman, beloved and indulging Nana of Joe and Sam. Church at 9:45am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

RAUCHER--Hon. Morris B.,97, beloved husband of Maizie Glaser and of the late Molly Raucher. Cherished father of the late David Neil Raucher and Shelly Goodman. Father-in-law of Susan Raucher Levinson and Michael S. Goodman. Step-father to Michael, Edward, and Lawrence Glaser. Adored grandfather of Nicole Raucher Finkel and her husband Dr. Steven Finkel, Jessica and Leah Goodman. Step-grandfather to Rebecca, Daniel, Josh and Ben Glaser. Great-grandfather of Shayna and David Finkel. Graduate of CCNY, Brooklyn Law School Class of '43, CPA degree. One of the founding members of the American Association of Attorneys-Certified Public Accountants. The Judge served under Abe Beame in the office of the Comptroller and, through Jackson Democratic Club secured the nomination and position of Judge of New York State Supreme Court-Civil Division, Bronx County. He served with distinction and was tapped by Harrison Golden as second Deputy Comptroller of the City of New York in charge of all financial aspects of litigation. After his service he was recalled by the Hon. Stanley Ostrau, Assignment Judge of New York Supreme Court, as a Judicial Hearing Officer where he served until his retirement at age 85. He was a loving, caring peaceful man who had a passion in the law and pursued justice in and out of the courtroom. He will be missed by all who knew him. Shiva will be observed at the home of Shelly and Michael Goodman, Demarest, NJ. Please consider a donation to the Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research Fund.

The actress Elaine Stritch said on Friday afternoon that she was talking to the producers of the Broadway revival of ''A Little Night Music'' about succeeding Angela Lansbury this summer in the role of Madame Armfeldt, but cautioned that no deal was in place and she was not sure if she would ultimately play the role. ''Committing to eight shows a week would be a big thing for me, so it's something that I have to carefully consider,'' said Ms. Stritch, the Tony and Emmy Award-winning actress (''Company,'' ''A Delicate Balance''), who is 84.

An article last Tuesday about a generational divide among Colombians in Queens over the upcoming presidential elections in Colombia drew an erroneous comparison between the Colombian city of MedellÃ­n, made infamous by the violent drug cartel, and Washington, D.C., known for its high murder rates through the years. BALTIMORE -- In a quirky effort to spin the positive, the N.C.A.A. refers to overtime games in its lacrosse tournaments as ''sudden victory'' rather than ''sudden death.'' After Duke and Notre Dame slogged through 60 sweaty minutes on a field where temperatures reached 120 degrees Monday, Duke's victory in the N.C.A.A. men's lacrosse championship epitomized that jargon.

A capsule summary on May 13 about an art review of statues from a medieval duke's tomb that were on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art referred incorrectly to the duke, John the Fearless of Burgundy. During the duke's lifetime (1371-1419), Burgundy was not part of France and thus he was not a French nobleman.

Alexander Carno passes too much time staring out the window of the tidy bedroom he shares with his grandfather, relying on binoculars to take him down 19 flights to the Harlem street below. Sometimes, being a 17-year-old boy, he notices a girl, or watches his old friends, hanging out and laughing. Sometimes, he stares at the corner where he was shot last December, remembering the moment when he realized, as bullet met bone, that his legs no longer did as they were told. ''I tried to run,'' he said recently. ''But nothing's faster than a bullet.'' With dizzying speed, the pace of his life slowed to a crawl. It now takes patience no teenager has to move to the door with a walker, to wait for a visit from a friend, to wait for someone to call someone who could arrange for the right paperwork.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- The Afghan government suspended the operations of two church-based relief groups on Monday over suspicions that they were involved in converting Afghans to Christianity, even though the evidence against them apparently consisted of nothing more than a listing in a telephone directory. An Afghan television station, Noorin TV, broadcast photographs that it claimed showed Westerners' baptizing Afghans, both men and women, and other Afghans' praying to Jesus at private prayer meetings. It mentioned the two groups in the same report, although it had no evidence tying them to such activities, officials at Noorin TV confirmed.

PARIS -- Are European tea drinking habits, refined over hundreds of years, ripe for change? NestlÃ©, the Swiss food and beverage giant, thinks so. The company plans to follow up on the success of its Nespresso coffee pod system in Europe with a similar product for the tea market. Code name: Special T.

Like a dedicated Starbucks patron on her fourth cup of Organic Yukon Blend, Carly Simon won't rest yet in her legal pursuits against that coffee company, The Hollywood Reporter said. In October Ms. Simon sued Starbucks, saying it promised to distribute her 2008 album, ''This Kind of Love,'' at its stores, then withdrew from its Hear Music retail project days before the album's release. That lawsuit was thrown out of United States District Court in Los Angeles on a summary judgment in April when a judge said Ms. Simon had failed to show that Starbucks made fraudulent misrepresentations or concealed facts to mislead her. But in an amended complaint, Ms. Simon cites assurances that she said she had received from Alan Mintz, vice president of content development at Starbucks, that the company would promote and distribute her album aggressively, as well as her contract with Hear Music and the album's proposed marketing plan. In its response, Starbucks said it did not make any agreements with the intent to deceive Ms. Simon. The Hollywood Reporter said a ruling on whether the case would proceed was expected soon.

For the past month, Americans have watched with growing horror as a huge leak on a BP oil rig has poured millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. As I wrote on Sunday in the Week in Review section of The Times, there is also shock that technology has so far not been able to control it. But it is important to remember that this mammoth polluting event, so extraordinary here, is not so unusual in some parts of the world. In an article published on Sunday in The Guardian of London, John Vidal, the paper's environment editor, movingly recalls a trip to the Niger Delta a few years ago, where he literally swam in ''pools of light Nigerian crude.''

SO far in 2010, the story from the battlefields is one of continued gradual progress in Iraq, some headway in Pakistan and uncertainty in Afghanistan. The other big headline is that United States force totals in Afghanistan now exceed those in Iraq for the first time since early 2003. Iraq is of course still complex, but mostly in regard to the political situation, not the military one. Despite incidents like the coordinated bombings last month that killed more than 100 Iraqis around the country, security trends are improving even as United States forces accelerate their drawdown.

10 P.M. (NBC) LOSING IT WITH JILLIAN For eight seasons, viewers of ''The Biggest Loser'' have watched the trainer Jillian Michaels, left, reduce the overweight into sobbing heaps through her drill sergeant tactics. Now, she's bringing her tough love to eight physically unhealthy (and unsuspecting) families. She'll move in with each for five days, analyze its eating and exercise habits, expose the issues at the root of its slovenly ways and, theoretically, set it on the road to health and happiness. In this premiere episode, she travels to Wilmington, Mass., to pummel some sense into the Mastropietros. Jimbo Mastropietro has already had unsuccessful gastric bypass surgery; Agnes Mastropietro has the same surgery scheduled. Both hope to walk their daughter, Michelle, down the aisle later this year. Along the way, Ms. Michaels uncovers the cause of the family weight gain: the loss of the Mastropietros' newborn son, Jimmy, more than 20 years ago. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICADenzel Washington is a guest, and Clay Aiken performs.

Last fall, 13-month-old Aidan Truett of Hamilton, Ohio, developed what seemed like an upper respiratory infection. He lost interest in food and vomited a few times, but doctors attributed it to a virus. After nine days of severe symptoms and more doctor visits, the hospital finally ordered an X-ray to look for pneumonia. What they found instead was totally unexpected. The child had ingested a ''button'' battery, one of those flat silver discs used to power remote controls, toys, musical greeting cards, bathroom scales and other home electronics.

JERUSALEM -- Israel faced intense international condemnation and growing domestic questions on Monday after a raid by naval commandos that killed nine people, many of them Turks, on an aid flotilla bound for Gaza. Turkey, Israel's most important friend in the Muslim world, recalled its ambassador and canceled planned military exercises with Israel as the countries' already tense relations soured even further. The United Nations Security Council met in emergency session over the attack, which occurred in international waters north of Gaza, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was flying home after canceling a Tuesday meeting with President Obama.

Francesca Schiavone's one-handed backhand is a thing of beauty. It is as formidable as it is flowing, and brings to mind Richard Gasquet's gorgeous one-hander. Both players have long, loose follow-throughs, with the shoulder joint an elastic hinge that allows the racket head to accelerate through the ball. Today she faces Elena Dementieva, a rival since their days in the juniors, and she will stride onto Court Philippe Chatrier as the first Italian woman to reach a Grand Slam semifinal. After a first-round, first-set hiccup, Schiavone has motored through the draw without dropping another set.

Lincoln Center's Calder sculpture, "Le Guichet" ("The Box Office"), will take up temporary residence at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a move to be announced on Thursday. Lincoln Center presented the sculpture as a temporary gift to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at its spring gala last month, offering to let him place the artwork anywhere in the city for 90 days. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, has sat on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts since 1965. The sculpture will leave the Lincoln Center campus on Thursday and be installed at the garden on Friday. "The Osborne Garden will frame 'Le Guichet' in an entirely new and evocative way," said Scot Medbury, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

With the World Cup games in South Africa just days away, soccer balls aren't the only things spinning out of control. The New York City artist Kehinde Wiley's "Africa Lifestyle" sneakers and sports apparel for Puma are creating their own brand of hysteria. Puma has been supplying African soccer teams with uniforms since 1997, when it signed on with Cameroon. It was no surprise that the audience present on Monday for the end of Marina Abramovic's epic, 716-hour sit at the Museum of Modern Art gave her a tremendous ovation. The remarkable thing was the extent, and especially the sound, of it. The cheers lasted a good 15 minutes, filling the museum's towering atrium with the sort of unbridled excitement that often greets (male) sports stars after a big win. Then again, when a woman of 63 has been sitting in the same chair almost daily for three long months, locking eyes with at least 1,545 individuals without moving or speaking, before 700,000 gawkers who came to watch, she deserves more than a pat on the back. A mental health exam might be in order, for instance. Or a long hot bath. But also a medal for heroism.

As Brian Stelter writes in Wednesday's New York Times, the latest weapon in international disputes has become the video camera. The power of moving images to drive public opinion in the midst of an unfolding crisis became apparent with the video of a young woman, Neda, dying of a head wound during protests in Iran. So it's little wonder that in the confrontation this week between Turkey's Freedom Flotilla and the Israeli Navy, both sides came armed with cameras. The truth, though, remains elusive. Mr. Stelter writes:

I had to run down to the supermarket yesterday during a break from tracking the petro-calamity that continues to unfold in the Gulf of Mexico. Walking through the frozen-food section, I was reminded just how far this country is from being engaged in the "energy quest" that'd be needed not only to wean ourselves from oil but also to limit the human influence on the planet's climate system. The oil disaster doesn't belong to BP, or to President Obama or his predecessor; we all own it.

8 P.M. (CNN) TOXIC TOWNS, USA In a two-night investigation, Dr. Sanjay Gupta (above right, with Harold Areno) examines the effects of exposure to toxic chemicals, which some experts say begins even before birth, and the laws that are supposed to protect against it but that often don't. The report starts with a look at two environmental activists. One is Wilma Subra, a chemist who has developed a ''chemical fingerprint'' test to trace toxic byproducts from factories. The other is Dorothy Felix, a lifelong resident of Mossville, La., who is trying to force 14 industries to take responsibility for the health issues of residents -- 8 out of 10 of whom have reported illnesses, including cancer and kidney disease -- who say that they're being taken advantage of because they are mostly poor and black. Dr. Gupta also interviews manufacturers and members of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention about safety standards. The investigation ends with ''Toxic Childhood,'' on Thursday at 8 p.m. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE The Season 7 audition rounds continue with stops in Chicago and Los Angeles.

A picture caption on Monday with a music column about the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., using information from a publicist, misidentified the pianist shown playing with Geoff Nuttall and Christopher Costanza. He is Pedja Muzijevic, not Stephen Prutsman, who also played in the concert. The column referred incompletely to the directorship of the festival's chamber music series. In addition to Charles Wadsworth, since the festival began in 1977, Scott Nickrenz and Paula Robison were co-directors from 1978 to 1987, and Mr. Nickrenz was the director from 1987 to 1993. While Mr. Wadsworth was the host of the series from 1977 through last season, he was not the sole director. (Mr. Nuttall is the new director.)

Adored wife of the late Albert, dear mother of Dr. Donald (Jo Ann), Milwaukee, and Dr. Steven (Maggie), Great Neck, sister of Charles (Betty) Weissman, beloved and indulging Nana of Joe and Sam. TOKYO -- A strike that crippled production at Honda Motor's factories in China has come as a wake-up call to Japan's flagship exporters as they seek to remain competitive and make a push into China's burgeoning market with the help of low-wage workers. The strike, staged by local workers to protest low pay and tough working conditions, has cost the automaker, Japan's second largest after Toyota, thousands of units in lost production in the world's biggest auto market. The walkout began May 17 at a Honda transmission factory in southeastern China and has shut down all four of the Japanese automaker's factories on the mainland.

Zipcar, the car-sharing company, filed on Tuesday for a $75 million initial public offering as it continues to expand its popular services. In a regulatory filing, Zipcar said that it planned to use the proceeds from its offering to pay off debt and help with general expenses as it tried to turn a profit. (The $75 million figure is an estimate to help calculate the company's filing fee.)

As his administration prepares a plan to lay off thousands of state workers, Gov. David A. Paterson suggested on Tuesday that the leaders of state public employee unions were poorly serving their own members by resisting salary concessions that could avert pink slips. Mr. Paterson said union officers had a perverse incentive to favor layoffs for some of their members rather than salary concessions for all of them, since those who are laid off cannot cast ballots against those officers when they come up for election.

SHEPHERD--Rosemarie Jacqueline, beloved wife of John E. Shepherd of Tenafly, NJ died peacefully at home of natural causes after a long illness. Married for over sixty years, she was the loving mother of five children: Nancy S. Webb of Greenwich, CT; Susan S. Storrs of Greensboro, NC; John E. Shepherd Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Amy S. Weinberg of Greenwich, CT; and Samantha S. Cronic of Chevy Chase, MD. She is also survived by fourteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was born in New York City, attended Hunter College and was an airline stewardess with TWA before her marriage in 1950. These five children and, in turn, their children are her crowning achievement. The burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, June 5, 2010 at Brookside Chapel, 425 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631. A reception will follow the service at the Shepherd family home at 25 Woodhill Road, Tenafly, NJ 07670. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her honor to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 6931 Arlington Road, Bethesda, MD 20814.

An article on Sunday about the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. men's lacrosse tournament on Saturday misidentified in some editions, at one point, one of the four teams that had won every national title since 1992. Besides Johns Hopkins, Syracuse and Virginia, the other team was Princeton, not Duke. (Duke won this year's championship, on Monday.)

BOURGEOIS--Louise. It is with much sorrow that we mourn the death of Louise Bourgeois, an artist treasured by the Whitney Museum family. Louise was an artist both world-wise and eternally young--always challenging, always daring. Above all, her abiding integrity and commitment to the essential truths of her vision will continue to inspire us to confront the comforts of complacency. As we extend our condolences to her sons, Jean-Louis and Alain, her grandchildren, and to Jerry Gorovoy, Wendy Williams, and her studio, we are reminded that Louise has just moved maisons--her art is with us. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director Donna De Salvo, Chief Curator and Associate Director for Programs

ROSS--Agnes O'Neill, 97, died in her sleep Monday, May 31, at her home in Spring Lake, NJ, to which she had retired after teaching third graders for more than 40 years at Horace Mann School in North Bergen, NJ. She was predeceased by her sister, Mary O'Neill Heitzman, by her son, James O'Neill Ross, and by her husband, Wilbur L. Ross, a lawyer who served as a Judge and was elected Commissioner of Revenue and Finance in North Bergen, where Mrs. Ross had been elected as a Democratic County Committee Woman for 45 years. She had been Valedictorian in the Class of 1930 at Sacred Heart Academy in Hoboken and was a graduate of Jersey City State Teachers College. She is survived by her son, Wilbur L. Ross, Jr., Palm Beach, FL, a prominent private equity investor, by her daughter, Karen Ross Tanzola, Spring Lake, by nine grandchildren, Jessica Ross Brown, Johannesburg, South Africa, Amanda Ross, Sag Harbor, NY, U.S. Marine Colonel Robert Tanzola III, Cedar Point, North Carolina, William Ross Tanzola, Vancouver, British Columbia, Jeffrey Ryan Tanzola, Mickleton, NJ, Meredith Ross and Dana Ross, Rochester, New York and by seven great-grandchildren, Alexander Ross Farris, Robert Tanzola, IV, Rachel Lauren Tanzola, Michael Kevin Tanzola, Nicholas Kyle Tanzola, John Christopher Tanzola, Luke Anthony Tanzola and Kirsty Colby Brown. The wake will be held at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Highway 35, Wall, NJ from 2 until 4 and 7 until 9pm on Sunday, June 6 and the funeral services Monday, June 7 at St. Catharine Church, 215 Essex Ave., Spring Lake, at 9:30am. Contributions suggested to Visiting Nurses Association of Central Jersey.

ROSLOW--Dr. Sydney. Happy 100th Birthday Dad. You're catching up to the 107 academic papers and journal articles that you published (and that you were always so proud of). We miss you...every day you are in our thoughts. Love from your family.

BOURGEOIS--Louise. The trustees and staff of Dia Art Foundation mourn the loss of Louise Bourgeois. An extraordinary artist, she enriched our lives with her visionary artwork and we extend our most heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. Nathalie de Gunzburg, Chairman Philippe Vergne, Director Yasmil Raymond, Curator
$7.9 MILLION 155 East 35th Street, Manhattan
International HIGHEST COURT IN IRAQ

BOURGEOIS--Louise. One of the leading figures in 20th- and 21st-century art, Louise Bourgeois inspired multiple generations of artists with her unique and ever-evolving practice. The power of her psychologically charged work to move and transform her audience cannot be overstated. The Guggenheim Museum has been deeply committed to her work, acquiring an in-depth selection in 1991 and culminating in the 2008 traveling retrospective. We will collectively continue to benefit from her lifelong engagement with art and her unflinching aesthetic vision. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; Jennifer Blei Stockman, President; Richard Armstrong, Director; and Nancy Spector, Deputy Director and Chief Curator; Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation

GOLDBERG--Robert Henry. Died June 1, 2010. Remembered lovingly by his brother, Eugene Goldberg for the lifelong personal bond they enjoyed and the business partnership they shared for 51 years. His friendship will be missed by his sister-in-law Eleanor Brown Goldberg. His niece Celia Zahringer will miss his guidance and the mutual affection they had for each other. His grand-niece Lauren and grand-nephews George IV and Killian Zahringer, Peter Marks and James Kessler will miss his infectious laughter, love of history and the joy he brought into all of our lives. We hope you have found peace.

RAND--Dr. Anna T.,who died peacefully on May 30, 2010 at the age of 96, is mourned by her family and the many people she touched. Anna led an extraordinary life. In addition to her private practice, she served as a staff physician for numerous embassies in the 1940's and 1950's, Director of Planned Parenthood in Washington, D.C. during the 1940's and 1950's, Board Member of Planned Parenthood in New York from the 1950's to 1970's, professor and Director of Family Planning Activities at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Jacobi and Lincoln Hospitals in the 1960's and 1970's. As the Chairperson of the Washington, D.C. Chapter of Physicians Forum in the 1940's and 1950's, she was a passionate advocate of women's reproductive health, abortion rights, National Health Insurance and the delivery of adequate health care to all communities. Anna was committed to, and worked tirelessly for social justice and was a lifelong supporter of countless progressive causes. She is survived by and will be greatly missed by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and their families, Steven and Marlyse, Naomi and David, Deborah, Sascha, and Kalpana, Travis, Cody, Krish and Anand, by her brother Sam and sisters-in-law Adele and Jeanne, and by her nephews, niece and numerous cousins, all of whom loved her deeply. The love of her life, her wonderful husband Harry I. Rand, died in 2005. A memorial in her honor will be held on Saturday, June 12 at 3pm at her apartment, 320 West 86 Street, Manhattan.

FRID--Samuel, Mexico City, Mexico, July 27, 1935 - Vancouver, Canada, May 21, 2010. An entrepreneur, a humanist and artist, was passionate about everything in his life, his family, his great love of art, dance, music, and the beauty in world around him. Survived by his loving wife, Esther, his children, Alejandro Frid (Gail Lotenberg), Dianna Frid (William Mazarella), Leonardo Frid (Rina Freed), and his treasured three granddaughters: Twyla Bella, Ursula, and Neve. His influence on all of us was enormous and we will miss him.

An article on Monday about the power of psychology on penalty-kick shootouts in soccer misstated the order in which Roberto Baggio of Italy took his kick in a shootout with Brazil in the 1994 World Cup final. While he did take his team's final shot, he was the 9th shooter over all, not the 10th.

BOURGEOIS--Louise, 98. Her life and work was an inspiration to the generations of artists and friends who visited her home over the last three decades on Sundays. We are all privileged to have known her and to have had her work in our lives. Our condolences to her sons Jean-Louis and Alain, to Jessica and to her grandchildren Alex and Claire, and to her great- grandchild Marguerite, and to her longtime companion, Jerry Gorovoy. Cheim & Read, New York

WASHINGTON -- The Obama administration said Tuesday that it had begun civil and criminal investigations into the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, as the deepening crisis threatened to define President Obama's second year in office. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in New Orleans that he planned to ''prosecute to the fullest extent of the law'' any person or entity that the Justice Department determines has broken the law in connection with the oil spill. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 120 points shortly after Mr. Holder's announcement as energy stocks tumbled on expectations of the federal investigations. BP lost 15 percent of its market value during the day's trading.

PASKOW TERNER--Eileen. Rest in peace now. We love and will miss you forever. May your memory always be a blessing to your beloved family. Stephen & Vivian Mook Baer

GRAYSON--Morton, of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Greenwich, CT. Beloved husband of Debe Lutrin Grayson and the late Annette Grayson. Loving father of Ellen Mason and Philip Grayson, and four cherished grandchildren, their spouses and two great-grandchildren.

SIEGEL--Eleanor C.,on May 30, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Stepmother of Donald Jerome Siegel (Joyce), grandmother of Yurii and Sophie, aunt of Elizabeth Carpenter and Carol Siegel. Berkeley, Calif. LAST year was a fabulous one for entrepreneurs, at least according to the Kauffman Index of Entrepreneurial Activity released last month by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation. ''Rather than making history for its deep recession and record unemployment,'' the foundation reported, ''2009 might instead be remembered as the year business startups reached their highest level in 14 years -- even exceeding the number of startups during the peak 1999-2000 technology boom.''

Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab. Q. I have what I hardly think is a unique problem, but I am at a loss about how to handle it. Even as an adult, I am a very picky eater, and there are many foods I don't like and would never consider trying. When I am eating with friends in someone's home, and something I don't like is served, I politely refuse a share, and everyone goes bananas. Other guests start making nasty comments about my eating habits, the hostess feels compelled to prepare something else for me, etc. I don't want all this attention, I just don't want to eat broccoli or mayonnaise!! What should I do, FloFab??

BRUELL--Marcel, beloved member of the Polarome International family, a global supplier of fragrance and flavoring materials headquartered in Jersey City, NJ, passed away unexpectedly on May 17, 2010 at the age of 47. Marcel is survived by father and Polarome CEO Pierre Bruell, his stepmother Amanda, his brother and Polarome president Claude Bruell and family, sister-in-law Valerie, nephew Ayden and niece Grace. Marcel attended the Lycee Francais of New York, the Ecole des Roches in Normandy and graduated from Boston University with a degree in Business Administration. Marcel was a multilingual man about town, full of life, charm, curiosity and adventure. He liked traveling, skiing and other sports. In his last years, he devoted himself fully to the art of painting. Services will be held at the Chancery of the Grace Church, Broadway and 10th Street, Manhattan, on Thursday, June 17 at 6:00pm. To those who wish to honor him, donations may be sent to the Nature Conservancy at 322 Eighth Avenue, 16th floor, New York, NY 10001.

YARUMAL, Colombia -- Tucked away on a steep street in this rough-hewn mountain town, an old woman found herself diapering her middle-age children. At frighteningly young ages, in their 40s, four of Laura Cuartas's children began forgetting and falling apart, assaulted by what people here have long called La Bobera, the foolishness. It is a condition attributed, in hushed rumors, to everything from touching a mysterious tree to the revenge of a wronged priest.

KAVEE--Barbara, died on May 31, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Kavee. Loving mother of Ellen, Stephen, Rhonda and Marc. Cherished grandmother of Lindsey, Gillian, David and Jonathan. Funeral will be held Wednesday 10am, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY. She will be missed by friends and family.

MERKELSON--Harold Louis, died on Tuesday, June 1 (Sivan 19) at the Boca Raton Community Hospital, in peace after a long illness. He was born in New York City on October 19, 1916, son of Alexander and Helen Berger Merkelson. He attended City College, playing basketball for Nat Holman, and earning a BBA in accounting; attended New York University where he graduated with a Masters in Business Administration; and spent his career as a certified public accountant in private firms and in public accounting. He was a treasurer of East End Temple, as well as an accountant for the Actor's Temple. Harold is survived by his loving wife of over 67 years, Pearl Bienstock Merkelson, of Boynton Beach, FL, his children, Dr. Scott and Barbara Merkelson of Bloomfield, CT, and Wayne and Nancy Merkelson of New York City, and his grandchildren, Adam Merkelson of Pasadena, MD, David Merkelson of Kibbutz Hashofet, Israel, Randall and Amanda Merkelson of New York City, and Jeremy Merkelson of Washington, DC. Services Thursday at 11:15am at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his honor may be made to East End Temple, 245 East 17th Street, New York 10003.

BOURGEOIS--Louise. How lucky I was to know Louise. I adored being with her, being a part of her life--she was an amazing woman and exceptional artist. Louise had a wonderful smile--both wicked and loveable--and an unmatched sense of humor. As an artist, Louise's relationship to people was particularly appealing to me. I admired her courage to express her past relationships through her art. Her loyalty to so many like Rob and Debby, her incredible generosity to nonprofits like SIAS and, especially, to artists was inspiring. Her Sunday salons are legendary. My sympathies to her sons, Alain and Jean-Louis, and to Jerry Gorovoy. Jerry is by far one of the most important people any artist has ever had in their lives. I will miss Louise a lot. Aggie

SIRULNICK--Joseph. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Mark Kalish, President

BRAMWELL--Henry. The Brooklyn Law School Community mourns the loss of Judge Henry Bramwell, Class of 1948. Judge Bramwell was a Senior Judge of the United States Court for the Eastern District of New York, as well as a distinguished graduate and Trustee Emeritus of the Law School. President Gerald Ford nominated him to his seat in 1974. He was the first African-American judge appointed to serve in the Eastern District. Judge Bramwell gave generously of his time to the Law School, serving as a member of its Board of Trustees for 23 years. We are deeply saddened at the passing of both a dear friend of the Law School and an accomplished jurist. Judge Bramwell's intelligence, wisdom and judgment will be missed, but his legacy will be long enduring. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Ishbel, and his family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

SIRULNICK--Joseph. The partners and staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield mourn the loss of Joseph Sirulnick, patriarch of the Sirulnick family. The Sirulknick family has been a cherished client of the firm for over 40 years. Our sincere condolences to Sandy and Jill, Phyllis and Carole and their entire family. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield

Updated: 6:15 p.m. About 80 children at Public School 20, an elementary school in Flushing, Queens, became ill Tuesday afternoon, apparently after drinking from water fountains that were contaminated by an air-conditioning chemical, the Department of Education said.

An obituary on Sunday about Gerald Roush, an expert on Ferraris, misstated his date of birth. It was Oct. 5, 1941, not Oct. 10. In addition, using information from the family, the obituary misidentified Mr. Roush's first car. It was a 1953 Austin A40, not a 1953 Austin-Healey.

DAVIS--Paul VanDien, of New York City died May 16, 2010. Born in Newport News, Virginia on July 12, 1943, he earned a degree from the University of Virginia's School of Architecture in 1966 and began his career in Washington, DC. His legacy of more than forty years in real estate includes the redevelopment of the Boston Naval Shipyard and Manhattan's West Side rail yards--Riverside South (also known as Trump Place). Most recently, he served as Senior Vice President of Residential Development at Midwood Investment and Development. A true gentleman who held himself to an exacting standard, he was a generous mentor and colleague. In addition to being passionate about his professional work, he also enjoyed time on the golf course and in his kitchen, where he nourished his family with his love of cooking. He was a devoted husband and father who found great joy in his new role as a grandfather. He is survived by his wife Sally (Hyland), two brothers, two daughters Ashleigh Donovan and Julia Davis, and three granddaughters. He was beloved by his family and many friends and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Thursday, June 3rd at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the SPCA of Westchester, New York.

About a year ago, the Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y., retrofitted its golf carts with solar cell roof panels. Sebonack said it was the first American golf course with a solar-powered cart fleet. The roof panels convert daylight into power and charge the cart as it is being driven.

Initial casting for the September revival of Tony Kushner's Pulitzer Prize-winning "Angels in America" includes Zachary Quinto and Billy Porter, according to two theater executives involved with the Signature Theater Company production.

While the tennis world is abuzz after Robin Soderling's upset of Roger Federer, don't count out his semifinal opponent, Tomas Berdych, who has quietly demolished opponents on his way to the final four at Roland Garros. In his five matches, he has not lost a set; in fact, he's only lost 43 games. He easily handled Andy Murray in the Round of 16, then followed that up by overpowering Mikhail Youzhny.

In another sign that Democrats plan to harness outrage over the BP oil spill to help pass a comprehensive energy and climate change bill, Senator Harry Reid wrote to six committee chairmen on Thursday calling for new proposals to respond to the current and future disasters, for inclusion in the broader package the Senate will debate this summer.

Many have fretted that oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico could spread to the Florida Keys and then northward up the Atlantic. Now, the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. has come up with some computer modeling suggesting that the spill could extend along thousands of miles up the Atlantic coast as early as this summer.

Thursday night marks the return of "Burn Notice'' for its fourth season. A hit spy series on USA, "Burn Notice" chronicles the adventures of a former government spy (Michael Westen, played by Jeffrey Donovan) who washes up in Miami where he tries to right the wrongs of various underdogs with the help of his sidekicks Fiona (or just "Fi," Gabrielle Anwar) and Sam (Bruce Campbell). The creator of the series, Matt Nix (whose latest show, "The Good Guys," recently made its debut on Fox), answered some of our questions via e-mail. He'd like to hear from readers as well, so fire away. Send along your inquiries and we'll post Mr. Nix's responses here.

A hole outside City Hall is the site of an archaeological dig this week. Workers have been testing to determine the age of an underground wall unearthed during the construction of a subbasement utility vault. The Landmarks Preservation Commission says that the wall appears to date from the 18th or early 19th century and may have been associated with the First Almshouse, a poorhouse that stood on the site from 1736 to 1797.

Hemant Mathur, the chef and founding partner at Devi, will leave in a couple weeks to open his own place, Tulsi, at 211 East 46th Street. The name of the restaurant, which he and his partners expect to open in September, means holy basil in Hindi.

Dell's chief executive, Michael S. Dell, said Thursday afternoon that he had considered taking the company he founded private and that the transformation of the computer maker was still incomplete, Reuters reports.

Armando Galarraga's perfect game is gone. Umpire Jim Joyce blew the call at first base with two out in the ninth inning Wednesday night, and that cannot be undone. (Perfection apparently requires the umpires to reach that same standard.) Yet there is still a way to get Galarraga into the record book, and one man has all the power.

Reports from Baghdad after a coordinated attack by Al Qaeda on May 10 were grim. The bombing was the latest in a series of large-scale attacks by Sunni extremists that began last August after a long and uneasy period of relative peace in the capital. The news of this and the previous attacks held importance for me. For nearly a year, my men and I patrolled areas fewer than ten miles from where Iraqi emergency personnel sifted through the smoldering remains.

Commercial producers have expressed interest in extending the lives of two generally well-received Off Broadway musicals, "Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson" and "The Kid.''The Public Theater is exploring ways to transfer "Bloody Bloody" to Broadway next season, according to two producers who have spoken to executives at the Public about the show.

One of the nine people killed in an Israeli commando raid on a flotilla of ships heading for Gaza this week was a United States citizen of Turkish descent, officials in Turkey and Washington said Thursday. The development added a new diplomatic complexity as Israel struggled to defuse rising international anger over its raid on six ships seeking to break its blockade of the Gaza Strip, where officials from the Hamas movement were reported on Thursday to be resisting Israeli efforts to deliver truckloads of goods seized from the flotilla.

David Pogue responds to AT&T's announcement that it is introducing capped data plans on its smartphones, which will require customers to gauge how much data they use and buy the appropriate number of megabytes a month. Those users may worry about either going over or paying for unused capacity.

It has been called the worst call in baseball in the last 25 years. On Wednesday night, with two outs in the ninth inning in Detroit, Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga was on the cusp of throwing a perfect game when the first-base umpire, Jim Joyce, called the Cleveland Indians' Jason Donald safe at first base. It didn't look close. Joyce has apologized for the error. On Thursday morning, Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig was considering the unusual move of overturning the call.

The real-life married couple Marin Mazzie ("Kiss Me, Kate") and Jason Danieley ("Curtains") will take over the roles of Diana Goodman and her husband, Dan, in the Broadway musical "Next to Normal" on July 19, the production said on Thursday. The roles mark the first time that the couple has appeared together in a Broadway musical; they last worked together on a major New York production in 1996 in the Off Broadway play "The Trojan Women: A Love Story," and were married a year later. Ms. Mazzie, a three-time Tony Award nominee who most recently appeared on Broadway this spring in "Enron," will succeed Alice Ripley, who won the Tony for best actress in a musical in 2009 for her portrayal of Diana, a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. Ms. Ripley is departing the show to prepare to play Diana in the North American tour, scheduled to begin in November. Mr. Danieley will replace Brian d'Arcy James ("Shrek"), who took over the role of Dan last month from J. Robert Spencer; Mr. d'Arcy James will rejoin the cast of the play "Time Stands Still" when it returns to Broadway in the fall. Ms. Ripley and Mr. d'Arcy James are to give their final performances on July 18.

Five years ago, after leaving her post as a visual director for the Limited Brand's Express, Suzi West opened her shop Collier West in Columbus, Ohio. The boutique is located in the Short North District, an ever-expanding strip of galleries, boutiques and cafes which seems to cater to the stylish employees of local empires like Express and Abercrombie & Fitch. Collier West is filled with all sorts of stylish bric-a-brac from crystal chandeliers to John Derian decoupage to necklaces made from reclaimed bits and baubs. "Suzi likes all things French and anything made by hand," says one staffer. "You won't find anything produced in China." Indeed, on one recent visit, there were organic bath towels made by a women's collective in Ethiopia, colorful silk bangles from India, and one-of-a-kind chunky cocktail rings that came with a nice Midwestern price of under $40 dollars.

The Transportation Department on Wednesday announced the proposal of several rules to address common frustrations among travelers, Susan Stellin reports in The Times. Among the proposals: raising the minimum compensation for passengers bumped from oversold flights to $650 to $1,300, depending on the destination and the length of the delay; allowing customers to get a full refund within 24 hours of buying an airline ticket; requiring reimbursement of baggage fees and expenses when luggage is not delivered on time; and requiring airlines to more speedily notify travelers about flight delays and cancellations. The proposals are subject to a 60-day comment period. Feedback can be submitted online atÂ Regulations.gov.

For weeks there have been discussions about the potential for the spreading Gulf of Mexico oil slick to slip around Florida and flow up the East Coast. Now a suite of simulations, run by an international team of ocean and climate scientists, shows this is a likely outcome should the flow remain unabated this summer. The researchers stress there are caveats and uncertainties, most notably related to the state of the gulf's highly variable loop current in coming weeks. (The Department of Energy put out its own fact sheet stressing that the simulations are highly uncertain.)

Extraordinary cases make bad law. In a sense, Armando Galarraga's non-perfect perfect game, spoiled by an umpire's call on what should have been the 27th out, offers the strongest possible exhibit for expanding instant replay's role in baseball. Who wouldn't want to have seen Galaragga take his rightful place in the history books, making this remarkable baseball seasonÂ - whose first two months have already featured two perfect games and a no-hitterÂ - more remarkable still? And after watching the post-game agony of Jim Joyce, a distinguished umpire whose career will be forever marred by this one unforgivable call, who would deny the next disastrously-erring ump the chance to watch a replay on a video monitor and make the whole thing right?

There are some weird substances underground this morning. Halon, a gas used in automatic fire extinguishing systems, was released in the World Trade Center PATH station, the Fire Department said. The smell, she said, was "very powerful and disturbing." The Fire Department is on the scene and trying to figure out what is going on.

The synthetic surfaces used in playgrounds and sports fields around the country have been a hot-button issue for years. A picture caption on Friday with an obituary about the opera singer Anneliese Rothenberger misstated the year of the production of ''Lulu,'' starring Ms. Rothenberger, shown in the photograph. It was 1967, not 1957.

The cover article in The Times Magazine on Sunday profiled the singer and political activist M.I.A. While discussing her efforts to draw attention to the civil war in her home country, Sri Lanka, she was quoted as saying: ''I wasn't trying to be like Bono. He's not from Africa -- I'm from there. I'm tired of pop stars who say, 'Give peace a chance.' I'd rather say, 'Give war a chance.' The whole point of going to the Grammys was to say, 'Hey, 50,000 people are gonna die next month, and here's your opportunity to help.' And no one did.'' While M.I.A. did make those remarks, she did not make the entire statement at the same point in the interview, or in the order in which it was presented. The part that begins, ''The whole point of going to the Grammys,'' up to the end of the quotation, actually came first. The part that begins, ''I wasn't trying to be like Bono,'' and ends, ''Give war a chance,'' came later in the same interview. The article should have made clear that the two quotations came from different parts of the interview.

New York City, United States Economic Consultant to Westdeutsche Landesbank of Germany. A Founder and later President of the New York Association of Business Economists. Reposing Monday, 5-7pm; Prayer Service 6:30pm, Patti & Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main St, Fort Lee, NJ. For information, 201-944-0100 or www.frankpatti.com

BRUELL--Marcel, beloved member of the Polarome International family, a global supplier of fragrance and flavoring materials headquartered in Jersey City, NJ, passed away unexpectedly on May 17, 2010 at the age of 47. Marcel is survived by father and Polarome CEO Pierre Bruell, his stepmother Amanda, his brother and Polarome president Claude Bruell and family, sister-in-law Valerie, nephew Ayden and niece Grace. Marcel attended the Lycee Francais of New York, the Ecole des Roches in Normandy and graduated from Boston University with a degree in Business Administration. Marcel was a multilingual man about town, full of life, charm, curiosity and adventure. He liked traveling, skiing and other sports. In his last years, he devoted himself fully to the art of painting. Services will be held at the Chancery of the Grace Church, Broadway and 10th Street, Manhattan, on Thursday, June 17 at 6:00pm. To those who wish to honor him, donations may be sent to the Nature Conservancy at 322 Eighth Avenue, 16th floor, New York, NY 10001.

The old saying ''history repeats itself'' applies nicely to technology toys these days. Take Simon, the 1978 memory game from Milton Bradley that, for many, was a first encounter with a microprocessor. Next month, Mattel will come out a modernized twist on the theme, with Loopz ($30, powered by four AA batteries), which replaces the big light-up buttons on the old toy with motion-sensing technology, of the variety found on any self-flushing toilet. You might think of it as a ''smart toy,'' one of a wave being released over the next three months from companies including Vtech, Jakks Pacific, Fisher-Price/Mattel, Hasbro and Leapfrog, as the holiday season approaches.

KAPLAN--Sally, 99, died peacefully at home on June 1st. Wife of the late Meyer Kaplan, mother of Steven Kaplan, mother-in-law of Alyce Kaplan, grandmother of Meredith Walsey (Craig) and Jeremy Kaplan (Silvia), great-grandmother of Ethan and Aden Walsey. This is not an ending, it is the celebration of a wonderful life. How privileged we all are to have been a part of her life. She has been and will always be an inspiration to all who have known her. Her warmth and affection surrounded us all in her love. Her intelligence and talent are respected and admired. She may be gone but never to be forgotten. Services Friday, June 4th, 9:30am Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

L'ECUYER--James A.,51 years old, of New York City, NY, formerly of Leominster, MA, died May 31, 2010 in UMASS Memorial Medical Center-University Campus in Worcester, MA of ALS. He is survived by his wife of 17 years Leah Hocking, his eight year old daughter Mabel L'Ecuyer of New York City, his mother Madeline L'Ecuyer of Leominster, his sister Lee Ann L'Ecuyer of Kensington, NH, five brothers David L'Ecuyer and his wife Susan of Georgia, Richard L'Ecuyer and his wife Caryl of Leominster, Mark L'Ecuyer and his wife Kim of Harvard, MA, Brian L'Ecuyer and his partner Steven of California and Florida and John L'Ecuyer and his wife Jan of West Virginia, his mother-in-law Genevieve Hocking of Michigan, his father-in-law Ralph Hocking and his wife Sherry of New York, many nieces and nephews and dear friends all over the world. Jim was born July 21, 1958 in Leominster, the son of A. Leon and Madeline (Lanza) L'Ecuyer and had lived in New York for the past 30 years. He graduated from Leominster High School in 1976 and Summa Cum Laude from Roger Williams College in 1979. He had been a Television Producer for Fox News Channel for 13 years. His courage in facing ALS was an inspiration to all he knew. Memorial contributions may be made to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, New York, NY 10004.

BOURGEOIS--Louise. The board of directors, the staff, the friends, and the members of Artists Space, acknowledge with great sadness the passing of our dear friend Louise Bourgeois. In 1975 Louise curated an exhibition at Artists Space, and joined its board in 1997. She continued to support our organization generously, including making the recent renovation of Artists Space possible. Louise always pushed us to push ourselves. She will be truly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her many families and in particular Jerry Gorovoy and Wendy Williams.

Assembling a terrarium requires little more than a glass container, gravel, soil and plants. Noel Rose, the owner of Anchor Aquarium Service in Brooklyn, a company that builds large terrariums and aquariums, provided some basic instructions. Spread gravel, preferably a natural kind like pea gravel, an inch or two thick in a glass container. Mr. Rose recommends using a 10-gallon fish tank, which is inexpensive and has a large opening that makes it easier to work in, but smaller containers like fishbowls will also work as long as they are transparent. Whatever size you use, it helps if your hand can fit through the opening.

Services Friday 1:30pm at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street, New York City. Contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Shaaray Tefila.

As the population ages, home monitoring devices like Lifeline and others -- which keep track of your whereabouts, monitor your bodily functions and remind you to take their medicines -- have become more popular. Lifeline, made by Philips, is easy to use. By pushing a button on a pendant, you connect to a home base station, which automatically alerts a central station that there's an emergency. Trained operators with the customer's medical history can quickly call for help and alert relatives that something's wrong. But the product has one shortcoming; it only works in and around the house. If you're in a distant location and fall, you'll need to either flag a passerby or use a cellphone, neither of which may be practical. Cell phone service could always be used as a way to communicate back to Lifeline, but the company has eschewed that approach, concerned that erratic mobile connections will provide a poor user experience, perhaps at the moment it's needed.

GETZ--Laura Joan. November 22, 1936 - June 1, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Paul Getz. Beloved mother of Matthew and Evan Getz, and Hilary Zelin. Devoted grandmother of Brian, Daniel, Jonathan, Sydney, and Rachel. Laura passed away following a lengthy illness, and will always be remembered in our hearts. Funeral services will be held on Friday, June 4th at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 5780 Cooper Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens at 11am.
Michael R. Bloomberg: the iPad mayor? In these lean times, the latest obsession in City Hall is Apple's gleaming multimedia device and how it can make government more efficient.

An Op-Chart on Monday, about the number of service members who died in American wars and whose bodies were unidentified, referred imprecisely to the number of unknown soldiers in the Civil War. The number of Union unknowns is 150,000-plus, or 41 percent of the Union dead and 25 percent of the total dead; the figure does not include Confederate unknowns, whose number is a matter of dispute.

GOLDBERG--Robert H.,of Delray Beach, FL, son of Shirley and Abraham Goldberg of Brooklyn, NY, died June 1, 2010 at the age of 81. At 16 he graduated from Lafayette High School and continued his education at NYU while playing football for their varsity squad. Upon graduating he joined THC Systems where he and his brother Eugene revolutionized the tabletop industry. He became president of THC Systems and developed innovative sales and marketing programs still used today. Considered an icon in his industry he will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife of 57 years Joan Goldberg; brother Eugene; daughter Ellen; sons Barry, Ira and James; seven beloved grandchildren and many nephew and nieces. We all are going to miss that smile that brought so much joy to the world.

An art column on Monday about Marina Abramovic's performance of sitting in a chair at the Museum of Modern Art for 700 hours erroneously attributed a distinction to Ms. Abramovic. The Taiwanese artist Tehching Hsieh has performed works lasting a year; Ms. Abramovic's is not the longest piece of performance art on record.

There is still no definitive evidence that electromagnetic radiation from wireless devices like cellphones and Wi-Fi networks is hazardous. But many companies are profiting from public concern about the issue, most by selling unscientific placebos, usually pendants or decals that do nothing to stop the radiation.

BOURGEOIS--Louise. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Louise Bourgeois, a great artist. Louise had a close connection to The Museum from the time Alfred Barr acquired her early prints and sculpture in the late 1940's and early 1950s. Other curators over the years have also strongly supported her work, among them, Deborah Wye, who mounted her first retrospective exhibition in 1982, as well as Rob Storr. Louise's sculptures, prints and drawings, forming a core of our collection, reveal the most essential elements of the human experience with an astounding originality. It is hard to believe that her boundless creativity has come to an end. Louise will be sorely missed, but her piercing vision lives on through her work. We offer our sincere condolences to her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchild, and to her long-time assistant Jerry Gorovoy. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

FRANCO--Frank Ottavio, 91, of Denver. Born in 1919 to Nicola and Marianina Franco. He was brought from Italy to America by his family and grew up in New York City. He served as a physician during WWII in the U.S. Army. He was a practicing surgeon for many years in private life. Dr. Franco is survived by his wife of 67 years, Patricia, a daughter Emily, four sons James (Ellen), Thomas (Allison), Paul (Jill) and Joseph (Brenda), his grandchildren Brett, Benjamin, Mathew, Patrick, Nicholas, Julian, Grace, Samuel, Clare, Patricia, Peter and Sophia, and a great-granddaughter, Audrey. Dr. Franco's daughter, Esther (married to Charles Hinkle), died in 2000. Mass of Christian Burial held at Archdiocese of Denver Mortuary Chapel on Thursday, June 3, 2010 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the CU Foundation/Hinkle Scholarship, Main Hall 314, 1420 Austin Bluffs Parkway, Colorado Springs, CO 80918.

We extend our condolences to Maury and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

8 P.M. (Science) CREATING SYNTHETIC LIFE On May 20 the genome pioneer J. Craig Venter announced that he and his team had synthesized a bacterial genome and used it to take over a cell. News of this ''synthetic cell'' resulted in speculation regarding its potential for solutions to global challenges like generating new food sources, drugs and vaccines; cleaning up pollution; devising new energy sources; and producing clean water. (It also led President Obama to ask the White House bioethics commission to complete a study of the issues raised by synthetic biology within six months.) This two-part report, filmed over five years at the J. Craig Venter Institute in San Diego, follows Dr. Venter; Hamilton O. Smith, a microbiologist and Nobel laureate; and Clyde A. Hutchison III, an investigator at the institute, as they work to create this synthetic single-cell organism. ''Creating Synthetic Life: Your Questions Answered'' follows at 9. 8 P.M. (CNN) TOXIC CHILDHOOD In the conclusion of a two-night investigation Dr. Sanjay Gupta demonstrates the places potentially harmful chemicals can lurk -- including the home, the workplace and in everyday products -- and offers tips on how to minimize risks. He also interviews neonatal and pediatric experts about chemical exposure in children and leads a conversation about how pregnant women can unwittingly pass along toxins to their fetuses.

Bose has long championed ease-of-use for its component entertainment systems, and the newest versions of its Lifestyle home-theater-in-a-box packages, called Unify, has a very smart way to hook up all the cables. It's a system other makers should imitate. A simple on-screen menu displays the right connector. Bose says that the console senses when a connection is made and confirms it with a beep. Rather that showing the most common labels for inputs on the screen guide, like Video 1 or HDMI, the Unify guru lists them as Blu-ray Player or Cable Box.

She was dedicated to encouraging other artists and in 1995 honored Yaddo by establishing an endowed residency for young sculptors. We mourn her death on May 31 and gratefully acknowledge her generosity, encouragement and support. Elaina H. Richardson, President Peter C. Gould, Chair The Corporation of Yaddo

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- As the battle for Tivoli Gardens raged, soldiers knocked on a door at Building 27. Inside, more than two dozen people were huddled for safety, including a 22-year-old barber named Errol Spence. His family said a soldier searched him and did not find any evidence that he was one of the gunmen shooting at security forces. Still, one police officer asked Mr. Spence's sister a question that at first confused her. ''He said how much brother I have,'' the sister, Twanna-Kay Spence, recalled, speaking in the local English patois. ''I said, 'Two.' ''

An article on Monday about the renewed rivalry between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers, the teams in this season's N.B.A. finals, misstated Trevor Ariza's status when the teams last met in the finals, in 2008. While Ariza, a Lakers forward then, was limited because of a foot injury, he was not missing from the team. The article also misstated the number of Lakers championships. They have 15, including a 1948-49 Basketball Association of America title recognized by the team and the N.B.A.; they are not seeking their 15th.

A listing last Thursday with an article about removing toxic substances from homes contained an incorrect Web address for a site that lists chemicals in cosmetics. It is cosmeticsdatabase.com, not cosmeticsupplies.com.

SAEEDPOUR--Vera Beaudin. Noted scholar and Director of the Kurdish Library and Museum, Dr. Saeedpour died peacefully Sunday, May 30th, 2010, in Upstate New York after a sudden illness. A memorial will be held in July in New York City. For more information, visit: kurdishlibrarymuseum.com.

HERE are the reactions of several business owners with related experience. You can read their complete comments, and leave your own, at nytimes.com/boss. Kevin Czinger, chief executive of Coda Automotive, an electric car company:

In a city of secret economies, few are as vital to the life of New York as the business of nannies, the legions of women who emancipate high-powered professionals and less glamorous working parents from the duties of daily child care. Those nannies, as well as other domestic workers who make possible the lives of New York's eternally striving work force, have long gone without basic workplace guarantees that most employees take for granted.

Richard Migliore, the jockey known affectionately in New York simply as the Mig, will never ride a horse again. It was not his choice to retire Wednesday morning: the doctor told him that he had sustained one broken neck too many and that he would be risking his life if he got on another horse. Migliore, 46, admittedly took it hard. He has been broken up before -- a near-fatal neck injury in 1988 sidelined him for six months, and he was tossed off a horse in 1992 in such spectacular fashion that the spill was featured on the television program ''Rescue 911.''

KANE-GROSSKOPF--Esther, May 4, 1912 - May 14, 2010, died peacefully at home in Jamaica, NY. She was a testament to Proverbs 31 Woman of Valour. Esther was born in Podkamien (Polish AH), studied nursing and emigrated to the US in 1938. She married Joseph Kane, who died in 1951, leaving Esther, at 39, a widow with three young children. She raised them with love and dedication to learning and Judaism, while holding leadership positions in Hadassah and Richmond Hill Jewish Center. She worked for Yeshiva of Central Queens, then opened Midland Candy. For 40 years she was much loved and respected by customers and neighbors. She remains in our hearts as a blessing and inspiration to a life devoted to family and community. To the last day of her extraordinary life she exhibited great affection, dignity, courage and humor. Esther is survived by her sons Herman Kane (Carole) and Ronald Kane (Ruth), daughter Deena Forman and grandchildren: Jon, Jamie, Ari, Alexie and Stephanie.
