The women's singles final between Francesca Schiavone and Samantha Stosur is as improbable as any Grand Slam final in recent memory. Just a year ago, the two met in the first round at Roland Garros, with Stosur winning in straight sets. While Stosur has captivated the tennis world with her back-to-back victories over Justine Henin and Serena Williams, followed by her lopsided one hour dismantling of Jelena Jankovic, Schiavone has quietly fought her way through a series of tough, seasoned opponents to become the first Italian woman to vie for a Grand Slam singles title. Both stories are compelling, and they point to an increasing depth in the women's game.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - Here's a rarity - a themed Saturday puzzle. It's not a full-blown theme, but it does have 10 symmetrically placed entries that are tied together using the same clue: "Triumphant shout." Half of these shouts are used in games (one in soccer, although it could be a bullfight) with the balance comprising cries of a more multipurpose nature.

As the Blue Jays prepared to meet the Yankees for the first time in 2010, they can feel proud of a surprising 31-24 record that has them tied with Boston for third place in the division, with New York within hailing distance in second.

Bush got a little too casual about waterboarding, and the world discovered that Israel's vaunted special forces cannot walk on water after all.

There is no piece of golf equipment more personal, more like a relationship, than the association of putter and golfer. Most people go through dozens of putters in a lifetime. Some pros go through hundreds. Some players are a little more faithful. My colleague Dave Anderson, who is a very good putter, has used the same flat stick for decades.

Thursday, I wrote about AT&T's new Internet-service plans for iPhones and other smartphones. Instead of $30 for unlimited Internet use, new customers will be asked to choose between two limited-data plans: $15 for 200 megabytes a month, or $25 for 2 gigabytes. I noted that most people will save money with the new plans, sometimes lots of it. (Existing customers can keep the $30 unlimited plan if they like, even if they get new phones.)

The Recording Industry Association of America late Friday afternoon filed a motion for a permanent injunction against LimeWire, the file-sharing service found liable for copyright infringement in May.

This week's Your Money column is about the treatment of student loans in the federal bankruptcy code and whether this treatment ought to change. Currently, it's nearly impossible for people to get rid of student loans in bankruptcy court, even though people in over their heads with credit card or gambling debts can often discharge those loans.

The Rangers bad boy Sean Avery, who had 11 goals and 20 assists this season, took a crack at handicapping the Belmont Stakes on The Rail. He sided with the underdog, picking the 20-1 shot Stay Put to win. Stay Put won at Churchill Downs on Kentucky Derby day.

In the latest back-and-forth over the legality of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's layoffs of hundreds of subway station agents, a judge ruled Friday that the authority violated the law when it closed booths and laid off about 260 agents last month without holding public hearings.
Persillade, the combination of (mostly) parsley and garlic, has many uses. My favorite: stuffing a boneless leg of lamb. I explain how in this week's Minimalist column.

Close allies of the Obama administration, seeking to rally the public behind President Obama's landmark health care bill, are planning to spend $25 million over the next five years to promote the measure and beat back mischaracterizations of it that could harm Democratic candidates.

Cape Town, Johannesburg, Port Elizabeth, Durban and Pretoria are among the nine host cities expecting hundreds of thousands of tourists for the World Cup in South Africa next week. Meet residents of these five cities, who offer their own personal mini-guides on where to shop, eat, and enjoy a night on the town.

The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who has been undergoing treatment for esophageal cancer, has canceled a weeklong tour in Europe with the Saito Kinen Orchestra to conserve his strength for performances in Carnegie Hall in December, a representative said on Friday. Mr. Ozawa was to have performed in Prague, Vienna, Berlin and Paris from Dec. 3 to Dec. 10 before opening Carnegie's Japan NYC festival with the orchestra on Dec. 14. "He said:Â  'Cancel Europe, I've got to go to Carnegie,' " Ronald Wilford, his manager, said on Friday. "That's a tough tour," Mr. Wilford added. "That's why he said no. Carnegie is absolutely right on." Mr. Ozawa is artistic director of the Carnegie festival. He is also principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera.

Israel's deadly commando raid on a flotilla seeking to break the three-year Israeli embargo on Gaza has once again pushed the Islamist Palestinian movement Hamas into the forefront of Middle East politics.

An Iranian immigrant who said he came to the United States "to live the American dream" was convicted on Friday of violating American trade sanctions on Iran by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move money between Iran and the United States. Hawala dates back hundreds of years and operates outside normal banking channels.
Vivek Shah, a former Time Inc. executive, has bought Ziff Davis, the media company that operates nine technology sites, including PCMag.com.
With the euro falling below $1.20 on Friday, it seems like a good time to recall the bear raid on the British pound that the billionaire hedge fund manager George Soros made in 1992.

New York City has never been short on public spectacle, but starting this week there will more to ogle when a number of outdoor installations go on view. So get out there and see some art.

Researchers announced this month that having a child with autism does not increase the odds that parents will divorce. It was a refutation of the commonly held -- but little documented -- belief that the strain of caring for an ill or challenging child regularly tears couples apart.

During her days in the Clinton White House, Elena Kagan rarely expressed her personal opinion in writing. But when administration officials contemplated asking Congress to make assisted suicide a federal crime, she proclaimed it "a fairly terrible idea.''

The Yves Saint Laurent cruise show was an uptown affair at the French Consulate General on Fifth Avenue. In a beautiful chandeliered room and set to a live string quartet, Stefano Pilati showed a sophisticated collection that deftly alluded to the 70's hey day of YSL -- via the 40's. There were butterfly prints, above the knee skirts, lots of shorts and multiple shades of pink. My favorite look was an abstract design that reminded me of a mushroom alien -- with just enough print for when you don't feel like wearing a floral dress.

When good food and the people who gather it are threatened by a disaster, chefs and diners have often rallied behind them. As the Gulf Coast oil spill continues to destroy some of the most fertile seafood beds in the United States, benefits are being planned.

WASHINGTON -- If you get an Internet appeal from Gen. Ray Odierno, the senior American commander in Iraq, asking you to pay lots of money to get your son or daughter out of combat duty, don't believe it. And certainly don't send the $200,000.

"Photography is an art for lazy people." So said Robert Frank, the celebrated Swiss photographer, to Allen Ginsberg, the celebrated New Jersey poet, as they gathered in a Lower East Side flat to make a movie. Frank was at the height of his fame after publishing his monumental collection of photographs, "The Americans," but had newly re-imagined himself as a beatnik and filmmaker. Also assembled in that apartment were Jack Kerouac, Gregory Corso, and an ensemble cast of hangers-on, lovers, admirers, and jazzmen, ready to conceive another erratic self-portrait.
The Mets made some roster moves on Friday although the fate of pitcher Oliver Perez, who has resisted a move to the minor leagues, was not immediately clear.

Chrysler is recalling about 25,000 of its 2007 Dodge Caliber and Jeep Compass models because the accelerator pedal could stick.

Tiger Woods has not yet worked his way into contention in the Memorial Tournament in Dublin, Ohio, but he took another step closer to regaining his form on Friday, hitting a few more shots that pleased him during a second-round 69 that left him at three under par, 10 strokes behind the leader, 21-year-old Rickie Fowler.

Citing the current Broadway imperative of casting star actors, the playwright Jon Robin Baitz said on Friday that he had decided to move his latest work "Other Desert Cities" (formerly titled "Love and Mercy") from Broadway's lineup for the 2010-11 season and instead have the work produced at the Mitzi E. This week's Wealth Matters column is about the tricky financial planning questions that arise when mom or dad remarries. Nothing to do this weekend? More than 100 national parks that usually charge entrance fees will be free this Saturday and Sunday. "Park Avenue Granola" is how Michael Kors referred to the organic cashmeres and cottons on the models at the showroom presentation of his resort collection. The undyed fabrics still maintained the super-deluxe quality and cool sportswear cuts we have come to expect from Kors (and there were other, apparently inorganic pieces, too, like a great orange taffeta peasant style tank dress and a white linen pant suit worn with flat sandals). But as he said, if you can wear it and feel you are doing a little something extra for the planet, then why not? It's his first venture into such territory and it looks sophisticated - especially the hemp canvas trench coat. Yes, hemp.Â  So yes, Michael. Why not?Â  If sustainability can really catch on and mean something and still look great, then why not, indeed?

High school students from Bushwick, Brooklyn, are starting an ambitious gardening effort on Monday - in New York Harbor. The students, from the Urban Assembly New York Harbor School, will set sail from Governors Island with Jacques Cousteau's grandson Fabien Cousteau and a cargo of 130,000 oyster spat, also known as baby oysters. The students will put on scuba gear and plant them in the harbor floor, starting near Bay Ridge and working their way up north, under the auspices of the younger Cousteau's new ocean-restoration nonprofit organization, Plant a Fish. If you don't want to spend all your time trawling the Web for updates on your favorite topics, have Google deliver the latest articles directly to your e-mailbox. Just create a Google Alert, which is a message full of links to current news articles, video clips and other sources concerning your subject. Visit Google's alert page, and in the search box, type in the topic you're interested in, say, "New Orleans Saints." Pick the types of sources you want to draw from, as well as the frequency and number of results you'd like to see. BP, already bedeviled by an out-of-control well spewing millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, now finds itself with one more problem: Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive. Among his memorable lines: The spill is not going to cause big problems because the gulf ''is a very big ocean'' and ''the environmental impact of this disaster is likely to have been very, very modest.'' And this week, he apologized to the families of 11 men who died on the rig for having said, ''You know, I'd like my life back.''

An article on Thursday about a bill in New York that would provide holidays, overtime wages and other benefits to nannies misstated the given name and title of an advocate for them who was quoted about ''healing the divide between employee and employer.'' She is Sarah Fields, not Sara, and she is the program coordinator, not the program director, at the advocacy group Jews for Racial and Economic Justice.

An article on May 25 about long-distance bird migration incorrectly described a threat posed to red knots in the Delaware Bay, where the birds land to feast on horseshoe crabs' eggs and regain their strength. Fishermen collect the crabs themselves (for bait in eel and conch traps), not their eggs.

A blog entry reprinted in the Postings column on Tuesday about oil spills in the Niger Delta repeated two incorrect assertions from an article in The Guardian. About 8 percent of American oil imports come from Nigeria, not 40 percent. (Over 40 percent of Nigeria's oil exports go to the United States.) And BP is not among the oil companies in the delta; it stopped drilling there in the 1970s.

As engineers made headway Thursday in containing the oil leak at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico, crews on two floating rigs flanking the spot where the Deepwater Horizon exploded and sank were doing what rig crews normally do: drilling wells. The two wells, aimed at the bottom of the runaway well that has spewed millions of gallons of oil into the gulf, represent the most conventional solution to the disaster and the one that experts say is all but certain to succeed. Once either of the relief wells strikes pay dirt, the plan is to pump heavy drilling mud and cement down it to bring the blowout under control and permanently seal the damaged well.

SHEPHERD--Rosemarie Jacqueline, beloved wife of John E. Shepherd of Tenafly, NJ died peacefully at home of natural causes after a long illness. Married for over sixty years, she was the loving mother of five children: Nancy S. Webb of Greenwich, CT; Susan S. Storrs of Greensboro, NC; John E. Shepherd Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Amy S. Weinberg of Greenwich, CT; and Samantha S. Cronic of Chevy Chase, MD. She is also survived by fourteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was born in New York City, attended Hunter College and was an airline stewardess with TWA before her marriage in 1950. These five children and, in turn, their children are her crowning achievement. The burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, June 5, 2010 at Brookside Chapel, 425 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631. A reception will follow the service at the Shepherd family home at 25 Woodhill Road, Tenafly, NJ 07670. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her honor to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 6931 Arlington Road, Bethesda, MD 20814.

Around the time the ninth New York City public-school teacher was being booed offstage Wednesday night at Harlem's legendary Apollo Theater, City Room started wondering who at the Education Department could have possibly endorsed the notion of an Apollo Amateur Night devoted exclusively to city teachers. Or whether the event, billed as a way to spotlight teachers' hidden talents (see video), was really some sort of crafty bargaining tool intended to show them that raises or no raises, they should consider themselves lucky to have their classroom jobs. After all, the Amateur Night audience is notoriously merciless. With dozens of students in the audience of 1,500, the booing came particularly fast and furious. And don't teachers endure enough already?

BRANDT--Lillian Sampson Fuhrtz, (93), died peacefully at home on May 30th after an illness of several months. She was the widow of George Brandt, Sr. and is survived by her children, Judyie Ella Al-Bilali and the Reverend Canon George Brandt, Jr. and grandchildren Lillian Hanan Al-Bilali and Muhammad Salim Al-Bilali. Her pioneering career in the fashion industry spanned over fifty years. She was active in community organizing and maintained a lifelong passion for national politics and international affairs. Funeral services will be held at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th street on Friday, June 11th at 11am.

Armando Galarraga deserves praise for the way he has handled himself after the blown call by Jim Joyce that cost him a perfect game on Wednesday. Galarraga, the Tigers' right-hander who will henceforth be remembered as the unluckiest pitcher in baseball, sets a great example for children. Trust me, as a Little League coach, I'll be using his example of sportsmanship, perspective and respect for authority. But the notion that Galarraga should be retroactively awarded a perfect game is misguided. It was not a perfect game. The game continued after Joyce awarded Jason Donald first base. A perfect game is defined as a full game in which nobody on a team reaches base. It's simple. And it didn't happen.

Dennis Hopper was buried on Wednesday after a memorial service at a church in Ranchos de Taos, N.M., The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hopper, the eccentric, wide-eyed actor of ''Apocalypse Now'' and ''Blue Velvet'' and the director, co-writer and co-star of ''Easy Rider,'' died on Saturday from complications of prostate cancer. He was 74. Among relatives who attended the service held at the San Francisco de Asis church were Mr. Hopper's son, Henry Lee Hopper, who read from Walt Whitman's ''Leaves of Grass.'' The memorial, above right, also drew the actors Val Kilmer and Jack Nicholson; Mr. Nicholson appeared in ''Easy Rider'' with Mr. Hopper and remembered his co-star as ''an all-around guy.'' ''It was a very singular relationship I had with him, like nobody else,'' Mr. Nicholson said, according to The A.P. ''We were soul mates in a way. I really miss him.''

Want to know what it's like to be the restaurant critic of The New York Times? It's a lot of eating, a lot of time at the gym and about 37 e-mail messages a day from friends, distant relatives, acquaintances, the spouse, the children, the boss and the boss's boss asking where to secure a reservation for six people tonight at 8 on the West Side, appropriate for both infants and a chief financial officer, that maybe serves Asian food or possibly Italian, though not fish and not too expensive, fun but not terribly loud. (Tell that jackanapes: Ruby Foo's!) Occasionally a reader will write. I wish that would happen more. The job here at The Times is to disseminate information, after all. The critic has it. You should feel free to ask for your fair share.

The Big City column on Tuesday about a 17-year-old shooting victim from Harlem, Alexander Carno, who uses a wheelchair misstated the source of financing for his physical therapy. It is paid for by private insurance, not the state.

An article on Tuesday about the deadly Israeli naval commando raid on an aid flotilla that had attempted to defy Israel's blockade of Gaza referred incompletely to the governance of Gaza by Hamas, the militant group that opposes Israel's existence. While Hamas took over Gaza by force in 2007, as the article said, the group's representatives had won elections there in January 2006, defeating the more moderate rival Palestinian group Fatah. Subsequent tensions between Hamas and Fatah forces in Gaza led to open fighting, and Hamas routed Fatah from Gaza in June 2007.

EMBLER--Edith (nee Smith), passed June 2, 2010 peacefully and surrounded by loved ones. Beloved husband of Tom, sister of Virginia, mother of Mike and Maura, mother-in-law of Maria and Rick, grandmother of Ricky, Ryan, Tara, Shay and Keira, sister-in-law of Richard, Maureen, Peggy, Bob, Ellie, Don and Debbie. Retired Executive Director of the Huntington Housing Authority, former president of Huntington League of Women Voters, director of Brookhaven and Suffolk County chapters of League of Women Voters. Former elected trustee of Northport-East Northport Library Board. Former active parishioner of St. Anthony of Padua of East Northport. Active parishioner of St. Francis Cabrini of Coram. Member of Society of St. Vincent de Paul. Avid reader, traveler, figure skating fan. Visitation Marinello Funeral Home, 493 Middle Country Road, Coram Saturday June 5, 7-9pm and Sunday June 6, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, 10:30am Monday June 7, St. Francis Cabrini Church, 134 Middle Country Road, Coram. Private cremation. Donations requested in lieu of flowers to Society of Saint Vincent de Paul, St. Francis Cabrini Conference, 134 Middle Country Rd., Coram, NY 11727. She cared deeply and is already sorely missed.

There have already been two perfect games this season, and that's not counting Armando Galarraga's near-miss on Wednesday night. It is quite a feat considering that no other season since 1880 has had more than one. A lot has to happen for a perfect game - great pitching, poor hitting and a heavy dose of luck. Defensive plays have to go your way, line drives need to be caught, and, as we've seen, umpires' calls need to go your way.

EVARTS--Landon, of Garrison, NY died at home on June 2, 2010. Born on August 14, 1930, he is a graduate of Westminster School, Harvard College, and Columbia Business School. He served in the U.S. Army in Washington, DC in the 1950's. Predeceased by his parents Cornelia Landon Evarts and William Maxwell Evarts and his sister Carol Evarts McLane, he is survived by his wife, Nancy Sayles-Evarts, his daughter Caroline Evarts, and his brother William M. Evarts. He is also survived by four step-children, many grandchildren, nieces, and nephews. He will be much missed by his family and his many friends. A memorial service will be held at St. Philips Church, Garrison, on June 25th, at 2pm. If one wishes, donations may be sent to St. Philips Church, Box 158, Garrison, NY, 10524.
MALLIMSON--David, of Great Neck, NY died June 1, 2010 at 95. He was beloved by his family and friends and will be greatly missed.

9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS The Sea Shepherds, above, return with more ships -- including the Bob Barker, christened for the host of ''The Price Is Right,'' who donated the money for it -- larger crews and greater determination. Their Whale Defense Campaign takes them on a three-month journey to the South Ocean to stop whaling that the group asserts is illegal and exploits a loophole in international ocean law. At the heart of this series's third season is the imprisonment of Capt. Pete Bethune, whose ship, the Ady Gil, sank after colliding with the Shonan Maru 2 whaling vessel on Jan. 6. In February Captain Bethune was arrested after he boarded the Shonan Maru 2, tried to make a citizen's arrest of the captain and presented him with a $3 million bill for damages. Captain Bethune is now awaiting trial in Tokyo and could be sentenced to 15 years in prison. In the meantime, the Shepherds say that their 2010 Antarctic Defense Campaign has saved 528 whales. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 2010 SCRIPPS NATIONAL SPELLING BEE More than 270 champion spellers, ages 8 to 15, from the United States, as well as American territories and schools around the world, will converge in Washington to test their abilities. Chris Harrison hosts this two-hour final round. Semifinal rounds will be broadcast live on ESPN, starting at 10 a.m.

At Roland Garros, Rafael Nadal's driving, superspin forehand peels off the red clay, knocking opponents off-balance and sometimes blowing them off the court. He is 21-0 on clay this year, 37-1 at six French Opens and at one point had a record streak ofÂ 81 victoriesÂ on his favorite surface. He isÂ the best player on clay, perhaps the best clay-court playerÂ of all time.

Astute readers may have noticed that I've been neglecting this blog lately -- and my Sunday column explains why. About a month ago, a tumor was discovered in my right kidney, and it was removed 10 days ago in a three-hour surgery. I still feel like I've been hit by a truck, but maybe a smaller truck than it felt like yesterday. And the tumor turns out to be benign. So I'm celebrating.

With her incandescent smile and even brighter play, Francesca Schiavone lit up Paris, the City of Lights, with an electrifying performance, beating Samantha Stosur, 6-4, 7-6 (2), to win the French Open. Schiavone outplayed Stosur, who seemed stunned by Schiavone's daring play and fist-pumping displays of confidence. After beating Justine Henin, Serena Williams and Jelena Jankovic to reach the final, Stosur was considered the favorite to win. But it was Schiavone who played to win, outhitting and outserving the powerful Stosur. In many ways, she beat Stosur at her own game, serving big and setting up her groundstrokes to keep Stosur on the move and off-balance.

Robin Soderling will play Rafael Nadal in the French Open final Sunday, a rematch of a last year's round of 16 match that Soderling won.
